PROCTEXT.PARA: Mr SPEAKER (Hon. Leo McLeay) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows and copies will be referred to the appropriate Ministers:

PETITION.TITLE: Rights of the Child
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned Australian citizens shows:
The United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child:
- gives wide rights to children in Articles 12 to 16, including the right to privacy and freedom of association;
- gives only qualified rights to parents in Article 5;
- fails to recognise the prior right of parents to determine the education of their children;
- could, if ratified by Australia, result in government-assisted rebellion against parents who want to set limits for their children in their children's best interests.
Your petitioners therefore pray that your Honourable House will:
- request the Federal Government not to ratify this potentially damaging Convention.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Dr Blewett (from 141 citizens), Dr Catley (from 248 citizens) and Mr McLachlan (from 507 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Rights of the Child
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and members of the House of Representatives assembled in the Parliament.

We, the undersigned citizens of Australia, draw to the attention of the House that; there is widespread concern and strong objection to the possible implications of the United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child. Guidance and responsibility for our children belongs to parents not Government.
Your petitioners therefore request the House call upon the Government to refrain from ratifying this Convention.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Rights of the Child
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament, this petition of certain citizens of Australia invites to the attention of the House that:
a. there is widespread concern and strong objection to the United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child; and
b. guidance and responsibility of our children belongs to us, the parents, NOT the government.
Your petitioners therefore request that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled require the Government to refrain from ratifying this convention.
And your petitioners, as is duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Natural Therapy
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives assembled in parliament:

We, the citizens of Australia, wish to bring to your attention our objections to the Therapeutic Goods Regulations under the Therapeutic Goods Act, 1989. Under the guise of protecting the public against inferior produce those Regulations will have the effect of putting out of business many natural therapists and small-scale manufacturers of natural remedies. The charges levied at manufacturers will increase the cost of supplements and constitute an indirect taxation on users of Natural Therapies. The clauses in the Regulations which purport to exempt Homoeopaths and Herbalists are so badly drafted as to be inoperable, and the prohibition on allegedly misleading representations will make it impossible to refer to efficacies of natural remedies which have been public knowledge for centuries. The Regulations, therefore, represent a fundamental attack on the Australian people's freedom of choice in medicine and are an abomination.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the House will reject the Therapeutic Goods Regulations and request the House to constitute a Public Enquiry into the question of registration of the natural healing professions and the supervision and regulation of natural therapeutic goods.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound will forever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Bradford (from 84 citizens), Mr Taylor (from 137 citizens) and Dr Bob Woods (from 20 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Natural Therapy
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives assembled in parliament:

The petition of certain citizens of Australia, draws to the attention of the House our objections to the Therapeutic Goods Regulations under the Therapeutic Goods Act, 1989. The Regulations, therefore, represent a fundamental attack on the Australian people's freedom of choice in medicine and are an abomination.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the House will reject the Therapeutic Goods Regulations and request the House to constitute a Public Enquiry into the question of regulation of natural therapeutic goods.

PETITION.TITLE: Rights of the Child
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

1. that ratification of United Nations Conventions, such as the above, by the Federal Government, without Parliamentary debate or consultation with the people through a referendum, is a gross abuse of the Australian Constitution and is contrary to democratic principles;
2. that the Convention's philosophy of parent/child relationships is based on a false premise and embodies the totalitarian principles of State ownership of children;

3. that the Christian principle of parental authority is essential for the proper functioning of society, but phrases in the Convention implying parents' rights are virtually meaningless, with escape clauses permitting the widest of interpretation;
4. that Articles 12 to 16 giving children the right to seek, think, say and be whatever, where ever and with whom they wish violates the common sense of any normal parent;
5. that some Articles contradict other Articles and imprecise wording adds to the confusion by providing loopholes for the protection of paedophiles and certain types of child traffickers;

6. that some of the proposed rights are inappropriate for immature child minds and have no logical connection with the protection of children from abuse or deprivation, such protection being already provided by existing Australian laws.
Your petitioners therefore request the House to legislate or provide for:
(a) a twelve month Moratorium on the ratification of the Convention to enable the people of Australia to discuss and examine in detail the 54 Articles;
(b) a referendum to follow the Moratorium, seeking public approval before ratification of the Convention.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Beale (from 95 citizens) and Mr Charles (from 114 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Rights of the Child
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The Petition of the undersigned Citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That, because the United Nations' Convention on the Rights of the Child would allow Governments to deprive parents of their rights, we request that the Parliament delay ratification for at least a year, to allow full open public debate and then a binding referendum.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Rights of the Child
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives Assembled in Parliament:
The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House their deep concern about the U.N. Convention on the Rights of the Child.
Your petitioners therefore pray that:
1. The Australian Government not ratify the U.N. Convention on the Rights of the Child.
2. That the Australian people be made aware off its contents.
3. The Convention be debated in the Parliament.
4. That an Act of Parliament be made to ensure all international treaties (excluding national security) are debated by the Parliament.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Bradford (from 1,891 citizens) and Mr Broadbent (from 240 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Medicare: Abortions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The Humble Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
- That every abortion kills an unborn human baby.
- That the right to life of all humans is the most fundamental and essential of all human rights.
- That the Government's first duty is to protect this right to life.
- That the most defenceless and threatened lives are those of unborn babies for whom the Government is duty bound to take extra steps to protect.
- That in 1987/88 taxpayers funds through Medicare provided medical benefits for 61,879 abortions totalling $6.4 million.
- That in the same year Commonwealth grants to the States indirectly financed the deliberate killing of thousands of other unborn babies in State Public Hospitals.

Your Petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Australian Parliament carry out its duty to protect the right to life of Australian babies by ceasing to fund abortions through Medicare, restricting grants to the States and by all other means at its disposal.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Cadman (from 33 citizens) and Mr Sinclair (from 19 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Natural Therapy
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

We, the citizens of Australia, wish to bring to your attention our objections to the Therapeutic Goods Regulations under the Therapeutic Goods Act, 1989. Under the guise of protecting the public against inferior therapeutic goods and devices, the Regulations will have the effect of putting out of business many natural therapists and small scale manufacturers of natural remedies. The clauses in the Regulations which purport to exempt Homoeopaths and Herbalists are badly drafted and the prohibition on advertising will make it impossible for Australians to use natural medicines. The Regulations therefore, represent a fundamental attack on the Australian people's freedom of choice in medicine.
Your petitioners pray that the House will reject the Therapeutic Goods Regulations and request the House to constitute a Public Enquiry into the registration of natural medicines.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will forever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Prosser (from 31 citizens) and Mr Taylor (from 474 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Assets Test: Family Allowances
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth:

That the Government's Asset Test on Family Allowances and reduction of eligibility for Austudy as a result of the tighter Assets Test will further contribute to the hardship and disadvantages facing the rural community compared to their urban counterparts.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House should immediately seek that special consideration be given to retaining the original criteria for assessing eligibility for Family Allowance and Assets Test levels in relation to Austudy.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Fuel Costs
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speakers and members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:
The petition of certain residents of the State of South Australia, draws to the attention of the House-
fuel crisis

1) Goods are transported from the City to Country towns-this incurs freight rates. With the high rise of fuel, freight rates are on the increase. This means the cost of goods are much higher in the country areas, than in the City.
2) Some business houses are reluctant to keep increasing their prices every week. Therefore, they will run at a loss.
3) Country wage earners are paid on the same awards as City wage earners.
4) Goods in the Country areas cost more. Therefore the Country wage earner pays more.
5) Employment in the Country is not plentiful. Therefore quite a few Country people travel to the City on a daily basis. This costs more.
6) Country people living a distance from their closest town, have to travel to and from to do their shopping. This costs more.
7) People on Unemployment Benefits are unable to travel the distances to seek employment. This would reduce their benefits.
All in all, due to the fuel increases, the country people have a very high cost of living to cope with.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the House stop this continuous fuel increasing and reduce fuel prices back to a reasonable level. Also, a subsidy on fuel and freight would greatly benefit Country people.

PETITION.TITLE: Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled; the humble petition of the undersigned citizens showeth:

that your petitioners deplore the Federal Government's decision to remove 53 Pharmaceutical drugs from the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme including the best available for the treatment of high blood pressure, cancer, epilepsy, high cholesterol and uneven heartbeat-and place them for cost saving reasons only on a special list requiring Authority from a Canberra bureaucrat, and;

that we believe a patient's doctor is clearly the best judge for medication needed for their particular illness and that it is therefore wrong and unfair to force that doctor to seek permission from a bureaucrat in Canberra who has no personal knowledge of that case.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled will call on the Government to immediately abandon the proposal and keep its election promise of high quality and universal health care for all Australians.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Fuel Costs
PETITION.PARA: To the honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Parliament of Australia will:

1. Review the 47% Government excise duty on every litre of petrol in view of the rising price. Therefore keeping the Government revenue equal to what it was before the Middle East situation in an endeavour to stabilise the price of petrol.
Our concern is for the inflationary effect the rise in price has on the whole economy. We urge you to consider the welfare of the people as many will suffer as the price of petrol rises.
2. We urge you to exercise stricter control over the Petrol Companies not to unduly increase petrol prices because of the Middle East situation when most of the petrol comes from Australia anyway.

PETITION.TITLE: Aid
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in the Parliament assembled.
We, the undersigned citizens, wish to record our support for the One World Declaration:
- to focus Australian aid, and policies at the World Bank, IMF and Asian Development Bank, on fighting poverty and protecting the environment;
- to restore Australian aid to 0.5% of GNP, cut military spending by 1% and work for a fairer international economic system;
- to promote human rights through aid and a code of conduct for companies.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives call upon the Government to implement the above.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Economy
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in the Parliament assembled.
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
that the current economic policy mix is incorrect and is causing widespread harm to Australia's export sector; primary producers; small business and the general community;
that the current high interest rates and high Australian dollar have destroyed the competitiveness of Australian products on the world market and hampered export growth.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the Australian Parliament will move that the Federal Government change its current emphasis on monetary policy to a more balanced economic approach in order to bring about a reduction in interest rates; a lower Australian dollar; and more efficient and competitive business environment.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Oxley Airlines Ltd
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives Assembled in Parliament.
The petition of certain citizens of Australia points out to the House the following:
1. On the 7th April 1988 an Aircraft VH-HOX owned by Oxley Airlines Limited crashed whilst approaching Coffs Harbour Airport. The pilot and two passengers died in the accident.

2. An Inquest into the causes of the deaths of the pilot, Tony Lester Bowen and the two passengers, Leslie John Allen and Gloria Dunn has been conducted by Coroner, Derrick Windsor Hand, who gave his findings on 14th November 1989.
3. On page 4 of his Judgment Mr Hand stated:

``I'm not holding an inquiry and never intended to hold an inquiry into Oxley Airlines but it seems to me that there is such a lot of evidence regarding allegations about breaches of A.N.O. 48 and the operations of Oxley Airlines that it would be remiss of me if I did not recommend to the Federal Minister for Transport and Communications that some inquiry should be held into Oxley, the running, operations of Oxley Airlines. I cannot just ignore what has been said in this Court in this hearing regarding the operations of Oxley Airlines and as I've indicated that safety is a paramount consideration. Now I feel it is for another inquiry to more fully go into this question as I do feel that I have sufficient evidence to recommend to the minister accordingly and I intend to recommend to the minister, the Federal Minister for Transport and Communications . . .''.
4. He later said:

``. . . I also recommend, in accordance with what I stated, to the Federal Minister of Transport and Communications that an independent inquiry be conducted into the operations of Oxley Airlines . . .''.
5. At the present time the Federal Minister for Transport and Communications has not conducted or commenced an independent inquiry into the operation of Oxley Airlines Limited.
Your Petitioners therefore ask the House as representatives of the people assembled in Parliament to direct the Minister for Transport and Communications:
(a) To set up an independent inquiry into the operation of Oxley Airlines Limited;
(b) To direct the Minister for Transport and Communications in setting up the inquiry that it be conducted independently of the Civil Aviation Authority.

PETITION.TITLE: Medicare Office, Murray Bridge
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

The petition of certain residents of the State of South Australia draws to the attention of the House the contrast between the level of service provided by Medicare to city residents and the level of service provided to rural residents in this State.

In particular, the lack of a Medicare Office in Murray Bridge is seriously disadvantaging the people in this and other country areas. Claims often take several weeks to be processed; the cost of posting the claim to Medicare is an extra burden on Medicare clients and it is also very difficult to conduct enquiries by correspondence or by telephone rather than dealing with people face-to-face. This is particularly so for the elderly and those with poor English.

Your petitioners therefore respectfully ask the House of Representatives to consider the needs of people living in rural areas such as Murray Bridge and provide a Medicare Office or agency for their convenience.

PETITION.TITLE: Coat of Arms and National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.

The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth their concern that proper protection be afforded both the Australian Coat of Arms and the present Australian national flag. It respectfully requests that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled will take legislative action to protect the present Australian Coat of Arms and National flag along the lines of existing legislation which protects the word `ANZAC'.
The petition further requests that in any legislation the House of Representatives ensures that:
1. Penalties are provided for the unlawful use of the Australian Coat of Arms in any commercial undertaking without seeking the approval of the relevant Minister.

2. It is an offence to assist knowingly in any act to deface, defame or denigrate the Australian national flag, or any Armed Force or Merchant Marine ensign with a penalty of no less than $500.00 and/or three months imprisonment for any such offence.
3. The offence of destroying or burning the flag or emblem provide for a fine of not less than $1,000.00 or six months imprisonment.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will every pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Abortion Funding Abolition Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in the Parliament assembled.
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
- That every abortion kills an unborn human baby.
- That the right to life of all humans is the most fundamental and essential of all human rights.
- That in 1987/88 the Federal Government paid $6.4 million from taxpayers' funds for 61,879 abortions under Medicare Items 6469 and 274/275 alone.
- That in the same year Federal Government grants to the States indirectly financed the deliberate killing of thousands of other unborn babies in State Public Hospitals.
- Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Australian Parliament will carry out its duty to protect the right to life of Australian babies and abolish Government funding of abortion.
And your petitioners as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

The petition of certain pension recipients, electors of the Division of Melbourne Ports, points out to the House the recent cut in the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme involving a $2.50 charge per prescription strikes a heavy blow at those already living below or close to the poverty line. It is particularly iniquitous to many of us on multiple prescriptions.
Your petitioners therefore ask the House to overturn the $2.50 charge and to provide prescriptions free of charge to pensioners.

PETITION.TITLE: Commonwealth Bank, Keperra
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament.

The petition of certain residents and small business persons of Keperra and surrounding suburbs, draws to the attention of the House the fact that the Commonwealth Bank of Australia is presently assessing a submission for the closure or otherwise of its Keperra service centre. The closure of this service centre would cause undue hardship to the elderly and infirm residents, mothers with young families and businesses.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the House will take the necessary action to prevent the Commonwealth Bank from closing its Keperra service centre.

PETITION.TITLE: Wealth Inquiry
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled
The Petition of the undersigned shows:

That in Australia, the rich are getting richer while poverty is increasing, as shown by recent research that 10% of the population own 50% of the wealth while people in poverty have increased from 1.6 million in 1982 to 2.1 million in 1986.
Your petitioners ask that the House of Representatives should:
. . . request the Australian Government-
to establish a Wealth Inquiry as a first and essential step to the achievement of a more just society;
and that this Inquiry should seek to establish-
- the current distribution of wealth, how it has changed over time and the causes of these changes
- the effectiveness of the Australian taxation system in raising revenue at all levels of taxpayers' income and assets
- the measures which should be taken to achieve a more just society

PETITION.TITLE: Saturday Trading for Banks
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

The petition of certain staff of the Commonwealth Bank of Australia, Upper Mt Gravatt Qld points out to the House that the staff members whose signatures appear below are opposed to the introduction of Saturday trading for Banks based on the following facts:
1) There is no demand for weekend banking;

2) At great expense, banks provide services such as Automatic Telling Machines (ATM's), Electronic Funds Transfer-Point of Sale (EFTPOS) and Phonebank to cater for customers outside normal trading hours;
3) Nightsafe deposit facilities for use after hours have served business well over many years;
4) The Bank's agency network is extensive and popular;
5) Extensive use of credit cards reduce the need for cash;
6) Airports and most hotels cater for tourists with currency exchange facilities;
7) The increased cost of opening branches will not be met by the banks, but will be passed on to the customer.
Your petitioners therefore request the House to strenuously oppose the proposed introduction of Saturday trading for Banks on our behalf.

PETITION.TITLE: Pollution
PETITION.PARA: To The Honourable The Speaker and Members of The House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

The Petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House the concern of the said citizens regarding the increasing dangers caused by polluting substances in our air food and water.
Public bodies whose function it is to protect us against these dangers have been ineffectual.
Your petitioners therefore request the House to:
1. Require the public bodies concerned to enforce present laws regarding water and air pollution more rigorously.
2. Minimise the use of food additives which do not enhance nutrition.
3. Prevent the production, sale or giving away of irradiated foods.

PETITION.TITLE: Woodchipping
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament. The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of this House that we are concerned at the threats caused by logging to the integrity and continued existence of what remains of the forests of south eastern Australia.
Your petitioners therefore request the House to direct the Prime Minister and his government
1) to phase out woodchipping for export;
2) not to renew a long-term export licence to Harris Daishowa;

3) to ensure that sensitive environmental areas, and specifically the proposed national park and wilderness areas of Coolangubra, Cathcart, Egan Peaks and the Tantawangalo catchment, are protected and excluded from the proposed woodchip export licence; and
4) to promote ecologically sound and sustainable forestry practices including:
- re-afforestation and plantation of native hardwoods on already cleared land to reduce pressure on native forests; and
- minimisation of wasteful uses of forest products.

PETITION.TITLE: Medicare: Abortions
PETITION.PARA: The Honourable Speaker and members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament. This petition of the below citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House of Representatives that we support the continued cover for all abortions on the Medicare schedule. We oppose any attempt to restrict access to the rebate under Medicare.

Medicare cannot pretend to be a Universal health care system without providing a rebate for a termination of pregnancy. Those who will be hardest hit by proposals to restrict access to items 6469, 274 and 275 on the Medicare schedule are poorer and disadvantaged women who will not be able to meet the cost of a non-subsidised abortion.
Your petitioners humbly pray and request that the House will vote against any attempt to restrict access to abortion or any abortion-related items on the Medicare schedule.

PETITION.TITLE: Chlorofluorocarbons and Halons
PETITION.PARA: Petition to the Honourable Speaker and members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:
This petition of certain students, citizens of Australia and stewards of the earth draws to the attention of this House that we are concerned about ozone depletion.
Your petitioners therefore request the House to direct the Prime Minister and his Government to:
- change our legislation in the Spring Session of Parliament this year to enact a total phase-out of consumption of CFCs and halons by 1994
- reduce our CFC export quotas to 1986 levels immediately and then phase-out exports by 20% per annum, with a complete phase-out of production and export of CFCs and halons by 1995
- support the above phase-out schedules globally at the Montreal Protocol Review in June 1990.

PETITION.TITLE: Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House that the construction of the third runway at Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) airport would be uneconomic, environmentally damaging and disruptive to the community.

Your petitioners therefore request the House to urge the Minister for The arts, Sport, the Environment, tourism and Territories to conduct a full public inquiry to the proposal to construct a third runway at Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport under the provisions of the Commonwealth Act relating to environmental impact assessments.

PETITION.TITLE: Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws the attention of the House to the fact that the construction of a third runway at Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport will cause great harm to the environment and the economy of Sydney.
Your petitioners therefore request the House to oppose the third runway and to urge the Government to proceed instead with the development of an airport at Badgery's Creek.

PETITION.TITLE: CSIRO Charter
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:
The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws the attention of the House to the current status of the C.S.I.R.O.

Your petitioners therefore request the House expand the charter of the C.S.I.R.O. so that it can develop environmentally sound manufacturing and recycling procedures which are supported and subsidised by the Commonwealth Government.

PETITION.TITLE: Constitution
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:
The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws the attention of the House to the current status of the Constitution of the Commonwealth of Australia.
Your petitioners request that the House alter the Constitution so as to make provision for the public of Australia to be able to initiate referenda.

PETITION.TITLE: Joint Coal Board
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth.

Our appreciation for the valuable medical, health and welfare concern and care, the Joint Coal Board has over many years taken with mineworkers and retired workers previously employed in the coal mining industry.

We the undersigned not only appreciate the role played by the Joint Coal Board, protecting mineworkers health, (compared to incombustible asbestos workers) but also look forward to further important progressive changes in the future of the Coal Board after the Federal Government review.

PETITION.TITLE: Family Allowance
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament.

The petition of certain residents of the State of Western Australia draws to the attention of the House the Government's recent decision to introduce an assets test restricting Family Allowance Payments and points out that this will disadvantage many low income rural families by denying them assistance because of their assets, including the family farm, exceeding $300,000 in value.
Your petitioners therefore request the House to support rural families by opposing the Government's decision.

PETITION.TITLE: Family Allowance
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament.

The petition of certain residents of the State of Western Australia draws to the attention of the House the Government's recent decision to introduce an assets test restricting Family Allowance payments threshold to $200,000 and the Family Allowance payments threshold to $300,000 and points out that this will disadvantage many low income rural families by denying them assistance because their assets, including farming property exceed these low limits.
Your petitioners therefore request the House to support rural families by opposing the Government's decision.

PETITION.TITLE: Citizen Initiated Referendums
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The Humble Petition of certain Citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
Governments of the Commonwealth of Australia have in past years adopted policies which have been against the opinions of the majority of voters, for example, the Australia Card Bill.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Parliament pass a Bill to provide for a Constitutional change so that when five per cent of the voters demands a referendum to initiate or veto legislation, the referendum shall be held within a specified time, for example, nine months, and its decision shall be binding.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Advertising by Political Parties
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and the Honourable Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully draws the attention of the House to the threat to free speech contained within the recommendations of the majority report of the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters.

We believe that all persons have the right to express their views through paid commercial advertising on television and radio and that any limitation on that right constitutes a threat to the peoples' freedom of speech and to the Australian democratic system.

Your petitioners therefore request that the Parliament rejects the recommendations of the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters and preserves the right of all persons and political parties to exercise their right to free speech through any media they choose.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Assets Test: Family Allowance
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament.

The petition of certain electors of the Division of Maranoa points out to the House that the 1990/91 Federal Budget stipulates that from January next year Family Allowance payments will be subject to an assets test. Family Allowance will be withdrawn if net assets, excluding the family home and debt exceed $300,000. Furthermore, the parental assets test threshold for Family Allowance Supplement, Austudy and Assistance for Isolated Children has been severely slashed in the 1990/91 Federal Budget.

Considering the economic crisis facing rural communities in Australia, asset tests of such a nature are not viable because the assets are incapable of generating enough income to sustain families and send children away for schooling.

Your petitioners therefore ask the House to abolish the assets test for Family Allowance and Assistance for Isolated Children and to reconsider the decision to reduce the assets test for Austudy, and Family Allowance Supplement.

PETITION.TITLE: Medicare Office, Maroochydore
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

The petition of residents of the State of Queensland draws to the attention of the House of the fact that the residents of Maroochydore are disadvantaged by the fact that they have no Medicare office in the vicinity and must travel to Nambour or Kawana for claiming purposes.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled require the Government to supply us with an accessible Medicare office in Maroochydore.

PETITION.TITLE: Rights of the Child
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House that the proposed ratification of the United Nations Convention on the rights of the Child gives our nation a unique opportunity to:
- declare our belief that all children have the right to be protected from abuse and exploitation, and to enjoy the opportunity for full development of the human personality,
- affirm the fundamental importance of the family in our society,
- recognise the unique rights and responsibilities of the parent/child relationship.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the House express the view, on behalf of the citizens who interests it represents, that the ratification of the Convention be in a form which emphasises these rights and principles, and which pays the highest regard to the importance of the family unit in Australian society and to the rights and responsibilities of parents.

PETITION.TITLE: Gosford City Council Area: Flooding
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

The Petition of the residents of Gosford City points out to the House that Gosford City has suffered greatly in recent years from flooding. Investigation by Council shows the principal causes to be rapid development, changing standards, old developments carried out before effective policies, and insufficient knowledge of causes and solutions.

Flooding affects thousand of people in the Council area. Since 1980 the Council has implemented flood management policies designed to prevent perpetuation of the problem. Many old problems exist which need to be overcome.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your Honourable House urgently seek to help the residents of Gosford, Woy Woy and surrounding areas find ways and means to reduce, mitigate or overcome the flooding problems of the Gosford City Council area.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scholes The Hon G.G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Standing Committee on Procedure, I present the Committee's report entitled Responses to Petitions, together with the minutes of the proceedings.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is the second report of the Standing Committee on Procedure in the Thirty-sixth Parliament. The Committee resolved to inquire into the adequacy of the provisions for responding to petitions, as it was aware that many members were dissatisfied with the current follow-up procedures and were taking their own steps to ensure that petitions were provided with some sort of response by the House.

SPEECH.PARA: As all honourable members would appreciate, many of their constituents spend considerable time and effort preparing and circulating petitions to gather signatures. We have seen petitions presented in this House with many thousands of signatures, and yet it is rare for any further action to be taken once the petition had been presented in the House. The Committee feels that this situation is unsatisfactory.

As an aside, I draw honourable members' attention to a table on page 3 of the report which sets out the numbers of petitions which have been presented to this House in blocks of 10 years since Federation. Honourable members will note from that that between 1901 and 1910 in the first fluster of Federation over 800 petitions were presented.

In the next 40 years only 200 petitions were presented. That number doubled in the following 10 years. But in the last two 10-year periods, 15,500 petitions were presented between 1970 and 1980, and 25,000 between 1980 and 1990. Thus, an enormous amount of effort went into presenting material to this House for virtually no response.

The lack of follow-up on petitions has been recognised by the House in the past. The Procedure Committee addressed this problem in 1986 in its report on the days and hours of sitting and the effective use of the time of the House. Following that report, sessional orders were adopted giving Ministers the option of responding to petitions that had been referred to them. Under the present arrangements, Ministers may lodge a response with the Clerk and that response will be announced at the end of petitions being announced.

That provision has been in the sessional orders for nearly three years and, at this time, not one Minister has taken the opportunity to respond to a petition in this way. The failure of Ministers to respond has been very disappointing. The Committee feels that the failure of Ministers to provide responses points to the need to direct Ministers to do so within a specified time. The Committee proposes therefore that Ministers be required to respond to petitions in the area in which they have responsibility. These responses should be lodged with the Clerk within 21 sitting days of the petition being referred formally by the House, and that the responses be printed in Hansard, along with answers to Questions on Notice.

In recommending that Ministers be required to respond to petitions, the Committee feels that it is not placing an unreasonable demand on Ministers. In many other comparable legislatures, follow-up procedures on petitions are far more positive than in the House of Representatives. For example, in the New Zealand House of Representatives, and the Lok Sabha in India, petitions are referred to committees, while in the Canadian House of Commons, a response must be provided by the Government within a specified time. Even in the United Kingdom House of Commons, where Ministers are not obliged to respond to petitions, approximately 70 per cent of petitions actually receive a response.

The Committee is aware that many members, although they are not obliged to, acknowledge petitions they have lodged for their constituents, either in writing to one or more petitioners to advise that a petition has been presented to the House, or perhaps by forwarding a copy of the Hansard report. We would like to encourage all members to acknowledge petitions in this way and feel that it is an important means by which citizens are provided with some immediate response to their grievance.

I am sure all members will agree that petitions can form an important link between the parliament and the people and that the changes proposed in this report can strengthen this link by making the process a two-way one by ensuring the grievances of petitioners receive consideration. I commend the report to the House. I move:
That the House take note of the paper.

TALK.START.PARA: —In accordance with sessional order 102B, the debate is adjourned, and the resumption of the debate will be made an order of the day for the next sitting Thursday.

DEBATE.TITLE: PARLIAMENTARY DELEGATION TO THE EUROPEAN PARLIAMENTARY INSTITUTIONS

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edwards Mr R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: — I present the report of the Australian parliamentary delegation to the European parliamentary institutions, Switzerland and France, September and October, 1990. I thank you, Madam Deputy Speaker, for your assistance this morning. I am pleased to present this report on behalf on my colleagues in the delegation. It was a very opportune time to be visiting Europe, and my colleagues the honourable member for Dobell (Mr Lee) and the honourable member for Indi (Mr Ewen Cameron) will also speak in this debate and make some comments about their viewpoints.

SPEECH.PARA: I thank those honourable members and also my colleague the honourable member for Phillip (Ms McHugh), who took over the delegation in its time in France. I would also like to thank Senators McLean and Tambling. Senator Tambling was the deputy leader of the delegation and at all times was very helpful and cooperative.

It was a very successful delegation from a number of viewpoints, and it was successful with respect to the cooperation we received from our posts overseas and certainly from the support we received from the secretary to the delegation, Mr Michael Ong, and the secretary to the leader of the delegation, Mrs Albertha Williamson, and I would thank them very much. I would also like to thank people in posts overseas, particularly our Ambassador in Brussels, Mr Curtis, and the team who work with him; our Ambassador in Berne in Switzerland, Mr Brook; and our Ambassador, Mr Pocock, in France. I would also like to acknowledge people such as Mr Ferdinand Rammelt and Mr Luciano Cao, who acted as liaison agents for us and helped us in our various visits.

It is important, I think, at this stage to emphasise to this Parliament that this report is very timely from a number of points of view. It is timely in particular because, right at the moment, we have the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT) Uruguay Round-I suppose one could say-proceeding in a very uncertain fashion in Brussels. There is great interest in this Parliament, certainly by our rural community and by the community at large, with regard to the significant outcome of those GATT talks-that is, about the reduction of tariffs on trade generally but, in particular, our interest happens to be in agricultural as well as services and manufacturing trade.

It was a concern, I think, of the delegation that the Europeans were reluctant to bring about changes in terms of their attitude towards border protection, which is basically tariffs on entry to products but, secondly, in terms of subsidies to third markets. So we have a situation where the Europeans are not only making it virtually impossible for Australian products to get into the European market but, secondly, making it very difficult for Australia's unsubsidised rural products to compete in third markets. That is very unsatisfactory from the point of view of Australia and the point of view of the delegation.

I will portray an image which I am sure will help to illustrate this point. When in Switzerland, I decided to take the prices of some basic commodities and compare them with what price one would pay in Australia. If people recognise that one Swiss franc is equal to one Australian dollar, one will begin to understand. I decided to buy some emmentaler cheese: 22 Swiss francs a kilo; in Australia, one can buy emmentaler for 9 Swiss francs or $9. Wine, a vin ordinaire, costs 15 Swiss francs for a bottle; in Australia, one could buy a similar bottle for five Swiss francs or $5. Veal bought for a meal that night cost 32 Swiss francs per kilo; in Australia, one could buy similar veal for nine Swiss francs. Milk, which is basically a commodity the Europeans produce in great quantity, costs 1.8 Swiss francs a litre; in Australia, one can get milk for 0.8 or 80c a litre.

TALK.START.PARA: —Disgraceful.

—A loaf of bread costs 2 Swiss francs; in Australia, one can buy a similar loaf of bread for $1 or one Swiss franc. That analogy I could continue on to illustrate the difference in prices. I acknowledge that incomes are a bit higher in Europe but when we look, as my colleague suggests, at the relationship between those prices that people pay and the prices at which we could put Australian products on to European markets, one understands the significance of what the Common Agricultural Policy is about. It is about European consumers paying very high prices, and Australian producers being denied access. So it is a very serious issue and one that we ought to, in my view, use these sorts of analogies to illustrate the differences.

SPEECH.PARA: I now turn to the question of the North Atlantic Treaty Organisation (NATO). Clearly there has been a significant change in Europe, and the significant relationships in Europe are something that we would all welcome. We were very encouraged as a delegation by the attitude of the North Atlantic assembly in NATO to see itself as having an out-of-area role: that is, to have a responsibility for maintaining piece and security in other regions. It is interesting that we now have in the Persian Gulf this first test of the Europeans as well as the United States of America and other countries in a wider setting.

I was encouraged, and I am sure my colleagues were encouraged, by the attitude of the Europeans at NATO, the North Atlantic Assembly, the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) and the Council of Europe to have Australia play a wider role-and that is something we are very keen to pursue.

I turn now to the question of the environment. It is very clear that the Europeans regard Australia as a significant country in terms of environmental protection and policy. The delegation at large was encouraged by that attitude. It is important that we recognise that the Europeans are looking to Australia in many respects for environmental management. We can provide a lead on a number of issues. The Europeans would be keen to talk with us on those matters.

I turn further to our visit to Switzerland. We were very encouraged by the bilateral relationships that were established there. It should be pointed out that clearly the corporate collapses in Australia have created a crisis of confidence amongst the Swiss banking community. We found it necessary to try to reassure the Swiss bankers that Australia was a good place to do business. We all have a responsibility in this Parliament, and in the parliaments in all the States, to ensure that. We need an Australian Securities Commission regulation in Western Australia to give overseas investors security in knowing that their money will be safe within Australia. That is very important. I say that very clearly, not in a partisan way, but to assure overseas investors of our position.

I conclude by noting that we were very pleased that the visit to France went so well. I am sure my colleagues can add further to that. I close by saying that we felt it was important to get this report to the Parliament immediately. It is very timely, given the events in Europe. My colleagues found it a very valuable visit. We appreciated the support we got from the overseas embassies here before we went. We appreciate the opportunity we had to conduct those visits and we certainly appreciate the support we got whilst we were there. Like my colleagues, I am pleased to commend this report to the Parliament.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cameron Mr E.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was a great honour to be included in the parliamentary delegation to the European parliamentary institutions so ably led by the honourable member for Stirling (Mr Ronald Edwards). I will briefly comment on a few areas and try to keep away from the areas that the honourable member for Stirling spoke about. Our visit to Switzerland was most interesting. We were the first Australian parliamentary delegation to visit the Swiss Parliament. It was quite an honour and a unique experience.

SPEECH.PARA: An area I was particularly interested in was the Swiss system of constitutional initiatives and referenda, whereby citizens can exercise ultimate control over government and certain types of legislation. In Switzerland if 40,000 citizens sign a petition requesting a referendum on a specific issue it is compulsory for the Government to conduct that referendum. That is on all issues other than issues which would affect the Constitution. A petition requires 100,000 signatures if the issue affects the Constitution.

Having these numbers so low-the Swiss parliamentarians told us that those numbers had been even lower and had only recently been raised-there are many requests for referenda. I felt the politicians were rather hesitant about the number they have. They felt that the legislators were inclined to water down legislation to make the legislation soft enough so that they would not have to face up to a referendum. It was very interesting to look at this aspect because there is such a movement throughout Australia for citizen initiated referenda.

After visiting Switzerland we went by bus to Brussels and spent 11 days there. It was very interesting. We talked to officials from the European Commission and the Council of Ministers of the European Communities. All the executive and administration of the Council of Ministers, the European Parliament and the European Community are based in Brussels. This is unique because the Council of Europe and the European Parliament meet in Strasbourg.

We also visited the Belgium Parliament and we had a meeting with the Belgian-Australian parliamentary friendship group. It is expected that a delegation from the Belgium Parliament should visit Australia next year.

We spoke to executive members of the North Atlantic Assembly, the European Trade Union Conference and the North Atlantic Treaty Organisation. A very special part of our visit to Belgium was to Ypres and the Menin Gate. So many Australians who lost their lives during the First World War are buried there. It was a very moving experience. The Belgians are very aware of the Australian contribution to the First World War.

After Brussels, we travelled by bus to Strasbourg where we attended a meeting of the Council of Europe and took part in the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development debate. Our leader, the honourable member for Stirling, addressed the Council of Europe in that debate very effectively, I thought, and I congratulate him. There was certainly enormous interest in the fact that there was Australian participation in and attendance at that debate.

The following week we attended the European Parliament. There was enormous interest in the fact that Australia was interested in the European Parliament. We had some quite intensive discussions, revolving particularly around the European Community agricultural policy. As the honourable member for Stirling has already pointed out, there is enormous political resistance from certain areas in Europe to change in that policy, mainly for political reasons. The politicians are under heavy pressure from their rural constituents who very much enjoy the protection given to them by that policy. That is why there is difficulty with the Uruguay Round talks at this stage.

After Strasbourg, we moved on to Paris as guests of the French Assembly. That was a most interesting period. We spent six days in France. Ambassador Pocock and Mrs Pocock accompanied us virtually everywhere. We were very well looked after. Ms Alice Gay from the Embassy accompanied us. Mr Nicolas Milosevic, the Secretary of the National Assembly of France Friendship Group, accompanied us everywhere and without him we would have been lost because when one moves around France one is surprised by the number of people who do not speak our language, and I must admit we could not speak their language. As I said, we were well looked after.

It was very interesting to ride on the TGV, which is the French very fast train. We travelled from Paris to Tours, in the south of France, on this very fast train. We were taken up to the forward control area and I sat next to the driver. We were travelling at 300 kilometres an hour straight down the track. It was like flying in a jet; it was just so smooth; it was fantastic. We were going through sets of points at 250 kilometres an hour. It was a unique experience.

I was particularly interested, because the proposed very fast train in Australia would pass through my electorate, in the noise factor. I would look out the window and see some cows in a cow yard who had just been milked, chewing away at some hay. We would go slipping past and they would not even look up to say, `How do you do', because they could not speak English anyway. An important aspect which was pointed out to me with regard to the noise factor is that, whilst going through the towns, the big buffer walls are put in, while out in the countryside there are no walls. It was explained to me that there is a one second approach noise, one second passing noise and one second going away. One, two, three, and it has gone. It is not like aeroplane noise. So the noise factor is not as great as people who have not experienced the situation might think.

There is very strong consideration given to the environment. Tunnels were even put underneath the line for the frogs to travel through. The environmentalists were very concerned about squashed frogs on the railway line. They were concerned not only about the effect on the train, travelling at 300 kilometres an hour, but also the effect on the frog. Anyway, it was a magical experience.

The next matter I want to mention is the visit to the Chinon power station, which was of great interest. Some members of the delegation were a little concerned about being in a nuclear power station. However, it was very well run and we had the unique experience of seeing the top of one of the reactors off when people were extracting the spent rods-all done underwater and very efficiently. It was a most interesting experience.

Then we went down to Marseilles, where-hold your breath!-we examined a very modern sewage treatment plant. We did hold our breath! It is unique. It has been built under the city, a sports ground has been built on top of it and it has the capacity to handle a vast amount-270,000 cubic metres-of liquid waste every day. Formerly this was sent right out into the Mediterranean, causing enormous pollution. These matters are related to some of the problems we are having in Australia today. Sewage is now treated under the city in a very modern, unique piece of French engineering.

I do not have time to go into all of the vast number of interesting things we saw in France, but I want to mention our visit to the multifunction centre called Sophia-Antipolis. It is an enormous success. The founder of the Sophia-Antipolis, Senator Pierre Laffitte, advised that in the Australian multifunction polis the emphasis should be on a research and high technology centre and not a manufacturing centre.
I have run out of time, Mr Deputy Speaker, and thank you very much.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lee Mr M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to start my contribution this morning by thanking you, Mr Deputy Speaker, as the leader of the parliamentary delegation to the European parliamentary institutions, for your leadership and support and for your ability to make the delegation an outstanding success. I also thank Senator Tambling, the deputy leader, and Madame le Presidente, who led the delegation during part of our period in Strasbourg and France. Of course, as other people have pointed out, the delegation was able to visit Switzerland. You yourself, Mr Deputy Speaker, have mentioned how important the bankers in Switzerland believe it is for Australia to have improved, adequate and tough corporate legislation. That is something we all hope can be achieved nationally in all parliaments, including that of Western Australia, in the near future.

SPEECH.PARA: While we were in Switzerland, the Swiss were conducting a referendum on the future of nuclear power. A proposal to phase out the use of nuclear power was defeated; however, an alternative referendum to prohibit the construction of any new nuclear power stations for the next 10 years was carried. Many people in Australia who support these citizen initiated referenda would be wise to look at the experience of Switzerland. Switzerland is not a member of the United Nations (UN) because, while the government supports Switzerland's joining the UN, it cannot convince the majority of the Swiss people to vote in a referendum to join the United Nations. In one of the states making up the federation of Switzerland, women still do not have the vote in state elections or state referendums because the males, who have the vote in that state, have not seen fit to grant women the vote for state elections. So people who support citizen initiated referendums might look at the experience in Switzerland as to whether that is the way they wish to go.

We also had the great honour to be able to join you, Mr Deputy Speaker, in laying a wreath at Menin Gate in Ypres. We had many discussions with members of the European Parliament and the Council of Europe on human rights, the future of the common agricultural policy and the future of eastern Europe. Some of the previous speakers have already touched on these issues.

Common agricultural policies seemed to dominate our discussions everywhere we went. Given the fact that the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade negotiations are now coming to a climax-hopefully, a successful outcome-it was quite natural that many of our debates, arguments and discussions were about these issues. In particular, Australia is very concerned that the Andriessen accords which were given to our country by the European Commission may be breached. The European Community has in the past assured Australia that it will not dump its products on third markets, and Australia is very determined to make sure that those assurances are met.

During our visit to France we were very fortunate to be looked after by Nicolas Milosevic from the French Assembly, and the Chairman of the France-Australia Parliamentary Friendship Group, Jean-Jack Queyranne, and Robert Le Foll went to great lengths to make sure that our visit was successful. Despite past difficulties in our relationship with France, the French went to great lengths to emphasise to us that they believe our common work on areas such as Antarctica and New Caledonia means that the Australia-France relationship has grown and improved greatly.

In conclusion, I thank Michael Ong, the delegation's secretary, and Ms Albertha Williamson for the help that they gave us. I also pay tribute to all the embassies and overseas missions that assisted us, particularly to Peter Curtis in Brussels and Hugh Borrowman who made sure that our delegation was able to successfully represent Australia overseas.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Webster.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Webster Mr A.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I stated when I introduced the Abortion Funding Abolition Bill 12 months ago, one of the responsibilities of this Parliament-in fact its first responsibility-is the protection of the life and rights of the citizens of Australia. It is usually accepted on both sides that there is a particular obligation upon us to safeguard the life and rights of those in our community who are too weak to protect themselves.

SPEECH.PARA: For many years now, for both ethical and political reasons, members of the House of Representatives and senators have been asked to make their own judgment as to what rights are held by unborn individuals-that is, individuals in the antenatal stage of their human development. We have been obliged to assess what rights exist and to what extent we will protect and affirm those rights.

I believe it is time that we made our position on the questions of the rights of the unborn, abortion and our responsibilities clear to ourselves and to the electorate. I believe-and here I echo the Senate Select Committee on Human Embryo Experimentation-that from conception what we call an embryo and then a foetus is a new human life with a status and set of rights which command respect. I believe that scientific and metaphysical logic suggests that an individual human's antenatal and postnatal development constitutes a single process of becoming what she or he already is-a human being. We are consequently obliged, I believe, to protect the basic right of unborn human beings to life. I therefore submit this Bill for the consideration of the Parliament.

The Commonwealth's main involvement with abortion is through Medicare subsidisation of abortion procedures. The Bill therefore addresses Medicare subsidisation of abortion and seeks to allow Medicare funding only for abortions performed to avert the death of a mother or in cases where the procedure is for a different purpose and where the doctor was unaware an abortion would occur. The Bill also requires the doctor to certify that the reason for an abortion was, in his opinion, to avert the death of the mother.

Honourable members may not be aware that approximately 85,000 abortions are performed in Australia annually; that is, for every three live births, there is one aborted life. Since 1975, approximately 800,000 abortions have been subsidised by Medicare with the current subsidy to the abortion industry running at over $8m per annum. That is the background to this Bill.

I have written to all members asking for their consideration of the Bill and the basic issues that it addresses. I respectfully suggest that we do not have the right as members of parliament to ignore this issue or to refuse to make our own position on the matter clear to the electorate. I challenge the House and the Government to allow this Bill time for full debate and resolution.

There are a number of detailed arguments about the Bill and a number of misgivings and misperceptions which are widespread about this issue. I intend to deal with these issues in the Bill's second reading speech and subsequent debate. In the meantime, given time restrictions, I commend the Bill to the House, table an explanatory memorandum and challenge honourable members to come to grips with this important ethical and urgent political issue.
Bill read a first time.

TALK.START.PARA: —In accordance with sessional order 104A, the second reading will be made an order of the day for the next sitting Thursday.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Peacock.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Peacock The Hon A.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —In February 1987 the Committee for the Review of Commonwealth Criminal Law, chaired by a former Chief Justice of the High Court of Australia, Sir Harry Gibbs, was established. The Committee has produced four interim reports which seek to consolidate and rationalise the criminal laws of the Commonwealth. The work of the Committee has been outstanding. All too often this Government has been too slow to respond to law reform proposals, much to the detriment of Australian society. The reports of the Committee are good reports, and I urge the Government, with all the resources at its disposal, to respond promptly to the Committee's recommendations.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill I have introduced seeks to implement the recommendations made by the Committee in its most recent report of November 1990. In its report, the Committee has produced draft legislation. This Bill picks up those parts of the draft legislation which deal with offences relating to the administration of justice and bribery and corruption. I have selected and concentrated on those parts for a very good reason. If Australians are to have faith in our system of government, they must know that our law makers and administrators are subject to the full rigour of the law should they engage in corrupt conduct.

The Bill, amongst other things, modernises the criminal laws of the Commonwealth relating to the bribery and corruption of judicial officers, parliamentarians and public servants. Time does not permit me to go into these changes in any detail, and for those interested in the background to the Bill, I refer them to the Committee's report.

Organised crime only flourishes when it can corrupt public officials. In the short time that I have had the responsibility of being shadow Attorney-General, I have heard many allegations of links between organised crime and the corruption of public officials. Furthermore, and this causes me the greatest concern, I have seen this Government turn a blind eye to such allegations. Two notable examples include the Government's refusal to ensure that allegations by a journalist that a Cabinet Minister is somehow involved in a grubby murder have been promptly investigated, and its refusal to establish a joint Federal-New South Wales royal commission to investigate the circumstances surrounding the murder of Colin Winchester.

So updating the law relating to bribery and corruption is only part of what is needed. We also need a government which has the will and the determination to tackle effectively, at the administrative level, the problems of institutionalised corruption. This Government simply does not have the resolve to do that.

Over the next year I will be examining a number of measures designed to combat official corruption. These include what is referred to as whistle blowing legislation to protect public officials who report colleagues suspected of corruption. I will also be looking at the desirability of reforming the present law and practice dealing with the disclosure of pecuniary and other interests of public officials which affect their ability to perform their duties of office impartially.

The report of the New South Wales Independent Committee Against Corruption exposed a mysterious network of financiers, developers, Australian Labor Party figures and Federal public servants operating with respect to land developments. Indeed, one former senior adviser to a Federal Minister, riddled with conflicts of interest, formed the subject of a secret, separate report for his abuse of office.

Once again we have to ask: what has the Government done about these allegations? Have they conveniently been swept under the carpet because of the connections this former ministerial adviser has with senior Australian Labor Party figures?

Australians are entitled to expect public officials to perform the duties of office according to the highest standards of integrity and probity. If they fail to meet those standards, the law should, without fear or favour, expose and punish them for what they are: criminals who undermine the very essence of open and responsible government. I commend the Bill to the House.
Bill read a first time.

TALK.START.PARA: —In accordance with sessional order 104A, the second reading will be made an order of the day for the next sitting Thursday.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Charles.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Charles Mr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The objects of this Bill are to ensure that employers are free to belong to, or not to belong to, representative bodies of employers; to ensure that employees are free to belong to, or not to belong to, representative bodies of employees; to ensure that independent contractors are free to belong to, or not to belong to, representative bodies of employers, or representative bodies of employees; and to make provision incidental to the operation of the Industrial Relations Act.

SPEECH.PARA: In democratic societies we have long held sacrosanct the rights and responsibilities of the individual. Foremost of the rights that we hold dear are the right of free speech and the right of freedom of association. I have dealt in part with the first of these-the right of free speech-in a minor way in an earlier Bill which seeks to amend the Industrial Relations Act to remove a provision which in my view is a violation of our right of free speech, including freedom of the press.

This Bill addresses a major inequity which has existed in practice if not in law since Federation. That inequity is the right of individuals to make a choice of whether or not to join a union or representative organisation. States and Federal law and the courts have always upheld the rights of employers to form organisations and the rights of employees to form and join unions. For a long time both State and Federal governments have countenanced the concept of the closed shop in industrial relations. The closed shop requires all employees of an industry or an organisation to belong to a trade union.

In some instances employers are required to belong to an employer organisation in order to participate in practical, day to day business activities. Such provisions deny individual employees and individual employers their basic right of association, which is not to belong to such an organisation if they so choose. I remind honourable members that public opinion poll after public opinion poll in this last decade has indicated overwhelmingly that membership of unions and membership of employer organisations should be voluntary.

Compulsory union membership is objectionable. But trade unions themselves and the right of individual workers to form and join unions are clearly supported by the majority. If for no other reason trade unions have an historical right to exist. In times past unions have won many victories against oppression by unprincipled employers and have helped raise standards of living for many if not all of their members. But this is 1990, not 1890, and it is now past time that we ensured the removal of reverse oppression that describes the closed shop.

It is largely the high degree of unionism in the public sector of our country which props up the whole system. A research poll by the Roy Morgan Research Centre published on 8 November 1989 indicated that 87 per cent of the general population believes that union membership should be voluntary and that 82 per cent of union members held the same view.

This Bill in its several parts is designed to ensure that membership or non-membership of an organisation is not to affect employment; that is, it gives full effect to the concept of voluntary union membership and voluntary membership of associations.

I wish to thank the honourable member for Higgins (Mr Costello), on whose earlier work this Bill is to a large extent based, and Mr Ian Harris, First Clerk Assistant, for his substantial and invaluable drafting assistance.
I commend the Bill to the House.
Bill read a first time.

TALK.START.PARA: —In accordance with sessional order 104A, the second reading will be made an order of the day for the next sitting Thursday.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Langmore Mr J.V.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House expresses grave concern at the rate of global population growth because of its economic, social and environmental implications and therefore (a) supports the moderate growth in the funds allocated for population programs within the 1990 Australian aid budget and (b) calls for such funding to be further substantially increased.

Rapid population growth inhibits the development of human potential through restrictions to education, health and productive labour. It also threatens the destruction of our fragile ecosystem through resource depletion, environmental degradation, and disruption of global climate.

The world's population passed 5 billion in 1987. In the year 2000 the world's population will be more than 6 billion, increasing by 90 million to 100 million each year. About 95 per cent of future demographic growth will take place in developing countries. Even if women worldwide were to have only two children each year by the year 2025, world population would not stabilise until it was about 10 billion-twice the current population. Any delay in fertility reduction will mean an even greater increase in ultimate population size.

The number of school age children is projected to rise from 940 million in 1980 to 1,280 million by the year 2000. Despite dramatic increases in school enrolment, the actual number of illiterates in the world continues to increase because population growth outstrips the current capacity to provide education. Under current labour force growth projections in developing countries, around 1.6 billion new jobs-that is, billion new jobs-will have to be created between 1980 and 2025, with nearly one billion, that is 1,000 million, of them in Asia.

Population increase is often higher than agricultural growth. Food production per capita has declined in 70 developing countries, and techniques of increasing yields are often dependent on oil resources and/or have negative long term environmental implications. Much of the projected population increase will take place in environmentally fragile regions of the developing world. Population pressures contribute to deforestation, desertification, and scarcity of clean water supply.

The burden of high fertility is felt especially by the women of the developing world, whose health, education, productivity and autonomy would be enhanced by providing them with the ability to choose the number and timing of their children. Currently couples in many parts of the world bear more children than they want or can afford because they lack access to efficient methods of contraception appropriate to their needs, or lack the knowledge, confidence or personal freedom needed to control their fertility.

The world fertility survey indicated a large unmet demand for family planning. The United Nations Fund for Population Activities (UNFPA) has estimated that in Asia over 43 per cent of women not using family planning would in fact like to postpone, delay or limit their childbearing.

World fertility survey results indicate that, among married women who say they want no more children, fully one-half are not currently using any contraception. A recent analysis of world fertility survey data examining women who stated their last birth was unwanted found that, if they had had the means to prevent birth, the rate of natural increase in the countries represented would have been reduced on average from 2.2 per cent a year to 1.3 per cent.

Surveys have identified lack of information and fear of side effects, also related to poor understanding of methods, as key reasons for non-use of contraception. Programs designed to provide a wide range of contraceptive choices and to empower people to make personal family planning choices achieve significant effects on both a macro and a micro level.

The proportion of couples using contraception has increased rapidly in the past decade. Over half of the world's couples of reproductive age are now using contraception. Numerous studies have shown that the provision of family planning services can reduce fertility levels, even in the absence of other socioeconomic changes. Without the population policy and family planning services to date, it is estimated that China's population would now be 110 million larger and India's 80 million larger than has actually occurred.

Effective fertility control provides the extra bonus of reducing infant, childhood and maternal mortality. Infants born at short intervals after the previous birth have higher mortality rates than those born after longer spacing. Effective birth spacing depends on prolonged breast feeding and the use of appropriate contraception.

Both infant and maternal mortality rates are higher when childbirth takes place when the mother is aged under 20 or over 35.
