Family planning to postpone the first birth and to eliminate late child bearing would reduce both child loss and maternal illness and death. Both infant and maternal mortality are greater with higher order births, for example, fourth, fifth, sixth and later births. Reducing average family size is an effective way of reducing infant and maternal mortality.

Various forms of development assistance are crucial to population programs, particularly in poor nations facing debt burdens and shortages of trained personnel and equipment. Despite a significant increase in the commitment of Third World governments to population and family planning programs, in most countries these programs receive less than half of one per cent of national budgets. Many developing countries are cutting back budgets for social services, including health and family planning, because of the current economic crisis.

According to the World Bank, foreign aid now supports about 25 per cent of all family planning costs in developing countries. Official development assistance in population and family planning currently constitutes between one per cent and 2 per cent of total overseas development assistance by all donor countries.

The UNFPA estimates that international donors contribute a total of half a billion dollars annually to those programs. About two-thirds of such assistance goes directly to family planning and related maternal child health programs. Donors also contribute to data collection, operations research, policy and institutional development, and information and education activities-providing training and technical assistance in support of family planning and health programs. About $150m is spent annually on basic research on reproductive biology and contraceptive technology.

The two largest organisations in population assistance are the United Nations Fund for Population Activities and the International Planned Parenthood Federation-the IPPF. The UNFPA assists about 100 developing countries. It receives requests for assistance that far exceed the budget available. The IPPF is a non-governmental body with over 100 national family planning associations as members. The World Bank has given a high priority to population assistance, with large programs in Bangladesh, Egypt, India, Indonesia, the Philippines and Thailand.

Among bilateral donors, the United States and Japan have the largest programs. Despite the dominance of the US program, its contribution has been falling in real terms since the early 1970s. In terms of dollars disbursed as a percentage of gross national product, the most committed donors by far are Norway, Sweden and the Netherlands. A recent report of donor assistance for population by 13 countries put the US at the top with nearly $200m. The two smallest contributors were Finland and Australia. Non-government organisations (NGOs) play an active role in population programs. About one-quarter of US population aid is administered through non-government organisations.

Australia currently provides a relatively low level of support to population and family planning programs. Assistance provided in the population field by the Australian International Development Assistance Bureau (AIDAB) totalled about $4.5m in 1989-90 and is expected to be about $6m during this financial year. I congratulate the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans) for his commitment to this area in arranging that increase. That total, by the way, includes contributions through multilateral, bilateral, NGO and other channels.

The inclusion of $1.4m through a development import finance facility application for ultrasound equipment for China's state family planning program this year is the principal reason for the increase in funding for this year. But that total represents only about half of one per cent of our total development assistance-considerably lower than the one per cent to 2 per cent average proportion reported for other national donors. By significantly increasing assistance to international family planning efforts, Australia would both enhance the effectiveness of its development assistance through reducing population growth rates and help to improve the welfare of millions of families.

The World Bank has estimated that, to achieve the levels of contraceptive use necessary for further improvements in maternal health as well as for continued rapid declines in population growth, total family planning expenditure in the developing world would have to reach at least $8 billion annually, through both domestic and external contributions. Assuming donors maintain a constant proportion of contributions at the current level, an $8 billion family planning budget would require population assistance globally to quadruple-that is, to be multiplied four times-to a level of $2 billion annually.

Australia should increase the proportion of its development assistance budget devoted to programs of assistance in population and family planning, and I suggest that an increase to 2 per cent, or to around $20m, in line with other major donors, could be achieved initially mainly through multilateral or multilateral-bilateral channels, with a gradual build-up of assistance through bilateral, regional and non-governmental organisational channels over time.

Such a large increase in commitment to population and family planning contribution offers great challenges and opportunities to AIDAB and the community. AIDAB will need to allocate sufficient staff to assist in the development of a cohesive program of long term support which is integrated with country, regional and NGO programs as well as current health, women in development and environment strategies. The large network of Australian trained demographers, medical trainers, policy makers and social scientists in Asia and the Pacific promises great opportunities for effective collaborative work.

The time to act is now. The encouraging fertility declines in Asia in the early 1980s have stalled due to shortages of funds and declining commitment to family planning. Large cohorts entering child bearing years in Asia and the Pacific lack effective access to contraceptives. Australia has the opportunity to take a regional, and even global, leadership role in population assistance, which will help to improve the health and welfare of individuals and reinforce progress towards wider economic development and environmental protection goals.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the motion seconded?
—I second the motion and reserve my right to speak.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Filing Mr P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The issue that we are addressing today is one of grave importance to the people of Australia and indeed to the people of the world. I believe it is imperative that we should endeavour to understand the issue of world population growth as a sociological phenomenon that spans many different cultures of the world. The mistake that is being made is the terms of reference that we as legislators of the developed world adopt. Policy makers have made a number of inferences about the increase in the world's population that warrant further investigation. Those conclusions have considerable policy implications for the human rights of a considerable section of the world's population.

SPEECH.PARA: Foreign aid finance from Australia for 1990 to 1991 has been directed away from agricultural research and volunteer programs towards population control groups. In the 1990-91 aid budget, the United Nations Fund for Population Activities (UNFPA) received from the Australian Government an extra 44.2 per cent in funding, while the International Planned Parenthood Federation (IPPF) received an additional 92 per cent in funding.
On 11 October, the honourable member for Fraser (Mr Langmore) gave notice of his motion:

That this House expresses grave concern at the rate of global population growth because of its economic, social and environmental implications and therefore: (a) supports the moderate growth in the funds allocated for population programs within the 1990 Australian aid budget; and (b) calls for such funding to be further substantially increased.

With reference to the honourable member's motion, we must ask ourselves to assess the validity of some of the assumptions being made. We must address the methods and conclusions that advocates of population control have put forward, and ask ourselves the following fundamental questions: is population growth undesirable and inherently bad? Is population growth the root cause of environmental decay, economic decline and social disintegration? Is the money that is being spent on population control programs actually having an effect on population growth? By slowing down the population growth rate will economic, social and environmental progress be made? By enforcing the aims of lower population on Third World countries, are we truly acting in the interests of their people and, indeed, for that matter, the interests of all societies of the world?

There are a number of disturbing counter arguments against aspects of population control, and these are as follows: Population control can be exercised as an oppressive tool by authoritarian governments who are not acting in the best interests of their own citizens. Population control has enabled governments to detract attention away from the failures of their economic, social and environmental policies. Population control facilitates the lack of attention given to corruption that is so much a part of the world's economic, social and environmental problems. Population control is a violation of human rights. Governments are given the power and international support to enforce rules on the people pertaining to the size of their families. In at least one instance, it has been used as a prerequisite for political candidature in a local election. Population control is the enforcement of Western values on people who do not share these values.

Enormous pressure has been applied to African governments to adopt policies of population control as a solution to hunger and poverty in their countries. However, it is claimed by the Food and Agriculture Organisation (FAO) that even Zaire could feed the whole of Africa if enough attention was paid to agriculture reform. Many arguments advanced in support of population control are racialist and sexist in their sentiment and they mitigate against the human rights of the poor and poorly educated in Third World countries.

Population control is not the cause of environmental decay. Within a world of unequal resources, of corrupt and exploitative Third World governments, and of an increasing demand on developing countries to satisfy the desires of Western people, it has been the procedure to blame environmental problems on the fertility of poor women in lesser developed countries, who, with their families, are minimal per capita users of the world's resources.

One good example against the environmental proposition is the area formerly known as East Germany, where the birth rate has dwindled over recent years, but enormous environmental damage has been wreaked on its landscape by the former corrupt totalitarian regime.

One country that supports a birth control program that facilitated the achievement of a low birth rate in the 1970s is the People's Republic of China. The People's Republic of China is used by advocates of population control as an example for other developing countries to follow.

The President of the Population Institute, an organisation with close ties to the People's Republic of China's State Family Planning Commission, has repeatedly defended China's program during visits to that country. In November of 1984 he was reported to have said that China has shown the world what can be done when people conscientiously tackle the problem, adding that he had not detected any coercion during his tour.

The Chinese population control program has also received the praise of the head of the United Nations Fund for Population Activities, whose charter explicitly condemns the use of coercion. However, evidence supports a frightening violation of human rights in the People's Republic of China. In that country a woman is strongly encouraged to conceive only after the age of 24 and is penalised if she has a child at a younger age. A couple is allowed to have only one child and a wife who is unwilling to abort a child may be compelled by the State to do so if her husband agrees.

It has been alleged that between one and two million unborn children are removed prematurely from the womb and put to death annually. There have even been suggestions of scientific experimentation on these babies.
A Dutch governmental adviser on population issues, Edit Sizoo, states:

It has always been assumed population growth blocks development, and birth control was seen as a means to solve many problems from education to food shortages, but this has turned out to be a myth. At its best, population control may have some positive effects, but it doesn't address the many development problems people have.

Biologist Paula Bradish of West Germany, who has lectured for years on nutrition problems and reproductive technology, has pointed out that the expenditure of $US3 billion on population programs in the 1980s compared with $US2m in the 1960s has yielded meagre results.

Farida Akhter, who works with Ubinig, a research institute on development alternatives in Bangladesh, points to a sinister by-product of birth control projects in that country. Birth control programs funded by the Ford Foundation in the United States and the World Bank, among others, have become an important source of income for Bangladesh's military government.

We must address the implications of donating funds to organisations which advocate population control. The Australian International Development Assistance Bureau (AIDAB) funds the following organisations which have been suggested as recipients for further funding increases. The United Nations Population Fund, an organisation which the honourable member for Fraser believes should receive more funding from Australia, is involved in the development and testing of new abortion drugs to be used in population programs.

The United States of America has refused to support UNFPA since 1985 because it `participates in the management of a program of coercive abortion and involuntary sterilisation in the People's Republic of China'. Australia's funding arrangement with the IPPF should also be analysed. This organisation is a major international lobbyist for the repeal of abortion laws and no longer receives United States overseas aid funding because it has refused to sign a declaration that it will not promote abortion in developing countries.

AIDAB has been criticised for its support for a project to send 100 ultrasound machines to the Shanghai section of the State Family Planning Commission of the People's Republic of China, despite evidence that suggests that such machines most likely will be used to ensure that Chinese women, in accordance with population control regulations, have not illegally removed their compulsory IUD, and for the detection of unauthorised pregnancies and subsequent forced abortion.

Advocates of population control claim that by procreating too often, the poor help to create and perpetuate their own poverty. Their numbers consume scarce agricultural and environmental resources at an alarming rate, keep wages low, and cost governments too much money in social services. Forcing down birth rates through population control programs is thus said to help the poor help themselves.

However, there are two distinct problems with this analysis. Firstly, it obscures the real cause of poverty in the Third World: the unequal distribution of resources and power within individual countries and between the developed and underdeveloped sections of the world. Secondly, the emphasis of population control distorts social policy and undermines the delivery of safe, voluntary family planning services. In many countries the World Bank has urged governments to make population control a higher priority than basic health care. It has also pressured them to relax prescription guidelines for contraceptives and aggressively push those considered most effective-that is, intra-uterine devices, pills, injections, and now implants. That has been done in the absence of adequate screening and treatment for side effects which can be serious and even life threatening. As a result, many women have become disillusioned with these methods and have dropped out of family planning programs altogether.

Population control is not the only policy that we can adopt to alleviate poverty and promote economic growth. Education programs and better international cooperation must be utilised to ensure that the less developed countries and, indeed, the world can benefit from the population of developed countries. Funding for developing countries should be invested in human resources. These people should be employed to increase economic activity and ensure the productivity of their countries. There is a huge amount of resources in the form of human capital which is under-utilised and which requires better management for its potential to be fully realised.

I feel that the effects of population control enforcement are felt most strongly by the poor and powerless, people who have no control over the policies that have such a dramatic effect on their lives. The women in developing countries are detrimentally affected by countries such as Australia, which financially and legitimately support the bureaucratic power to force birth control legislation on them. We must understand the effects of our ideological policies that do not take into consideration the cultural and sociological differences between life in what we term developing countries and in Western countries, which is what we are pushing the people of less developed countries to aspire to. However, I emphasise that no matter what our cultural and sociological differences are, we all share the same desire and respect for unequivocal human rights. I think, Mr Deputy Speaker, that that is the issue that is at stake here, today.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hollis Mr C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support this motion and commend my colleague the honourable member for Fraser (Mr Langmore) for initiating this very important debate. I do not want to enter into an argument with the honourable member for Moore (Mr Filing), but I would suggest that he should read up a little on this subject. I, myself, have been involved in activities on population and, as a member of the Asia Forum on Population and Development, I know many of the people in the United Nations Fund for Population Activities (UNFPA). For him to say that they are not concerned with the cultural or sociological aspects is just sheer nonsense.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Moore talks about women. There is nothing about human rights for women in developing countries who are repeatedly giving birth to child after child. That is a danger to their health. Of course there are social and environmental problems; of course they need education. Many of these countries cannot put their funds into education. Because of the increasing population every year, the money that should go towards education cannot go there. Many of the Third World countries have an international debt; they are cutting back on their social welfare programs every year because of their increasing population.

The honourable member opposite is right when he says it is not just a population problem. I agree with that. It is a whole interrelated problem, and I am not going to say that one just takes the population issue out and deals with that. Of course one cannot. One has to, as the honourable member opposite rightly said, deal with the educational, sociological and environmental problems. One should go to India or any of the Asian countries-and Asia is the fastest growing part of the world-and ask people living in those countries what their human rights are today. One should go to India. Why do Indian men always want more and more sons? If India had a proper welfare system, they would have guarantees for their old age.

The honourable member opposite talked about China. I think that China has an enviable record. We are not talking about Australia's population. I am amazed that once again in this debate, it is mostly men talking about these programs. The real impact is always on women, but it is always men who deal with these matters. However, if one goes to any of these countries and talks about the population there, one will find that we are not putting our values on the people in those countries.

In Australia, we have not got a population problem. We are one of the countries whose population increase each year is coming from immigration, not from natural increase. We have a declining birth rate here. Yet I believe that because population is not an isolated Australian problem but an international problem, we must improve our contribution to solving it. Although we have contributed and over the last couple of years increased our contribution to the International Planned Parenthood Federation and the United Nations Fund for Population Activities-we doubled it the year before last and we had another increase this year-still it is low by international standards. I believe we must lift that. There seems to me to be no doubt about that, when we start talking about these issues.

I cannot believe it when people start talking about the `human rights issues' of this matter. One does not have too many human rights if one is born into poverty and dies at the age of 30 still in poverty. There are not too many human rights attaching to people who are forced into prostitution to exist in these countries. If one observes the sex trade in Thailand or any of these places, one will be aware that that is a result of over-population. If we are going to talk about human rights, let us be assured that we know what we are talking about. When we start putting our values and start pontificating about what is wrong in these countries, let us not always put forward our own values-the values that are a luxury, a result of not having over-population. Let us not start putting these values on these people where overpopulation is a real problem.

We only have to look in our own region at Papua New Guinea. In Papua New Guinea, the birth rate is 3 per cent a year. One-third of the population of that country over the age of 15 is illiterate-and this is the International Year of Literacy. Papua New Guinea, the Solomon Islands and Vanuatu are among the fastest growing countries in the world. We know of the problems in Papua New Guinea but, unless adequate measures are taken, by the year 2015 the current population of Papua New Guinea of 3.9 million will be six million to nine million. We read in the papers every day about the problems in Papua New Guinea. We read about the `rascals'-the unemployed urban youth, often coming from the hinterland to the coastal cities. How much greater will that problem become, unless something can be done about the population situation in that country?

As I said, I am a member of the Asia Forum on Population and Development and the third general assembly of that group was recently held in Bangkok in Thailand. I attended that meeting, as indeed did the honourable member for Franklin (Mr Goodluck), and I am sorry that he is not here to contribute to this debate today. At that meeting, the link between population growth and the environment was constantly made; people are realising this.

The honourable member opposite has quoted various experts from Bangladesh and so forth. I would have liked that expert from Bangladesh to have been at that general assembly with the Bangladeshi delegation-most of whom were Ministers-the Indian delegation and the Thai delegation. We can all trot out from our favourite bit of research facts, figures and statements to support our particular case. We can all do that, whatever the case is. It is not hard to dig out a quote to support an argument. But when one listens to the leading experts and politicians from other countries, one realises that these people are asking Australia and the United Nations to do more in those countries to help them in their population program.

If these people are going to advance at all to a decent standard of living, they cannot do it while their population is increasing every year at such massive rates. Malthus was talking about this 150 years ago. Surely, we have learned something. We have seen the population of the world increasing, doubling every 15 or 20 years. It is not a small increase that we are talking about; it is a massive increase.

The greenhouse effect can be seen even in places like Kiribati which, although it does not have a huge population, is densely populated. Something will have to be done in areas such as that. In Australia young people move from country towns to the cities. If one lives in Kiribati, the Cook Islands or somewhere like that all the young people leave to go to New Zealand or Australia. This is because there is not enough work there. It is wholly caused by overpopulation.

I agreed with the honourable member for Moore when he said that we cannot isolate population and that by controlling it that will be it. It is the major cause of all the other problems that he mentioned. I worry about the whole situation of human rights. In some countries I believe that there has been, if not coercion, a form of inducement to comply. When we are dealing with such huge populations sometimes there is no other answer. Japan is a good example of a country that has achieved population control. In countries where women enjoy a standard of education and literacy there is no need for these inducements for fertility control. This has been seen in Japan and, to a lesser extent, Korea.

I was talking only last week to the Assistant Director-General of the United Nations Fund for Population who was out here. It is a pity that many more members of parliament did not go to hear him talk. Two of us were there; this shows the interest in this place about this issue. He is a Japanese national. He made the point about how Japan had been successful. I raised with him the question of coercion. I suggest that the honourable member for Moore join the Australian branch of the Asia Forum for Population and Development. Maybe when we resume in this debate in the not too distant future his speech may be a little different from the speech he made in this chamber today.

I congratulate the honourable member for Fraser and have great pleasure in supporting this very important motion that he has put forward. I think it is about time politicians in this place talked more about this international problem of population and development.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bradford Mr J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have been looking forward to participating in this debate on global population growth. The honourable member for Fraser (Mr Langmore) enthusiastically moved his motion and then left the House. If he was entirely serious about participating in the debate he might have remained to see what we had to say about his motion. I would have thought that this motion was extremely superficial. On the face of it, it may be rather appealing to talk about this problem in this way. When one looks beyond what is actually proposed I believe it has absolutely horrific ramifications.

SPEECH.PARA: It is ironic, when we look at the Notice Paper for today, that we find Notice No. 1 deals with the Abortion Funding Abolition Bill which has been moved by the honourable member for Macquarie (Mr Webster). I would ultimately hope that that Bill will have the support of this House. What a contrast! In this place earlier we were talking about a Bill to prevent the funding of abortion within Australia; we are now talking about a scheme that ultimately will allow the spread of abortion in other countries.

We are talking about population control at its most base. As the honourable member for Moore (Mr Filing) has said, we are talking about a violation of fundamental human rights. I find it astonishing that a nation such as Australia can not only continue to support but also increase its support for the methods employed by some other countries in population control schemes.

Many of the countries that we are talking about helping-some have been mentioned here this morning, such as China, in particular-have a deplorable human rights record. We are talking about increasing our support for schemes that violate the right of individuals to have control over what is done to their own bodies. Let us be even-handed about this. I am sure that the honourable member for Prospect (Mrs Crosio) would be interested to see some balance here. For instance, in Indonesia we are talking about schemes which see men fleeing their villages and deserting their wives and children to avoid forced sterilisation. We are talking about schemes that force Chinese mothers to abandon their home to escape abortion or sterilisation under the strict government policy of one child per family.
Earlier I was looking at an article in the Canberra Times on 3 July dealing with what is actually happening in China under this scheme which we are supporting. It states:
Chinese mothers are fleeing their homes to escape abortion or sterilisation under the strict government policy of one child per family, the People's Daily said today.
Government officials have previously denied allegations that the population-control policy includes compulsory abortion and sterilisation.

We are talking about an inhumane government regulation that would not be tolerated for one minute in this country. Yet we will stand by here and promote it and move in this House that we should not only support it but increase our support for it.
The honourable member for Throsby (Mr Hollis) talked about Malthus. Malthus was clearly wrong; at least he acknowledges that what he said was--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The time for the debate has expired. The debate is adjourned and the resumption of the debate will be made an order of the day for the next sitting Thursday. The honourable member will have leave to continue his speech when the debate is resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bailey Mrs F.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House:
(1) calls on the Government to recognise the vital role of small business to the prosperity of the nation; and
(2) condemns the Government for its policies which have caused the failure of small businesses.

Particularly at this time of recession this Government must realise the vital role played by small business in our national economy. Small business comprises about 95 per cent of all enterprises. Small business is one of the largest single employers. There are over 750,000 small businesses, which include 150,000 small businesses in the farming sector. These small businesses operate in all sectors of the economy-in retail trades, finance, property, business, agriculture, construction and manufacturing industries.

Small business often acts as the specialist supplier of parts and components to larger companies because it can produce these parts more effectively than the larger firms. Small business provides competition by offering a wide range of goods and services and highly specialised skills. Small business is such an important source of innovation in products, techniques and design. Most importantly, it provides the means of entry into business for new entrepreneurial talent.

One would think, especially in these tough times, that this Government would recognise the vital role played by small business. One would imagine that a government facing a gross foreign debt of $156,275m and growing, a severe downturn in our rural economy, with the predicted fall of net farm cash income of 32 per cent, still high inflation compared with our major trading partners in the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development, poor productivity, low savings and inefficient work practices would recognise the value of this large source of employment and the productive sector of our economy and that it would ensure that it was providing a stable, healthy economic structure in which to operate-that is, lessen excessive reliance on monetary policy, ensure that fiscal and income policies accept a greater share of the burden of restraint and actually achieve micro-economic reform instead of simply talking about that reform.

Never has it been more necessary for this Government to introduce micro-economic reform than right now. We on the Opposition benches will support the Government, if only it will show the resolve to initiate change. We are currently in recession-the one I remind this House that the Treasurer (Mr Keating) stated we had to have-a recession induced by this Government's economic policy.

TALK.START.PARA: —Shame!

—Yes. This policy has been responsible for unprecedented increases in small business and personal bankruptcies-a massive 32.7 per cent increase for the September quarter. In the Government's response to the report of the House standing committee examining the role of small business, entitled Small Business in Australia: Challenges, Problems and Opportunities, the Minister for Small Business and Customs (Mr Beddall) stated:

SPEECH.PARA: A dynamic small business sector provides the engine for innovation, employment generation and growth in our economy.

If the Minister and his Government genuinely believe this, then why have they not addressed the principal findings and recommendations of this committee? Those findings identified a range of problems, from duplication of regulation, compliance, taxation, incorporation to industrial relations, as areas of major concern. At page 3 of the Government's response to that report, it says that it `seeks to set in place a results oriented package of measures to assist the small business sector'.

I commend the Government for being prepared to make some decisions in regard to reviewing regulations, a strategy to reduce paper work and minimise costs, having greater consultation with small business organisations and to taking into account the impact new regulations will have on small business. But there are in fact 66 very worthwhile recommendations awaiting action. However, small businesses are struggling to survive today because this Government has failed to tackle the issues that are of most concern to small business: taxation reform and industrial relations reform.

It is the lack of taxation reform and industrial relations reform that prevents small business from functioning as efficiently as it might and impedes its growth potential in earning and employment capacity. It was the complexity of taxation issues-income tax, company tax, provisional tax, sales tax, capital gains tax, fringe benefits tax, superannuation and trading stock valuation-that most concerned those numerous small business representatives who made submissions on problems facing small business. But all this Government has been prepared to do is make administrative changes. Pay as you earn tax collections and some sales tax collections can now be made on a quarterly basis rather than a monthly basis.

There is still no decision to assist developing, innovative small businesses in regard to roll-over of capital gains tax. There is no incentive whatsoever for a small business that begins as a concept, develops into a thriving industry, provides employment, continues to invest and expand, pays income tax at hefty rates throughout this period and then pays capital gains tax on the sale of that business.

Chapter 5 of the Government's response to the small business inquiry, headed `Taxation Reform', is indeed an illuminating chapter because it focuses on this Government's real position-its lack of commitment to small business. The Government's response to the problems small business faces with roll-over capital gains tax is:
The Treasurer and the Minister for Small Business and Customs will continue discussions on this issue.

That is the Government's response to the problems of the holding costs of stock, income averaging, company and provisional tax, employee share acquisition schemes, superannuation and business establishment costs. There is certainly plenty of rhetoric contained in the pages of the Government's response, but that is about all there is.

The Minister is continuing to discuss the 21 recommendations made by the committee dealing with taxation matters affecting small business. If this Government was sincere in its stated commitment to simplify the tax system, from both an administrative and equitable viewpoint, it would start to tackle these problems now. Instead, it is procrastinating with further discussions, more reports, more administration, more bureaucracy.

TALK.START.PARA: —They have done nothing.
—Exactly: this government has done nothing. The small business sector needs urgent action that will increase productivity and competition and provide incentive.

SPEECH.PARA: As well as taxation reform, small business urgently needs reform of our industrial relations system. I recently visited a shoe factory in Russia that was a joint venture between the then West German Government and the Soviet Union. I could hardly believe what I was hearing when the manager of the factory announced that the workers were paid bonuses. I asked what criteria were used to determine who was paid a bonus. The answer was those who increased production and maintained quality and safety in the workplace. Here was a shoe factory in Russia embracing the market economy and moving away from centralised control of workers. What a contrast to the centralised, fixed labour market decisions and of the deals done between the Government and the Australian Council of Trade Unions in this country.

It is such a paradox here that at a time when membership of trade unions is diminishing-in fact only 32 per cent of those working in the private sector belong to a union-employers are locked into accepting award payments, work practices, conditions, hours of work, et cetera, having had little or no consultation in the highly centralised process of industrial relations. Yet there is an alternative to this approach, and that is employer and employee reaching a voluntary agreement on the terms and conditions affecting their particular enterprise. Such a voluntary agreement was made at Power Brewing in Queensland. This agreement resulted in an 85 per cent increase in productivity with the workers earning $8,000 to $10,000 per annum more than their counterparts working elsewhere and the company gaining 20 per cent of the Queensland beer market.

The underlying principle of these enterprise agreements is that there must be a close relationship between what workers are paid and what they produce. Enterprise agreements would allow better use of capital assets. In many countries overseas, industries are able to utilise their plant fully; they are not restricted to a four-day week.

If the Government would actually reform our transport system, instead of holding discussions about reform, small business would benefit from not having to hold large reserves of stock. It would be able to use the more efficient and less costly system of just-in-time inventory management. That is just one example of how small business would benefit from micro-economic reform.

It is not only the lack of resolve of the Government to initiate the 66 recommendations of the Beddall report, and in particular those 21 recommendations relating to taxation issues, but also the failure of this Government to change the economic policies that have caused this country to sink into recession. It is this lack of direction that has caused the demise of both urban and rural small businesses.

The bankruptcy figures for small business are increasing and there is a flow-on effect from contracting big business-subcontractors, for example. Unemployment figures are increasing. One of the unfair aspects of this recession is that the public sector is protected at the expense of the private sector. We are witnessing the collapse of thousands of small businesses, and that, in both economic and human terms, is a tragedy.

But an additional problem is developing for small business, and that is the decline in business investment that is required to ensure the future viability of the private sector. We are witnessing, as I said, the collapse of many small businesses, largely because the monetary policy of this Government has produced high interest rates and an inflation rate well above those of our trading partners that has in turn produced a reduced cash flow and low levels of profitability for small business. Interest and tax payments in the current economic climate barely allow small business to remain solvent. What incentive is there for reinvestment?

The policies of this Government are causing the failure of small business. In economic terms, we have lost valuable productive units; in human terms, we have lost the skill and expertise of thousands. How many small businesses have to add to the growing statistics before this Government will, firstly, change the direction of its macro-economic policy and, secondly, introduce real micro-economic reform and initiate the recommendations of its own parliamentary committee, the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology, in its inquiry into small business? That is necessary not only to ensure the survival of small business but to provide the economic framework in which it can grow. How else are we as a nation to trade our way out of debt and build for the future?

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the motion seconded?
— I second the motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crosio The Hon J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am rather appreciative that the honourable member for McEwen (Mrs Bailey) has moved this motion because it not only gives an opportunity for Government members to bring information forward as a history lesson for the honourable member for McEwen but also allows me to say that not only does this Government recognise the vital role that small business has had in the development of this nation, but also, since coming to office in 1983, this Government has worked towards creating an environment conducive to small business growth in Australia by implementing policies which recognise the important and major role small business plays in our Australian economy. Even Opposition members would recognise that if we are to have such debates, honest information must be represented before the House. I will, for the information of honourable members opposite, supply them with some history.

SPEECH.PARA: Since 1983 we have had the deregulation of the financial system, which has resulted in small business having greater access to finance as opposed to the pre-deregulation period when funds were not readily available to many, especially to the middle income earner. The Labor Government floated the Australian dollar and removed the exchange controls. Small businesses were given greater opportunities to expand into overseas markets through enhanced price competitiveness. In 1985 this Labor Government began a series of cuts to the personal tax rate, reducing it from 60 per cent to 47 per cent, and reducing the company rate from 49 per cent to 39 per cent. This Hawke Labor Government brought that action in, and it resulted in an increase in internal funds available to small business to finance growth. In 1983 this Labor Government recognised that real unit labour costs had fallen by 10.6 per cent, enabling the gross profit share to increase from an average of 27.3 per cent in the years 1973 to 1983 to 34.4 per cent from 1984 to 1990.

It was Labor which established direct consultative links between small business and the government and implemented a range of support programs. In 1984 we established the Small Business Council, whose functions included providing a forum for consultation for small business, identifying major development problems for small business, advising the Minister for Small Business and Customs on policies to minimise impediments to the establishment and development of small business enterprises and, particularly, advising the Minister on matters referred by him to the Council.

Later I will mention Labor's fourth term and the report of the Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology inquiry into small business-the Beddall report-which has been mentioned in the debate, but in its first term in office Labor developed schemes to help small business industry. They included the new enterprise incentive, the scheme aimed at encouraging the formation of new small enterprises through joint assistance from Federal and State governments. It was never heard of until the Hawke Labor Government came to office in 1983.

The export market development grants scheme was devised to assist Australian firms in seeking out and developing new export markets and sales. The scheme was again amended in 1985 to improve its cost effectiveness and to target it more closely at small and medium sized exporters. The scheme is again being updated and amended. In fact, proposals are before the Senate now to bring it more up to date with current changes. We are not stopping still; we are continually moving.

It was under the Labor Government in 1987 that the National Industry Extension Service was established. This service is based on bilateral agreements between the States and the Commonwealth. It coordinates, rationalises and works on improving Commonwealth and State extension services to small and medium sized businesses with potential for growth in internationally traded goods.

In 1988 we saw the launching of the national small business information and awareness program (NIAP), aimed at establishing small business extension services and increasing the use of small business advisory programs. The program involves both the Commonwealth and State governments, as well as five private sector organisations-the Australian Bankers Association, the Institute of Chartered Accountants in Australia, the Australian Society of Accountants, Business In The Community Pty Ltd, and the Law Council of Australia. NIAP was developed by the National Industry Extension Service and has been particularly successful in Victoria, where a number of pilot projects have been running and will be running during 1990 and 1991-and thank goodness they are reaching success in that State at the moment.

The ANZ, Commonwealth, State and Westpac banks are all involved in the NIAP pilot projects, which are aimed at improving local networks between banks, lawyers, accountants and other business support and information providers to help to advise small business.

The new enterprise incentive scheme was also introduced by the Labor Government in 1985-86. The honourable member for McEwen, having been in small business, surely would recognise that. That is still successfully operating, even today. That scheme aims to assist unemployed people receiving social security benefits in establishing self-employment ventures through the provision of a comprehensive package of assistance. That scheme operates as a partnership between the Commonwealth, State or Territory governments.

For the first time, as has been acknowledged by the honourable member for McEwen, an inquiry was undertaken by a Federal parliamentary committee whose report, Small Business in Australia: Challenges, Problems and Opportunities, also known as the Beddall report, was referred to in glowing terms by the editor of the Australian Small Business Review, Peter Thorpe. That reference was made not last year, not last month, but in November, in the current issue that the honourable member surely must have read. For her information and for the information of other Opposition members, I will quote from that article. Mr Thorpe said the Beddall report:

. . . is the most comprehensive study of small business ever undertaken in this country. It has covered everything from the regulations small business operates under, through taxation, superannuation, training, marketing, access to information and advice and industrial relations. It also examined the impact of Government policies on small business, compared to larger businesses.

Mr Thorpe then praised the Hawke Labor Government's initiative in appointing the Chairman of the Standing Committee, our colleague on this side of the House, the honourable member for Rankin (Mr Beddall), to the position of Minister for Small Business and Customs. Mr Thorpe went on to say:

This is the first time the head of a parliamentary committee has been given the job of Minister, to carry out recommendations he was responsible for making . . . The move was largely welcomed by the small business community around Australia . . .

They are his words, not mine. They were printed in the November issue of Australian Small Business Review. There is a general feeling that at last we have someone in a position of influence who not only understands the major problems of small business but has been a small business man himself.

The Beddall report has made a number of recommendations, but the Government has put in initiatives designed to assist and stimulate small business activity in Australia, and we have certainly started to put those into practice.

Let us look at what followed the 1990-91 Budget initiative. One reform is that the wholesale sales tax law will be amended from 1 August 1991 to allow businesses whose wholesale sales tax liability is $50,000 or less to pay that tax quarterly instead of monthly. It was not mentioned by the honourable member for McEwen that this will benefit 80 per cent of sales tax payers. Another tax reform announced in the Budget which is aimed at reducing the burden of compliance for small businesses is the increase in the threshold for exemption from quarterly payments for fringe benefits tax payers. Again, it was not mentioned by the honourable member for McEwen that more than 70,000 small businesses will now be able to make annual payments with effect from the financial benefit taxation year commencing on 1 April 1991.

Simplifying tax law and administration to reduce compliance and reporting costs for small business is a high priority of this Hawke Labor Government. Major reviews by the Australian Taxation Office of the sales tax administrative system and compliance costs relating particularly to small business have already begun. That is not rhetoric but action. The Australian Taxation Office is also establishing small business liaison committees in branch offices, aimed at increasing consultation with small business communities. Committees have already been established in the branch offices in Adelaide and in Newcastle, which is in my State. A small business coordination group is also being established by the Australian Taxation Office to contribute to guidance and coordination of small business initiatives.

As a result of the Beddall report, our Labor Government is also taking action on rationalising government regulations and simplifying licensing procedures for small businesses; organising a coordinated response to franchising, retail tenancy and other small business concerns; and achieving greater cooperation in the delivery of management training and advice to small business proprietors.

The Hawke Labor Government recognises that, although high interest rates and the slow-down in the economy have made it very hard for small business, an easing in interest rates and an improved inflationary situation will now help small business and emphasise the importance of communication between government and small business to ensure an environment conducive to small business success and growth.

To promote better communication between the Government and the small business industry, a national small business forum was held in Melbourne last week-not last month or next year-between the Minister for Small Business and Customs, the Small Business Council and relevant business and professional organisations. The forum examined issues of common concern within the sector and was, as all acknowledged, a great success.

The first annual meeting of State and Commonwealth small business Ministers will take place this month and aims to get a commitment from the Ministers for a more coordinated approach to small business issues. This meeting will provide a vital mechanism for progressing many of the recommendations of the Beddall report. I know that my time is limited, but I believe that this is so important, there is so much to be said, that one has to have a debate that has all the facts before the Parliament, not just one person's interpretation of them. There are major reforms in the Beddall report that are not only being implemented but have been acknowledged and will be put into place. A major forum for business suppliers and government purchasers, Meet the Buyers-Canberra 1990, was held in November as a result again of a recommendation in the Beddall report.

I could go on for at least another four pages about what has already been achieved as a result of the Beddall report and the action of the Minister and the Hawke Labor Government. But in winding up, I think it will suffice to put to rest some of the furphies put forward by the honourable member for McEwen during her contribution to the debate. The information is contained in the report of the operation of the Bankruptcy Act, tabled in this Federal Parliament this week. If she failed to read that, the information was also listed in the Sydney Morning Herald today, which states that there were 5,546 non-business bankruptcies granted in 1989-90, compared with 2,947 for businesses. That is a ratio of nearly 2:1 and compares with the 57 per cent of businesses and 43 per cent of non-businesses in 1972-73. Any bankruptcy is a disaster for the country, but the facts and information provided show the full story of what is happening with small business and how this Hawke Labor Government, through the implementation of its program, is assisting small business and will continue to recognise the vital input that it makes to the community.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Broadbent Mr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a pleasure to try to bring some truth into the argument. Perhaps the previous speaker, the honourable member for Prospect (Mrs Crosio), should go back to her electorate and have a look at the problems that people are facing on a daily basis. They are not interested in the litany of quangos existing today that have arisen since 1983 under the Hawke Government; they are all still there. Small business has been routed and has nearly gone; it is on its knees. We have witnessed since 1983 new taxes and the destruction of small businesses. How times have changed. How can the honourable member for Prospect be so deceived as to present the arguments that she did?

SPEECH.PARA: I commend the honourable member for McEwen (Mrs Bailey) for her explanation of the difficulties facing small business in Australia today. Let us get to the seriousness of the argument where we talk about what is happening today. There has been a rise in bankruptcies of 30 per cent across Australia. Let us look at what is happening in my State of Victoria, where, according to the Age of 2 October, bankruptcies are rising by 70.6 per cent. Today's Australian quotes the Minister for Small Business and Customs (Mr Beddall) as saying:

In every member's electorate there are empty shops and people who no longer have jobs. Do not tell me that interest rates are not a cause of that; every member of the House would know that over the past year-after deregulation in 1983-small businesses paid above the rate, not below the rate. Someone had to pick up the charge, and who picked it up? Small business in Australia. That is who picked up the charge.

We talk about bankruptcies, but that is not the end of the story. Let us talk about all those people who decided to close down their businesses because they could not go on, they could not make the payments. Let us talk about the anguish of the owners of those businesses who had employed people for a long time and who know the names of the wife or husband and children of their employees. The blood of those businesses is on the Hawke Government. The honourable member for Prospect should not talk to me about what the Hawke Government has done to small business. TALK.START.PARA: —I have.

—I think I do know the honourable member for Prospect well enough to say that she has probably lain awake on many nights. I hope that since she was elected to this House, she is still lying awake on behalf of all those who have lost their businesses this year. This is a tragedy facing Australia. This is not just some blimp on the skyline; this is a tragedy. Anybody who has been in small business will know that it is closely aligned with the people who work for it. There is real anger out there. Small business people are saying, `Why should it be my business and my staff that have to lose their jobs or be put off because of this engineered recession that we just had to have?'. Honourable members should go to Victoria and see street after street after street of empty shops. People had viable businesses, but interest rates have broken them down day after day after day. They were meeting those commitments. The Minister says that these people cannot make any money, that these people are bad business managers. This is how much he cares. Small business people in Australia are sick of government reports, of quangos that are set up supposedly to help them.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us talk about small business. Small business in Australia is often a family business or a husband and wife working together and then employing people in that business and trying to expand it. A business cannot grow when interest rates are 25 per cent. That is what we have done to Australia-let us be fair; we have wiped people out. While the Government is prepared to pay its advisers an extra 30 per cent, the people in my electorate are losing their jobs. Yes, I lie awake at night thinking about the issue. There is a lot of disappointment out there. People are disappointed with this Government that they put in office in 1983. I am one of those people who say, `Australia, we put them in and now we are suffering the consequences of just that'. I am angry; it has probably come out in what I have said today. I am angry that a lot of businesses like mine are struggling today. People are hurting and many will have the toughest Christmas that they have had since the Second World War. That is exactly what is happening.

Retail business, especially in Australia, has been in a slump which, in my opinion, started about 18 months ago. Yet it is only now that this Government has finally realised that there is a problem out there, that the damage is so far gone that people are losing their jobs day after day. We have a problem. I plead with the Government to begin to address this problem. Now is the time to address it; we can wait no longer. We do not want dole queues. SPEECH.PARA: This is a very good report. It contains lots of information and very good propositions about what this Government should do with respect to small business policy. The honourable member for McEwen comes in today and says that that is what we should do. She is three years out of date. The other fact is that there are approximately 66 recommendations in this report and this Government is working its way through them. These propositions have been welcomed by the small business community of this country. Sixty-six propositions cannot be introduced overnight, so we are working our way through them. The small business community of this country knows that.

The second matter I would like to deal with before getting into some more substantial items is the proposition that this Government should introduce micro-economic reform. We have been introducing micro-economic reform for 7 1/2 years. When the opportunities arise to dismantle the dirigisme, the regulated economy, that these turkeys opposite constructed during three decades of rule of this country, we seize those opportunities.

Let us take some examples. When opposition members were in government, a report recommended that they deregulate the finance sector. What did they do? They did nothing. We came in and deregulated the finance sector. As soon as the opportunity arose for us to dismantle the inefficient, regulated two-airline policy, which has maintained an overhigh rate of air fares for Australians-honourable members opposite, businessmen, small business people and private travellers-we deregulated it and thus the price of air transport is coming down.

With respect to tariffs, which Government has steadily reduced the rate of tariffs in this country in order to produce cheaper imports for consumers and small business? This Government. What party is capable of introducing micro-economic reform and has a record of doing so? The Australian Labor Party. What did the Opposition do in office? It talked and regulated. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fisher Mr P.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House:
(1) recognises the importance of the citrus industry to the social and economic life of regional Australia; and
(2) calls on the Government to:
(a) remove developing country status and tariff concessions from Brazil, the world's major citrus producer;
(b) immediately introduce anti-dumping and countervailing legislation which is fast and reliable;
(c) remove sales tax from all fruit juice products;
(d) stop the abuses of labelling, packaging and quality regulations which are confusing the consumer and harming the producer; and
(e) streamline and make applicable to the operation of the Food Standards Committee, commercial practicalities and technological development.

We all recognise the advantages of a free trading system. The theory is impeccable, but in practice world trade is neither free nor fair. Every form of protection, subsidisation and market corruption is rife and generally is increasing, despite the best efforts of governments and members of the Cairns Group to bring some sense into General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade discussions.

But this House cannot simply sit back and wait for changes to occur. Australian rural industry is facing an unprecedented crisis, the economic structure of our rural industries is crumbling and rapidly affecting the social fabric that has bound together and carried them through droughts, low prices and volatile markets in the past.

This motion specifically refers to the citrus industry, but applies generally to many Australian industries the viability of which is under threat from the smorgasbord of imported food entering our markets at cheap and subsidised prices. It is not just the issue of consumer access to cheap imported food. The effect on our economy in the city as in the country on the transport and processing sector and on workers will be serious if agricultural industries are weakened or closed down.

There is more than a touch of madness in our trade and tariff policies. On the one hand, governments praise the efficiency and productive capacity of primary industry but, on the other hand, tariffs and other forms of protection of this sector have to be reduced to a level lower than 10 per cent. However, similar changes have not been made to tariffs and costs on our inputs-machinery, chemicals, fuel and water-so there is no level playing field. The open door trade policies are not just squeezing our competitiveness on overseas markets, but now on the domestic market as well. We have today become the repository for many nations' imports of cheap, subsidised, often low quality surpluses and the list grows daily. All this is at a time when Australian farmers plough their produce back into the soil or cannot afford to pick it.

Citrus fruit production in 1991 will be close to 600,000 fresh tonnes. It is a vital regional industry, and in the Murray Valley some 700 citrus growers produce crops in excess of $80m. The marketing of the crop varies from season to season, but approximately 5 per cent goes to fresh exports, 40 per cent of the crop to the fresh domestic market and some 55 per cent of the crop is processed into juice.

Australia produces but 1.26 per cent of total world citrus production, while Brazil produces 26.6 per cent. Imports of citrus juice into Australia have had a massive influence on Australian growers' viability. In the 12 months ending June 1990 imports from various countries were worth in excess of $8m. TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the House. World prices have fallen to disastrous levels. Dominated by Brazil, the world price has dropped from a high of $US2,350 per tonne in May to $US1,271 in October, and for an equivalent fresh fruit price they have gone from some $US300 per tonne to $US60 in just 12 months. These prices are clearly unsustainable and if immediate action is not forthcoming from the Government financial ruin will be the result of years of effort by many growers and their families.

SPEECH.PARA: What can be done? We must immediately remove developing country status and tariff concessions from Brazil. There is no justification for this. Not only is Brazil the largest world producer, but much of its production is a result of massive amounts of German and United States foreign investment. The United States does not grant developing country status to Brazil; neither should we. The question of labelling of products which are being sold in Australia from overseas has become an increasing problem. These subsidised food products are flooding our market and now account for 10 per cent of our current account deficit, and are causing great harm to our farmers and horticultural industries.

Dishonest labelling practices by importers are rife. Australians would prefer to buy Australian goods, but it is almost impossible to identify them. I acknowledge the excellent promotion exercise carried out in Melbourne last week by our horticultural industries and the apparent positive response from the Victorian Government, and I believe that a deputation which we have had this morning to the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs, Senator Tate, will also have a similar positive outcome.

I now wish to refer to the loophole in the law which allows imported ingredients to be processed into other products and then labelled `Produce of Australia'. For example, imported fruit juice concentrate can be imported, mixed with Australian water and labelled `Product of Australia'. Efforts are also being made to introduce a code of practice for the fruit juice industry which is aimed at eradicating adulteration and dilution of fruit juices and other unfair practices at the processing level. It is expected that this code will be in operation early next year. However, on the other hand, the introduction of food regulations aimed at simplifying the present complicated and inefficient system is making slow progress and is in fact hindering the industry's attempt at restructuring and self-help.

We all know in this House that the imposition of a sales tax on all fruit juice products will add to the burden of an already stressed industry. An exemption is therefore sought by the industry for the removal of the tax on 100 per cent fruit juice containing not less than 25 per cent by volume of Australian juice.

Finally, I turn to the most significant point in this motion, concerning the anti-dumping and countervailing legislation. I acknowledge the work of my colleague Senator Ron Boswell in successfully establishing a Senate inquiry into this issue and I refer the House to the Senate Hansard of 6 November, page 3486, for the detail. The current anti-dumping legislation is time consuming, cumbersome, prohibitively costly and biased against industries with a long production time and fluctuating cost structures. This inquiry's investigations are urgent and must be completed as quickly as possible.

This issue is not one of erecting trade or tariff barriers. Our future well-being is dependent on two-way trade, but a trade that is fair and uncorrupted by subsidisation. Growers are currently being told by the Government that their answer to the rising flood of imported foods is in anti-dumping and countervailing legislation. Again this is fine in theory, but it simply does not work out in practice. In the first instance, an industry has to suffer material damage before a case can even begin. The Australian Customs Service and the Anti-Dumping Authority can take anything up to 295 days to decide whether the case is positive, and this is far too long. Cash securities can be applied only after the case has been under way for almost five months, and well after the case has been accepted as positive.

The terms of reference of this inquiry suggest that these securities should be applied after a preliminary positive case has been determined, that is, after an initial 55-day period. If the Anti-Dumping Authority agrees with the producer that material damage has been suffered and the product has been dumped, then a duty should be imposed on the incoming goods. However, the producer now has to take that case back through the entire process every three years to have the market situation reassessed, otherwise the imposed duty automatically expires.

This also is time consuming and expensive and it can take up to $200,000 simply to re-establish a dumping duty. Many Australian primary producers and their industries simply cannot afford to do this every three years. The necessity, therefore, for these sunset clauses must be questioned in this inquiry. In many situations a case also has to be mounted against the importers of the processed product, usually a major retailer who is also the main customer of the Australian canner, and the retailer is often reluctant to take on its customers in court. By the time a case has been prepared and presented and the Australian Customs Service has made a decision on it, so much damage can be done to one of our industries that it is simply not worth the money, or the trouble, and it walks away from initiating such a case.

It is time that anti-dumping and countervailing legislation was made to work to the benefit of the Australian producer, not the importers, and to give them adequate protection. We must have a mechanism that can immediately identify dumped products and suspend distribution until such time that the exporter proves the authenticity of the quoted f.o.b. value. This, in effect, would place the onus of proof where it should lie- with the perpetrator, rather than the victim.

Many members of this House this morning attended the last great Aussie breakfast outside Parliament House. This morning we saw the diversity, the quality and the value of Australia's horticultural production. It is second to none and better than most. Most industries have been through a continuing process of restructuring, of improved irrigation and farming practice, and of market diversity. We must support their efforts to maintain their viability and their productivity and so continue to contribute to the well-being of the nation. It is a disgrace that these highly productive people are forced on to the streets to protest in order to survive.

TALK.START.PARA: — Is the motion seconded?
—I second the motion, Mr Deputy Speaker, and reserve my right to speak.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Courtice Mr B.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Last week the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs, Senator Michael Tate, announced that there would be compulsory labelling regulations introduced for not only orange juice but also apple juice, pineapple juice, and all other fruit juices and fruit juice products. The change in regulations will make it compulsory to show a declaration on the package of any juice, or juice product, to identify the country or countries of origin. Also, a declaration must be made in the case of mixes; in other words, products that have both Australian and imported juices in them. So we have now an opportunity for consumer preference; an opportunity for consumers to make their mind up. I am sure, with the strengthening of marketing and promotion, that more and more people will simply choose Australian products.

SPEECH.PARA: It is expected that the amendments to the food standards code will be gazetted early next year. This also gives ample time for importers and distributors to make the necessary changes to their packaging arrangements. Today, the Minister for Consumer Affairs announced that he will be calling on all the State Health Ministers to support his initiative in having country of origin labelling on all food products, both fresh and processed. I think that, too, is a remarkable landmark, and it is very important because it is not only the citrus industry that has raised some of these problems; of course, it is also the fruit and vegetable industry.

I am very proud to say that Bundaberg, my home town, is the leading centre in Australia for horticulture. I had a meeting only recently with fruit and vegetable producers and they raised their concerns in regard to food products coming in from other countries. If they are labelled, and I am sure that all State governments will support this initiative, then we will again have the opportunity for all mums and dads in the supermarkets to say, `We want to buy the Aussie product', that people will not be conned by the slick labelling of the past, where it says `Product of Australia' when it has only been packaged in Australia and the product has been imported from another country.

I think this is a landmark decision. I do recognise that when this motion was formulated the honourable member for Mallee (Mr Peter Fisher) would not have been aware that this initiative was about to come forward, and I think that everyone on all sides of the House would support the initiative of Senator Tate.

There are approximately 3,500 citrus growers in Australia, mainly small farmers located in the Riverland, the Murrumbidgee Irrigation Area, Sunraysia, and of course at Gayndah and Mundubbera in my region. There is an expanding citrus industry, too, in the Emerald region. In fact, I believe that there is going to be a very large production of citrus coming out of the Emerald region over the next few years. Of course, that means that we need to look not only to the domestic market and holding our market share here in this country but also to expanding our export potential, because that is where the future for Australian primary products lies-overseas.

There have been many concerns raised in regard to the developing country tariff preference. The removal of developing country status from Brazil effectively would mean an increase in tariff. In my view, this would be contrary to the Government's trade and industry policy on the need for industries to attain international competitiveness. Also, I feel it would be prejudicial to Australia's position in the Uruguay Round negotiations. I recognise, as we all do, the seriousness of the intransigence of the European Economic Community at the present time, but it is in our interests, more than any other primary producing country, to ensure that we get the best opportunity to gain fairer trade because some 80 per cent of our farm product has to be sold overseas. I would like to point out that both Australia and Brazil are members of the Cairns Group who, as fair traders, stand to gain enormously from any trade liberalisation outcome that could be achieved through those negotiations.

Because of the short time allotted I will not take up much more of the time of the House. I do recognise that the honourable member for Wakefield (Mr Andrew) wants to make a contribution, too. However, I would just like to stress that the initiatives taken by Senator Michael Tate last week, and again today, are going to play a very positive role in regard to the fruit and vegetable industry, as well as the citrus industry. I think they will be welcomed by everybody, but again it does not contradict our position of arguing through the Cairns Group for freer trade. In other words, we are allowing consumers to make the choice instead of putting up walls of protection. Surely, if we look at history, it has been shown that protective barriers only work in the long term against the interests of the very country that hides behind them. As I said last night in the House, Europe will regret the position it has taken on protection because it is creating inefficiency in its own countries. Those countries are showing that they are cowards when it comes to decency and integrity in free trade.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Andrew Mr J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the couple of minutes remaining to me I will not retrace the ground that has already been well ploughed by the honourable member for Mallee (Mr Peter Fisher). I want to acknowledge the role of the honourable member for Hinkler (Mr Courtice) in sitting down early to give me an opportunity to say a thing or two, and I want to thank the honourable member for Mallee for introducing this motion and for the work he has done in preparation of it.

SPEECH.PARA: There has been a popular view, Mr Deputy Speaker, that honourable members on this side of the House have been as guilty as those on the Government side in regard to the attitude that we have taken to a free trade policy. I just want, in a couple of minutes, to make a point or two about that. I want to acknowledge that I stand as part of a coalition that has been proudly consistent in the way in which it has dealt with all primary products, particularly horticultural products. We have stood here for freer trade, and we stand here for fairer trade. I want you, Mr Deputy Speaker, to compare our stand with the bloody-minded and cheap approach taken by the Australian Democrats, who would tear both of the major parties apart, and I want you, too, to compare our stand with the stand taken by the Australian Labor Party when it was in opposition. I want to remind the House that the ALP in opposition, through the now Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), had the sheer barefaced audacity to say in 1983 to citrus growers in Griffith, in the electorate of the honourable member for Riverina-Darling (Mr Hicks):
The citrus industry is threatened by the Fraser Government's decision to reduce its protection. A Labor Government will maintain existing protection levels.

So much for a promise from the ALP. Never will either of these coalition parties be guilty, in opposition, of saying something they were not prepared to deliver in government. Citrus growers might do well to remember that, tough as things are now, from these parties they got some realistic protection-protection that was levelling down, it is true, but nonetheless they got it. I say that with conviction, because I was a citrus grower at the time. These parties have stood for recognising the essential role that horticultural industries play, not only in the Australian domestic market but also in generating export income for Australia.
