SPEECH.SPEAKER: Atkinson Mr R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —On first arriving in this place, I was pleased to hear the commitment of both the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) to lifting the standard of behaviour and the resulting quality of debate in this place. I was pleased to hear the Prime Minister state, and I quote from Hansard of 8 May 1990:

SPEECH.PARA: There is on us all a responsibility which we have not met as often as we should have. That responsibility is to give to this Parliament its proper status as a forum which commands respect within the community. We can expect that respect only if we earn it through the relevance of what we discuss and conduct those discussions in a positive and constructive spirit

With such promises in mind, I was therefore dismayed when I witnessed the outrageous behaviour of the Prime Minister and the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Hand) during Question Time on 15 November 1990. Responding to a question from his own back bench regarding the changing diplomatic situation between Australia and South Africa, the Prime Minister launched into an unprovoked and unnecessary attack upon the Leader of the Opposition. Further, the Prime Minister, in answering a question relating to South Africa, had the temerity to use this time to embark upon a sordid attack on Australia's involvement in the Vietnam war and Indo-China.

I thought we had scraped the bottom of the barrel when we heard the Prime Minister accusing members on this side of the House of being responsible for the loss of young Australian lives because of political opportunism. But the worst was yet to come. This House was to witness the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs interject with the disgraceful comments, `You never went yourself. None of you went' and `They are on your heads, all those deaths'.

The behaviour of the Prime Minister and the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs deserves the condemnation of this House. My objections to the outbursts of the Prime Minister and the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs are threefold.

Firstly, the Prime Minister's abuse of Question Time, especially when the question emanates from one of his own backbench, is total hypocrisy when one considers his statement in this House of 8 May 1990. Let me repeat the words of the Prime Minister:
The responsibility is to give to this Parliament its proper status as a forum which commands respect within the community--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It is inappropriate for the honourable member to refer to the Prime Minister's `total hypocrisy'. He will withdraw, please.
—I will withdraw that remark. I continue the words of the Prime Minister:

SPEECH.PARA: The responsibility is to give to this Parliament its proper status as a forum which commands respect within the community. We can expect that respect only if we earn it through the relevance of what we discuss and conduct those discussions in a positive and constructive spirit.

How can anyone take these comments seriously when we see such blatant examples of the Prime Minister abusing Question Time? His comments to which I referred earlier were not relevant, nor were they positive, nor were they said in a constructive spirit. The Prime Minister's conduct fell short of his goal of lifting the respect with which the nation views this place.

The behaviour of the Prime Minister and the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs during Question Time on 15 November was not a case in isolation. Indeed, since arriving in this place I have been appalled at the way in which the Government has abused Question Time. On many occasions we have seen Question Time corrupted by longwinded answers which have had no relevance to the question. So often answers are tarnished by abuse and personal attacks. Question Time has been corrupted by dorothy dixers being used as a device for what are really ministerial statements.

With regard to interjections by the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs, I wrote to the Prime Minister on 22 November 1990 expressing my disappointment at the actions of his Minister. I expressed my belief that the Minister's actions were unbecoming of a Minister of the Crown and I urged the Prime Minister to ask the Minister to withdraw his comments. I seek leave to table a copy of my letter to the Prime Minister.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. I have not had a reply from the Prime Minister at this stage. However, the Minister has approached me privately to offer assurances that he had not intended to insult any individual in the House with respect to service in the armed forces in Vietnam. Whilst I thank the Minister for his private assurances, the Minister's interjections are recorded in Hansard and are therefore on public record, and I believe that the Minister should correct the situation.

SPEECH.PARA: My second objection to the Prime Minister's behaviour on 15 November concerns his selective interpretation of history. Certainly the decision to commit Australian troops to Vietnam belonged to the coalition government of the day, but that is only part of the very long story. The Prime Minister should be careful when he so carelessly blames the coalition government of the day for the loss of young Australian lives. Is this not the same Prime Minister who was a senior player in the Australian trade union movement and the Labor Party which supported anti-war moratoriums, advocated the burning of draft cards, and invoked union action against the supply ships Boonaroo and Jeparit; all of this while young Australians were serving their country in a combat zone?

The Prime Minister's selective interpretation of history does not, it would seem, include the confusion and dismay experienced by young Australians serving in Vietnam as a result of the anti-war movement back home. The Australian Labor Party and the union movement have much to answer for for the manner in which they treated young men who served in Vietnam.

Almost 21 years ago-in fact, on 15 December 1969-Bob Hawke, as he was then, addressed delegates from about 30 left wing unions at a meeting called by the Melbourne anticonscription committee, not long before he became Federal President of the Australian Council of Trade Unions. According to his biographer, John Hurst, he spoke strongly against the war, declaring that no Australian with any sense of decency would tolerate Australia's involvement in the Vietnam holocaust.

After he left the meeting, a provocative resolution was passed calling on national servicemen in South Vietnam to lay down their arms in mutiny against the heinous barbarism perpetrated in our name upon innocent aged men, women and children. Yet now we have the Prime Minister attempting to divorce himself and his colleagues from the Vietnam days. The men who served in Vietnam will long remember his contribution. Indeed, I was one of those young men serving in the Australian forces, in fact in an infantry battalion, at that very time. I believe that his comments were totally out of order.
My third objection to the events of 15 November relates to the incorrect statement of the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs:
You never went yourself. None of you went

In my letter to the Prime Minister, which I have tabled, I made the point that the Minister should acquaint himself with the facts before making inaccurate statements. The Minister should be aware that 32 members of the present Parliament list military service in their curricula vitae and I am aware that at least three members-the honourable member for Farrer (Mr Tim Fischer), the honourable member for McPherson (Mr Bradford) and myself-have served in Vietnam. We can only pray that our servicemen now serving in the Gulf receive greater support from the Labor Party left wing than our troops did in Vietnam.

The difference between the Labor Party and the coalition while in opposition is very clear. Unlike the disgraceful behaviour of the Labor Party during the 1960s and 1970s, we as an opposition have offered bipartisan support to the Government for its military commitment in the Gulf. Young Australians serving their country in the Gulf will have every confidence that they have not only the support of the Government but also the support of the Opposition and the vast majority of ordinary Australians. In contrast to the Labor Party in opposition, we on this side of the House will continue to play a positive and constructive role in this debate. We will not allow political opportunism to cloud our judgment and our commitment to the well-being of our service personnel.
Finally, I remind the House of the words of the Leader of the Opposition on 8 May 1990 in response to the Prime Minister's commitment to lift parliamentary standards:

I believe that the standard of parliamentary conduct has continued to decline and possibly reached its lowest level in memory during the last Parliament. Members of the public, rightly, are appalled by the personal attacks and by the bad language that so frequently mark debate in this chamber . . . I invite the Prime Minister to join me in making a commitment to ensuring the highest standards and the proper functioning of this Parliament.
The actions of the Prime Minister and the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs on 15 November would seem to indicate that that invitation has not been accepted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woods Mr H.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have been trying to work out exactly what and who the National Party of Australia represents. In pursuit of that I have been looking at statistics. I had a look on an electorate basis at the statistics from the last census in Australia, which was in 1986. I looked firstly at families with incomes of less than $12,000. According to that census, 11 of the 15 electorates with the highest percentage of people below that income level were National Party electorates. In fact, all 18 National Party seats at that time were placed in the bottom one-third of the list. At that time Page, Richmond and Kennedy were National Party electorates.

SPEECH.PARA: That tells us that a big proportion of families in National Party electorates are on low incomes in comparison with the rest of the nation. In comparison with Bradfield, for instance, which had only 6 per cent of families with incomes below $12,000, my electorate of Page had 30.8 per cent, or five times as many families, on that low income or less. One can conclude from that that for some reason National Party electorates have many families on low incomes.

Then I looked at the other end of the scale, at the proportion of families with incomes above $40,000. I found that the six electorates with the lowest percentage at that income level were all National Party electorates. All National Party seats would fall within the 40 per cent with the lowest percentage of families earning more than $40,000. So a reasonable conclusion is that in National Party electorates there are only a small number of families with high incomes and a very high proportion of families with low incomes. In my electorate, which in 1986 was a National Party electorate, there were 8.2 per cent of families with incomes higher than $40,000. If we compare that again with Bradfield, on the other end of the scale, there were 54.8 per cent with incomes of more than $40,000 while Page had only one-sixth of that number of families on high incomes.

I then looked at statistics of median family income. I found that 12 of the lowest 14 median family income electorates are National Party electorates and that all National Party electorates fall into the 40 per cent with the lowest median family income. In my electorate of Page the median family income was $16,940, compared again with Bradfield, at the other end of the scale, which had $43,000, or more than 2 1/2 times the average income of families in my electorate. In other statistics we find that five of the eight electorates with the highest unemployment rates are National Party electorates. In my electorate the unemployment rate in 1986 was 18.5 per cent-five times the unemployment rate for Bradfield.

The conclusion we can draw from all that is that there are a lot of people on low incomes; few on high incomes; and that families in all National Party electorates are low income earners. Unemployment in National Party electorates, we can also conclude, is very high. This has built up over many years, I believe, and is the result of poor representation by National Party members. We now have the likes of the Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Tim Fischer) complaining of unemployment rates of 7 or 8 per cent, but in their own electorates they have put up with 15, 16, 17, 19 per cent and more unemployment rates for many years.

One would think that the National Party members, with the high proportion of low income earners, the low proportion of high income earners, and the high proportion of unemployed, would be more concerned about the needs of their low income constituents and other disadvantaged people in their electorates than about the high income earners. But after the latest efforts of the National Party one really has to wonder whether that is so-whether it has ever been so. We have to ask how these figures came about. Are they the result of inadequate representation?

One of the Budget measures that we proposed was a family allowance assets test limit of $500,000 net of debt, exclusive of the family home, and income of $60,000 a year. But this was overturned, largely at the instigation of the National Party. Now that really does say something. It says that National Party members are undertaking to look after the very wealthy, people with large assets. Some of those people will have $500,000 of assets; others will have $2m; others $10m. These people are very, very wealthy but because of National Party intervention they will still be eligible for the family allowance.

It stands to reason that if a benefit is given to one group in the community it should be taken away from another. So they are giving a benefit to that top section of the community at the expense of the bottom section. And I ask honourable members to remember what I said before: the number of people in that bottom section of income levels is highest in National Party electorates. So are National Party members really representing everyone in their electorates? They are not. They are representing very small groups in their electorates.

This misrepresentation can be seen over a whole range of issues. It might be thought that National Party members would represent strongly the low income earners who make up such a large percentage of their electors. But there is evidence-I have just given some-that that is not what National Party representatives are doing. In other areas, they want a flat tax rate, a consumption tax, Skillshare training to be abolished, cuts of $1 billion to the social security budget, and they have already refused to change the assets test for people with $500,000 of assets, net of debt. These are all things that would disadvantage low income earners. They are not doing the job of representing that large portion of their electorates. Rather, they are choosing to support the views of a very narrow and a very small group in their electorates. The benefit they give to those chosen few is to the cost of the many.

The most damning evidence of that is the absolute ambiguity of proposing $3 billion in cuts to the Budget whilst refusing us the ability to make cuts by blocking Bills in the Senate. I might say that the Leader of the National Party of Australia presides over a party that is rapidly losing any significance. Its views are the greedy aspirations proposed by the few. The Leader of the National Party shows his absolute insignificance with the lack of argument he always has to fall back on. In fact, a few weeks ago here he dropped to the level of attempting to quote my remarks at a meeting of the Grafton Midday Rotary Club. Can honourable members imagine that-the great National Party leader having little people running all around Grafton reporting the words of one of the newest members here? It really is big time stuff. It really does demonstrate the absolute insignificance of the National Party and its leader. His informers got it wrong anyhow; they misquoted and took my words out of context, especially my alleged remarks about Keating and Hewson.

If 10-80 is insignificant, how insignificant does that make the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) who buckled on the assets test provisions on the family allowance? But people are waking up to the National Party. They have realised that the National Party does not represent ordinary country people but only a small group of the people who bankroll it, and that is plain to see from the evidence I have given.

But there is other evidence. In environmental matters, the National Party displays its usual ability to take quite an unbalanced view. The local National Party person up my way, who happens to be the former State Minister for Natural Resources, in charge of forestry, asks me for unqualified and unequivocal support for logging. That means support for whatever the industry wants, even if that is not in the interests of the workers in the industry, even if it is not in the interests of the community or the environment. The National Party asks me for unqualified support for policies that may reduce employment, especially in the long term; be responsible for the extinction of flora and fauna; destroy the natural attributes of the area; and put forestry on an unsustainable basis.

I support the need for the north coast of New South Wales to have a sustainable timber industry and I support the need for the industry to have a secure resource. But that must be qualified by the wishes and needs of other sections of the community and it must be recognised that community expectations may change over time. The community expectations regarding the timber industry now are vastly different from what they were 20 years ago: 20 years ago the forests were drastically overcut by the industry. Can we make a decision now that cannot be changed for 20 years?

The people in these electorates are waking up to the injustices perpetrated on them by the National Party. Recent election results in Page, Richmond and Kennedy demonstrate this. Recently the north coast seat of Coffs Harbour had a by-election. The Labor Party obtained an unprecedented 16.7 per cent swing on a two-party preferred basis against the National Party. If that result was transferred to a Federal situation now, the National Party would have four seats left here. For the sake of National Party constituents let us all hope that that happens.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tuckey Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the time allowed to me in the grievance debate today I want to raise two matters, both of which I think qualify for the grievance debate. The first relates to honesty and open government, something frequently mentioned but not so often practised. Recently we have had announced some royal commissions which I trust will contribute substantially to that cause. In this regard I welcome the naming of royal commissioners in Perth and wish those gentlemen well in their efforts. The Premier of Tasmania, Mr Field, also announced a royal commission to investigate aspects of an attempt to bribe a member of parliament in Tasmania. Mr Field obviously believes that the court proceedings that have already dealt with this matter have not covered all aspects of the case and that further inquiry by way of a royal commission is necessary to guarantee to the people of Tasmania that justice has both been done and is seen to be done. I am sure that this action to give the people of Tasmania all the information regarding this matter must be welcome.

SPEECH.PARA: The members of the public are entitled to all the information relating to a member of parliament prior to casting their votes for that person or the party he or she represents. This was certainly the situation in my case. Shortly after my Liberal endorsement to the seat of O'Connor in 1980, the honourable member for Fremantle (Mr Dawkins) drew this Parliament's attention to my 1967 conviction for assault. The matter received wide publicity as a result. The people considered the issue and elected me notwithstanding. No doubt Mr Field wishes the results of his royal commission to be available before the next Tasmanian election and in this I support him. However, now he has commenced this process of cleansing the political scene in Tasmania, he is obliged to do the task completely, and as he is yet to announce his terms of reference for that royal commission, I think it necessary that Mr Field ensure that those terms of reference include some other court cases involving politicians, and in particular the one in which in 1973 Mr Field was found guilty of growing Indian hemp or cannabis.

I suggest this because notwithstanding that the charge against Mr Michael Walter Field was proven and then upheld in the Supreme Court by Chief Justice Green-judgment 23, 1974 of 29 May 1974-no conviction was recorded in this serious matter as the original magistrate decided to release Field under the Probation of Offenders Act 1973. I find the decision of a magistrate on a matter where the penalty in 1973 was $2,000, two years in gaol or both extraordinary, particularly as Field was a schoolteacher at the time and consequently held a position of trust with children in Tasmania. I am not sure what the purpose of his cannabis growing was, but I hope it was not to supply it to schoolchildren.

This decision is therefore also worthy of inquiry by the royal commission to guarantee the public of Tasmania that no outside influence was attempted by any person or any member of the then Labor Government. I certainly have no evidence of this occurring, but nor has Mr Field identified any specific issues to warrant his royal commission. He says he wants an inquiry to ensure that no additional impropriety occurred, and so do I. I trust therefore that in the spirit of honest government that Mr Field so earnestly supports he will also allow this matter to be fully investigated by his royal commission.

The second matter I wish to raise relates to the circumstances of public servants here in Canberra and their right to promotion. I refer to the circumstances of one Mr Patrick O'Malley, an employee of the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce (DITAC) who recently applied-in fact, in about April-May-for a position that was advertised as No. 7578. Mr O'Malley was unsuccessful in his application. I am not in any way questioning whether the various agencies that considered his application made the correct decision in appointing somebody else, namely, a Ms Katherine Jones, but I am deeply concerned from the information provided to me as to the procedures that were followed.

When Mr O'Malley was advised that he was unsuccessful and that Katherine Jones had been appointed, he was told that, firstly, his interview technique was bad. One might wonder whether somebody's work effort is best judged by his interview technique. By the way, he denies that that is the case other than he did have bronchitis on the day, which was mentioned in the report. Mr O'Malley's concern is that although he had been working at DITAC since January 1988-Miss Jones had been working in the Department for only six months-he was able to get references from only his immediate superior but Miss Jones got references from the First Assistant Secretary. In fact, it is further of concern to me that Miss Jones's referees were the Department's Assistant Secretary and First Assistant Secretary.

One would wonder why a fairly moderate promotion to class 6 or position 6-whatever it is called-would warrant references from people so senior in the Department and, in fact, how they had sufficient knowledge of someone who had worked for six months in the Department to give such references. You would be aware, Mr Deputy Speaker, that there are procedures by which people gain these promotions. The first of these is that they are interviewed and a decision is made by a departmental committee.

We can all put ourselves in the position of sitting on that committee when one applicant comes up with the boss's and the assistant boss's reference. It would be a pretty fair tip who was going to get the job, would it not? I think it is outrageous that those two people chose to give a reference in a matter of this nature and it raises considerable concerns as to the procedures.

There were other problems. O'Malley, of course, appealed and when he appealed and went before the promotions appeal committee, he discovered that the promotee, Miss Jones, had refused to attend. She just would not go. So he went and put his case. When he got there he found that one member of the committee hearing his appeal was a very close working associate of the chairman of the original committee that failed to appoint him. He complained about that. He said that he did not think that this was very appropriate considering there were hundreds of members of DITAC who could have been appointed to the task and been more independent. That was rejected apparently on the grounds that-I will see if I can find the words:
Canberra is a company town and you should not worry about things like that.

But the reality is that he was rolled in his objection to the fact that one of the three people who were hearing his appeal was very closely associated with the chairman of the original committee. He went to a Ms Bruin, I think it was at the time, who was supposed to have a role in protecting public servants in such cases and was given short shrift. He was forced to buy a copy of the Public Service Act because the Public Service Commissioner would not even give him certain information he sought.

Most importantly, he was the only person to turn up to the appeal and yet he still was not given the job. I just do not know how. These processes are all there to protect public servants. Surely if somebody appeals it is incumbent on the person who is being appealed against to attend and give evidence to the new committee. That her refusal to do so could be accepted as some reason why she should keep the job astounds me. I am asking through this Parliament and directly to the responsible Minister that he have some independent inquiry into Mr O'Malley's failure to be appointed. I will accept that maybe the other person was better anyway. I do not know that. I have only met Mr O'Malley, but I can tell you this, Mr Deputy Speaker: if I were trying to get a Public Service job and I found that one of my opponents who had only been working in the place for six months had references passed down by the First Assistant Secretary and the Secretary, I would be a bit nervous. I certainly would not like to be one of those trying to make a judgment on the proper merits of the applicants when one of the applicants was anointed from that high up.

I further question how those particular individuals could have had the knowledge of this worker to give that sort of reference. Quite clearly those sorts of interdepartmental references should come from your immediate superior, and no higher. I think it is quite a concerning matter. I do not know whether it happens frequently in DITAC. I do not know whether there are any outside influences. I really think the Minister should look into that matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hulls Mr R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise today to defend the historical claims of Queensland, the Queensland Australian Labor Party (ALP), and many of the cities and towns in my electorate of Kennedy. While I respect the commitment of the New South Wales branch of the Labor Party to a fitting celebration of the Labor Party's centenary, it is important that the historical record be set straight before any more spurious articles appear like the one by Paddy McGuinness in the Australian of 29 November.

SPEECH.PARA: The New South Wales branch of the Labor Party is made of a great bunch of people deeply committed to our party and the people of Australia. But unfortunately New South Wales misses out on the honour of being the place where the Labor Party was formed. The claim by McGuinness that it was at a meeting of the New South Wales Trades and Labour Council on 28 November 1890 that the decision was made to form what became the ALP is clearly incorrect. I am afraid I have to disappoint my New South Wales colleagues and put them on the right path.

The Labor Party was, as most of us should know, actually started in Queensland on 1 August 1890. On this historic day in Brisbane 100 years ago, the first annual session of the Australian Labor Federation (ALF) took the decision to involve itself directly in political activity and drew up a program for reform as well as a set of conditions of Labor candidature. At this meeting it was the delegate for Charters Towers, a city also in my electorate, who raised the question of political action by the union movement. This delegate was one Charles McDonald, who was also the President of the Australian Labor Federation.

I am extremely proud to stand in this place today and highlight the central role played by Charlie McDonald in the formation of this great Australian Labor Party. It may interest to know that I am his successor as the member for Kennedy. Charlie McDonald actually held Kennedy for Labor from the seat's creation in 1901 until his death in 1925. It may also interest you to know, Mr Deputy Speaker, that not only did he start the discussion that formed the Labor Party on that day in Brisbane 100 years ago, but he was also the first Labor Speaker of this House. Charles McDonald will be pleased to know that Kennedy is back where it belongs, with the Labor Party, and where it shall remain for many years to come.

As an aside I point out to the House that Mr McDonald, or fighting Charlie as he was known, was a famous cyclist. On one campaign he reportedly rode over 4,800 kilometres. As the Kennedy electorate is now just over 44 per cent of the Queensland land mass I am thankful for charter allowances. Not only did Charters Towers produce Charlie McDonald; it also produced the first Labor Premier in the world, Anderson Dawson as the member for Charters Towers in the Queensland Parliament, Dawson was able to form the world's first exclusively Labor Ministry in December 1899. Unfortunately for Dawson and the government it was a short-lived Ministry, and I am pleased to see that nearly 100 years on Labor governments do tend to last a little longer.

To set the record straight for my New South Wales colleagues, Mr Deputy Speaker, I would like to point out that the first branch of the Labor Party in Australia was formed in Fortitude Valley, Brisbane, on 26 February 1891. The Charters Towers branch was formed only two weeks later. The Charters Towers branch will celebrate its centenary on 11 March 1991, nearly a month before the celebration in Balmain.

I do not want to labour the point but quite clearly when the committed workers of the Balmain labourers union got together to form a branch on 4 April 1891, they were not the first. April follows March which, of course, follows February. It was not surprising that a city like Charters Towers that is so steeped in Labor tradition gave the Prime Minister an enthusiastic welcome when he visited there, just last month.

As well as the Towers, many other towns and cities in Kennedy are indeed rich in Labor history. I am sure I do not have to remind honourable members that the battleground for the great shearers strike of 1891 is now largely covered by my electorate. As a result, the Queensland ALP can also lay claim to the symbolic birthplace of the Labor Party. In the main street of Barcaldine in my electorate there is a 150-year old eucalypt, the Tree of Knowledge. In 1891 the ringleaders of the shearers strike were chained to the Tree of Knowledge to await transportation to prison.

As we all know, it was the great shearers strike that galvanised the workers into concerted political action. It was the shearers strike that gave momentum to the Australian Labor Federation's decisions of the year before to form the Labor Party. In Barcaldine in May next year we will be having a week of celebrations to commemorate the role of that strike in Queensland history. I would like to take this opportunity to invite all my colleagues, especially those from New South Wales, to travel north to my electorate to join in those celebrations next year.

I come back to the ALF decisions of 1890 because they further confirm the case for Queensland being the birthplace of the Labor Party. As well, they point to the contribution made by another town in my electorate, Blackall. At the August meeting of the ALF in Brisbane, when the delegates had finished drafting the platform and conditions for being a Labor candidate, they ended the meeting by instructing the executive to meet in the near future to draw up a set of rules for the organisation of the party they had just founded. This meeting occurred in the western Queensland town of Blackall on 9 December 1890. It drew up a set of seven rules covering such things as selection of candidates, determination of policy, and so on.

It gives me great pleasure to inform honourable members, especially those from New South Wales, that to commemorate the 100th anniversary of this significant meeting Australia's Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and, I might add, a senior member of the New South Wales Labor Party and the Deputy Premier of Queensland will visit Blackall this coming weekend. As well as official duties, a series of wonderful community events have been planned.

It would have been remiss of me to sit back and let the heritage claims of my electorate be sidelined by inaccurate history. Whilst I hope my good friends in the New South Wales branch have a wonderful celebration of their own significant dates, I think it should now be clear to everyone in this House that the Labor Party was indeed formed in Queensland. As this really is a question of great historical and heritage value-a point on which I am sure I would get bipartisan support-I seek leave of the House to have incorporated in Hansard two documents that prove my case. The first is an account of the 1 August ALF meeting from the Worker newspaper of September 1890 and the second is an account of the 9 December meeting in Blackall from the Worker newspaper of 27 December 1890.

TALK.START.PARA: —I should advise the honourable member for Kennedy that the standing practice is that documents of the nature that he is trying to have incorporated in Hansard are outside the Speaker's guidelines. It may be that as an alternative he can seek to table these documents.
—I seek leave to table the documents.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —In conclusion, having demolished their historical claims, just as Queensland cricketers and footballers will demolish New South Wales throughout the coming season, I commiserate with my New South Wales colleagues. I can fully appreciate the disappointment they must now be feeling, having been enlightened as to the true origins of the ALP. Queenslanders, however, can be proud that this great Party was born in our State, a State that is now governed admirably by a Labor Government. We can also be proud that it was born in the Federal electorate of Kennedy, which now has a Labor member-and will have for many years to come. This really sets the scene perfectly for next year's centenary celebrations, which will take place in Queensland.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McGauran Mr P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Most members of the Parliament would agree that we spend far too little time engaged in discussions on the future of the Australian information industry. Given the importance of the future of the computer industry specifically, I feel that not nearly enough time or effort is spent within this chamber or within the committee system discussing and debating Government policies that will affect the future of the information industry. We need such an effort now more than ever, given that the current recession threatens to reduce Australia to the role of subcontractor in the global high technology information industry.

SPEECH.PARA: The recession has hit the Australian information industry extremely hard. I will give the House some background, Mr Deputy Speaker, on the Australian information technology industry. It generally employs 170,000 people and has an annual turnover of $13 billion to $14 billion. Australia's trade deficit in information technology now stands at around $4 billion but it is claimed this deficit will reach $10 billion by 1996. Information technology is essentially an enabling technology and is, therefore, crucial to raising efficiencies and competitiveness across industries.

Importantly, as the Bureau of Industry Economics (BIE) pointed out in its paper on the trend towards globalisation in this industry and its relationship to trade generally, the indigenous information technology industry, as a producer of largely generic technologies, generates important spillovers for the rest of the economy. A stable and growing indigenous information technology industry is, therefore, at the heart of whatever Australia hopes to achieve towards building an internationally competitive manufacturing and service sector.

The recession, however, has struck at the information technology industry in much the same way as other sectors in the economy. For the first time in 12 years the computer industry has recorded a profit fall in real terms, and this from one of the most dynamic sectors of the global economy. It is quite tragic.

The recently published annual report by the Australian Information Industry Association (AIIA) shows its membership to have reported revenue growth for the past financial year to total below the consumer price index increase, namely, growth has been set at 5.7 per cent. While exports of hardware, software and services had increased, the trade grab had also increased. The computer industry has begun to shed staff. Furthermore, investment, which fell by 13 per cent in the past year, is set to fall even further over the coming year. Though exports by AIIA members grew to $455m, it was still necessary to import some $2.4 billion in computer systems and services.

The general downturn, or now the official recession, threatens this important sector of the economy, particularly those companies struggling to meet demand and close off the looming export gap in information technologies. A fall-off in demand for networking services, data processing, personal computers and so forth is already in evidence. Ironically-and this will be one of the real problems as the nation struggles out of its recession-the collapse in investment in computer technology by companies will mean their efficiencies and competitiveness will fall away even further over the course of the downturn. The lead time for recovery will be greatly extended as a result. In the interim rival economies will be moving into increasingly higher realms of efficiency in regard to their operations.

This is not a passing claim, Mr Deputy Speaker. Reportedly, US businesses spend as much as 11 per cent of annual turnover on new computer systems and networks to increase their overall efficiencies. By comparison, Australian businesses currently spend about 1.3 per cent of total turnover. The recession, therefore, will suppress investment even further and push back our competitiveness relative to our trading partners. Importantly, the recession also threatens the viability of those many fledgling Australian information technology businesses for which life was enough of a struggle before the Government induced recession arrived.

The recession threatens to deluge the Australian information industry sector and overturn the Government's predictions for growth in exports and import replacement as made in its 1987 information industries strategy. Though a crucial area of the economy, the information industry is a notoriously difficult sector for government to oversee. It warrants close examination and carefully designed policy responses. A recession, therefore, is the very last thing this industry sector needed as it struggled for stability.

There are very real problems associated with the extent of government interaction in any selective way with the information technology industry. The industry is very volatile, as are most industries undergoing rapid growth. Therefore, what are ostensibly stable markets one day can rapidly disappear the next day, and industries can be quickly swept away as a result. Australian domestic companies as well as heavily capitalised transnationals operating locally have been cleared out of the marketplace overnight because of the volatility of the information technology sector.

Domestic companies like Impact Systems which broke ahead of the pack in recent years as a manufacturer of laser printers and automated office equipment has failed owing to a number of internal management and cash flow difficulties. Similarly, Texas Instruments Australia Ltd, a subsidiary of a multinational which invested significantly in the Australian personal computer market in the early years of the last decade, quit the local scene after incurring losses of some $200m. For better or worse, it needs to be said that most Australian companies operating in certain sectors of the information technology sector have potential but are compromised by a range of external and internal difficulties. The hardware, software and component arms of the industry face many difficulties.

Regardless of this, there are windows of opportunity in certain of the small scale and value added domestic enterprises. Australian companies do have strengths in communication related technologies and specialist application of software development. Australia possesses competence in these areas because they are basically driven by human skills, by intellectual resources. Success in these areas is not solely dependent upon high levels of capital investment and volumes of production, as is the hardware sector. There are quite a large number of component suppliers or highly specialised computer services businesses which have won their niche in the local market. It is a niche, it needs to be added, which is largely built around supplying components and related services to transnational hardware and software enterprises or their subsidiaries operating in Australia.

The ambitions of these companies are forever thwarted because they are mostly dependent upon the purchasing policies of the transnationals; that is to say, they are mainly subcontractors to the transnationals. Importantly, the development of their own technological expertise is therefore greatly retarded. It comes as no surprise, as the BIE has reported, that markets are often transitory and local component suppliers are prone to fail without warning. Even the successful ones are likely to be directly taken over by the transnationals.

Alternatively, successful local component or service industries become so deeply locked into the buying needs of particular foreign companies as to preclude their selling to competitors. These factors profoundly retard the development of any indigenous export orientated supply and specialised service industries. The battle then is to win back the nation's technological sovereignty. Sadly, this battle is currently being lost.

The domestic information industry is a volatile, immature, yet strategically important sector of the economy. It must now not only struggle against a host of structural and financial difficulties; it must also cope with the ravages of recession. In order to ensure the survival of the domestic computer industry, the Government must provide the leadership to improve its operational efficiency. The industry needs government guidance so as to boost its labour productivity, overcome its depleted skills base, encourage higher quality controls and ensure aggressive marketing initiates are forthcoming.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newell Mr N.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, in the first speech which I made in this House I claimed a mandate to represent Richmond on a number of grounds. That claim was based upon the massive swing against the sitting National Party of Australia member, Charles Blunt. It was a decisive statement by the voters in the Richmond electorate. Since then that swing has been confirmed by the State by-election in Coffs Harbour, where the electorate has shown that the move away from the years of conservatism on the north coast, demonstrated by the decisions of the voters in Richmond and Page, were no aberration.

SPEECH.PARA: I particularly claimed a mandate on the basis of that vote of no confidence in the National Party of Australia in the Richmond electorate. I claimed a mandate as an anticorruption member and as a pro-environment member. I also claimed a mandate to represent the business sector for which the Richmond electorate had become the Cinderella electorate of New South Wales because of the lack of effective representation over many years.

Today I want to direct the attention of this House to several problems which people living in this electorate are facing. The population of the Richmond electorate is soaring, with a growth rate surpassing that of almost any other region in Australia. Many people who have retired have come to live in the lovely environment which Richmond provides--

TALK.START.PARA: —You got them a post office, too.

—Along with its excellent post office facilities, as the honourable member said. So many of the people moving to that area have young children, and many of the younger people growing up in the region are now seeking a new life for their younger families. Many of them are sole parents. It would be wrong for anyone to suggest that they do not have the right to seek a good life for their families. I have heard it said that they should stay in the capital cities where employment might be available, rather than come to the north coast. This is a hoary myth, and many of the people who would like to seek work in the capital cities cannot afford to live there, with rents outstripping wages. Who can blame people who then seek to make a new life for their families? One of the characteristics of the north coast, and particularly the Richmond electorate, is its low industry base. A big effort is being made to change that; but that is another story which I do not have the time to address here. It is sufficient to say that changes do not occur overnight.

SPEECH.PARA: In the south of the electorate much depends on the prosperity and growth of the city of Lismore in the future provision of work opportunities. Even in these difficult economic times that city is experiencing something of a rebirth and, through encouragement from this Government and from such schemes as the new cities approach announced in Lismore by the Leader of the New South Wales Opposition, Bob Carr, that prosperity seems assured.

In the north of the electorate, in the Tweed area, the population is increasing even more rapidly, again outstripping available employment opportunities. Each morning an observer can detect that lack of a substantial industry base as an endless stream of traffic leaves New South Wales to cross the border into Queensland, and in the evening that stream is reversed. I pay tribute to the efforts that have been made through the various Skillshare projects within the electorate and to the dedication of those at the helm. I have also taken the opportunity to visit some of these programs and the job training programs operating in conjunction with the Commonwealth Employment Service offices at Lismore and Murwillumbah.

Anyone who doubts the enthusiasm of unemployed people in retraining for the work force should get out there and see that enthusiasm for themselves. For those who adopt a `blame the victim' attitude these visits should be mandatory. Because of the high rate of unemployment I would be anxious for our best thinkers to put their heads together with the movers and shakers to deal with the imbalance between our industry base in the north and the needs of the people to be engaged in useful and productive employment.

I am seeking to foster a coming together of groups within the electorate- groups which, at least in the Richmond electorate, have never come together before-to see what can be done. Those groups would include the trade unions, through the provincial trades and labour councils; the entrepreneurs and developers; the environmental groups; and representatives of local government and small business. Such a task force, should it come about, could prove to be a useful sounding board at worst and an exciting catalyst at the very best to attract appropriate development and hence create jobs within the electorate.

It has been estimated that in a few years nearly one-third of the population of the Tweed Shire will be under 19 years of age. We must continue, with the help of the Government and various interests within the electorate, to address their needs. The loss of a generation to the future of this nation of young people who should be allowed to reach their own stature is too awful to contemplate.

I want now to address the problems experienced by people at the other end of the age spectrum, many of whom are described as the frail aged. The home and community care program, known as the HACC program, operated jointly by the Federal Government and the New South Wales Government, has recently been the subject of much media discussion and comment within the electorate. The program provides funding for support and maintenance services in the community for frail, elderly people, younger people with disabilities, and their carers.

Recently grants totalling $332,832 under the home and community care program for the electorate of Richmond were announced. The funds were largely for new projects, and the projects will allow many people who might otherwise have had to move into residential care to remain in their own home. The changing population within the Richmond electorate is putting great strain on resources for programs such as home and community care, and that clearly is a problem when people move from the city to the north coast and funding for support programs lags behind the new need. This matter will have to be faced squarely by the New South Wales and Federal governments if the skewed funding brought about by the shifting population is not to cause hardship to those people who are least able to endure it.

I recently met the home and community care organisers to discuss the whole problem. The major problem for HACC workers and their clients appears to stem from the policy decisions of the home care program, a program which operates under the HACC umbrella in New South Wales. Because of these policy decisions made under the program's guidelines, 131 Lismore people have been axed from the service, and 163 have had their hours reduced. The anecdotal evidence of the distress these cuts have imposed on the frail and aged in Lismore are certainly horrifying.

Just to add some realism to that, I will refer to particular meetings that I have had. I have met with one particular lady, a 61-year-old myalgic-encephalomyelitis, or ME, sufferer who has had all her hours of support withdrawn; I have met with another lady of 83 years of age who has had her hours of care, which provided services such as washing, removed from her; and I also met with an 88-year-old lady who had her hours reduced to zero, and her particular care involved looking after her 92-year-old husband. There have been calls for the State Minister for Family and Community Services, Mr Webster, to restore home care services to the Lismore people who have been cut out of these programs.

Before the introduction of a so-called regional equity rationale, these Lismore people were considered to be in need and as one critic, the Australian Labor Party candidate for the Lismore seat, Janelle Saffin, said, `In comes the formula and, hey presto, they are no longer needy'. Home care clients who have had their hours reduced and those cut from the services have expressed the fear that they are headed for an institution. Home care is part of the home and community care program which is jointly funded by the two governments, and the aim of the program is to give support to the frail and elderly or disabled so they can remain in their own homes. The cuts in this Lismore region certainly appear to be contrary to these aims.

The New South Wales home care program has certainly concentrated on providing personal care; that is, bathing, dressing and the like. What the users of these services are telling them is that they do not want that, they need heavy housekeeping done. I think it is about time the New South Wales Government listened. It is a big issue in New South Wales and anything the Minister for Community Services and Health (Mr Howe) can do to persuade his colleague, Mr Webster, in New South Wales to prevail upon home care, to review the north coast situation, would be gratefully welcomed by many people who are now worried about their future when just a few dollars or a few more hours would make all the difference and at the same time save the taxpayers of this nation much more in the short term as well.

For elderly people the lack of assistance with home keeping services is often the deciding factor in their being able to live in their own homes, and in this case for the sake of a few dollars we are taking away people's independence and forcing them into an institution which costs the taxpayers more money. One of the submissions that I have received on behalf of the frail and elderly has come from the chief executive officer (CEO) of the Campbell Hospital at Coraki, a hospital which services both the electorate of Richmond and the electorate of Page-and the honourable member for Page (Mr Harry Woods), who spoke previously in this debate, pointed out some of the problems which have faced the electorates of Page and Richmond, the low income base being one in particular which he addressed most forthrightly earlier this afternoon.

The CEO of that hospital, Mr Brian Mahaffey, also pointed out the problems that the frail and elderly are facing. I also received representation from Mr Rummery, the chairman of the board of the Lismore Base Hospital. A submission was presented by Mr Rummery, and he again pointed out similar problems to those I have been raising, some of the problems that the frail and elderly are facing. He has also pointed out that these cuts have certainly placed hardship on clients, when in some cases the home care service has been their only form of support.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mack Mr E.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government is considering the expansion of Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport by way of a third runway, subject to a satisfactory environmental impact statement (EIS). The EIS is unsatisfactory, both for what it reveals and for what it does not address. It is fundamentally flawed in that it has no proper cost-benefit study of either the third runway or the various options. It has a range of dubious assumptions as to the effects and extent of noise and the effects of noise on property values. There is no consideration of the potential toxic effects of aircraft emissions on health; no proper examination of the effect of the third runway on management operations and the efficiency of Sydney Airport; and no proper consideration of compensation for the `losers' of the proposal.

SPEECH.PARA: The EIS contains unvalidated assumptions that Australia will lose tourist business from congestion at Sydney, ignoring the benefits to the national economy from growth in other cities and States. There is no full analysis of hazard assessment for the proposal or alternatives, no statement as to where 11 million cubic metres of fill from marine sources would come from, or any environmental assessment of those sources. The EIS contains no real analysis of the constraints at Kingsford-Smith on the Government's deregulation of the airline industry.

Other issues emerging from the EIS are inappropriate concepts in relation to airport capacity and international comparisons; inconsistencies in cost estimates; considerable understatement of the effects of noise on both people and property; insufficient attention to air pollution; safety concerns; inconsistencies and omissions in relation to the marine environment and the problem of bird strike; biased consideration of health effects; and inadequate consideration of capacity problems in road access.

The EIS is misleading in its minimisation of the effects of the take-offs to the north and the use of the east-west runway. The fact that the east-west runway can be operated independently of the other two runways means that its use will grow in the future, as will pressure to have the curfew lifted by the time the third runway is completed. The benefits of reduction in air traffic on the areas east and west of the runway and increase in property values are also grossly exaggerated.

The EIS is fundamentally flawed, as has been virtually every study done on Sydney Airport in the past, in that it does not address the famous `big picture' of the Treasurer (Mr Keating). It ignores the long term economic, social equity and environmental effects of continuing to expand Australia's major airport in the densest part of Australia's largest city and the enormous implications that flow from such an action. The cost to the Australian taxpayer of this failure and of not establishing a long term strategy of providing a replacement airport at Badgerys Creek make the cost of airport construction pale into insignificance. The difference in public infrastructure cost alone between continuing expansion of Kingsford-Smith Airport and providing a replacement airport at Badgerys Creek over a 15- or 20-year period is in the order of $10 billion.

Over the 15 years from 1986, 441,000 new households will be formed in the Sydney region on an increasing population basis alone. Sydney's 3.8 million people will increase to close to five million people by 2020. Conservatively, over 15 years from 1986 a further 50,000 new dwellings will be required because of demolition of existing housing stock in the Sydney region. The vast majority of almost half a million new dwellings required will be on the outer fringes of Sydney, at a minimum basic infrastructure cost of $40,000 per dwelling. That cost approaches $20 billion. Such funds are, in all probability, simply not available.

These fringe dwellers will never, at least in the next half century, receive a comparable infrastructure to that available to inner Sydney, which is worth in the order of 10 times the basic infrastructure cost per dwelling-the parks, footpaths, street lighting, landscaping, libraries, child-care centres, sporting facilities, police, education and health services, job opportunities, entertainment facilities, and so on-but a demand will be set up which cannot be met.

The problems of urban consolidation and minimising the sprawl of Sydney and other major cities have been recognised in the last decade by both Labor and Liberal State governments in New South Wales. They have unfortunately achieved little by their ineffective developer-driven solutions of attempting to force high density housing on an unwilling community while having no transport and land use policy and no policy of conservation of residential land, which are the only effective answers to urban consolidation.

What have not been recognised in the urban consolidation debate are the economic, social and environmental effects of Kingsford-Smith Airport, burgeoning since 1945 like a black hole, absorbing housing, attracting motor vehicle traffic, breaking down the urban environment for kilometres around the airport. In the 19 years since 1971 there has been a loss of 50,000 people from the south side of Sydney and the environs of the airport. Twenty-five thousand new households have had to be created at the end of the development chain in western Sydney, at a minimum of $40,000 each: $1 billion and no jobs.

Did that appear on the Federal Airports Corporation balance sheet? It did not, just as the cost of social problems in the west does not and the cost of exacerbating Sydney's existing job imbalance, with the bulk of the people in the west and the bulk of the jobs in the centre and inner areas. Neither does the Federal Airports Corporation budget include increased travel costs for these displaced people and the increased road congestion, pollution, accident and environmental costs.

If the third runway goes ahead, with its four-fold increase in heavy jets to the north over the highest population density in any city, what will happen to the 82,000 people under the 20 ANEF noise contour shown in the EIS? In addition to the environmental and health effects, they will steadily move, creating yet more households at the end of the development chain on the western fringe and further massive public infrastructure costs.

What is the fate of residents of postcode 2044 in Tempe, Sydenham and St Peters-8,106 people within two kilometres of the runway, directly under the flight path; 47 per cent non-Australian born; 33 per cent below the poverty line; 46 per cent left school before 15? For them it is not just a matter of annoyance noise, it is vibration that cracks walls, and noise and kerosene from jets that seriously damages health. It is slow extermination of postcode 2044 as a residential area. Is the supposed electoral support for country members more important than this, or do minorities not matter? Have we reverted to Germany in the 1930s? I think of Australia as a liberal democracy where minorities matter and will be protected. These people would get a better deal if they were native flora and fauna.

Besides the 82,000 people living under the 20 ANEF noise contour of the environmental impact statement, there are 56 community centres and churches, 18 schools and educational facilities, and four hospitals. The medical board of Aus- tralia's largest hospital, Royal Prince Alfred, has only this week pointed out the unacceptable effect of the third runway on 51,000 patients per annum, as well as thousands of doctors, nurses and hospital staff. Yet even this is but the tip of the iceberg. In truth, over 600,000 people in Sydney will be affected to some degree by aircraft noise.

The proponents of the third runway rely on rhetoric about the importance of aviation to the Australian economy, to employment, about the benefits to tourism and the future growth of air travel. All these are undoubtedly true, but they are not at issue. All would be better served by the creation of a replacement airport at Badgerys Creek. The argument that Kingsford-Smith Airport is convenient really favours Badgerys Creek in the long term. Badgerys Creek will be more accessible and convenient to the majority of people of the greater Sydney region and the State, including Illawarra. Even now, 27 per cent of passengers do not leave the airport, and for international tourism the Badgerys Creek location is comparable to most other major cities. A railway is needed to the area in any case, and the development of the airport at Badgerys Creek offers an unprecedented opportunity for desperately needed infrastructure and employment opportunities in western Sydney.

It is unmitigated arrogance to put the convenience of a minority of Australians and even a minority of airport users in the long term above the overwhelming economic, social and environmental interests of millions of Australians. The risk of a major airline disaster is real. To deliberately exacerbate the risk by continuing the enlargement of the airport in the densest part of Sydney, adjacent to the Southern Hemisphere's largest petrochemical works, is almost criminal. Statistical evidence shows that a majority of airline disasters occur within 14 kilometres of the runway. Regrettably, a major airline disaster is inevitable, and when it comes the government of the day will U-turn instantly and get the airport out of Sydney to where it belongs.

The expansion of Kingsford-Smith Airport, which is one-third the area of any comparable airport in the world, would be a short term decision ensuring the continuation of a third rate, inefficient airport, damaging to the Australian economy and our international image. The present expensive campaign being run by selfish and vested interests by way of petitions at airports, business cards and radio advertisements is a sickening attempt to divert billions of dollars of taxpayers' funds to private profit.

On the basis of the EIS, a third runway is not justified in economic or any other terms. I urge the Government to ensure that a full public inquiry is held, as promised in both Houses of Parliament when the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act was enacted, and to make a decision, in the Prime Minister's words `for all Australians', not just the greedy minority.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crawford Ms M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on behalf of those people in our community who are the poorest, the most disadvantaged and the most marginalised. I speak, of course, of our original Australians, the Aboriginal group. Many of them who are seeking to make sense out of this, their modern world, are also seeking their identity. What does this mean? This means knowing who one is and where one comes from. Of fundamental importance to that is something which we, in modern Australia, take for granted-that is, an acknowledgment of who our birth mother happens to be.

SPEECH.PARA: I remind honourable members that from the 1930s through to the mid-1960s policies were pursued under which children were dragged from their parents, largely their mother, often simply on the basis of colour. It was believed by those people in authority, often adopting a superior point of view, that if children happened to have a little white blood in them then, of course, they should become part of this white society with no acknowledgment at all of their Aboriginal heritage, who their parents were or what may have happened to them.

To make matters even worse, we have tales now of children being dragged screaming from their mothers, of mothers being hoodwinked and not being told now what was happening. And all of this under the guise of some sort of paternalistic welfare and, even worse, undertaken by people purporting to using Christian values and Christian charity. What has happened to very many of these people? Very often they had no birth records at all and they were not registered. In fact, in good old Australian terms they fail to exist.

Their horror and the full impact of this kind of policy upon Australian society has been emerging for quite some time. What in fact it has now thrown up is a whole group of people who wish to know quite simply who they are, where they came from and a little bit about what their heritage was-surely not much to ask in a modern, wealthy Australia. But we find that the very people who at first enslaved them, dragged them away, pretended they knew what was best, are those same people who are now holding back the documents, holding back the records and not allowing this process to be pursued to the full.

Honourable members may or may not be aware of current changes to the adoption laws in Queensland which enable people to have access to information about who their natural mother was. If no objection is placed on the record, then they are able to make contact. The growth in Aboriginal identity and the development of land rights-the issues that have currently emerged throughout the 1980s-have led to the development of a program called Link, which is run in Brisbane. It attempts to establish or re-establish those ties between children and their previously unknown parents, families and others.

The full impact of this, of course, is very important in any sort of any cultural sense to the Aboriginal community because Aboriginals are largely defined by who they are related to, their family and their wide range of relations. It seems extraordinary that now that laws have enabled them to find out just who they are and who their family may be we now find that certain documents are denied to them.

Who holds these documents; what are they? Basically, many Aboriginals in central and north Queensland were taken and looked after by the Anglican Church. The Church of England ran a number of centres there. While people did not have birth certificates they were certainly registered as being baptised. A whole range of documents exists within the confines of the Anglican Church in Queensland which would enable people to make contact with their mothers if they were alive or at least with relatives, and also to make some sense and to get some value from an identity which is often at crisis point.

The very interesting point about all of this, of course, is that we now ask ourselves in whose hands lies the future of the poorest and most marginalised people in Australia. Of course, honourable members would be well aware that we have a new Anglican archbishop in Brisbane who is noted for his speeches, his concern for the poor, his concern for the marginalised, his concern for the disadvantaged.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crawford Ms M.C.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cowan Mr D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —In 1971 the Commonwealth passed back to the States the right to take over payroll tax, and today I call for a complete review of our taxation system. The payroll tax throughout Australia is an imposition, and to me it is immoral. It is a tax upon the worker, it is a tax upon industry and it is a big factor in the cost of production in Australia. Over $4 billion a year actually comes in to the coffers of the States through payroll tax, and over $2 billion of that comes into New South Wales.

SPEECH.PARA: In a climate where the economy is so bad and we are calling for micro-and macro-economic reform, surely we ought to have a look at our taxation system because it is at the foundations of many of the problems that we have. Industry has to pay a tax on the wages of every worker that it employs, and this of course goes on the cost of production. It means a lot so far as our ability to compete with other countries is concerned.

Therefore, I appeal to the Government and to the Treasurer (Mr Keating) to speak with the Treasurers and Premiers of the States and review the taxation system generally, and provide some relief from payroll tax.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I want to raise the matter of imported articles in Australia and particularly, as a new member of Parliament, the level of imported equipment given to new members by the Department of Administrative Services for their electorate office. Usually this food is inferior in quality, sometimes chemically contaminated, and not up to Australian food standards. It is always subsidised and often dumped. SPEECH.PARA: There is no country in the world that treats its farmers worse than Australia does. It is high time that the breakfast consumers of Australia were made aware of that and started recognising, when they fill their plates every morning, that Australian farmers are producing those goods.
