—My question is directed to the Prime Minister. I want to make it clear that my purpose in asking it is none other than to seek clarification from the Prime Minister on a vitally important aspect of Australian policy on the Gulf so that the Australian people are properly informed and the bipartisan approach on which the Opposition places such importance continues. I refer the Prime Minister to a report in the Sydney Morning Herald today citing a letter to him from the centre left's national convenor, Senator Beahan. I ask the Prime Minister to confirm whether he received such a letter yesterday and whether it reflected the concern of Senator Beahan and others about what they see as discrepancies between the text of the Prime Minister's statements to the House on Tuesday and his media comments following it. I also ask the Prime Minister, as I did on Tuesday, to inform the Parliament and the Australian people of any constraints which now apply to the Government's future response to the Gulf crisis as a result of internal party negotiations.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have, of course, seen the letter of Senator Beahan, and for the information of the Leader of the Opposition it is pronounced `Bee-an'. Let me say that whoever was involved in passing that letter on to the media, or a part of the media, has got it wrong. I had the opportunity of talking with Senator Beahan this morning, and Senator Beahan agrees with me that the story, as written by Ramsey--
—Who?
—Who is that?

—Do honourable members opposite say `Ram Say'? When he is writing, it could be `hearsay' or `any sort of say' but we will say Ramsey. As usual, when one gets to this gentleman, when he is talking about me, one will be lucky to get accuracy. Senator Beahan agrees with me that the account in the Ramsey story is quite inaccurate. The story says:

ANSWER.PARA: That approval was reached only after long bargaining on Monday between Mr Hawke, the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Senator Evans, and key members of the Government's three parliamentary factions. Senator Beahan insisted . . . that some form of words to this effect had to be written into Mr Hawke's statement to Parliament.

In respect of what I have read out here, Senator Beahan makes it quite clear that this is an inaccurate account of what happened. Let me give the facts to the House. I had a discussion with my colleagues in the leadership and Senator Ray and between us we, without dissent, came to the position that, as I put to the House in the statement, that should be the position of Australia, that is, the three ships.

That was the position agreed to by the leadership, including Senator Ray, with me. The representatives of the three groups came into my office on Monday morning and in a very short period of time the position which I put to those representatives was accepted by them. There was not any long argument. We put the position. It was accepted. That was then accepted by the Cabinet and then that was accepted by the Caucus. It is interesting that in the Caucus a question was raised, `Well, what if there were some requests and if the question arose about any additional forces?'. I said that, if that were to happen, we would look at it but there would be discussion. Those are the facts. The facts are that the position put by me on behalf of the Government was the position put by me with my colleagues to the groups within the Party. That was put to the Cabinet, put to the Caucus and has been accepted by the Party.

Of course, when these sorts of things are given to some sources, one can bet London to a brick that they will be perverted, as in fact they have been. It reflects very little credit at all, if any, upon the Leader of the Opposition that he should seek in a matter such as this to attempt to create some picture of diversion within the Government ranks. This was a position which was adopted across this Party. I have made it clear in the Party and in what I said after that on the radio. Our position is quite clear. We do not propose any further commitment. We do not expect any further request. But, in the unlikely event that one came forward, we would consider it.

Does the Leader of the Opposition suggest, for instance, that, if such a request came forward, we would not read it? That is the position. I repeat the three words which I believe appropriately describe the contribution of Australia-a contribution which, I may say, has been warmly and widely welcomed. It is a contribution which is significant; it is proportional and it is practical. I believe that that description of the Australian contribution is accurate. Rather than seeking to beat up something out of this letter, as one journalist has, the Leader of the Opposition would do very much better to concentrate on matters which reflect some credit on him.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Attorney-General. Can the Attorney-General please advise the House whether there has been any progress in convincing the Liberal and National parties in Western Australia to pass the important Australian Securities Commission legislation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Duffy The Hon M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for her question. Unfortunately, I can only report that I am disappointed with the response to the call yesterday for the Western Australian Liberals and Nationals to reconsider their actions. I can also report that I am disappointed with the response I received from the leadership of the Federal Liberal and National parties.
—What did you expect?

—The Prime Minister interjected, `What did you expect?' The fact is that I did expect a little better in this instance. I do believe that the honourable member for Wentworth may not have taken seriously the request that I put to him yesterday for assistance in this matter because of the enormous national significance of the issue.

ANSWER.PARA: On the matter of the passage of this legislation establishing the Australian Securities Commission, I can assure the House that I am serious in requesting assistance from both of those leaders opposite. I note today from newspaper reports that the honourable member for Higgins supports the New South Wales Premier, Mr Greiner, in wanting this nationally important legislation passed. I thank the honourable member for that.

The Deputy Leader of the Opposition, the honourable member for Flinders, also suggested that it was a matter for the Leader of the Opposition. It is interesting to note how that arose. It arose at one of those press conferences that the Treasurer refers to from time to time. In the press conference the Deputy Leader of the Opposition was referred to as `PKR'. The journalist, Laurie Oakes, asked this question:
Well, on this important matter of company regulations, are you going to approach the Western Australian Liberal Party and ask them to pass the legislation?
The Deputy Leader answered:
Laurie, I am very happy to talk about the Farrow Group if you want to talk about companies.
The journalist asked:
Why won't you talk about this, Mr Reith?
This was the answer:
Well, I think this Farrow-you reckon this is an important matter; I think it is important and my focus.
The next question was inaudible. This was the answer:

Well, I do not think it is important, but I'm quite happy to get into corporation regulations with you, Laurie, and I am inviting a few people around for drinks at half past eight tonight and I will be happy to see you there.
The journalist then asked the crucial question:
Will you or will you not approach the Western Australian Liberals?
In answer to that, the Deputy Leader said:
That is a matter for Dr Hewson.
The journalist asked:
Why?
The Deputy Leader answered:
Because he is the Leader of the Party, Laurie.
The journalist asked:
What are you talking about, company regulations now?
The Deputy Leader answered:
No, what I am talking about is the regulation or otherwise and the supervisory role of the Reserve Bank over our financial system. That is what I am talking about. I am not saying . . .
The next question was:
But are you the Deputy Leader, Mr Reith, and the shadow Treasurer and are you saying that you have no responsibility over corporations company law?
This was the answer:

Well, Laurie, you are switching your argument. You put to me that I had a responsibility on behalf of the Federal coalition to raise the question of the vote in the upper House last night in Western Australia. My response was a simple one to you and that is that the relationships between the coalition and the State parliamentary Party in Western Australia are principally the responsibility of Dr Hewson.
The journalist then asked:
Will you ask Dr Hewson to do it?
The Deputy Leader answered:
I would be very happy to talk to Dr Hewson about corporate regulation.
This was the next question:
Will you ask him to show the same courage as Mr Greiner?
The answer was:
Well, look, my discussions with Dr Hewson, Laurie, are matters between Dr Hewson and I.
The journalist asked:
Is Mr Greiner right?
The Deputy Leader replied:
Look, Laurie, if you want to buy into it, I will be very happy to discuss the matter with you.
Opposition members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! While the Minister might illustrate his answer with quotations, I do not think the whole answer should be quotation.
—I will conclude at this point, Mr Speaker. The final response from the Deputy Leader was:

ANSWER.PARA: I do not have a role in taking on Mr MacKinnon, which is the proposition you're putting to me, Laurie. The matter of parliamentary relationships, Federal and State, is essentially a matter for the Leader and the Leader is here, alive and well and quite capable of handling that issue, thank you very much.

Despite that plea by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, the only statement that I have noted from the Leader of the Opposition was a suggestion from his office that he strongly supported the legislation, but that he would not publicly tell this to the State Liberal Leader.

That is hardly the sort of role that one would expect from the national Leader of the Liberal Party. Mr Greiner put his public position and normally people in a leadership position are prepared to put a position which may or may not be accepted. Today, I again ask the Leader of the Opposition to please take some steps to get those people in Western Australia in line with the rest of this country.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Reith Mr P.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Treasurer. I refer him to part of his answer yesterday in regard to the Reserve Bank's involvement in the collapse of the Farrow group of building societies, in which he said that the Reserve Bank had advised the Victorian Government:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . to see that the problems of Pyramid Building Society did not go critical and that there were assets left which could then be sold and distributed back to depositors.

I ask the Treasurer to inform the House when the Reserve Bank gave this advice to the Victorian Government, and did his answer yesterday mean that the Reserve Bank was advising the Victorian Government to close the doors of the society while ensuring there were enough assets to ensure depositors could be paid out in the liquidation which would follow that closure?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have been over this issue in detail for the honourable gentleman, and now he is under political pressure.

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —They are like a bunch of frenzied sharks. He is under pressure. Yesterday he asked every question on behalf of the Opposition because he had had such a bad couple of months.
—Bar one.
—Bar one.
—You are misrepresenting the position.
—I misrepresented the position. That is it. So he asked every question bar one. Right oh, Clarence Darrow.
—Order! The Treasurer will refer to members by their title.

—On 13 September 1990, as appears in Hansard, I went through a series of questions which the honourable gentleman had put in a press statement. I said that I may as well answer them then, and I went through them in detail. All of the answers are there. Yesterday, again I made clear what the Reserve Bank's role was in this matter. But the fact is that this is dredging up an old matter. What relevance does it have now that it did not have when the honourable gentleman asked them last, other than to save his skin in here, other than to give him something to talk about other than something he does not have any structure in, such as national economic policy?

ANSWER.PARA: Let me make this dead clear-and if the honourable gentleman keeps asking the same question, I will refer back to this answer. Has he got that? The Deputy Governor of the Reserve Bank has informed me that the advice offered by the Bank to the Victorian Government covered such topics as the potential knock-on effects should Farrow collapse or be closed, the relative merits of moving more quickly rather than more slowly in appointing an administrator if the decision to make such an appointment was clear-and it is the role of the administrator which was relevant to the question the honourable gentleman put-the role of the Reserve Bank in liquidity support where the liquidity shortage was experienced by a non-bank entity. It did not extend to whether the Farrow group of societies belonging to it should be let go. Discussions that the Reserve Bank had with the Victorian Government officials in February related only to questions of liquidity support. In the subsequent period, discussions covered the general issues above.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Prime Minister. Can he inform the House of developments in the Uruguay Round at the meeting of trade Ministers in Brussels over the last 24 hours?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for his question. The Minister for Trade Negotiations, Dr Blewett, rang me again this morning to provide an update on negotiations at the meeting of trade Ministers in Brussels. Negotiations will continue until noon on Friday, European time, but at this point, it appears most likely that the Round will be formally suspended until next year, through the agreement of all parties, who believe that the substantial gains made in the last four years of negotiations, with the obvious exception of agriculture, should be preserved.

ANSWER.PARA: Whilst obviously I regret to inform the House of this development, at this point of time this is a better result than either, on the one hand, accepting a minimalist position that would perpetuate the present iniquitous agricultural trading practices in the European Community and in the United States into the next century or, on the other hand, abandoning the negotiations and plunging the world into completely uncertain trade in future.

There is no doubt that the failure of the Brussels meeting to finalise the Uruguay Round is due to the impasse in the agricultural negotiations. All other negotiations were predicated on the development of a balanced package which has been impossible due to the European Community's refusal to negotiate its unacceptable offer on agriculture. The question that will be canvassed over the next 12 hours is: what can be salvaged from the Brussels meeting? There are two pressing needs: first, of course, to bring the meeting to a close without undue acrimony; and secondly, and importantly, to preserve the gains made in the negotiations to date. Such an outcome from the Brussels meeting would obviously be a profound disappointment to myself, as I know it would be to all honourable members of this House.

But the Government has always maintained-and this is our position-that it would not sacrifice our fundamental interests in agriculture in any way. In this sense, we take the view that no deal is better than a bad deal. The House may be assured that the Government will continue to pursue through all possible avenues a satisfactory outcome in the Uruguay Round. We deeply regret that the timetable that had been set and which would have represented the ending of some four years of important negotiations has at this point broken down in this way.

It is important that we do everything we can, not only on our own account but also as the leader of the Cairns Group, in discussion with other like-minded nations, to try to ensure that a situation of chaos is not perpetrated upon the world by this failure. We will do everything we can to try to work towards a satisfactory outcome in the months ahead.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Fischer Mr T.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —With your indulgence, Mr Speaker, I might add that we hope that that will give France and Germany time to come clean in those important negotiations, which are of interest to many in the gallery, including persons involved in the citrus industry.

QUESTION.PARA: My question without notice is to the Prime Minister. I refer him to reports over the past few weeks about several major retrenchments in Australian industry, including 3,000 jobs to be lost at Ford Australia; 750 jobs lost at Email Ltd; 2,000 jobs to be lost at CSR Ltd; 8,000 jobs lost in Coles Myer Ltd; 1,000 jobs to be lost at the Australia and New Zealand Banking Group Ltd; 1,500 jobs already lost with the Westpac Banking Corporation; and 300 jobs already lost with BTR Nylex Ltd. Does his statement yesterday that `the Australian people should not fear the recession' apply to the workers of Ford, Email, CSR, Coles Myers, ANZ, Westpac and BTR Nylex?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Let me refer to the things this Government has done to provide opportunities for dealing with those who become unemployed. The Opposition's policy, as put at the last election and which apparently is still its position, is that one throws people on the scrap-heap if they cannot find a job in nine months. I ask Opposition members not to come to us talking about unemployment and the position of the unemployed. Their position is that they throw people on the unemployment scrap-heap after 12 months. Let us consider the situation of 1982-83, the recession that came about because of the Opposition's total incompetence and its lack of a wages policy. Throughout the Opposition's period in office, it had been not only reducing in real terms the value of unemployment benefits but it also had in place no schemes for offering training or retraining opportunities to those who were unemployed.

ANSWER.PARA: Unlike the Opposition, this Government has in place strong and active training and retraining programs and special measures to assist the older unemployed, the sort of people whom the honourable gentleman who asked the question is referring to. Without being exhaustive about those programs let me remind the House of the Newstart program which commenced in 1989 and which provides a major focus on the long term unemployed up to the age of 54. The Newstart program involves intensive interviews with the target group, seminars and information packages of employment and training opportunities, 25,000 places for training, work experience and Jobsearch programs, with emphasis on tailoring assistance to the specific needs of individuals, active job placement involving the Commonwealth Employment Service canvassing for suitable vacancies and job placement opportunities. Approximately $85m will be spent on this program in 1991. In addition, special retraining programs are available for industries where major restructuring is now taking place, for example, in textiles, clothing and footwear and in motor vehicles. In addition to those we also offer Jobsearch assistance to develop appropriate skills in finding jobs--

TALK.START.PARA: —But there are no jobs.
—Order! The honourable member for O'Connor will cease interjecting.

—We offer job training to provide particular vocational training-that will probably involve an expenditure of about $120m this year; Jobstart, involving wage subsidies to employers, costing $73m; and Skillshare, designed to offer new educational opportunities in skills, training and enterprise activities at community level, costing about $95m this year. There are also enterprise incentive schemes aimed at embryonic small business and rural education and training for the unemployed in country centres.

ANSWER.PARA: I ask the House to consider all those programs that have been put in place by this Government during a period when it has created jobs five times faster than the Opposition did when it was in office. It has created 1.6 million new jobs, 90 per cent of them in the private sector. While we have been creating jobs in this country, five times faster than the Opposition ever could, at the same time we have been increasing, where the Opposition reduced it, in real terms the assistance available to those who are unemployed. Whereas the Opposition's policy is to leave these people on the unemployment scrap-heap we have this whole range of programs and policies on which a lot of money has been expended to deal particularly with the problems of the sort of people which the honourable member referred to.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Finance aware of reports that government expenditure could be reduced by as much as $3 billion? Can he advise the House of what the impact of such expenditure cuts would be?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Willis The Hon R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of statements by the Leader of the Opposition and his shadow Treasurer that their election time proposals for expenditure cuts remain relevant and should be implemented by the Government. Firstly, their memories are rather rusty. They claim that these proposed expenditure cuts were worth $3 billion and that they remain unchallenged, in the words of the shadow Treasurer, or uncontested, in the words of the Leader of the Opposition. The fact is that they were heavily challenged and contested at the time of the last election and found to be worth far less than $3 billion.

ANSWER.PARA: The Opposition claimed that the cuts were worth $2.7 billion but I remind the House-this is simply a reminder; I am sure that everyone basically recalls this-that the Department of Finance said that the costings of these proposals show that the savings were actually worth about $800m less than the Leader of the Opposition and the shadow Treasurer claimed, that is, that they were worth less than $2 billion. Let us forget this $3 billion nonsense. They are talking about $2 billion. So much for the figures being unchallenged, uncontested or, in the words of the Leader of the Opposition, figures that no one has been able to lay a glove on. A billion dollars worth of a glove was laid on them by the Department of Finance.

It is also worth noting where the Opposition would make these savings. About one-third of those savings would come off the unemployed through reduced entitlements to the unemployment benefit and the slashing of labour market programs, such as those mentioned by the Prime Minister in the previous question, and about a third of the unemployed would be put on special benefit which has a much tighter means test than unemployment benefit. In other words, at a time of rising unemployment, the Opposition's solution to the problem is to engage in a massive onslaught on the unemployed.

I remind the House also that included amongst those savings was $300m from the States. We took $600m off the States in this year's Budget, but the Opposition says, `No, our package of expenditure cuts is still relevant; knock another $300m off the States'. Of course, the traditional soft targets it does not give a damn about, like the Aborigines and overseas aid-knock $100m off each of those. The Opposition would introduce a new tertiary fee which would cut expenditure on tertiary education by $200m by increasing costs on students enormously. That shows its concern about tertiary education!

At the same time as the Opposition is being all hairy-chested about these theoretical expenditure cuts, when it comes to the point of being confronted with making hard decisions to reduce expenditure, it wants to water them down or abandon them altogether. I recall the discussion recently in Question Time about the family allowance assets test, which the Opposition has opposed. Whilst it was opposing it, the Leader of the Opposition was still going around the country saying that he supports targeting income support payments. He said on Perth radio on 20 November:
I am concerned that what's happened over the years is that the genuinely needy have been disadvantaged by the failure to effectively target income support payments.

What unbelievable hypocrisy. That is a very good statement of what happened when the previous Government was in office, but the Leader of the Opposition gets an opportunity in relation to the family allowance assets test to show his conviction about targeting income support payments and what does he do? He goes to water and will not support it. So much for his credibility.

Another example is the deeming provisions for the pensions income test. When that went into the Senate, the Opposition wanted a higher threshold for married couples. These same people who were all hairy-chested about getting stuck into various welfare groups, when it comes to a small thing like the threshold for the deeming provisions, want a higher amount.

In relation to the liquid assets test on unemployment benefits and sickness benefits, the Opposition wanted a much wider discretionary power for the Department to exempt people from its application. When it came to the pipeline, of course, the Opposition was notoriously unable to front up to its convictions about privatising that, simply because it was unable to accept that it was first necessary to put it on a commercial basis before it could be effectively privatised.

TALK.START.PARA: —And you lost.

—The Leader of the Opposition says that the court does not agree with me. This just shows his abysmal ignorance on this subject. The fact is that the court decision in relation to the appeal by the Australian Gas Light Co. (AGL) was about the right of first refusal. It simply means--
—And you lost.
—We lost and we are appealing it. It makes no difference whatever to the proposal--

—I take a point of order. I refer you again to sections 143 and 145 of the Standing Orders. Section 143 states that questions may be put to a member, not being a Minister or Assistant Minister, relating to any Bill or motion relating to public affairs with which he is officially connected. I put to you also the ruling of Speaker Snedden on 9 September 1981, when he said, `The Minister will answer the question and not engage in irrelevancies such as contrasting the Government and the Labor Party'. What is more, he made that stick on the Minister, who was a Liberal. Section 145 says that the answer shall be relevant to the question. The Minister has not addressed any matter of Government responsibility, and in the present circumstances one would think that he would have plenty to talk about like his--
—Order! Has the honourable member for O'Connor finished on the point of order?
—I would ask that you ask the honourable member, as Speaker Snedden did of a Liberal Minister, to bring his answer to a close.
—The responsibility of the Minister for Finance is the expenditure of public money and he is commenting on the expenditure of public money.
—Oh, Mr Speaker! That is not--
—If the honourable member for O'Connor continues to interject, I will deal with him in the way that Speaker Snedden would have dealt with him.

—I was referring to the proposed privatisation of the pipeline, which I remind the House was, of course, in the Opposition's so-called economic action plan. The point I was making was that the Leader of the Opposition's claim across the table, which he has made at other times as well, is that the courts were against us on this issue and therefore that stops the privatisation. That is a nonsense. The court decision simply said that, if we had to offer right of first refusal to AGL, it would make no difference whatever to the price that we would get for the sale of the pipeline if that decision were to be maintained and our appeal were to be lost.

ANSWER.PARA: The only thing that is stopping the sale of the pipeline for an effective sum to the Australian people is the attitude of the Opposition, which is supposed to be a supporter of privatisation but which does not have the guts, when faced with the issue, to support it. We do not regard the Opposition as having anything worthwhile to say on expenditure cuts. Members of the Opposition grossly exaggerate what could be achieved by their proposed cuts. What they propose is inequitable and repugnant, and when it comes to supporting hard but rational decisions they simply do not have the guts to do it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Will the Prime Minister confirm the advice of the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy that the Government will continue its support for the minimum reserve price of 700c a kilogram for clean wool for this selling season and the next?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I adhere to the statements of my Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. As I have had cause to say before, he is the best Minister for primary industry in the history of this country, a fact widely recognised. I have total confidence in the Minister in all respects.
—Make him Treasurer.
—Give him a promotion.

—Honourable members opposite talk about possible moves on the front bench. I am in the very fortunate position, according to the Leader of the Opposition, of having a beauty. I want to quote the words of the Leader of the Opposition-very brief but very relevant to what I have had to say. The Leader of the Opposition said :

ANSWER.PARA: The Hawke Government is very professional and is probably the best front bench since World War II.
Hear, hear!

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel, and I know that honourable members will join me in welcoming the Minister's triumphant return to the chamber after his recent indisposition. I refer the Minister to reports that the Australian Defence Force (ADF) intends to conduct a survey of all members and their families next year. I ask the Minister to confirm the accuracy of these reports and, if they are accurate, inform the House of the purpose of this activity.
—The Minister might like to answer from his own place!

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bilney The Hon G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are too kind, Mr Speaker, but for the moment I will answer from here. I thank the honourable member for his question, which reflects some rumours circulating in the defence community about the purpose of the census which we propose to take. I inform the House that I have given approval for the Department of Defence to commission a census of all Defence Force members and their families, including single members and personnel serving overseas, to take place in March next year.

ANSWER.PARA: The census is for the sole purpose of designing future family support policies, to which, as you know, Mr Speaker, this Government attaches great importance. Questionnaires are to be delivered to all serving members so that they and their families can fill them out on 12 March next year in the privacy of their own homes. The census will seek information on families' housing, transport, schooling, health and employment needs. It will be conducted with the utmost respect for people's privacy and the results will be processed on an anonymous basis by the Australian Institute of Family Studies (AIFS). The AIFS, as honourable members will know, is a highly regarded independent body which understands and respects the desire of its clients for confidentiality. Family members' names will not be collected with the information they provide and people have no reason to fear that the census will compromise their privacy. Indeed, they can only gain as a result of the improved family support policies which will come out of it.

While much good work has been done since the Hamilton Review of Effect of Service Life on Spouses and the Cross report-the report of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade-including the introduction of the family support funding program and the creation of the family information and liaison staff, we are always looking at ways of easing the demands of service life. The census will help us achieve this by identifying priority areas where ADF families need more assistance.

It will also enable us to press home to the States that Defence Force families have special needs which are not currently being met and thus assist us to present a case to all levels of government for improved services for ADF families, especially in the areas of child-care, education and the employment of spouses. In conclusion, I encourage all defence families to participate in the census, and I personally guarantee that the information collected will not be abused in any shape or form.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories approached State governments to have the State governments endorse the Federal Government's guidelines for the development of pulp and paper projects? Does the Government consider it necessary to have common guidelines applying throughout the country? What response has been received from the Tasmanian Government to the Federal guidelines? Has the Tasmanian Government endorsed the Federal guidelines or offered any alternative proposal? If the Tasmanian Government has not bound itself to the published Federal guidelines, does the Minister agree that any new proposal for a pulp and paper plant in that State could again be used for political expedience by radical conservation groups? Will the Federal Government approve any proposal that conforms with its own guidelines?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kelly The Hon R.J.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: THE ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for his question. I do not know whether the Tasmanian Government is adopting the Federal guidelines for pulp mills. But I do think that it is important that all States and the Commonwealth adopt very similar guidelines for development projects, particularly in relation to environmental assessment procedures. That has been one of the great initiatives of the Prime Minister in the new partnership. Honourable members may not be aware that, as a result of the Premiers Conference, there was an environmental declaration at the end of that Conference. It has now set the processes going to try to get agreed standards for environmental assessment procedures, guidelines for development and standards for water and air quality. I think that the development of a pulp mill would fit into those sorts of discussions that are being undertaken.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Transport and Communications. Has the decision on foreign ownership limits for commercial broadcasters contributed to the current state of the Australian television industry?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for his question. A number of statements have been made by the Leader of the Opposition and others generally in the context of micro-economic reform which suggest that the Government's refusal to bend rules in relation to foreign ownership in the broadcasting area is, in some way, responsible for its existing state and, in terms of a micro-economic reform program, ought to be changed to permit higher levels of foreign ownership.

ANSWER.PARA: I myself have doubts as to whether broadcasting is sensibly included within the area of micro-economic reform, in exactly the same way as telecommunications, the transport sector and the waterfront unquestionably are, and whether these particular alterations in the broadcasting area add to the national economy, as opposed to serving other particular objectives which also ought to be of importance to honourable members.

Be that as it may, it does not seem to me to be any part of a micro-economic reform process to allow owners to escape the consequences of poor investment decisions, excessive demands and wages in staffing areas and the payment of extraordinary sums, in this case, to foreign producers, by going outside what has been a time-honoured framework of the ownership structure in the broadcasting industry.

One of the networks that raised the interest of the Government in the foreign ownership provisions did so because it was already well in excess of 40 per cent foreign ownership-and, on some interpretations, over 50 per cent-without that curing its particular problems. So quite clearly the issue of foreign ownership in that particular instance was not resolving the problems that it was confronting.

It has to be understood by honourable members that the broadcasting sector has experienced extraordinary increases in revenue until this year-well above the inflation rate. In 1988-89, from recollection, it was something like 17 per cent. I recollect 1988-89 for the purposes of this argument because in that same year there was an adjustment in what was paid for foreign product on Australian commercial television stations, from $126m in the previous year to something more than $250m. That suggests a bargaining process of which absolutely nobody here ought to approve.

As a result of these sorts of decisions and the well known extraordinary salaries that have been paid out in the broadcasting area until recently, obviously adjustment is bound to have to occur. It ought not be thought, however, that because that adjustment ought to occur, it should be able to be escaped by changing what is a reasonable limit on broadcasting ownership-a limit which is not only applicable in this country but which other countries themselves have also seen fit to impose.

The United States, for example, imposes a 20 per cent limit on foreign ownership of American broadcasting, even though the United States has infinitely more broadcasting outlets than Australia. The Canadians impose a 25 per cent limit on ownership of foreign broadcasting. Most European nations have limits, but these days those limits have been compromised not in the context of the change of foreign ownership policy so much as changes taking place within the structure of the European Economic Community. Otherwise there are quite stringent rules related to foreign ownership.

The reasons for the existence of these rules today are the same as those in Bob Menzies' time. The position that he used to argue at that time was that national broadcasting was absolutely central to the development of a national culture. With an ownership structure dominated by foreign interests, it is not sensible to argue that that will not be compromised. It is true that limits could be imposed on foreign broadcasters, on Australian content and all the rest of it, but the fact of the matter is that if a country's television stations are owned substantially by foreign production houses or outfits with an interest in foreign production, whatever particular rules are in place in relation to Australian content, those rules will not be permitted to operate in such a fashion that the Australian product is competitive with theirs elsewhere around the globe.

We have one or two advantages as a small nation. One of those happens to be that we are English speaking. In broadcasting, in the cultural area, that is an enormous advantage. It gives us an opportunity, if we develop good Australian product, to have a capacity for the development of a substantial export market-which is again a fundamental issue across the board of our economy in the area of micro-economic reform.

Indeed, over the past five or six years-despite anything I might have to say about the way in which the owners of our broadcasting industry, until recently, have conducted themselves-a notable series of achievements have been racked up by Australian production houses in being able to export Australian product. That is to be encouraged. It will not be encouraged if their competitors are permitted to own the broadcasting outlets of this country. That is why the Government put in place and reinforced those limits which had existed for most of the period that the Opposition was in office and until the conclusion of that period. We put that rule in place both because of the very great significance of the broadcasting industry to our national culture and the possibilities it offers us of operating elsewhere.

Reasonable criticism might be levelled at that if other people did things differently. As I indicated earlier in the answer, other people are in a much stronger position, both in terms of the strength of their national broadcasting production industries, such as the United States, and in terms of the numbers of outlets that they have-at least at this stage in the television area, for example, television access to the spectrum is a finite resource; it is not unlimited-to impose their limits for exactly the same sorts of reasons that I have outlined here.

The question of foreign ownership has absolutely no part in the micro-economic reform agenda in the way in which the Opposition Leader argues it has. The micro-economic reform agenda has a position in so far as it encourages the export of Australian product in the way in which I have outlined.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct a question to the Prime Minister. In the light of the announcement he has just made about the seeming collapse of the agricultural round within the Uruguay Round of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT) now under way in Brussels, will he instruct his Minister for Trade Negotiations to consult with other members of the Cairns Group in an effort to ensure that there might be a refusal to accept that part of the Uruguay Round, which apparently is in agreement, if there should be a private deal between the United States and the European Community on agriculture? Secondly, in the light of the apparent failure of that agriculture round, will he initiate discussions with other members of the Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation group to consider whether or not it might now be desirable for APEC to become more than just a regional body consulting on general matters of economic consequence and perhaps an economic group with free trade barriers and other customs exemptions?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the right honourable member for New England for that important question. As to the first part, I think the right honourable gentleman would agree with the position that the Government has taken to this point-and it has been common in the Cairns Group-that we should not be talking about a walk out and denying operability in other areas of actual or potential agreement. It would not have been appropriate to do that at this stage, but increasingly as we have come up to this point there have had to have been indications made much more firmly, and we have made them, that, as far as we are concerned and the Cairns Group is concerned, the negotiation of an acceptable outcome in agriculture is sine qua non for any agreement at all. We are not going to have a situation where there can be side deals and satisfactory arrangements made between some groups. The right honourable member mentioned the United States and possibly Europe. We have made it clear, and our colleagues in the Cairns Group have made it clear, that if we are not satisfied in that area then, as I have put it in an earlier answer, no agreement is better than a bad agreement.

ANSWER.PARA: Let me pick up, while still answering the first part of the right honourable gentleman's question, his reference to the United States. I am very pleased to be able to say to the right honourable gentleman that, despite the apprehensions that some people may have had earlier in the processes that the United States may not have adhered to the strong position of reform and meaningful reform in regard to agriculture, the Minister for Trade Negotiations, Dr Blewett, reports to me that the United States has stayed absolutely firm. There has not been any suggestion that it would be doing other than adhering to the position which it has discussed with us and which it has put forward in the negotiations. On the basis of all that has been said, I would expect that to remain its position.

I come to the second part of the question that was put by the right honourable gentleman-and again, it is an important question. When I initiated the APEC group, which the right honourable gentleman will recall was in January of last year in Seoul, I made it clear then, because we were very, very much into the guts of the Uruguay Round, that this was not intended to be a grouping of a trade bloc type but rather that we saw this as having as one of its original motivations and causes the bringing together of that group of nations around the Asia-Pacific rim, which would espouse and advance in the Uruguay Round and elsewhere the cause of freed-up international trade.

I did indicate at one stage, as the right honourable gentleman may recall-I was not saying that is what would happen-back in 1989 that if one took the worst case scenario that the Uruguay Round turned out to be unsuccessful, then it may be in those circumstances that we would have to look in this group in a way whereby together we may be able to pool our interests.

So I say to the right honourable gentleman-and I do accept the seriousness of his question-that, as I have said, in that worst case scenario I had flagged that possibility before. But I do want to repeat now-and I think the honourable gentleman will agree with me-that it still remains preferable from Australia's point of view that we do what we can to try to get a successful outcome from the Uruguay Round. But it is quite clear that, if we take now the most pessimistic view-that it breaks down completely and we are not able to revive it at the political level-the sort of thing that the right honourable gentleman referred to will have to be among the options that we look at.

If we look at what is happening on the other side of the Pacific, there is the agreement between the United States of America and Canada. As the right honourable gentleman will know, currently, obviously, very serious negotiations are going on between the United States of America and Mexico. Noises were made to us relatively early in the life of our Government as to whether Australia would be interested in that sort of arrangement. I do not want to overstate that; it was just an idea that was floated. I put the position very firmly then that we did not see it as appropriate then because we were wanting to make the Uruguay Round a success. But the right honourable gentleman is absolutely right in the implicit premise of his question that if, as a result of the intransigence, particularly of the Europeans, the world is plunged into the insanity of a system not based upon totally international free trade and the world goes into the blocs and groups, the only responsible thing in those circumstances, which I trust will not occur, is for Australia to look to its interests; they may be of the kind that the right honourable gentleman suggested, but there may be others.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Science and Technology. Can the Minister inform the House of the objectives of the housing industry development strategy agreed to at a meeting of Ministers yesterday? Can he tell us how that strategy will be pursued and what the implications are for Australian home buyers?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Crean The Hon S.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for her question, particularly given her deep interest in the area of providing affordable quality housing for Australians. The meeting yesterday was a very significant one, and by all measures also an historic one because for the first time it brought together Ministers at State and Commonwealth level responsible for the spheres of government that cover planning as well as housing, and it also involved local government. So the three spheres of government were involved.

ANSWER.PARA: The approach of the meeting was to try to develop this target, this goal, that we have set for ourselves of quality affordable housing from both an economic and a social perspective. It is important that we recognise the significance of the different spheres being involved, as well as the different dimensions of the problem. The meeting itself took place against the background of some significant initiatives that this Government has taken: the Prime Minister's initiative in terms of the new approach to Commonwealth-State relations and the new cooperation that has come from the States in that regard; the initiative of the Minister for Community Services and Health, who has been advocating since he took responsibility for that portfolio the need for an urban development and infrastructure strategy; and the initiative of my colleague the Minister for Local Government, who has been a strong advocate for involving local government in these discussions.

My responsibility-this is the specific point of the question that the honourable member has asked-goes to the role that my portfolio responsibilities involve, that is, ensuring that we have an effective industry development strategy that makes sure that from a cost or supply side of the equation we are contributing to the lowering of costs for both land and housing to ensure this goal of quality affordable housing.

The industry development strategy that was yesterday unanimously agreed by Ministers to be pursued was one in which we should try to make the industry itself more efficient, more competitive and more flexible. I say `more' because it does have to be acknowledged that in the house building industry there is already considerable flexibility by virtue of the numbers of players and their ability to respond to the level of house commencements. But I say that what has tended to happen in the past is that this flexibility has tended to be a reactive one-one that has simply reacted to what has happened or to what was about to happen rather than one that tried to anticipate better and prepare accordingly.

Our approach is to try to ensure that, within the industry development strategy, the industry itself takes a more forward looking stance; that it commits itself to more effective research and development, as does the housing industry in other countries; that it looks at mechanisms for the recycling of products used in the construction industry; that it looks at the circumstances in which energy efficiency can be introduced into the housing market; and that it looks at means by which building materials and processes can be delivered more cheaply and effectively.

This has significance not only from the point of view of lowering costs here, but also, if we get it right, because it means that we have the capacity to sell the services and the product overseas. So it has potential not just for cost reduction here, but for net export growth as well.

That is the direction that we are seeking to get the industry to take. It is very important to acknowledge the framework that the Government has established to facilitate this, because we have been mindful that there are circumstances over which the housing industry does not have control which make it difficult to plan in this framework.

As a result of the Special Premiers Conference on housing some two years ago, we set out to better establish the database upon which industry could respond. The statistics that have come from the Indicative Planning Council for the housing industry have been acknowledged by all States to be top quality statistics. What we have now asked the States and what they have agreed to do--

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. The Minister will sit down.
—Order!

—The point of order I take is that questions shall not ask a Minister to announce government policy. It is clear that the Minister in his answer is doing just that. It is also a subject that should be dealt with by statement. As you know, on a six-year comparison, the number of statements made has dropped from 513 to 267.
—Order! The honourable member for O'Connor will resume his seat.
—I would love to ask a question; so would some members on the other side.
—I warn the honourable member for O'Connor. The Minister will continue with his answer.

—The purpose of this response is not to announce government policy but to indicate the level of agreement that we can get from States-including States that are governed by people from the Opposition's parties-if we develop a sensible framework. We got that agreement yesterday, and it needs to be understood against the background in which it was obtained.

ANSWER.PARA: Before I was interrupted, the point I was making was that we have provided a better statistical base to the extent that the States are now prepared to indicate to us, because it is their responsibility, the basis upon which they will release land over the next five years, to attempt to contain the spiralling costs of land that are consequent upon the peaks and troughs that industry has experienced in the past. I think that is a very important development. To the extent to which we can control more effectively the release of land supply over which the States have control, we can contain the costs.

The other area over which this Government has established certainty is the review of the regulatory environment in which the construction and planning industry has to operate. The figures suggest that if we can streamline this process, there will be a saving of $1 billion, which is not insignificant in terms of benefits to home buyers and people in the construction industry.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister might streamline his answer.
—The strategy will improve the quality of housing and the range of choices available, and I thank the honourable member for her question.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Small Business and Customs. When will the Minister show his commitment to small business by making a decision on the 21 recommendations relating to taxation issues made by the parliamentary committee examining the problems of small business? I refer the Minister in particular to the recommendations concerning rollover capital gains tax, trading stock valuation adjustment scheme, income averaging, company and provisional tax, and employee share acquisition schemes.
—We want an indicative answer.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Beddall The Hon D.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member would not have any indications about small business. I thank the honourable member for McEwen for her question. I start off by saying that this Government is the first government to have a comprehensive policy formula for small business. The report that was brought down by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology, which I had the pleasure of chairing, brought together a whole range of issues that really did address medium and long term issues for the small business sector.

ANSWER.PARA: In the response that was tabled only a couple of weeks ago in Parliament, we have now set in train a whole range of mechanisms to get the priorities of the small business sector. Last Thursday in Melbourne we had a meeting of the Small Business Forum, which is 19 organisations representing the small business sector.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Minister will resume his seat. The honourable member for Deakin on a point of order.
—Standing order 145 states quite clearly that an answer shall be relevant. The question asked was quite specific, and the Minister is dealing in generalities.
—Order! The Minister is answering the question. The honourable member for Deakin will resume his seat.

—As I was saying, we had a meeting of the Small Business Forum in Melbourne last Thursday at which the organisations present listed their priorities as people who represent the small business sector. Next week we will have a meeting in Canberra for the first time of all the State Ministers who have responsibility for the small business sector. That is about as cooperative an approach-not just a knee-jerk reaction-as one can get. The only time we hear this Opposition talk about small business is when there is a recession or a downturn. In the interim, it does nothing about it; it does not care about the small business sector. This Government does. It has a comprehensive policy that will address all the issues raised in the report.

—I address my question to the Minister for Land Transport. Is he aware of the Bureau of Industry Economics forecast of a $6 billion boost to gross domestic product (GDP) from micro-economic reform? Is he also aware of a Business Council of Australia estimate that two-thirds of the advantages of micro-economic reform will come from land transport? What action has been taken to reform land transport?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I appreciate the question that has been asked by the honourable member for Eden-Monaro. I am aware of both those reports and I am pleased as well that both of them tend to confirm an earlier report or study which was undertaken by the Industries Assistance Commission in 1988. The last report of the Industries Assistance Commission before it was revamped into the Industry Commission also confirmed that and indicated that if Australia was able to achieve world best standards in terms of general operating costs, we should be able to achieve an increase in national gross domestic product each year of something like 3 per cent within the transport sector alone. Those people who understand the significance of that will realise that as a result of GDP currently being in excess of $300 billion a year, that would represent an increase to GDP of something in excess of $10 billion from one sector alone.

ANSWER.PARA: That is the type of improvement in GDP that Australia has traditionally depended upon to be provided by the growth within the whole economy. We can achieve that within transport alone. It was suggested that, as a result of the reforms that can be introduced and reforms which are being pursued by this Government, in the area of land transport alone the amount would be something like $6.5 billion; in the area of rail transport, we could achieve something like $2.5 billion; and in road transport, it would be something like $4 billion.

Those are some of the reasons why we have been pursuing the types of reforms which the honourable member opposite obviously had in mind when he asked that question. There are two particular reasons. The first one, which I am pleased to be able to enumerate and which, I am sure, the Leader of the National Party in particular appreciated and applauded, is the fact that, when the Prime Minister met with the Premiers and the Chief Ministers at the Special Premiers Conference, they showed even greater initiative and commitment towards the purposes that could be achieved than their own transport Ministers. This was obvious when they very positively endorsed the concept of a National Rail Freight Corporation and, with the Prime Minister, entered into and signed a heads of agreement as an indication of their very firm commitment.

The second reason is that at the Special Premiers Conference an agreement was reached by the Premiers, together with the Prime Minister, to pursue at least the principles that were contained in the Inter-State Commission report into economic pricing of the road asset and sensible economic cost recovery. Some of those principles, of course, have been very significantly embraced, and the Premiers themselves acknowledged that the three essential elements of that particular approach would include, in the first place, a national registration scheme for all heavy vehicles, as part of that reform process.

They also recognised-and this has been very warmly welcomed by the land transport industry and all of the operators in it-that for the first time we would pursue and hopefully secure uniform operational and technical regulations for the whole of Australia throughout the industry. The third essential element of that approach was the one that I have referred to where they agreed that there would be economic pricing based on full cost recovery.

The other matter that I would like to emphasise is that, as far as we were concerned-and this has been one of the elements of the Government's approach which a number of people have misrepresented, for reasons best known to themselves-we insisted that the whole of the exercise should be based on revenue neutrality. That is, that out of that exercise there would not be, as far as we could possibly ensure, one extra cent taken from the road transport industry. We would ensure that, based on economic cost recovery and economic pricing, we would put into place an arrangement where, for the first time ever, we would be able to take road pricing, funding and programming out of the Budget cycle, the election cycle and partisan politics and place it firmly and comprehensively on an economic basis.

I would have thought and hoped that that would secure a bipartisan approach. I know it would be supported by the Leader of the National Party and, I hope, by many of his colleagues-the honourable member for Lyne, for example, who speaks frequently on the question of road programming and road funding, and his colleagues from the coast of New South Wales who have expressed concern about the Pacific Highway. If those honourable members are prepared to support this, as the State Premiers and the Chief Ministers of the Territories have been prepared to support the Prime Minister, we will put that into place for the first time. If we put that into place not only will we be able to achieve a level of efficiency within the road transport industry and the general land transport area but, as the honourable member for Eden-Monaro quite correctly indicates, we will also be able to bring major dividends to the Australian people and the national community. Those major dividends could be in excess of $10 billion every year.

The opportunities are there and we will be pursuing them, I hope, in a bipartisan way. I also hope that members of the Opposition will prevail on some of their less responsible colleagues, particularly those in the Senate and in Queensland, not to misrepresent the essence of the objectives which are being pursued in that area because, if they continue to do that, those objectives may not be achieved. But we will continue to pursue them and I endorse the decision that the Prime Minister was able to arrive at with those Premiers and Chief Ministers.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member might just say where he was misrepresented.
