DEBATE.TITLE: RELEASE OF COMMITTEE EVIDENCE AND RECORDS

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to the resolution of the House of Representatives on 11 October 1984, I present a report on the release of evidence and records of House of Representatives and joint committees for the period 5 June 1987 to 5 December 1990.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from the honourable member for Flinders (Mr Reith) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The persistent failure of the Government to give a clear, honest and realistic assessment of the state of the Australian economy.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reith Mr P.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have analysed the last seven speeches given by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) on matters of public importance. On every occasion, without exception, he starts with personal abuse of the person who raises the matter of public importance and, almost without fail, on each and every occasion, he finishes with personal abuse. The content of the speeches virtually always follows the same line. He says that all Australia's problems are the fault of somebody else, that the coalition's policies are all wrong and usually that he is one of the world's great Treasurers, busily building a better Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: We in Australia have been riding a world boom for virtually the whole time that this Government has been in office. During that whole time he has been misleading the Australian electorate about the state of our economy. I think it has been only in the last 12 or 18 months that many people have started to realise that there is a huge gap between what the Treasurer says and what is actually happening in the real world. Obviously, he cannot and will not concede this point, but the fact is that the Treasurer is the `Mr Recession' of Australian politics and basically his political career is finished. The public will not wear a Treasurer who engineers a recession and then has the arrogance to stand here and say that this is a recession that we had to have. Does the Treasurer know what people will do to him? They will use a traditional Labor tactic. He will be the Laurie Brereton of Federal politics.

The honourable member for Chifley (Mr Price) was right. He got a free market award last night in the Labor Caucus awards. He ran three dinner functions. For one, the charge was $65; that was to be in the presence of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). For the second, the price was $750; that was to be in the presence of the Minister for Transport and Communications (Mr Beazley). The third function-guess who was the guest?-was free.

This is not a good recession; there is no such thing as a good recession. These are not beautiful numbers. The fact is that this recession, the Treasurer's recession, is a personal tragedy for tens of thousands of Australians. Many factors have contributed to this recession, but one of the most obvious is the persistent refusal by the Treasurer to give the Australian people a realistic, honest and fair assessment of our economy. He persistently misleads people on the fundamental data.

Today I am releasing some examples of how this man has consistently misled people on those basics. I challenge the Treasurer to give me a detailed response to each and every example that I raise. I say to those in the gallery, those who are interested in the substance of the debate rather than the perception, that they ought to assess the Treasurer's performance on the basis of the detailed responses that he gives when I sit and he stands.
Let us look at Keating claim No. 1. He said on 22 March 1990:
We won't let there be a recession.

That is one of the most arrogant statements ever made by a Federal Treasurer. Of course, as everybody knows, the September quarter revealed a 1.6 per cent fall in gross domestic product. That was the second largest fall since 1959 and probably since World War II. Now the Treasurer comes in here and says, `It's the recession we had to have'. Keating claim No. 1 is wrong. What about Keating claim No. 2? He said on--

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member should refer to members by their appropriate title.
—Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. The Treasurer said:

SPEECH.PARA: High interest rates are behind us.
On 2 November 1990 he said:
We don't have high interest rates now.

The truth is that we will continue to have high interest rates whilst we have the massive current account deficit problems that confront us. It misleads people to tell them that the days of high interest rates are over; they are not. As a supplementary to that argument, the truth is also that, yes, the Government had a lucky break in respect of inflation, and, yes, I understand, I think it is fair enough, that the Government ought to do all it can to break inflationary expectations in this country. But the fundamentals are that we have had a high inflation economy for a long time and when we have high inflation, we will continue to have high interest rates. So the Treasurer's claim No. 2, about high interest rates being behind us, is simply wrong.
The Treasurer's claim No. 3, on 20 November 1990, was:
Our inflation rate is, as you know, one percentage point below the OECD average.

That is a very misleading claim, because the comparisons that he uses are simply wrong. Australia's inflation performance of 6 per cent in the September quarter is actually worse than the average of the seven major Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) countries, their average being 5 per cent in the September quarter. The Treasurer's use of the average inflation rate for the total OECD-that is, 7 per cent for the 12 months to September, compared with Australia's 6 per cent-hides much more than it reveals, because that total figure is boosted by the inclusion of very high inflation figures from places such as Turkey, Portugal, Iceland and others. It is much more relevant to compare Australia's performance with that of our major trading partners in the OECD. The Treasurer's claim No. 3 is wrong.

The Treasurer's claim No. 4-and he has repeatedly made this claim over the years-is that this country's debt problems are due to `30 years of coalition indolence'. That is not true. If we go back to 1972, at the end of the great Menzies years-and the Treasurer ought not dare to compare himself with Sir Robert Menzies-we find that in October of that year, Australia actually had a current account surplus. In 1972-73 we had a $754m surplus, and in October we had a surplus of $90m-odd. Compare that with the October 1990 deficit of $1.2 billion. Last year we had a record current account deficit of $21 billion. At the end of this term, the Treasurer's lot will have been in office for 13 out of the last 20 years. By and large, most of the problems that we have got today are as a result of the Treasurer's economic policies. The Treasurer's claim No. 4 is wrong.
The Treasurer's claim No. 5, on 20 November, was:
Factor productivity is really at or above the OECD average.

Any fair assessment would reveal that claim to be wrong. If the Treasurer wants a fair assessment, he should go to his own advisers in the Industry Commission and to its 1988-89 annual report, which says:
Australia's productivity growth rates have not been impressive compared with other countries, particularly in the decade since 1979.

The Treasurer should go on to the further detailed analysis and look at the fact that in the public sector productivity in Australia is about half that of the OECD average-one of the areas crying out for reform, one of the areas where there is tremendous potential to turn around this country's economic performance. So the Treasurer's claim No. 5 is demonstrably wrong.
The Treasurer's claim No. 6, on 20 November, was:
Now it is worth recalling that when the Government came to office Commonwealth outlays were 30.5 per cent of GDP. This year they are about 23.7 per cent.

Honourable members should ask themselves what was left unsaid. What was left unsaid is that the Treasurer is a cutter of the States' expenditure but not a cutter of his Commonwealth own purpose expenditure. Look at the figures. In 1989-90, as a percentage of gross domestic product, Commonwealth own purpose expenditure was 18.8 per cent. What was it when this lot came into office? It was 18.9 per cent. In other words, there has been virtually no change whatsoever. This claim about the Treasurer's tremendous capacity on fiscal policy is absolute nonsense. The Treasurer's claim No. 6 is clearly wrong.
The Treasurer's claim No. 7 was:
. . . we have had a secondary monetary policy operated by banks of the credit squeeze variety which has exacerbated this slowdown and in part has caused it to be called a recession.
He went on-and I emphasise these words:
I might lament that, but I can't do much about it.

The Treasurer made those remarks on 4 December. But on the very same day he said that he purposefully engineered the recession. He blamed the banks for creating it and then said there was not much he could do about it. I do not know how that squares with statements that this was the recession that Australia had to have and his astonishing claim that:
. . . this is not a condition beyond control. It is a condition, in fact, engineered by the Government.
The Treasurer cannot say that he is in control, also blame the banks and then say that there is not much he can do about it. The Treasurer's claim No. 7 is clearly wrong.
Claim No. 8 is a doozey-it really shows the competence of this man! On 4 December a journalist put a question to the Treasurer:
But the reason your balance of payments is much better than you thought it was is because the activity levels are much lower than you anticipated.
In other words, we have a recession so we are not having the imports we expected; it is a pretty simple proposition. The Treasurer's answer was:
But what has that got to do with the current account?

What an incredible statement! For heaven's sake-that is the Treasurer's policy. That is what that means. The Treasurer's policy was to engineer a slow down that became a recession. What unbelievable incompetence! If I said that, I would be hounded out of Canberra-and rightly so. The Treasurer will be hounded out of Canberra for his incompetence. So claim No. 7 is simply wrong.
Honourable members will remember the Treasurer's next claim:
Let me remind you that Nobby's savings bank went insolvent in 1986 and was saved by the banks subsidy introduced by me.

What an abuse of office that was. That claim was wrong and it shows the Treasurer for the sort of person that he is. That was the week that was he practising Prime Minister; it was not a good week. He ought to stop carrying that baton around in his back pack because it is a dead weight for him. That claim was clearly wrong.
The next claim by the Treasurer was:

If we don't touch the budget any further, or the forward estimates we've published, in two years' time the spending of the Commonwealth of Australia will be the same level it was in GDP (terms) the first year Robert Menzies came to office in 1950.

TALK.START.PARA: —True or false?

—That is false. His own people do not even have the data going back to 1950; it is just a nonsense. I have given the Treasurer that material and he has never come back with a response. Why? Because he does not have one.
—I did yesterday.

—I do not want him to give us that table out of the Budget Papers because it is hardly worth the paper it is written on. He should read the comments of his own Treasury officials in the Senate Estimates committee in the last month or so which show that point. That claim was clearly and demonstrably wrong.

SPEECH.PARA: The Treasurer's next claim was:
We've now got a profit share greater than any time in the nation's history-this very day. This very day, and a wage share and GDP back at the 1950s levels.

That claim is wrong. I have given the Treasurer the papers. Let us see him stand up here and give us a detailed response. He should forget the personal abuse and actually stand here and meet the challenge. On that claim: wrong. What a cruel hoax it has been to the average worker that the Treasurer claims to represent. He reckons that he has boosted profits and investment and that that means jobs for people. Obviously it does not. The J-curve never worked, we have never seen it and never will under his policies. On that claim the Treasurer is wrong.
When the Treasurer was interviewed on the October balance of payments, the following exchange took place:
Journalist: Mr Keating, are you concerned that imports are rising on a daily basis even when that (LNG) tanker is taken out?
Treasurer: Well, I am not sure that is right, Steve; I'm not sure that is right.

Well, as a matter of fact, Steve, you were right and he was wrong. One of the concerns about that last set of figures is the simple fact that on a daily basis, whether the tanker is in or out, endogenous imports actually went up.

Whether it is that claim, the claims about the consumption tax, the bank bashing exercise or the claims about capital stock, the fact is that year after year this Treasurer has misled the Australian people. I call on the Treasurer to stand now, defend himself and give us a decent response and not the personal abuse he usually starts and finishes with.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, the first five minutes of the speech by the shadow Treasurer (Mr Reith) was devoted to what he claims I specialise in, personal abuse.
—Now let us hear you.
—Order! The honourable member for Mayo!

—That is what his first five minutes were about-how much per head people were paying to hear someone else and it was free for me, et cetera. I will tell the Opposition what this little exercise is about today. Yesterday, the shadow Treasurer asked every question bar one. Today, not one question was asked on the economy, not one-and this is the major issue. The fact is, the shadow Treasurer is dead meat and over the summer when the cricket is on the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) will give the shadow Treasurer the coup de grace. The shadow Treasurer will quietly slip into the history of the Liberal Party-another shadow Treasurer who bites the dust. That is what is in store for him.

SPEECH.PARA: We saw him at his best the other day in the press conference. We saw the shadow Treasurer the other day when he was telling us we had to cut outlays by $3 billion, and under three minutes worth of questioning he had already given the $3 billion away. I mean, he is such a big, tough he-man when it comes to fiscal policy; after four or five minutes, he had to give the $3 billion away.
Mr Reith interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, he was heard in silence.
—Order! The Deputy Leader of the Opposition!

—The Deputy Leader of the Opposition was quoting me. He spent the whole of his speech quoting me. Of course, the transcript of his press conference was indecipherable for anybody interested in public policy. The shadow Treasurer went to a press conference, journalists asked him questions, and they came away. The press transcript was indecipherable. He does not even understand what the terms mean.

SPEECH.PARA: Today the shadow Treasurer's principal thing is that we have misled the electorate. Members of the Opposition are still smarting over the fact that even with 20 per cent interest rates we beat them; they cannot get over how they did not nail the Government in these conditions. Now they are going back over it, thinking about where they went wrong and what we had to say, and the shadow Treasurer says that we must have been misleading.

The fact of the matter is the Government won the election because it is the only party in Australia with a policy structure, and that is absolutely as clear as day today as it was during the election campaign. That is basically what rankles the shadow Treasurer. I have no intention of going over the propagandising of the shadow Treasurer-none. He just does not understand the things. I will go through some of it. He said the profit share was wrong.

TALK.START.PARA: —Go through all of them.
—I warn the honourable member for Mayo.

—The shadow Treasurer said that the profit share was wrong. The national accounts which came out last week show that the profit share is well higher than the last 25-year average, slightly down from 1988-89. Does the shadow Treasurer dispute that fact or not? That was in the national accounts last week.
—It is unbelievable. You do not understand the debate.

—There is the stupid reply-I do not understand the debate. I have said to the shadow Treasurer that the profit share of the national accounts of last week showed profits still this year well above the average of the last 25 to 30 years. Yet the reply of the shadow Treasurer-his inane reply-is that I do not understand the debate. That will give the House some idea of what he is about. He does not understand that.

SPEECH.PARA: Then he referred to outlays to gross domestic product (GDP) and said that the Budget Papers were hardly worth the paper they were written on. He relies upon what a Treasury officer said in the Senate about outlays to GDP, about whether they are on the basis of the Department of Finance or on a national accounts basis after the early 1970s. He said that that was the point, a differentiating point, by a Treasury official. The shadow Treasurer relies upon that but the Budget Papers, that is, the tabulations which are worked over by the Department of Finance and by the Treasury year in year out, he says are hardly worth the paper they are written on.

Do honourable members know why the shadow Treasurer says that? He says that because the Budget Papers show that in two years time this Government will have outlays of the Commonwealth at the average of the 1950s or below, and that galls him. He makes this puny, spurious claim about outlays, saying that they are different now because then they had the income and outgoings of telecommunications, then the post office; he says that that is now off. Those tables are adjusted for the ons and offs. I will tell the Opposition one thing they are not adjusted for, and that is Medicare.

Medicare is an on, and it is still in there in the outlays. Even with Medicare in we are likely to have outlays lower than the average of the 1950s. Why try to deny the Government that achievement? Why try to deny Australia that achievement? But that is what the Opposition is about. The Opposition is basically never about owning up to the fact that it left us with a bloated government sector, which we have run back to one of the smallest public sectors in the world, and that is why we get the commendations from almost any international visitor to Australia on our effort on fiscal policy. I get asked about it by every finance Minister around the place. The Economic Planning Advisory Council (EPAC) media release of 14 November states:
Australia's general government sector is small.
-The share of general government expenditure in the Australian economy is low compared to most OECD countries.

-Australia has substantially lower but more targeted social welfare transfers; but even excluding such transfers, government expenditure in recent years has been below the level of most OECD countries . . . and getting smaller
-In recent years, government outlays have been declining proportionally more in Australia than in most OECD countries.

It goes on and states that government is becoming more efficient. There have been significant improvements in program effectiveness. That is what EPAC has to say about it, and yet we have these sorts of inane political remarks dressed up as argument so that I am supposed to say, `Oh, the shadow Treasurer has some conceptual grasp of outlays to GDP, which is better than the Treasury or the Department of Finance, and that seven years of work, of cutting $28 billion on a national accounts basis out of the outlays, all went for nothing; it was all a fiction of someone's imagination'. I am supposed to get up and answer this stuff. This is the performance of the shadow Treasurer; this is his last throw of the dice on economic policy before the curtains come down on the parliamentary year and before, of course, the curtain comes down on him. And this is the best he can do.

`No change whatsoever in Commonwealth outlays', he says. He then refers to my claim about factor productivity which, as I said, was at or above the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) average. He then says that is wrong and what he then refers to is the Industries Commission report, which refers to the fact that Australia's productivity performance can be improved. Of course it could but it does not mean to say that it is not at or above the OECD average, which it has been. That is supposed to be another telling remark.

Then I said that a secondary monetary policy was operated by the banks. He said that I am now blaming the banks for what has happened. I never blamed the banks at all. What I said was the Government took responsibility for its policies but that after deregulation it was not possible for the Commonwealth to put a quantitative control on money. We cannot run a credit squeeze. The only organisations that can run a credit squeeze now are banks because they can decide not to lend, and credit growth has dropped to very low levels. Part of the reason is their unwillingness to lend and the withdrawal of lines of credit. That has made economic conditions more harsh than official policy would otherwise have them. I said, `I cannot do much about that. I lament that but I cannot do much about that'. Is that unreasonable? No. But this is a high political point in this pea-brained presentation we heard a few moments ago.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are at it again.
—If the honourable member for Hume can think of a better description of it I will adopt it.
—There is something for you to do for the rest of the day, Wal.

—That would be a challenge for the honourable member for Hume too, let us face it. He said that our inflation rate was one per cent above the OECD average. Then he made the terribly puny economic point; he said the September quarter was five point something. But it was the year figure. It was inflation for the year which was above the OECD average; the underlying inflation rate is not only below the OECD average, it is at our trading partners' average, which does not include the Turkeys and some of the other countries with high inflation rates. At 5.5 per cent we are at the OECD average. Again, he said that the figure was more relevant with our trading partners. Even with our trading partners it is 5.5 per cent. So what point did he make there?

SPEECH.PARA: The shadow Treasurer then got on to me about my claim that higher interest rates are behind us. In November 1990 he said, `He had a lucky break with inflation'. There was nothing lucky about it. We had $5.5 billion in tax cuts in 1989 to try to hold the wage system from responding to the big lift in spending. We had the most ambitious monetary policy of any country in the OECD-which he has been complaining about all year. Then, when we get a low inflation figure, he says that it is a lucky break. This is supposed to be all quality argument. Where does he get off? He does not have any policies; that is the plain fact of it.

Then he went on about the profit share being wrong. He has no policy and no policy structure. This Parliament has been sitting for the better part of a year and he does not have any idea about what sort of policy he would run. He says that he would cut $3,000m from outlays. But, when pressed for five minutes under a bit of scrutiny, he says that he would give it back in tax cuts. What is the difference in the public sector balance if one cuts $3 billion from outlays and gives it back in tax cuts? It remains the same. But that is what he said. He said:
. . . tightened fiscal policy now would worsen the recession . . .
The transcript reads:
JOURNALIST: So, it would pick up some part of or all of the $3 billion?
REITH: Well, the $3 billion is obviously going to be in the hands of taxpayers-
All of a sudden it went from Budget outlays back into the Budget and the next thing it is in the hands of taxpayers-
and, yes, that will effect consumption and savings patterns, but the truth is that it is not a single policy prescription.
JOURNALIST: . . . hands of taxpayers, Mr Reith?
REITH: Well, if you are talking about the size of Government and if you reduce the total level of taxes, which I thought was the proposition being put to me and-
JOURNALIST: . . . going to reduce the level of spending?
REITH: Yes.
JOURNALIST: by $3 billion and then you said that that's going to be in the hands of taxpayers. Are you going to make tax cuts worth $3 billion?
REITH: Well, look, our tax, we will release our tax policy . . .

The shadow Treasurer does not have a clue. He is more to be pitied than despised. I say to him, `You are not despised by any of us, pal-not at all'. I made it clear the other day that, despite all of these woes we hear about the state of the recession and its impact on the public, the shadow Treasurer said on 29 November:
. . . I would scrap the Accord and the $12 would go with it . . .

So the $12 wage increase-the only one from the centralised system this year-would be out; he would not pay it. He would take $12 from every Australian worker. He made it dead clear-an unambiguous quote that he has not denied. But these are the same people who he has been crying crocodile tears over. He also said, `I would cut out the unemployment benefit after nine months'. The questioner then asked, `At a time of increasing unemployment?' He replied, `Yes, but we ought to be operating the economy more efficiently.' These are the people he supposedly cares about and is worried about-the thousands being put on to unemployment benefit. The Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Tim Fischer) has detailed various firms where people have been made unemployed. These are the people who the shadow Treasurer says should have their unemployment benefit cut off after nine months. How disingenuous is he?

The same applies in relation to interest rates. When he was asked a question about whether interest rates would be reduced if he were in office now, he replied in the negative. In other words, he goes on with all this crying and whingeing, but really he would run the most savage policy he could get his hands on because he does not have the wit or the imagination to run anything better.

The fact is that Australia will come out of this recession and into a recovery. It will be driven by a pick-up in housing starts. Honourable members may have noticed that already this week the Housing Industry Association has said that housing is set to recover. Its media release heading was `Housing Set To Recover'. It then stated:
Today's dwelling approvals provide further signs that the housing industry has levelled out and is about to turn the corner.

Stocks are at very low levels. The stock cycle will contribute to production over the next 12 months as those low stock levels are rebuilt and the lower interest rates and the tax cuts will pick up consumption as we go through the year.
So the Government is in control of events and we do not need to answer inane propositions from the Deputy Leader--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Smith Mr W.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The interesting thing about what has just taken place is that, while the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Keating) of this country was defending his economic record, what did we see on the front bench? There has not been one Minister in here to support him. For three-quarters of his speech, there were more people on this side to hear what he had to say in his defence than there were on his own side. That is the measure of concern that Government Ministers have about where Australia is going. His glib, cynical and foul mouth was the way he started and again at the end of his speech he resorted to the cheap shots that he was trying to extract from a press conference. What he tried to succeed in doing was to convince his own side-who are not convinced and they know they are not convinced-that everything is okay, that it will all get better and that we are looking to better times after Christmas.

SPEECH.PARA: Any people sitting in the gallery and my colleagues here will know what the headlines were today if they picked up any of the three major newspapers in this country that report economic news. The headline in the Sydney Morning Herald was `Merry Christmas, you're redundant'. The headline in the Australian was `Councils sell rate debtors' homes'. It is reported that there has been the worst rate level collection for over nearly two decades in Victoria, apparently. One can go to Port Douglas and have a look. People are being put out of their homes. This is because of national economic policy. This is because of the myopic approach that the Treasurer has taken to interest rates. The headline in the Australian Financial Review was, `Ford staff strike over lost-jobs package'. They all left yesterday because many of their colleagues will be thrown out of work. They hoped, by getting the Treasurer down there to have a look and explain to them what the car industry and the steel industry mean to this country, that he would listen. But it was absolutely unbelievable. It was great television but it was absolutely unbelievable and irresponsible. All he could say to journalists who wanted to ask him questions was, `Disappear, pal'.

The essence of government is about telling people what it is really all about and what is going to happen and to treat everyone equally. But under this Government we have the mates syndrome. I am sure that many people saw the incredible example this morning in the Australian, which carried a report of a speech from a former managing director of Qantas Airways Ltd, Mr Menadue. The article stated:
Politicians regularly used their positions as the heads of Government Business Enterprises (GBEs) to advance political colleagues without regard for the profitability of their organisations.
It further stated:
. . . governments saw it as an opportunity to give broad appointments to political friends.

The Treasurer and his colleagues have been masters of this in this country. There has been no concentration on the profitability of government business enterprises. There has been no concentration on the need to address those problems. This Government has starved them of loan funds. That is why the chairmen of the boards of Qantas and Australian Airlines Ltd are standing up and saying that it will be terribly difficult to sell them. That is why people in Telecom Australia are saying, `Well, if we cannot access loan funds, how are we going to pay the OTC merger fee? Where is the money going to come from?'. This Government is denying them all opportunities to privatise properly and effectively. This is the sort of attitude that is now being exposed. When the mates fall out, all will be revealed. This may be the first example of it-seeing Mr Menadue tell the truth.

We all know that the Treasurer is consumed by power. He has strutted his stuff in this country for some seven years. It is the arrogance that upsets people. It would be all right for him to come into this place and say, `I have made a mess of it. I am sorry and I am now going to seize the opportunity and get it back on course again'. People would accept that. But it is the arrogance and the cynicism of the Treasurer, the honourable member for Blaxland, that upsets people. It upsets his colleagues and it upsets the Australian people. He drives around in cars with tinted windows and takes VIP flights to the football. He blames television hosts and banks for everything. It is always the fault of someone other than Paul Keating. He is almost like a wilful child or someone who needs a caning.

The language of the Treasurer has been made a national issue by him, not by us. The way that he has used the language in here has denigrated this place. When the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) took over, the first thing he said was that we were going to try to lift the standard of debate in this place.

We have just had an example of the language of the Treasurer. He came in and called my colleague a peabrain. What was the point of that? Why not address the issues? The Treasurer has created his own reputation as the `Freddie Foulmouth' of Australian politics. That is something that Australian people do not want. They do not enjoy hearing that. What they want from their politicians is a little bit of vision, understanding and compassion and for everyone to be treated in the same way. That is not what the Treasurer has done. It is that cynicism that he displays so often that has led him into trouble.

It was interesting to see him dining last night with the honourable member for Kingsford-Smith (Mr Brereton). Mention was made that we could well see an Unsworth episode. Mr Unsworth removed the honourable member for Kingsford-Smith for inflicting damage on his Government-just as the honourable member for Blaxland is inflicting damage on the Hawke Government.

The Treasurer has lost touch with reality; he has introduced economic policies that have failed; and he is terribly unpopular. He may well go. Now would not be soon enough for many in this country. He is no John Major, come to save the Labor Party; he is its biggest liability. As I said before, the Minister for Transport and Communications (Mr Beazley) is on a fast track to the top and the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin), if he keeps telling jokes, will probably end up being Deputy Prime Minister.

The essence of it is that there has been a breach of faith with regard to the relationship between the Treasurer and this country. He has not told the people the truth. He has not addressed the economic issues. He tried to skate around the issues today in a very glib way. The shadow Treasurer, the honourable member for Flinders (Mr Reith), has introduced detailed arguments that need to be answered-some 20-odd points.
One of those points, I think, requires mentioning again-that is, the issue of spending. The Treasurer said on 21 November 1990:

If we don't touch the budget any further, or the forward estimates we've published, in two years' time the spending of the Commonwealth of Australia will be the same level it was in GDP (terms) the first year Robert Menzies came to office in 1950.

Clearly, that was not true. But all that the Treasurer did was embrace the rhetoric again and ignore the facts. That is what he has consistently done in these arguments. He embraces the rhetoric and ignores the facts. He embraces all the material from Treasury that he is told to convey, without having any true comprehension of the impact it is going to have on ordinary Australians.

That is why we take the view that when we look at issues such as the level of spending we have to look at them more closely. Last year, the total Commonwealth sector represented 26.2 per cent of gross domestic product (GDP). In the equivalent Budget back in 1956-57-a typical 1950s Budget-the Commonwealth sector represented 21 per cent of gross domestic product. The 5.2 per cent difference between now and 1956-57 represents about $21 billion. That is an enormous bill compared with the discretionary savings in this year's Budget of around $1 billion, as asserted by the Treasurer.

Quite clearly, he is leading people to believe that he is doing a good job by making comparisons that simply are not true, when in actual fact he is not doing a good job at all. He is leading people to the false assumption that he is doing the things that ought to be done. Of course, they are not being achieved.

One of the other issues that does not get a lot of play but which has some significance is the question of capital stock. The Minister for Community Services and Health (Mr Howe) raised the concern to attend to infrastructure needs. The honourable member for Fraser (Mr Langmore) has raised this issue as well. On 11 October 1990, the Treasurer said:

We have reinvigorated all of our capital sectors both in the trade and in the non-trade areas of the economy. The economy out there in terms of capital stock is almost brand new . . . We have had the job of rebuilding the capital stock and we have used some of that wealth to do it.

That is just utter rubbish. How can the capital stock have been run down when total investment in Australia during the 1950s and 1960s steadily grew? Investments were expanding and so was the capital stock. It is just a complete and total furphy. Without improvement in the quality and quantity of export oriented investment capital stock, all the Government's efforts have come to naught. The pain and stress experienced by Australia's families have been worthless. Quite clearly, he does not understand, he does not want to understand and he is not responding to the needs of Australians and the need to make that capital stock grow.

I make a couple of other points. We are starting to see a new phrase used-`policy structure'. It is just like the J-curve. It is used to describe the great big picture-micro-economic reform. The Treasurer says that the policy structure is in place. Well, it is not in place. Australians know it, and he ought to accept his own message. It is time that he was the one to disappear. He is the one who has brought about difficulties for all Australians. It is time that his colleagues on the Government side woke up to that fact and did something about it. I understand that many of them have; they will take that opportunity and we will see the Treasurer disappear, just as the honourable member for Kingsford-Smith disappeared from the Unsworth Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Punch The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The proposal this afternoon from the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, the honourable member for Flinders (Mr Reith) is just a little more sanctimonious than some of the usual ones which unfortunately we on this side of the House have to put up with from time to time from those opposite. It is dressed in terms of honesty and clarity, but in all reality this proposal is not about honesty; it is not about clarity; it is in fact very much about contrasts. It is about the contrasts that we have consistently evidenced in this chamber over the last seven years, time and time again. It is about the very clear and stark contrast between the continued, never ending, shameless rhetoric of a half-armed Opposition and the very real, hard slog, principle based decisions that this Government is pursuing, and will continue to pursue, in the long term interests of this country, despite the fact that at this moment it is probably to our own short term electoral risk.

SPEECH.PARA: The debate this afternoon, as has been the case with so many debates, is about us versus them. It is about commitment versus weakness; it is about hard decisions versus populist television grabs of 30 seconds; it is about resilience versus compromise; and it is about quality of decisions versus an intellectual squalor lacking any consistency. How those opposite can quite honestly come into this House this afternoon and say that in the last seven years there has not been a clear, honest and realistic assessment from this Government at all times to and on behalf of the Australian people is quite simply beyond the pale.

Do we not remember all too well the heady days in this country after the banana republic statement by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) and the vilification that he went through because of that statement? The Treasurer had the temerity to be interviewed on Australia's most popular radio show, hosted by John Laws in Sydney, to try to shake the country out of its 30 years of sleep and to say to the country that we had to do something different.

Vilification and wry humour was thrown at the Treasurer by those on the other side of the chamber. After they had done nothing, after they had hidden the absolute decline and demise of any worthwhile manufacturing base in this country after being in office for so long, when the Treasurer had the audacity to be honest with the Australian people, those opposite vilified him. I say to the honourable member for Bass (Mr Smith) that, some four years later, it is because the Treasurer had the guts to tell this country a few hard facts that this country's long term future is a lot brighter than it was before we came to office in 1983.

We are seeing the same pattern yet again. When two successive lots of figures put us technically in a recession, the Treasurer bluntly went to the press, faced the Press Gallery, faced the television cameras on every television screen across the country on the day that the figures were released, and bluntly told the nation that we are in a recession-a recession that may do some good. That takes a lot of honesty, guts and a great deal of presence of mind-something which I would say is lacking almost consistently on the other side.

More significantly, let us contrast the capacity of the nation today to understand the economic debate with the capacity a decade ago, because that goes to the very heart of this country's capacity to absorb change and to plan for the future. Would we have ever heard Prime Minister Fraser, Deputy Prime Minister Anthony, or Treasurer John Howard, let alone their advisers whispering in their ears, explain to the Australian people the significance of our terms of trade, the importance of micro-economic reform or the complexities of the wage tax trade-offs? No; they would have kept it hidden from people because there was a bit of bad news in it which would not be to their short term electoral benefit.

Where has the Opposition been with regard to this long and winding road along which this Government has had to take this country? While we have been cutting deficits year after year and putting this country into a surplus, the Opposition has been out there on the electoral stump whingeing about assets tests, fringe benefits and capital gains taxes. One by one, Opposition members have been forced to accept them, with the exception of the capital gains tax because that represents big dollars to their supporters.

Now they have found some new ones to squib on-the family allowance asset tests and the pipeline issue. It goes to the very heart of the matter that there may be a new face in the Leader of the Opposition's chair on the other side of the House at Question Time, but there is the same old backsliding still going on. The present context is no different. Let us consider fiscal policy. The Opposition has made much of its $3 billion list, which was exposed at Question Time today by the Minister for Finance (Mr Willis). Much has been heard of course about its prejudice over policy where the Deputy Leader of the Opposition tripped over his tongue in attempting to explain in a most clumsy, half-hearted and disingenuous manner how our repeated surpluses were in fact crowding out private sector investment.

The Deputy Leader of the Opposition, in his contribution this afternoon, also had something to say about our deficit cutting. He said, in effect, that the Treasurer had placed the onus for cuts on the States. I invite the Deputy Leader of the Opposition to have a look at the Treasurer's press release of 28 June 1990, where general government own purpose outlays are explained, and this facade that he has picked up from the New South Wales Government by including outlays of the public trading enterprises, such as Qantas, Telecom and the State electricity authorities, to distort the figures is shown for the distortion that it is.

If that is not good enough, the Deputy Leader of the Opposition ought to look at the Commonwealth's contribution to the reduction in the net public sector borrowing requirement (PSBR), because it shows that the Commonwealth has contributed much more than the States to the turnaround in the PSBR from deficit to surplus. If that is not good enough, he should have a good look at the own source revenue growth, because that is a correct measure for the comparison between the State and Commonwealth sectors. It shows that the States' own source revenue has increased by a far greater amount than that of the Commonwealth.

We raise the interesting subject of monetary policy, and I refer to interest rates. It was not so long ago, I seem to remember, that those on the other side of the House were accusing the Treasurer of ringing the Reserve Bank and telling it to place interest rates at a level lower than what they would otherwise have been. The Opposition said that interest rates should have been higher. That was the rhetoric. Today, December 1990, despite the fact there has been a fall of some 5 per cent from the peak rates in the 90-day bills, it is saying interest rates are still too high. The rhetoric is inconsistent. There has certainly been no discussion about the timing of any interest rate movements from the Opposition; that is a bit too technical and too hard. Opposition members give that a big miss.

In his rush to accuse the Treasurer of misleading this afternoon, the Deputy Leader of the Opposition also falsified the figures in this House in relation to the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) inflation figures. The facts are that in the 12 months to September, the total OECD inflation was 7 per cent, compared with ours of 6 per cent. The Deputy Leader of the Opposition invited comparisons with our major trading partners. He should know that the inflation rate for the comparable period in the United States was 6.2 per cent, above ours. In Maggie's England, it was a good old 10.9 per cent. He invites comparison; there is the comparison.

In the very limited time left to me, I want to raise one further point, and it is this: never once has there been a truly international perspective offered by members of the Opposition. There has been no mention whatsoever of one by them-with the exception of a question at Question Time today from the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair), who is on the back bench. There has been no perspective at all from them about the ramifications for the Australian economy; of what is happening in the American economy; what is happening in the Japanese economy, with the various stock market corrections; what is happening in the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT); or the significance of the Gulf war. There is no consistent overview, no international perspective.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fife The Hon W.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, under governments of both political parties a trend has developed over the past few years-and I emphasise `under governments of both political parties' because I want to be bipartisan in this matter-to come back here towards the end of the year to deal with matters returning from the Senate. For the benefit of those who are unaware of what is happening now, the Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services (Mr Baldwin) has moved that the House at its rising meet again on 20 December 1990 at 10 am, unless Mr Speaker fixes an alternative day or hour of meeting. What is intended, of course, is that we will now go into recess for a number of days until 20 December 1990 and we will come back probably for one, or perhaps two days. The trend that has developed over recent years is that when the House comes back for, say, two days, in parliamentary terms it develops as one day. In other words, at the end of the first day, the Parliament rises to an hour or till the ringing of the bells and, when we come back on the second day, there is no Question Time. SPEECH.PARA: I appeal to the Government-and I realise that the Leader of the House (Mr Beazley) is not present, so I do not seek a response from the Government at this moment-to consider allowing a Question Time on that second day, if we meet on 21 December 1990. Indeed, it is the second lowest number of sitting days since Federation.

Each time we have a day cut off the sitting pattern, it means that there is one less Question Time. Not only are members of the House of Representatives suffering in this way, but we now also find that the maximum number of questions that we can anticipate being asked on a sitting day is 14. DEBATE.TITLE: REDEVELOPMENT OF AERONAUTICAL RESEARCH LABORATORY, FISHERMENS BEND

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Approval of Work: Public Works Committee Act

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beddall The Hon D.P.

TALKER.NAME: Mr BEDDALL
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Small Business and Customs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, it is expedient to carry out the following proposed work which was referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works and on which the Committee has duly reported to the Parliament: Redevelopment of Aeronautical Research Laboratory site, Fishermens Bend, Vic.

The Aeronautical Research Laboratory (ARL) is part of the Defence Science and Technology Organisation of the Department of Defence. ARL's terms of reference are to develop, maintain and exploit scientific and technological skills and facilities in areas generally central to military air vehicles and relevant aspects of weapons for the benefit of the Australian Defence Force. Existing laboratories and office accommodation at ARL are crowded and unsuitable for effective research, development and investigation in a number of areas of technology.

ARL operates from a site at Fishermens Bend, Port Melbourne, which until 30 June 1988 was leased from the Victorian Government. On the expiration of the lease the Commonwealth purchased the site as well as an adjacent site, previously used by the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation (CSIRO), from the Victorian Government. ARL will ultimately expand into both sites.

The Department of Defence is purchasing useable ex-CSIRO buildings with the aim of refurbishing them. The redevelopment proposal also includes refurbishment of some existing ARL buildings. The redevelopment proposal has evolved from a need to rationalise the operation and management of the research facility and will provide badly needed laboratory and office space and enable staff of the scientific divisions to be collocated. This in turn will enable other buildings to be appropriately modified to provide more flexibility and efficiency and assist ARL to meet its research and development objectives.

Health and safety surveys and site investigations commissioned by the Aust- ralian Construction Services and co- ordinated by Scientific Services Laboratories identified areas of hazardous chemical and radiation contamination on the ex-CSIRO site and radiation contamination on the existing ARL site. Both sites have now been cleared of all radioactive waste and a consultant has been engaged to further investigate the chemical-solvent contamination on the ex-CSIRO site.

The Department of Defence will be monitoring and surveying the removal of contaminants and redevelopment of the site is dependent on full decontamination of the ex-CSIRO site. Work will not proceed on the affected part of the site until it is safe to do so.

The project will consist largely of refurbishment and demolition works and will provide functional laboratory facilities to support the advanced technologies embodied in recent aircraft acquisitions such as the FA18 fighter, Black Hawk and Seahawk helicopters. The provision of roads and car parking, extension of the existing security system and provision of electrical services will also be undertaken in the planned redevelopment.

In its report the Public Works Committee agreed that many of the existing buildings at ARL are inadequate and therefore recommended that the proposed redevelopment should proceed. However, it made two points that should be noted. Firstly, it recommended that ARL investigate the possibility of providing child-care facilities for its employees, and ARL has advised it will survey staff requirements in this respect and also canvass neighbouring organisations about the possibility of a combined facility being set up nearby.

Secondly, the Committee recommended that Australian Construction Services undertake an energy audit to ensure the most efficient use of energy at the site, and I have been advised that this audit is currently being arranged by ACS in Victoria, which will report back to the Committee on the audit results.

Submissions were received by the Committee from the Government and Opposition of Tasmania suggesting that the aircraft systems division of ARL be moved to Launceston. A second hearing was held by the Committee in September 1990 to discuss this matter but the Committee ultimately concluded that the laboratory would function more effectively and efficiently if that division were to remain in Melbourne.

The limit of cost estimate for the proposed work at April 1990 prices is $17.5m and comprises $15.48m for building refurbishment and modification and $2.02m for site works and services. The work will be undertaken in two phases to accommodate funding arrangements of ARL, with phase A planned for commencement in 1990-91 and phase B in 1994-95.
I would like to thank the Committee for its support of the project and I commend the motion to the House.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beddall The Hon D.P.

TALKER.NAME: Mr BEDDALL
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Small Business and Customs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, it is expedient to carry out the following proposed work which was referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works and on which the Committee has duly reported to the Parliament: Brisbane Air Traffic Services Centre.

The proposed work is for the development of an existing building into an air traffic services centre in Brisbane for the Civil Aviation Authority (CAA). The new centre is a vital component in the CAA airways productivity investment program as it will enable upgraded radar data to be displayed at new radar display consoles. It will also provide the necessary accommodation to permit consolidation and rationalisation of remote air traffic services units into Brisbane.

The proposal will provide the necessary floor space to accommodate the replacement radar displays as well as the functions currently provided by the existing Brisbane flight service centre and the existing flight service units at Charleville, Mount Isa, Weipa, Cairns, Townsville, Rockhampton, Dubbo and Coffs Harbour.

The proposal is to rehabilitate the former Australian Airlines domestic terminal building located at the old Brisbane Airport. The CAA has purchased 14 hectares of the Queensland airport, including the former Australian Airlines building, to enable it to ultimately consolidate and collocate all its off-airport activities at the one location.

The proposal will provide a main building and adjoining annex with a total floor area of approximately 6,800 square metres comprising: an air traffic services operational and support area of 2,200 square metres; technical services and support areas of 2,500 square metres; services areas of 1,500 square metres; and administrative support and social facilities of 600 square metres. The CAA's estimate for the proposal including allowances for contingencies and fees is $9.7m at June 1990 prices.
I thank the Committee for its report and I commend the motion to the House.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beddall The Hon D.P.

TALKER.NAME: Mr BEDDALL
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Small Business and Customs)

TALK.START.PARA: (4.39) I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, it is expedient to carry out the following proposed work which was referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works and on which the Committee has duly reported to the Parliament: Jindalee Over-the-Horizon Radar.

Through its information policy paper `The Defence of Australia 1987', the Federal Government announced a commitment to defence self-reliance and the development of a defence force capable of meeting the unique strategic demands of Australia. A significant part of Australia's achieving self-reliance rests with our ability to detect and prevent an attack by aggressors through air and sea approaches.

In light of our expansive coastline, Australia is obviously extremely vulnerable. The Government has placed a high priority on the development of an extensive radar network capable of broad area surveillance of these vast air and sea approaches. Using state of the art technology, the Jindalee over-the-horizon radar (OTHR) is designed to do just that and Australia is leading the world in this type of defence facility.

Unlike traditional ground based radars, the sophisticated Jindalee system will scan over the horizon and it is expected to be able to detect ships and aircraft up to 2,000 kilometres from the Australian coastline. The present phase of the project will involve major installations near Laverton in Western Australia and near Longreach in Queensland with a coordination centre at RAAF base Edinburgh in South Australia.

The entire network is estimated to cost in excess of $500m, with the cost of the works component estimated at $95m. The network will significantly enhance the ability of Australia's defence forces to effectively monitor air and sea movements across our remote northern approaches. The system is expected to be operational by the mid-1990s and, in addition to its major defence role, will have other significant applications. For example, it should be able to provide a deterrent to illegal immigration and drug smuggling through neighbouring South East Asia as well as providing valuable weather information and assistance in aircraft safety and search and rescue operations.

Phased over five years, the development of the OTHR will involve not only the erection of the sophisticated radar equipment, but also construction of facilities to house the equipment and operation centres at each radar and the main management cell in South Australia. In the past, defence and other consignment works were built using a design and construction approach where buildings and works are specified separately to the equipment part of a project. In the case of the Jindalee project, this approach has many disadvantages as the equipment and facilities parts of the project are dependent on one another and timing for each component is critical. Therefore, a turnkey approach has been adopted, allowing the prime contractor to undertake all aspects of the project simultaneously, thereby having more control over project timing and minimising financial risk to the Commonwealth.

The project will provide employment opportunities and economic activities to the remote areas which will house each installation and, once operational, each radar will employ between 20 and 30 maintenance personnel, mainly civilian. The Department of Defence has actively pursued avenues of public consultation and has developed effective relationships with the local communities, all of which generally support the project.

In its report, the Public Works Committee determined that there is a need to establish the Jindalee radar network and that to provide optimum radar performance both radars, as proposed, will be ideally sited. The Committee therefore recommended that the Queensland, Western Australian and South Australian sections of the project should proceed. In making this recommendation, however, it also made a number of additional comments. The Committee recommended that the Department of Defence provide an analysis of the effectiveness of the turnkey approach being adopted for this project. The Department of Defence will provide the requested information upon the completion of the project, when a full analysis of this approach can be made.

The Committee further recommended that the Department of Defence give a high priority to overcoming technical problems related to the source of electrical power, including possible alternative energy sources; undertake an independent assessment of the electro-magnetic effect of the transmitter near Longreach in Queensland; and broaden its community consultation programs in the Longreach area. Defence has indicated that arrangements are well in hand for the additional work and that it will be completed as quickly as possible.

The Committee also recommended that it be advised of the cost split between the antennas and other facilities following the awarding of the Jindalee contract. The Department of Defence expects to award a contract in early 1991 and has undertaken to report back to the Committee with the successful tenderer's costs and details of the cost break-up as requested.
I would like to thank the Committee for its support of the project and I commend the motion to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hawker Mr D.P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —While the Opposition supports the building of the Jindalee over-the-horizon radar, there are a couple of points I would like to raise arising from the report of the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works. I commend the Committee for its work, particularly as I know it has had a number of references over the last few months. This matter was referred to it only at the end of August.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister for Small Business and Customs (Mr Beddall) referred to a turnkey contract. While we accept that this type of project is probably best suited to a turnkey contract, it does really then put a lot of responsibility on the prime contractor and, in particular, on the ability of the prime contractor to manage the costs of the project. I think this is something that the Opposition will be watching fairly carefully.

The Public Works Committee reported that there was no limit of cost estimate given to it when it was assessing the project. While that in itself is of some concern, it was also noted that the price ceiling originally of $125m, which was negotiated for the three Jindalee over-the-horizon radar stations, was subsequently reduced by the Department of Defence to $95m. The report does not indicate how that drop of $30m was arrived at or how the Department of Defence was able to estimate that the turnkey approach will save it $8m.

I think this demonstrates the difficulty of estimating costs and the problem of measuring the total final cost with the turnkey approach. So we still have the possibility that this project could suffer a blow-out in its cost. I say to the Minister and the Government that the Opposition will be watching these two points very closely.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Howe, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.

TALKER.NAME: Mr HOWE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Community Services and Health)

TALK.START.PARA: — I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

When it was introduced in 1947, the Social Security Act 1947 brought together separate legislation dealing with age, invalid and widows' pensions, maternity allowances, child endowment and unemployment and sickness benefits. Commonwealth legislation in the area of social security dates back to 1908 with the enactment of the Invalid and Old-Age Pensions Act.

Since 1947, the Act has been subject to over 100 amending Acts. At the outset, the Act depicted a passive payment mechanism, providing benefits in the form of direct cash payments to clients. It has now become more attuned, because of the many recent amendments, to the changing social and economic environment through its development into a more active piece of legislation that targets individuals and families in genuine need while positively encouraging them toward independence of the welfare system.

These developments have involved increasing complexity and diversification within one of the most important pieces of Commonwealth legislation. A large proportion of the Australian population is affected by the Act. The volume of recent amendments, the increased complexity of certain areas of the Act and changes in drafting styles since 1947 are some of the factors that have contributed to reduced comprehensibility of the Act as well as a hodgepodge of styles and presentation.

A legislation review was instituted by the then Minister for Social Security and carried out by the Department of Social Security with the cooperation of representatives of the welfare sector. This Bill is a result of that process. In February this year copies of an exposure draft of the Bill were released for public comment. Public seminars were held in each capital city to explain the background to the review of the legislation and to examine the structure, format and style of the draft legislation. Those attending were invited to suggest changes or improvements to the exposure draft. The response to these consultations was both constructive and positive.

The object of this Bill is to overcome the problem of readability by using a `clear English' drafting style and format. That style and format should make it a more accessible piece of legislation that ordinary Australians can reasonably be expected to understand. In many instances, traditionally used legislative words such as `notwithstanding' have been dropped or replaced by non-technical words such as `despite' or `even if'. In some places `cease' has been replaced by `stop' and `request' by `ask'. These are just a few examples of one aspect of `clear English' drafting.

Two main aims have been pursued in redrafting the Social Security Act. The first has been the aim of making each individual provision as simple and easy to read as possible. The second has been the aim of making the arrangement of the provisions in the Act logical and easy to follow. As a result, this Bill contains many new features at both the individual provision level and at the overall organisation level.

Chapter 1 of the Bill is of fundamental importance because it provides the basic interpretative tool for the reader. It sets out in one place the definitions of principal terms used in the Bill. Definitions may:
- settle the meaning of a word or phrase that might otherwise be of doubtful meaning;
- extend the ordinary meaning of a word to achieve a broader effect;
- narrow the ordinary meaning of a word to achieve a restrictive effect; or
- allow a shortened reference to a complicated concept or a long name.
Two innovations of note in the definitional part of Chapter 1 are:
- an index of defined words and phrases; and
- groups of definitions according to subject matter.
The main advantage of grouping is that it reduces the ambit of the search area for a reader. The index will improve accessibility.

Chapter 1 includes a part concerned with determinations having an interpretative effect. Some definitions in the current Act confer powers. For example, an organisation cannot be a `benevolent home' for the purposes of receiving a portion of a social security payment under the Act unless the organisation has been approved as such by the Secretary. The use of definitions in this way is inconsistent with the purpose of definitions and puts the reader to unnecessary trouble. Hence, such provisions, where they remain essential, have been reworked and grouped together in a separate part of the interpretational chapter.

Chapter 2 sets out the modules for each of the 20 types of social security payment. Each payment module is almost totally self-contained so that a reader will find out everything he or she needs to know about a particular pension, benefit or allowance without referring to a multitude of provisions outside that module. Special or less frequently used provisions that affect qualification or payability, such as the effect of compensation payments, are located outside the payment modules for cost and space efficiency reasons but they are signposted at appropriate points in payment modules. Rate calculators are also located outside the payment modules for similar reasons. The provisions of each payment module deal with matters in a procedural order covering in turn qualification criteria, how to claim, determination of claim, how to assess rate, how payment is made, recipient obligations, continuation, variation and termination of benefit, bereavement payments and fringe benefits provisions. Equivalent provisions to these are currently found scattered throughout the Act.

Chapter 3 of the Bill contains general provisions which relate to rates of benefit and to means testing. This chapter contains the rate calculators for the social security payments covered in chapter 2. The generic rate calculators are probably the most effective innovation of the rewrite exercise. This is because they have transformed an incomprehensible set of rules into more useful tools that, while still complex, are set out in steps to assist social security clients and their advisers to check rate calculations.
Chapter 3 also includes general provisions relating to the ordinary income test, the maintenance income test, the assets test, the effect of the receipt of compensation payments and indexation.

Chapter 4 provides for payment of certain pensions outside Australia and sets down the rules regulating the rate payable to people who can take their pensions overseas. The chapter also covers bilateral social security agreements between Australia and other countries.

Chapter 5 consolidates provisions dealing with the identification of debts arising under the Bill and with the recovery, waiver or write-off of those debts. Currently, these provisions are found in different parts of the legislation.

Chapter 6 mirrors Part XIX of the present Act that deals with the review of decisions by officers of the Department of Social Security; the Social Security Appeals Tribunal; and the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. Part XIX was an early piece of `clear English' legislation to emerge from the legislation review and was introduced into the Social Security Act 1947 by the Social Security (Review of Decisions) Act 1988. Hence, it is one of the few areas of the Bill that did not need substantial revision.

Chapter 7 of the Bill sets out the Secretary's responsibilities regarding general administration and information gathering. There is a separate division dealing with confidentiality and the protection and use of personal information. Chapter 7 also provides for the establishment, membership and organisation of the Social Security Appeals Tribunal. Chapter 8 contains a number of miscellaneous provisions.

The Bill contains notes following some provisions. These are designed to assist readers in locating definitions and other relevant provisions. Examples showing the operation of the provisions have been incorporated in the text to explain how some provisions work-especially those involving complex calculations. At the front of the Bill is a `Reader's Guide' which explains how the Bill is structured and how it can be used.

The rewrite of the Act does not involve any major policy initiatives and it does not have any financial impact. The new legislation is intended to reflect existing policy which is, in turn, reflected by the existing legislation. The primary purpose of the rewrite is to overcome readability problems that had developed mainly as a result of the volume of changes made to the current Act since 1947. Another important object of the rewrite is to make the Act easier to change in the future as the need arises. Those purposes would be fulfilled by this Bill. Furthermore, it is expected that this will pave the way for other large pieces of Federal legislation to be written or rewritten in a similar `clear English' style and format. The Department of Veterans' Affairs has already begun working on a `clear English' rewrite of part III of the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986.

This Bill does not include any amendments to the Act introduced during these sittings. These changes will be introduced as amendments in the autumn sittings next year. A Bill covering the transitional arrangements and consequential amendments will follow this Bill.

The legislation working party of the Social Security Advisory Council played a major part in the preparation and discussion of research papers and other less tangible ways in the development of this Bill. The members of the working party, especially its chairman, Professor Terry Carney, deserve special thanks for their enthusiastic and important contributions. That working party did an extraordinary amount of work for very limited compensation-well beyond the call of duty.

TALK.START.PARA: —They must have. It is a very interesting piece of legislation.

—It is very exciting. In terms of this legislation, we owe a great debt to Monash University and the law school, headed up by Terry Carney and Peter Hanks, who co-authored one of the important texts on social security legislation in Australia. I would like to say also that in the Department of Social Security Michael Sassella and other members of his team in the legislation division of the Department worked very closely with the Parliamentary Counsel and his staff. Again, a great deal of forbearance and patience was necessary on the part of our external advisers. In the Department itself, people can imagine that some of the battles were, if not quite bitter, at times very heated. Those in the Office of Parliamentary Counsel were working with a very different approach. I place on record a tribute to all those people. I think this legislation will, hopefully, be a precedent for rewriting much more Commonwealth legislation in a way that is accessible.

SPEECH.PARA: I say in conclusion that, if there is one Act of a Federal Parliament that ought to belong to the people of Australia, it is the Social Security Act. In this case, this Act is much more the people's Act as a result of these clarifying amendments, albeit on the basis of existing policy. I commend the Bill to the House and present the explanatory memorandum.
Debate (on motion by Mr Peacock) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Kerin, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALKER.NAME: Mr KERIN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

Since coming to power in 1983 the Government has committed itself to improving the management of Commonwealth fisheries. In December 1989 the Government released a major policy statement setting out the future directions for Commonwealth fisheries management. The policy statement emphasised four objectives for fisheries management: to ensure that fisheries resources are not overexploited and that any exploitation is at a level which can be sustained while maintaining the surrounding environment; to enable commercial fishing operations to be as economically efficient as possible, using the most appropriate technology to achieve the greatest net returns; to create conditions where fishermen are able to make a payment to the community for the right to exploit a public resource for private gain, recognising that such a payment should not reduce the profitability of fishing operations to less than their current levels; and to ensure that the administration of Commonwealth fisheries should be conducted on the most efficient and effective basis.

Legislation designed to achieve the first three objectives, which comprise the essence of the Government's fisheries management policies, is being drafted and will be put before Parliament in the autumn sittings next year. In addition to introducing new policies arising from the Government's policy statement, this legislation will replace the Fisheries Act 1952, which will be repealed.

The legislation before us now concerns the administration of fisheries management. The Government recognises the importance of an effective and efficient administrative structure if the fisheries management objectives which I have outlined are to be achieved and sustained. This legislation establishes a new statutory authority-the Australian Fisheries Management Authority (AFMA)-to undertake the Government's fisheries management responsibilities. It also establishes a Fishing Industry Policy Council to provide advice to the Government on matters affecting the fishing industry and an Australian Fisheries Management Authority selection committee. An associated Fisheries Research and Development Corporation will also be established under the auspices of the Primary Industries and Energy Research and Development Act 1989, to commence from 1 July 1991.

My remarks will be primarily about the new Authority, although at the end I will come back to the selection processes and the role and composition of the Policy Council. The Government has decided to establish the Australian Fisheries Management Authority to undertake its fisheries management responsibilities which will be included in the Fisheries Management Bill to be introduced in the autumn sitting. It has done this because it believes that the statutory authority model of public administration has a number of important advantages.

These advantages include: increased industry and community involvement in decision making through an enhanced role for the management advisory committees, and industry and community involvement in selecting the governing board; increased flexibility of operations, without the constraints of a departmental structure; increased public accountability for the Authority for both decision making and expenditure; increased independence in day to day decision making, with ministerial involvement at a strategic level rather than ongoing involvement in operational matters; and increased incentives to ensure that all of the Authority's operations are conducted in a cost efficient manner.

In order to ensure that these advantages are realised, the charter of the new Authority will be exclusively fisheries management. The Authority will not have to undertake the additional broad policy functions currently being performed by the Australian Fisheries Service. A policy branch will remain within the Department of Primary Industries and Energy to handle those matters. In most cases the functions of these two bodies will be quite distinct.

The Authority will be required to manage the marine resources of the Australian fishing zone in accordance with the Government's sustainable development objectives and policies. The Authority's principal responsibilities will be: to develop and implement fishery-specific management plans; to set sustainable catch quotas for our fish stocks; to grant ongoing or temporary access to fish resources; to effectively monitor the activities of Australian and foreign fishermen licensed to exploit our fish resources; and to monitor the general performance of each fishery and introduce, where necessary, appropriate restructuring programs.
