In order to undertake these responsibilities, the Authority will have an important role in identifying research and development requirements for fisheries and commissioning expert assistance from organisations such as the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation (CSIRO), the Bureau of Rural Resources and the Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics.

The policy branch within the Department of Primary Industries and Energy will retain its responsibility for advising the Government on broad strategic fisheries policy matters. These will include the development of resource use and environmental policies, advising on policy matters concerning foreign access to the Australian fishing zone, developing policy on fisheries access rights and the collection of community returns from the fishing industry, monitoring the effect of taxation rulings on fisheries management and developing policy that will reduce domestic and international marketing impediments for Australian fish products. The fisheries policy branch will also be required to monitor the overall performance of the Australian Fisheries Management Authority in regard to its implementation of the Government's fisheries management objectives and the general performance and profitability of the fishing industry.

As indicated and in keeping with the principle that formal inter-government negotiations are led by Ministers and their officials, the Department will generally take the leading role in delegations to inter-governmental negotiations on fisheries matters and will represent the Government on multilateral fisheries fora. The Authority will also have a role in inter-governmental negotiations where these relate to fisheries management. It will assist the Department as required in such negotiations, as for example in the bilateral and trilateral arrangements with Japan concerning the international management of the southern bluefin tuna stocks, and the arrangements with Papua New Guinea on the management of Torres Strait fisheries, and with New Zealand on the driftnet surveillance program.

Under the new arrangements there will be a need to continue and, where possible, strengthen the close working relationship which currently exists between the Australian Fisheries Service, the Bureau of Rural Resources, the Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics and relevant external agencies like the CSIRO. Because of the particular importance which I place on the work of the Bureau of Rural Resources, I will ensure that additional staff resources are made available to it from within my portfolio.

I also note, in keeping with the undertaking in the policy statement, that one quarter of one per cent of the gross value of fisheries production will be provided by the Government for fisheries research, and these funds will be distributed between the Authority, the Bureau of Rural Resources and the Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics at my discretion.

An important feature of the new administrative arrangement is the enhanced role which the Authority will be able to give-at its discretion-to management advisory committees. In order to meet the challenging responsibilities which I have outlined above, the Authority will be able to devolve functions to these committees to perform on behalf of AFMA. The Authority will still be the body which will be held accountable for meeting the fisheries management objectives, but nevertheless, provided that the Authority has confidence in a particular management advisory committee, that committee will be able to exercise considerable influence in the management of the fishery concerned.

The functions of the management advisory committees are to advise the Authority in relation to fisheries management, to act as a liaison mechanism between the Authority and the fishermen concerned, and to assist in keeping the Authority informed about the biological and economic status of the fishery. Management advisory committees will consist of a chairperson-to be selected by the Authority-the fishery manager and up to seven members selected by the Authority after consultation with the industry, relevant State or Territory governments and relevant members of the research community.

The Government recognises that the strength and success of the Authority will depend on the quality and calibre of its board. The Government is firmly convinced that it is highly desirable to select the board on the basis of expertise, and this legislation establishes a selection committee which will choose five of the board members. The selection committee itself will consist of two industry representatives to be nominated by the peak industry body, two community representatives, a nominee of the Australian Fisheries Council, and a presiding member to be selected by the Minister. I hope to be in a position to announce the name of the presiding member within the next few weeks. The National Fishing Industry Council will be specified in the regulations as the peak industry body.

There are clear parallels between these selection procedures for the Authority's board and those which are used for the statutory marketing authorities and the research and development corporations associated with my portfolio. However, there are also some important differences. The most important difference is the role which industry will play. Industry, quite rightly, has an influential role in the outlook and activities of the statutory marketing authorities and the research and development corporations, and is a key participant in the formation of industry commercial philosophy of those organisations.

On the other hand, the Australian Fisheries Management Authority will have the task of enforcing regulations which will prevent fisheries from being overexploited or overcapitalised. At times, the collective interest of all the fishermen in the fishery and of the broader community may be at odds with the self-interest of individual fishermen. Since the Authority will be a Government body undertaking the Government's regulatory role in fisheries management, it would be inappropriate for industry to have a dominant influence. To do so would be like asking the players to umpire their own football match. At the same time it is highly desirable for some board members of the Authority to have fishing industry experience.

For this reason I have decided that the board of the Authority will consist of a chairperson and a government member to be selected by the Minister, with five directors to be selected by the special selection committee on the basis of their expertise. The areas of expertise will include commercial fishing, fishing industry operations other than fishing, fisheries science, natural resource management, economics and business management. There will be a requirement that no more than two directors be currently engaged in the fishing industry. The managing director of the Authority will be chosen by these seven directors and will be an ex-officio member of the board.

As the Authority has been given some independence from the industry, and indeed from day to day ministerial control, it is important that there are mechanisms through which the Authority will be held accountable. The Authority will be accountable at three levels. It will be required to submit both a longer term corporate plan and an annual operational plan to the Minister setting out the means by which it will achieve its statutory objectives. The Minister may approve or seek a variation to these documents.

The Authority will be required to provide an annual report to Parliament and will be subject to the scrutiny of parliamentary committees. It will also be subject to an annual audit by the Auditor-General. The Minister will have the power to direct the Authority in exceptional circumstances, but it will be a requirement that any such direction be presented to both Houses of Parliament and reported in the Authority's annual report.

The Authority will be required to have a high degree of disclosure in its annual report. It will be required to focus in that document on strategic reporting against the goals and key parameters for performance outlined in its corporate and annual operational plans.

The Authority will also be accountable to the fishing industry and the general public. In addition to the annual report, the Authority will be required to hold public meetings at least once each year in order to ensure that the fishing industry and the community in general have an opportunity to consult the board, to question its members and to have them justify their management actions.

I turn now to the matter of staffing for the new Authority. I have consistently stressed that I want the employment conditions of the current staff in the Australian Fisheries Service to be safeguarded, and for employees transferring from the Australian Fisheries Service to the Australian Fisheries Management Authority to continue to work under the Public Service Act 1922 and to enjoy their current conditions of service, including superannuation entitlements.

I also recognise the importance of providing the Authority with the flexibility to develop remuneration packages to attract and reward staff with particular skills. For this reason the legislation will give the Authority the power to set the terms and conditions of those employees who are recruited from outside the Australian Fisheries Service.

I also wish to make some brief remarks about the Fishing Industry Policy Council. This legislation establishes a statutory Fishing Industry Policy Council which will advise the Minister on matters which have been referred to it, or indeed on any other matters affecting the well-being of the industry. The Council will convene meetings and conferences, produce reports, consult with other persons as necessary and generally provide the Minister with an independent and wide-ranging source of information on the fishing industry.

The composition of the Council will be broad. It will consist of a chairperson; the chairperson of the Authority; the chairperson of the Fishing Industry Research and Development Corporation; a representative of the National Fishing Industry Training Council Ltd; two industry representatives representing the spectrum of catching, processing and marketing interests to be nominated by the peak industry body; a representative of recreational fishermen; and a person having an interest in environmental and/or consumer aspects. This membership may be widened to include representatives of other groups at a later stage at the discretion of the Minister.

The Bill will not have any significant affect on government expenditure. The Authority will be funded on the same basis as that currently in place for the Australian Fisheries Service of the Department of Primary Industries and Energy, with 90 per cent of attributable management costs being recovered from the fishing industry.

Some additional government funding may initially be required to cover transitional arrangements. The Industry Commission is to review the basis of cost recovery for fisheries management prior to December 1991 and every five years thereafter. However, it is worth remembering that the Government, as custodian of the marine resources of the Australian fishing zone, will always retain certain responsibilities and meet the costs associated with the management of those resources. Examples of such responsibilities are surveillance costs to detect illegal foreign fishing activities, and protecting the traditional way of life of Torres Strait Islanders in joint authority with Queensland and in treaty with Papua New Guinea.

In drafting this legislation the Government intends that, where relevant, the new policy adjustments for statutory marketing authorities arising from the report of the Davis Committee be included in the arrangements for the Authority. In particular, this legislation does not contain any restrictions on the appointment of directors because of their age and limits the duration of their tenure to three consecutive terms. It also requires the Authority to identify key indicators of its performance in its corporate and annual operational plans and to report on these in its annual report.

The industry, through representatives of the National Fishing Industry Council, have been kept informed of the development of this legislation and have actively participated in ensuring a smooth transition to the new Authority through a special liaison committee. They have been supportive and constructive and many of their suggestions are embodied in this Bill. I thank them for their assistance and look forward to continuing productive consultations. With their assistance I believe that the target date for the establishment of the Authority on or before 1 July 1991 can be achieved. I commend the Bill to honourable members and present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill.
Debate (on motion by Dr Kemp) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: PRIMARY INDUSTRIES AND ENERGY LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1990

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Kerin, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALKER.NAME: Mr KERIN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The purpose of this Bill is to amend the Primary Industries and Energy Research and Development Act 1989 and the Grape Research Levy Act 1986 to remove minor legislative inconsistencies and improve the operation of research and development in the portfolio. The Primary Industries and Energy Research and Development Act 1989 set the framework for the establishment of research and development corporations and councils for smaller industries to improve the management of portfolio research activities. There are a small number of drafting errors in this Act, which this Bill will correct.

While these changes are relatively minor in themselves, collectively they are important and necessary for the smooth operation of the research and development corporations and councils established under the principal Act. These amendments to the Primary Industries and Energy Research and Development Act remove anomalies in reporting requirements for research and development corporations and councils and streamline reporting requirements for selection committees by allowing the incorporation of their report in the annual report of the associated research and development corporation.

This Bill makes references to representative organisations consistent throughout the Primary Industries and Energy Research and Development Act 1989. Representative organisations as defined by that Act are declared to be associated with the research and development corporation or council rather than with industry. This Bill corrects inaccurate mention of representative organisations being associated with industry.

This Bill removes the unintended anomaly of having different reporting schedules for research and development councils and corporations. Annual operational and five-year plans for research and development councils will now be submitted in line with timing requirements for research and development corporations.

This Bill also provides that the chairpersons of research and development councils attend annual coordination meetings along with chairpersons of research and development corporations. This Bill also amends the Grape Research Levy Act 1986. The Primary Industries and Energy Research and Development Act 1989 inadvertently amended this Act and removed the right of relevant industry organisations, whose members pay the levy, to make recommendations to the Minister regarding the rate of the industry levy for funding grape research. This amendment will restore that right.

The measures set out in this Bill will involve no Commonwealth outlays. Administrative savings may be achieved for the research and development corporations and councils through the inclusion of selection committee reports in the relevant corporation's annual report.

The major impact of the Bill will be the removing of inconsistencies in reporting requirements for research and development corporations and councils, the clarification of the use of the term `representative organisation' and the remedying of the unintended alteration to the process for determining the level of levies in the grape and wine industry.
I commend the Bill to honourable members and present the explanatory memorandum.
Debate (on motion by Dr Kemp) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Crean, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crean The Hon S.F.

TALKER.NAME: Mr CREAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

This Bill will amend the taxation laws in a number of respects. It will give effect to the personal tax cuts announced on 20 November 1990 and make a consequential amendment to the rebate allowable for medical expenses.

Capital gains tax amendments to be made by the Bill will ease restrictions on the availability of capital gains tax rollover relief and also ensure capital losses are not brought forward artificially as a consequence of asset transfers between companies under common ownership. Some technical amendments to the capital gains tax provisions as they apply to disposals of partnership assets are also proposed.

A Budget announcement to be given effect by this Bill will limit the franking credits available to life assurance companies under the imputation system. It will also provide for the taxation treatment of various bereavement payments that have replaced the special temporary allowance and funeral benefit.

Other amendments contained in this Bill will modify the foreign income legislation presently before the Parliament to remove some potential double taxation, to correct technical deficiencies and overcome tax avoidance avenues, and to implement the Budget announcement to extend the deductions for certain capital expenditures on particular activities in Australia to similar offshore activities that generate income to be taxed here.

The Bill will also ensure that a deduction is not allowable for bad debts of a foreign branch of a moneylender who has not derived assessable income from those debts. Finally, the Bill will amend certain provisions of the Taxation Administration Act that deal with the protection of taxation information. I turn now to a more detailed discussion of these measures.
Personal Tax Cuts

The Government announced on 20 November 1990 that it had reached agreement with the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU) to replace the first wage adjustment under accord mark 6 with personal tax cuts to cement in place Australia's decelerating inflation rate which is now lower than the average for Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) countries.

The Bill will amend the Income Tax Rates Act 1986 to reduce the lowest marginal rate of tax, applying in the income range $5,401 to $20,700, from 21 per cent to 20 per cent. This reduction will only apply for resident individuals and trustees. As the change applies from 1 January 1991 a composite rate scale will apply for the 1990-91 financial year. That scale will comprise a weighted average of one-half of the rate scale applying from 1 July 1990 to 31 December 1990, and one half of the new rate scale that is to apply from 1 January to 30 June 1991.

The lower rate of tax will be reflected in pay as you earn deductions from 1 January 1991. It will not be used in the calculation or recalculation of 1990-91 provisional tax, but will be available to provisional taxpayers on assessment in 1991-92. The cost to the revenue of the personal tax cuts is estimated at $430m in 1990-91, and $1 billion in a full year.
Rebate for Medical Expenses

As a consequence of the reduction in the lowest marginal rate of tax from 21 to 20 per cent, which I have just mentioned, the level of the rebate of tax for net medical expenses exceeding $1,000 will be reduced to 20 per cent for 1991-92 and subsequent years. The revenue savings from this measure are estimated at $2m in a full year.
Capital Gains Tax

Capital gains tax rollover relief will be made more accessible for asset transfers in a company group. Existing anti-avoidance rules require the issue of shares or securities equal in value to the transferred asset as consideration for the transfer. Taxpayers and professional groups have made a number of representations over difficulties that company groups experience in reorganising their business affairs to meet these requirements.

The Government has considered the arguments put to it and has decided to replace the existing requirements with a new anti-avoidance provision-to be inserted by this Bill-that will deem a transferred asset to have been disposed of at market value if the group relationship between the two companies subsequently ceases. The Government believes that this change will make it easier for company groups to reorganise without suffering any adverse capital gains tax consequences, while still maintaining the Government's antiavoidance objectives.

The Bill also proposes a number of technical measures to ensure that no artificial timing advantages are obtained by shareholders in a company as a result of the transfer of an asset to another group company for reduced consideration. At present, such asset transfers between 100 per cent commonly owned company groups can result in the early realisation of capital losses or reduced capital gains on the disposal of shares in the transferor company. Advantages can also arise in some cases in respect of loans made to the transferor company.

The Government believes that no taxpayer should obtain tax advantages by reason of an internal reorganisation of a company group's affairs, as a result of which assets are transferred within the group. To prevent this, the Bill proposes a series of cost base adjustments to shares or loans held, directly and indirectly, in the respective companies, that is, the transferor and transferee of the asset. The adjustments are intended to reflect changes in the value of shares or loans held within the group following the transfer of assets from one group company to another.

These provisions will apply only where actual consideration paid for the transfer of an asset is less than its indexed cost base or, if less, its market value. In other words, companies will be able to avoid the need to make any cost base adjustments by ensuring that consideration equal to the indexed cost base of an asset is paid for its transfer.

Finally, the Bill will make a number of technical amendments to make it clear that the capital gains tax consequences on the disposal of a partnership asset will be accounted for by the individual partners, and not by the partnership. The capital gains tax rollover and partnership amendments will not substantially change the operation of the existing law and should have no revenue impact. The amendments to deny timing advantages for asset transfers between commonly owned companies will prevent significant but unquantifiable revenue losses.
Dividend Imputation Arrangements for Life Assurance Companies

Under present law, tax paid by a company gives rise to a franking credit which may be used to frank dividends paid to shareholders. This is also the case for mutual life assurance companies and government insurance offices which have no shareholders to whom dividends can be paid.

Amendments contained in the Bill will give effect to the Budget announcement to deny mutual life assurance companies and government insurance offices the right to maintain a franking account, and cancel any surplus of franking credits held by them at 21 August 1990.

As also announced in the Budget, franking credits arising to non-mutual life assurance companies from the beginning of their next franking year on account of tax paid on the income from statutory fund business will be reduced by 80 per cent.

These measures will stop double dipping of imputation credits and prevent the potential loss of significant but unquantifiable amounts of revenue. New shareholders of companies that were previously mutuals, or of privatised government insurance offices, will not have access to franking credits that arose before such companies changed their status.

The Bill will also give effect to the Government's decision that franking credits should arise to non-mutual life assurance companies for 20 per cent of franked dividends paid on assets included in their insurance funds. This will apply to franked dividends received by the companies from the beginning of their next franking year.
Bereavement Payments

The Social Security and Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Act (No.4) 1989 gave effect to a number of measures announced in the 1989-90 Budget, including a scheme of bereavement payments to either replace the tax exempt special temporary allowance and funeral benefit, or to make such payments in a number of situations not previously covered by the special temporary allowance. This Bill will ensure that the taxation treatment of bereavement payments is broadly the same as the treatment which applied to the benefits they replaced.

Specifically, the Bill will exempt from tax the additional pension payment that is made following the death of a pensioner without a pensioner spouse, and the payment made to a third party in the situation where the death of the first deceased pensioner is not notified until after the spouse has also died. Further, the bereavement payment made following the death of a child to a person who was in receipt of a child related payment will also be exempt.

Sole parent's pension is now continued for 14 weeks after the death of the only qualifying child. These payments will continue to be included in assessable income. The continuation of carer's pension for 14 weeks after the death of the person being cared for, not being the carer's spouse, will be exempt in certain circumstances where the recipient is under age pension age.
The Bill will also exempt from tax the bereavement payment made to a widow or widower of a veteran or mariner who was in receipt of a disability pension.
The estimated cost to revenue of these proposals is less than $500,000 in a full year.
Foreign Source Income Measures

This Bill will give effect to the proposal announced in the Budget to extend the scope of certain special deduction provisions of the income tax law relating to capital expenditures incurred in particular activities or investments which take place in Australia.

Those provisions are to be broadened to allow these deductions for relevant capital expenditures incurred after 7.30 p.m. eastern standard time on 21 August 1990 in the derivation of income that will be assessable in Australia.
In particular, the Bill will extend, in relation to foreign activities that generate assessable income-
* the deductions relating to mining and petroleum activities in Australia;
* the deductions for industrial property granted, registered or subsisting in Australia; and
* the deductions for capital expenditure on buildings in Australia.
It is estimated that the cost to revenue of extending these deductions will be less than $15m in 1991-92 and subsequent years.

It was also announced in the Budget that, because of the way the income tax law dealing with bad debts is couched, it is arguable that a financial institution is entitled to an income tax deduction for bad debts of its foreign branch that are written off even though, under the proposed new foreign income measures, the income of the branch will generally be exempt from Australian income tax. Measures in this Bill will ensure that a deduction will not be allowable for bad debts in these circumstances.

An appropriate apportionment arrangement will apply where a relevant loan has been created or acquired after 7.30 p.m. Australian eastern standard time on 21 August 1990, and some of the income derived from the loan debt will be assessable to Australian tax. While there is no revenue gain or loss from this measure, it could be significant in protecting the revenue.

Other amendments contained in this Bill are directed at removing some potential for double taxation and correcting technical deficiencies in legislation now before the Parliament in terms of the Foreign Income Bill, and at removing tax avoidance avenues.

Some of these amendments are aimed at ensuring continuity in the capital gains tax treatment of assets when an entity either ceases to be or becomes an Australian resident. For the purpose of calculating the attributable income, the assets will be treated as having been disposed of and re-acquired on the change of residence. This will ensure that no part of any capital gain is taxed twice.

Also to eliminate double taxation, income of a controlled foreign company will not be attributed to Australian taxpayers where they hold interests in the CFC through another entity resident in a country that taxes the income under its accrual tax measures.

Other measures in the Bill will extend foreign tax credit and exemption arrangements to certain deemed dividends subject to appropriate notification within one year of the end of the relevant financial year. These credits and exemptions would then be available in much the same way as where an actual dividend is paid.

The definitions of `exempting receipt' and `notional exempt income' in the Foreign Income Bill are to be amended to ensure that premiums paid for insurance or reinsurance with non-residents are not categorised with income that has been subject to full rates of Australian tax. The cases covered are those where, under special provisions of our domestic law, only 10 per cent of the premium income is subject to Australian tax.

Changes being made to the foreign branch exemption provisions will create greater certainty about the time at which the tests for exemption are to be met, and close off tax avoidance opportunities. They will also align the treatment of foreign source capital gains and losses of an overseas branch of a resident company. This will be done by ensuring that a foreign capital loss is not available for offset against capital gains where, had that loss been a gain, it would have been exempt from tax.

Other measures in the Bill will close potential avoidance avenues by the use of interposed partnerships and trusts to prevent Australian residents being assessed on income from a CFC, and will allow a deduction for interest payable on certain convertible notes in calculating the attributable income of a CFC.

This Bill will also amend the Fringe Benefits Tax Assessment Act 1986, to effect minor technical changes consequential upon the proposed introduction-in the Foreign Income Bill-of a new system for the quarantining of foreign losses. The revenue impact of the amendments to the foreign income measures is not quantifiable.
Protection of Information

The Bill will amend the provisions in the Taxation Administration Act in two respects. The existing law makes it an offence for a person knowingly to take action to obtain information held under or for the purposes of a Commonwealth taxation law, unless the person does so in the course of exercising powers or performing functions under the law. This is having the unintended effect of hindering enforcement activities by State and Territory taxation authorities which, for purposes of their own revenue laws, are seeking access to information collected by businesses and used for the purposes of a Commonwealth taxation law.

The law will be changed so that an offence is committed if a person takes action other than in authorised circumstances to obtain access to records containing information about a person's affairs, but only if those records are in the possession of the Commissioner of Taxation and are held by the Commissioner for the purposes of a Commonwealth taxation law.

The relevant provision will no longer operate to prohibit access to records that are in the possession of someone other than the Commissioner. The amendment will not adversely affect the confidentiality of tax file number or other personal information as the taxation and criminal laws contain safeguards which ensure that any unauthorised conduct in these areas is an offence.

Finally, the law will be strengthened to create an additional offence if a person uses information in respect of another person's affairs held by the Commissioner, where the information was obtained by breach of a taxation law.
I present the explanatory memorandum which contains more detailed explanations of the provisions of the Bill. I commend the Bill to the House.
Debate (on motion by Mr Costello) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 5 December, on motion by Mr Duffy:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Costello Mr P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Privacy Amendment Bill 1990 is misguided legislation. It takes into the Privacy Act matters that ought to be the subject of a separate Act; it relies on an artificial use of Commonwealth constitutional power; it is opposed by the States, which have constitutional authority; it proposes enormous costs to industry; it proposes substantial costs to revenue, which the Government has not come clean about; it regulates consumer credit only and leaves unregulated other substantial areas where individual privacy ought to be protected; it denies access for those with legitimate interests to information on credit default and credit taking; and it constitutes a substantial imposition on small business.

SPEECH.PARA: The Commonwealth Parliament can do better than this. There are concrete proposals, which are substantially better, before the Parliament in the form of a private member's Bill. We offer the Government the opportunity to think again, to consult with business and to make sure it gets it right before it introduces this misguided legislation. As a result of that, I move:
That all words after ``That'' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:
``the House declines to give the Bill a second reading as it is of the opinion that the Bill:
(a) imposes arbitrary and unjustified prohibitions on the collection of information concerning the credit standing of applicants for consumer and commercial credit;
(b) fails to allow commercial organisations with legitimate needs to access credit records;

(c) will deter the detection of insurance fraud, add to the cost of insurance, add to the cost of goods and services and impose additional costs and inefficiency on business, consumers and commercial operations;
(d) will not adequately protect individual privacy;
(e) is opposed by a number of State Ministers for Consumer Affairs: and
(f) relies upon dubious constitutional authority''.
I ask the Government to reconsider, to vote for the amendment, to start again and do much better.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the amendment seconded?
—The amendment is seconded.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scott Mr L.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to be able to support the Privacy Amendment Bill 1990 which is before the House and, of course, to reject the amendment moved by the honourable member for Higgins (Mr Costello). I listened to the honourable member for Higgins last night and again just briefly this afternoon. He is certainly getting mixed up with regard to what this whole matter is all about.

SPEECH.PARA: If he had referred to the Bill itself and also to the second reading speech, he would have realised that this matter is about privacy protection for individuals in relation to their consumer credit records. I think that is very important. Privacy is something that we all cherish greatly. We are always very conscious of our own assets and information kept about us.

The other point made by the honourable member for Higgins that I want to pick up is in relation to businesses trying to provide credit for various clients. The Bill actually picks that up in proposed new section 18K, which provides that information can be made available to credit providers provided that the credit provider has specific written instructions or authority from his client. It is an important area that has been covered. I do not think that some of the concerns expressed by the honourable member for Higgins are valid.

The Bill represents a watershed in privacy provisions at two distinct levels: firstly, through the extension of information privacy principles contained in the Privacy Act to a private database; and, secondly, through the creation of a complete array of consumer rights in relation to that database.

In today's climate, the importance of a good credit rating cannot be underestimated. Take the case of a family applying for a housing loan. It would be grossly unfair for any incorrectly recorded information pertaining to the couple's previous credit history to be the sole reason for their loan application being refused. The honourable member for Higgins mentioned a similar situation with regard to real estate agents. It would be dreadful for somebody to be refused a roof over his head in a rental situation purely on the basis of credit reference information. I think that there are other ways of dealing with the situation. Rental accommodation is excepted. Bonds, rent in advance and all those sorts of aspects are covered quite well. It would be dreadful if someone were refused accommodation for his family because of misinformation provided to a credit bureau or agency.

Allegations that a person has failed to respond to letters requesting that he contact a financial institution may not necessarily be true. The person may not have responded because he had changed his address. A change of address form may not have been received by the institution. If it had been received, it may not have been recorded correctly.

These days a lot of information is kept on computers. I am sure that many honourable members have found when they have tried to notify a change of address that they still get mail sent to the incorrect address. These things do take time and errors do happen from time to time. Certainly, it would be pretty bad news if someone were adversely affected in that way.

If either of those situations were the case, people would have felt that they had adequately ensured that the institution knew of their whereabouts. For these and a host of other reasons, a person may incur a bad credit rating. Therefore, when people apply for loans, it is important that the credit information recorded by agencies be as accurate as possible. It should also be the case that where information has been incorrectly recorded a person should have reasonable means of redressing that error. The Bill specifically addresses this area in that in cases where a credit provider refuses an application for credit and the refusal is based wholly or partly on information derived from a credit reporting agency, that credit provider must give notice to the individual in writing as to why the application has been refused, whether the refusal was based wholly or partly, as the case requires, on information derived from a credit report given by a credit reporting agency, and the name and address of the credit reporting agency. The individual has the right under the Act to obtain access to his credit information file maintained by the credit reporting agency.

Such measures have twofold benefits in that they place great emphasis on the need for credit reporting agencies to maintain accurate records-something that is in their own interests, that protects their own credibility and that, importantly, gives the individual the means necessary to redress any erroneous records that a credit reporting agency may hold in his name. It is also only fair and reasonable that there be limits to the use or disclosure of material held by credit reporting agencies and, once information is given to credit providers, that they too be limited in what they are able to do with that information.

The Bill clearly provides for the first of these in its requirement for a credit reporting agency in possession or control of an individual's credit information file not to disclose personal information contained in the file to any person other than the individual, unless the information is required for the purposes of determining that individual's eligibility for credit of some kind.

The legislation also prohibits credit reporting agencies from disclosing personal information contained in an individual's credit information file if the file or other record contains personal information that the credit reporting agency would be prohibited from including in an individual's credit information file or would be required to delete from such a file. These requirements are backed up by severe penalties. Any credit reporting agency that knowingly or recklessly contravenes either of the above requirements is guilty of a maximum penalty of $150,000.

Additional safeguards for individuals include the requirement for credit reporting agencies to include a note on a person's file of any disclosures of information, and the requirement for agencies not to include in a credit report given to a credit provider any information relating to that person's commercial activities. Once the information has been given to credit providers, strict limitations are provided for in the Bill as to what the credit provider is able to do with that information.

The credit provider must not use the report or any personal information derived from the report for any purpose other than assessing an application for credit made to the credit provider by the individual concerned except in extreme circumstances. Such circumstances may be where the report was obtained from a record containing publicly accessible information and the credit provider uses the report or information to assess an application for credit made to the credit provider by the individual concerned; where the credit provider uses the information to assist in the collection of payments that are overdue in respect of credit provided to the individual by the credit provider; or where the credit provider believes, on reasonable grounds, that the individual has committed a serious credit infringement and the report or information is used in connection with that infringement. The penalty for breaching such conditions is also a maximum of $150,000.

Importantly, the possibility of positive reporting, that is, the provision of all information about a person's financial dealings, has been closed off through the imposition of such limitations to the use of credit information. Credit consumers' rights are greatly enhanced through the Bill's provisions for a person authorised by the Privacy Commissioner to enter the premises of credit reporting agencies and credit providers to inspect documents for the purposes of performing the Commissioner's functions as designated under the Act. It is also a requirement of the Bill that the person whose premises are entered should provide reasonable assistance to the person carrying out the investigation on behalf of the Commissioner.

Having a secondary interest in consumer protection through my involvement with the Ipswich and West Moreton Consumers Association in my electorate of Oxley, I am pleased that the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) principles on personal privacy have been maintained. Much of the credit for this lies in the detailed consultation with all players in the consumer credit protection arena which has gone on for some time.

In the 18 months of deliberations that led to the passing of the legislation in the other place, a wide variety of groups have been involved, including the Privacy Commissioner, the Credit Reference Association of Australia, the Real Estate Institute of Australia, the Institute of Mercantile Agents and the Insurance Council of Australia.

The diverse background of these groups illustrates a further point, and that is the complexities of the marketplace today and the array of information people must deal with when making consumer decisions. The sheer pace of today's society makes it vital for laws such as those proposed in the Privacy Amendment Bill 1990.

Through the Bill's provisions for the Privacy Commissioner to have responsibilities for supervising the consumer credit industry, this very question is addressed. Importantly, this will mean an enhanced level of consumer protection for credit consumers to a degree that will protect Australians from the sort of practices which have flourished in this area in the United States.

Through such measures Australia has adhered to the OECD's guidelines on personal privacy. These principles cover that there should be limits to the collection of personal data. Any such data should be obtained by lawful and fair means with the knowledge or consent of the data-subject; that personal data should be relevant to the purpose for which it is to be used and should be accurate; that the purposes for which personal data is collected should be specified at the time of collection and subsequent use limited to the fulfilment of these purposes.

Further, that personal data should not be disclosed for other purposes except with the consent of the data-subject or where required by law; that personal data should be protected by security safeguards, and individuals should be aware who holds their personal data; that individuals should have a right of access to and correction of their personal data; and that a data controller should be accountable for complying with measures to give effect to these principles.

While these internationally acclaimed principles are encompassed in the Bill, it is important to point out that so too is the protection of any existing State and Territory laws relating to interferences with privacy in credit reporting and which are capable of operating concurrently with this legislation. Appropriately, the conditions contained in the Bill are also extended to every external Territory of Australia. This will provide for a smooth transition for the changes contained in this legislation with consumers not being required to come to grips with a complete new protection system.

Redefinition of some terms contained in the Privacy Act 1988 will enhance further protection of credit information in Australia. For example, there needs to be a clear distinction between the protection of credit records in the commercial sector and those of individual consumers. This distinction is central to the scheme defined in the Bill. Because credit, as it is already defined, refers to consumer credit, the insertion of a new definition is required to cover non-consumer credit in view of the distinction between the two areas.

Hence the Bill satisfactorily addresses the need for the distinction by defining non-consumer credit as a loan given to an individual, other than a loan given to an individual to be used for domestic family or household, that is, consumer credit purposes.

To facilitate smooth administration of credit reporting regulations, the definition of a `credit reporting business' deliberately considers only such organisations to be those businesses or undertakings that involve themselves in the preparation or maintenance of records containing personal information relating to individuals for the purpose of providing information to other persons on an individual's eligibility to be provided with credit, history in relation to credit, or capacity to repay credit, whether or not the information is provided for the purposes of assessing applications for credit.

Because the purpose of the Bill is not to regulate the reporting of publicly available information, the definition does not include a business or undertaking that prepares records in which the only personal information is publicly available information.

With the complexities consumers face when making their daily transactions, there is an ever-increasing amount of information about individuals' credit histories. It is therefore imperative that there be limits placed on the number of institutions able to access that information which may be held by credit reporting agencies.

Clause 11B of the Bill addresses this specific need by providing that a body will be regarded as a credit provider for the purposes of the principal Act if the body is either a bank or a corporation which is one of the following: a building society, a credit union, a retailer which issues credit cards or charge cards, or a corporation a substantial part of whose business is the provision of loans, including the issue of credit cards or charge cards.

To link in with the previously cited distinction in definitions between domestic consumer credit and that of commercial concerns, this definition of credit providers will also include commercial credit providers. The benefit here is that in certain circumstances, disclosure of a consumer credit report by a credit reporting agency to a commercial credit provider will be allowed, as will the use of commercial credit reports by a credit provider for the assessment of consumer credit transactions. An integral part of the legislation is the provision for the development of a code of conduct for the collection and handling of personal credit information by the Privacy Commissioner.

Clause 18A of the Bill provides that the code can deal with the following: the collection of personal information for inclusion in individuals' credit information files; the storage of, security of, access to, correction of, use of, and disclosure of personal information included in individuals' credit information files or in credit reports; any other activities engaged in by credit reporting agencies or credit providers that are connected with credit reporting; and the procedure for the manner in which disputes between individuals, credit providers, and credit reporting agencies, including their initial resolution, are to be handled by the industry.

The consultative process that has been a piece of this legislation since its inception is again evident in the requirement for the Privacy Commissioner, in formulating the code, to consult with the credit industry, government, consumer and privacy groups and other relevant bodies to the extent that it is appropriate and practical to do so.

In addition, in preparing the code of conduct, the Commissioner is required to have regard for the information privacy principles set out in Section 14 of the principal Act, the provisions of part IIIA of the principal Act, and the likely costs to credit reporting agencies and credit providers of complying with the code of conduct.

On this last point, it is estimated that there will be minimal direct cost impact on consumer credit reporting agencies and credit providers, as the industry already finances a self-regulatory scheme for the industry. Clause 18B of the legislation requires that a credit reporting agency or a credit provider must not engage in any activity that breaches the code and in doing so regards any breach of the code of conduct as an interference with an individual's privacy.``As such, a credit reporting agency or credit provider could be prosecuted for an offence or be liable to pay damages as compensation for an infringement of an individual's privacy.

There are contained in the Bill rigid guidelines on organisations permitted to operate as credit reporting agencies. It is only those persons who are corporations who are able to carry out a credit reporting business.

Further strengthening the Government's commitment to privacy of individuals in the consumer credit area is the imposition of a maximum penalty of $30,000 for anyone who breaches such conditions. Strict limitations also exist as to the information which may be kept on a credit information file. Such information is limited to information which has a direct and relevant bearing upon eligibility for consumer credit.

Under the legislation proposed before us tonight, credit reporting agencies will be prohibited from holding personal information on any individual, except where the information relates to records of applications made for credit; defaulted payments-that is, where the individual's payments to the credit provider are at least 60 days overdue and the credit provider has taken steps to recover any part of the debt; bankruptcy; judgments; serious credit infringements; dishonoured cheques; and necessary identifier information. In addition, credit reporting agencies must delete from an individual's credit information file any personal information in respect of which the maximum permissible period to retain that information has expired. The Bill provides that the credit reporting agency has a period of one month after the expiry of that period in which to make the deletion.

Because of the great differences in the types of credit that people apply for today, there have been set aside varying limits on the length of time for which credit recording agencies are able to keep credit records. These include five years for information concerning a credit provider, or a mortgage or trade insurer having sought a credit report in relation to the individual. The five-year period will run from the day on which the credit report concerned was sought. A similar period is provided for in the case of credit provided to individuals that has lapsed into overdue status, and dishonoured cheques; information concerning judgments made against the individual; in the case of a notation of a current credit provider, 14 days from the day the reporting agency receives notification that the credit provider is no longer a current credit provider in relation to the individual concerned; and in cases relating to bankruptcy orders and serious credit infringements, a seven-year period of retaining credit records will be permitted.

During the time I served in my last occupation prior to coming to this place, I witnessed the down side of consumers being affected by inaccurate credit reporting, and how much those people relied on adequate protection in consumer credit areas. I can actually recall instances where information which had been provided by a credit reporting agency was incorrect, really through no fault of the individual. There may be some dispute in a lot of cases. Of course, I mentioned before that the change of address question often comes up, but certainly those cases in which there were disputes were quite common.

In conclusion, I feel it is important to emphasise how this specific Bill fits in with the Government's overall program to give consumers the necessary power to control their own financial destiny in an increasingly complex financial environment. The Bill sits firmly alongside the agreement reached earlier in the year on uniform national credit legislation. This will give consumers uniform information and uniform practices in their personal dealings with financial institutions. I point out that to complete such measures, the Government has moved to establish a complaint resolution scheme in the insurance industry and has put in place a review of levels of consumer information made available by the superannuation industry.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rocher Mr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Privacy Amendment Bill aims to extend privacy protection under the Privacy Act of 1988 to consumers subjected to credit reference reporting. It principally affects the Credit Reference Association of Australia Ltd (CRAA), which is responsible for about 98 per cent of all credit reference reporting in Australia. The CRAA is owned by its 4,800 members, who include major financial and lending institutions and various retail and manufacturing companies. This data base is accessed as many as 30,000 times a day by these credit providers.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition accepts the need for some regulation in this area. The information obtained by credit providers from consumers could be said to become the providers' property, which they should be free to dispose of as they wish, although in accordance with any conditions that consumers might wish to impose on the use of that information. Consumers and credit providers could, in theory, enter into contracts governing the uses to which credit information could be put which would obviate the need for legislation such as we are debating today. Unfortunately, the transaction costs that would be imposed by such contractual arrangements would be prohibitive if they were to adequately protect consumers from potential invasions of privacy.

Consumers generally wish to supply only enough information as will facilitate transactions for which they are seeking credit. Credit providers, however, obviously have an interest in combining and sharing this information to the greatest possible extent so as to apply it to all subsequent transactions and thereby minimise their exposure to credit risks. Today's information technology makes possible extremely comprehensive credit reference reporting. We have thus seen, on the part of the credit reporting industry, moves towards so-called positive reporting of consumers' credit records.

Such reporting would include not only the negative aspects of a person's credit record but also detailed information about spending habits, financial commitments, assets, timeliness of past repayments and the like. Credit reference reporting agencies would thereby be in a position to compile vast amounts of personal information about consumers, information that is simply unnecessary to form judgments about credit risks and which would pose a considerable threat to the privacy of individuals. It would seem that a regulatory solution to this problem is inevitable in current circumstances.

The Opposition will support moves by the Government to outlaw such positive reporting. The banning of positive reporting and the enhancement of the consumer protection provided for under the Privacy Act was to be the principal purpose of this Bill. However, the Government has taken this legislation much, much further. As it has emerged from its lengthy passage through the Senate, the Bill places numerous and unnecessary restrictions on current negative credit reporting practices. It will give Australia some of the most restrictive credit reference laws in the Western world.

This Bill prohibits much of the current commercial access to credit reference reporting. The CRAA has indicated that a great number of its current members would no longer be able to use its services after this legislation is passed. The exact number is difficult to ascertain since there is scope for greater access to be secured for some credit providers via application to the Privacy Commissioner and with the consent of consumers. Not only does this Bill impose enormous restrictions on access to credit reference reporting, in some respects it fails to adequately protect the privacy of consumers.

The principal problem with this Bill is that it is based on an entirely spurious and overly narrow definition of what constitutes credit. It is indicative of the entirely inappropriate concept of credit employed in this Bill that it effectively excludes so many of the current members of the CRAA. Credit under this Bill is defined as a loan, and then only a loan for domestic, family or household purposes. Clearly credit takes a myriad forms other than that of the direct provision of a loan to consumers. The Bill makes a wholly unrealistic distinction between personal and business credit. A lot of credit provision simply cannot be categorised in this manner. Particularly in the case of small business, it is common for commercial loans to be applied for household purposes while personal loans can be used to facilitate the operation of a business.

The effect of this narrow concept of what constitutes credit is to completely prohibit access to credit reference reporting by a whole range of credit providers such as real estate agents, insurance companies, mercantile agents and any other entity which is not deemed to be a so-called substantial credit provider under the terms of the Bill. The Attorney-General (Mr Duffy) claimed that the use of credit records for `insurance proposals, insurance fraud and rental housing' would `clearly breach privacy principles'. Why this should be so needs to be spelled out, since it is by no means obvious to us on this side of the House.

The extra costs imposed by this legislation on businesses, and ultimately consumers, will be enormous. Real estate agents will not be able to check on the solvency of tenants, despite the well established link between breaches of tenancy and credit difficulties. It will become extremely difficult for the insurance industry to combat the billion dollar insurance fraud racket.

Small businesses will not be able to use debt collectors to recover their debts economically since debt collectors will also be denied access to the CRAA database. It is small businesses such as retailers more than the large personal finance companies which are in the greatest need of the pooled resources of an organisation such as the CRAA. Yet mercantile agents are locked out of credit reference reporting by this Bill. In its place the Government somehow expects businesses to make an application to the Privacy Commissioner, who is then required to make a recommendation to the Parliament as to their suitability for access to the CRAA. There will no doubt be a stream of class-like actions by business groups, seeking a determination that they are `other credit providers' as defined, to obtain adequate security from excessive exposure to credit risk.

The Bill thus greatly enhances the powers of the Privacy Commissioner, powers against which there are inadequate appeal mechanisms. The Commissioner will be responsible for formulating the code of conduct which will regulate the behaviour of the industry. The Commissioner will be able to investigate breaches of the code, make binding determinations as to its interpretation and, where necessary, prosecute members of the industry for breaching the code. The Commissioner will thus be the rule-maker, judge and jury all rolled into one.

It is interesting that even Telecom Australia, which is one of the biggest credit providers in Australia, is denied access to credit reference reporting under this Bill, despite the millions of dollars it loses to bad debts every year. While this might not make much of a dent in Telecom's enormous monopoly profits, these problems will be devastating for many small businesses.

The cost of this Bill has been variously estimated at between $1.3 billion and $2.4 billion per year. These costs will be passed on directly to consumers in the form of higher prices and higher premiums. There will be a massive and wholly undeserved transfer of wealth from responsible consumers who will face higher prices to the increasing numbers of debtors who will be able to escape the wrath of the law under this misconceived legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —No!

—I see that the honourable member for Chifley is shaking his head. Who does he think is going to pay the $1.3 billion to $2.4 billion? I know that he believes in the fairies because he will follow the Treasurer (Mr Keating) anywhere and accept the nonsense that he trots out day after day. Who does he think is going to pay the $1.3 billion-plus a year? It will be the consumers, and the sooner that gets through his thick skull the sooner he will be developing sensible legislation in this place.

SPEECH.PARA: There will be a massive and wholly undeserved transfer of wealth from responsible consumers, and they will face higher prices. We will get a larger number of over-committed borrowers and creditors due to the greatly reduced accessibility to credit reporting. The Government subscribes to the nonsense that we see trotted out from time to time about how those in the lower socio-economic groups are the object of predators in the commercial world. Yet it goes through this sort of nonsense to facilitate the very thing it rails and rants against in this place. It does not think it through. It is particularly true of the honourable member for Chifley because he does not understand how these mechanisms work.

In order to illustrate the effects of this Bill, I need only quote from a letter to the Australian Financial Review on 30 August this year in which P. J. Balsarini, Managing Director of A &K Mercantile Pty Ltd, said:

From a selfish point of view, I hope the Bill does exclude debt collectors. If no debt collector has access to the Credit Reference Association of Australia, we all remain on an equal footing and the legislation will increase referrals to companies like mine.

It is debtors and debt collectors who will benefit from this Bill. The Bill encourages credit providers to seek out alternative, unregulated, and perhaps more intrusive means of assessing the creditworthiness of individuals and to track down debts.

In the case of the real estate industry, for example, we are bound to see the emergence of tenant databases that will be completely outside the scope of this legislation. Credit providers will adopt arbitrary measures of the creditworthiness of their customers in an attempt to compensate them for the lack of information available to them. They will resort to subjective appraisals of people's creditworthiness, whereas they previously had access to the far more objective information available from the CRAA. This will disadvantage people from lower socio-economic groups, and people with other characteristics of dubious relevance to their creditworthiness.

Despite extensive regulation of credit reference reporting there are some major omissions in terms of the privacy protection afforded by the proposed amendments to the Act. There is no automatic notification to consumers when credit reference files are accessed. The artificial distinction between personal and commercial credit means that while individuals seeking personal loans must be notified if their credit reference report was responsible for their being denied a loan, would-be commercial borrowers have no such benefit; nor can commercial borrowers access their credit files or challenge the accuracy of information in them in the way that personal credit users can.

The Bill thus violates many of the provisions of the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development guidelines on personal privacy, which the Minister claims this legislation is meant to uphold. It is little wonder then that business and the credit reference reporting industry have been overwhelmingly opposed to this Bill. This Bill imposes enormous and wholly unnecessary costs on the Australian community, and yet contains major omissions in terms of its protection of the privacy of individuals, which was the supposed rationale for this legislation in the first place. This Bill totally fails to achieve the balanced approach that the Minister claimed for it in his second reading speech.

It is for those reasons and others advanced by the honourable member for Higgins (Mr Costello) that I wholeheartedly support his amendment. He goes to the heart of the matters of concern to us where he refers to the Bill proposing arbitrary and unjustified prohibitions on the collection of information concerning the credit standing of applicants for consumer and commercial credit. Between us I think we have detailed enough argument to support that contention.

This Bill fails to allow commercial organisations with legitimate needs access to credit records. It will deter the detection of insurance fraud, as I have already said. It will add to the cost of insurance. It will add to the cost of goods and services and impose additional costs and inefficiency on business, on consumers and on commercial operations. It will not, I am afraid to say, adequately protect individual privacy. It is opposed by a number of State Ministers for consumer affairs. I would have thought that the Minister at the table, who made such a virtue out of the cooperation he has been able to obtain from all governments in connection with corporations legislation, would have made the effort to get the cooperation and support of his State counterparts. Obviously if he has sought to do that he has been singularly unsuccessful because there is much opposition from State Ministers for consumer affairs or their equivalents, as I have said.

The corporations legislation-that enormous piece of legislation, probably the most important in terms of company law in this country in my 12 years in the Parliament-was guillotined through the House of Representatives in something like 70 minutes or less at the last sitting. No wonder people in Western Australia are saying, `What is this Government about? It won't even debate the most important piece of corporation legislation-in the history of the country, probably-in the House of Representatives.

TALK.START.PARA: —Sixteen people.
—Sixteen people? Would you explain that?
—They blocked it--

—It has not been debated in the House of Representatives. The Government has chopped it through in 60 to 70 minutes. That is what I am saying. If the Government cannot go through the parliamentary processes demanded of us as elected representatives, why would it expect the upper House in Western Australia to pay much attention to it? Why would that House take the Government seriously--
—I raise a point of order. The honourable member for Curtin is obviously straying to one Bill that has passed through the House of Representatives and away from the Bill under consideration.

—I think the point of order is correct. I accept it. I will not stray any more. The Attorney-General (Mr Duffy) provoked me and I did not quite understand his interjection. This Bill does, as the honourable member for Higgins has said in his amendment, also rely on dubious constitutional authority. I am no lawyer. The Minister is a lawyer and he shakes his head. I have seen that happen once or twice before and it has not proven to be the case. I guess we will have to wait to see on that, but a challenge to its constitutionality does seem likely.

SPEECH.PARA: This is a crazy piece of legislation. It is motivated by some sort of anti-business sentiment. It misses the main point in that it does not adequately address the needs for the privacy of individuals.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is a better Bill in the House.

—Indeed, there is a better Bill in the House, and I thank the honourable member for Goldstein for reminding me of that. The amendment does deserve to be supported and even the honourable member for Chifley (Mr Price) might come around to our point of view.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Price Mr L.R.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I speak against the amendment, I speak for the Privacy Amendment Bill and I speak for the poor. I notice that the honourable member for Curtin (Mr Rocher) raised the plight of the poor. The plight of the poor has got nothing to do with this Bill. Indeed, the plight of the economy has got nothing to do with the poor; it has got all to do with corporate cowboys wasting billions of dollars.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member did make a number of remarks during his contribution which I need to respond to. He pointed to the plight of real estate agents, which I thought was an unfortunate example. Here we are talking about the provision of credit. What happens if people want to lease or rent a house, a flat or a unit? The first thing they have to do is put a bond up. They are not going to draw on credit; they actually have to provide the reverse. They must provide physical money to the real estate agent. Often it is necessary to provide a week's rent in advance. That is not credit; that is the reverse. The real estate agents are getting money out of their clients. If the clients are poor, it hurts. So it is not really a credit transaction at all. The ones who are benefiting, the ones who have got the money, are in fact the real estate agents. I do not understand at all why the honourable member raises the plight of real estate agents.

Like the honourable member, I have had real estate agents come to talk to me. Yes, there have been some who have bleated about it and said that it is terrible and they cannot do it. Others have said, `Look, quite frankly, we have a number of ways of assessing clients and we will be using those. They will not be intrusive; they will not invade people's privacy; but they will rely on our good business judgment. After all, I am assessed by owners on the quality of the tenants I put in, their turnover rate, the return they are getting on their buildings. I have in my wherewithal as a small businessman sufficient judgment, acumen, whatever, not to require to be propped up as I currently am'. I report those remarks quite frankly.

Perhaps the honourable member for Curtin is saying that in Western Australia there is a lower quality of real estate agent. There certainly is a lower quality of corporate cowboy-or maybe a higher quality. In the electorate of Chifley in New South Wales we have our fair share of poor people. They are great people. The honourable member made the absurd proposition that small business would not now be able to use debt collectors. I have really looked through the speeches and the Bill, and I cannot see why debt collectors are going to be excluded from recovering debt.

I want to raise a concern with the Attorney-General (Mr Duffy) about the implication of the Bill because I do believe people need to be protected. I notice that in some areas the Bill shows flexibility and latitude. For example, it allows non-credit providers, people who are not banks or finance companies, to seek a reference, providing they have the written authority of the party, which is exactly the situation outlined by the honourable member for Curtin. It can be done on a voluntary basis, as it should be.

I have a concern to make sure that people do not abuse this, that they have their rights and that they have full information. I say to our Privacy Commissioner, Mr O'Connor: this is an area that I think you ought to monitor carefully. People will be interested to know how effective it is. They will want to know that people are not being intimidated, whether they be small sublessees or even tenants of real estate agents. Should those unfortunate real estate agents in the honourable member's electorate who have to rely solely on outside information and who cannot apply their skills to the problem of selecting tenants intimidate the tenants and force them to sign voluntary contracts?

The honourable member raised the issue of Telecom. It really made me smile because here again we have customers who are asked to pay rent in advance. They are not asking for credit. They have to pay a connection fee. They have to pay rent in advance. Then they get a quarterly bill. I have been very critical about Telecom's approach to credit management because it arbitrarily, and not on a uniform basis, applies security deposits. The practice varies from district to district. I have described it previously as a tax on the poor. I find it offensive and it is an area which we need to clean up. Here we are saying, `Poor Telecom has been excluded from drawing on privacy information'. I have said to Telecom often enough that this is an act it will have to clean up. Of course, with a second competitor, it will not have any choice about whether it delays cleaning it up.

I think Opposition members have been very short-sighted in their contributions. Sure, we live in an age where businesses have access to information and like it as quickly as possible, preferably in real time; but we have to protect their clients, their customers and their subcontractors. We must ensure that the information they seek is proper and appropriate and it is not breaching privacy. Why would a piece of legislation dealing with credit reference not allow information only to those organisations like banks and finance companies actually providing credit? I fully support this Bill.
Sitting suspended from 6.30 to 8 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the suspension of the sitting for dinner, I was responding to some of the remarks of the honourable member for Curtin. In particular, he raised the issue of real estate agents and asked why we had not responded to their need for credit reference information. I think every member on this side of the House would have been contacted by real estate agents. I certainly was. They came to see me and wanted representations made. But the real crux of the issue is what actually happens to individuals seeking to rent a house or a unit. They do not seek credit; they are not extended credit by the real estate agent or the owner. In fact, the real estate agent, acting on behalf of the owners, asks for a bond as a deposit of goodwill to ensure their appropriate conduct. If people go to a real estate agent they have to put some money up; they are not getting credit. Real estate agents often ask for rent in advance. Once again, it is not an issue of the real estate agent or the owner being a provider of credit or money; it is actually the reverse-the tenants put the money up front.

SPEECH.PARA: I suppose there is a case to be argued about the rights of tenants to have information about the owners, because tenants are extending credit by way of bonds and rent in advance. The real crunch is that when people actually sit down and work through the issues with the real estate agents, as I have done, they will tell people that when they are making their assessments of tenants they do not have to rely solely-as apparently the real estate agents in the electorate of the honourable member for Curtin do-on the information provided by the Credit Reference Association of Australia Ltd. They are small business men, they are in a very aggressively competitive area and they are able to make realistic judgments about tenants without that information.

I have no real concerns, and nor should anyone else, from my perspective. It is just a pity that the honourable member for Curtin does not do the decent thing and speak up for the poor and the vulnerable in our community. He should speak frankly to his real estate agents and suggest that if they are giving him problems-but I do not know that they really are-they should use their good business sense and judgment to make those sorts of decisions.

I am very pleased to report that in this Bill we are not moving to positive reporting. There is a tendency to want all sorts of information, to pool it and then have to question where and how it will affect individuals. Of course, a positive system of reporting would mean development of a system of reporting comprehensively on a person's credit history regardless of any new loan application or defaults on a payment.

Under this positive reporting system, as is described in the second reading speech, people who use consumer credit in any form-for example, credit cards or personal loans-would have a monthly statement on their account provided by their relevant credit providers to a central national database operated by a central agency. Credit providers would supply the reporting agency with computer tapes of all their customers' credit accounts. These tapes would have been merged with the central database, usually every 60 days.
