Credit providers would receive a report listing all known credit accounts, the balance owing on each account and its currency. I am very pleased about that.

As I said, I stand here opposed to the amendment pursued-quite fallaciously, I believe-by members of the Opposition, although it is realistic in terms of their real concerns. They are not concerned for the poor; they are concerned for the big money end of the community. I stand for the poor and I stand in support of this Bill.

The amendment is an extension to the original Act, the Privacy Act 1988. In terms of the Act and this amendment, I want to report to the House some problems I have experienced as a member of this Parliament in relation to the application of the Privacy Act. Indeed, I have discussed the matters with the Privacy Commissioner. Unfortunately, some departments were, in my view, restricting members in the conduct of legitimate constituent representations to departments. They took the view that departments ought to have to get their members of parliament to provide written authority before the members or their staff could pursue the matter. I am pleased to report to the House that, following discussions with the Attorney-General, whom, I sincerely thank for his keen interest in and concern about the matter, and with the Privacy Commissioner, Mr Kevin O'Connor, we were able to overcome these difficulties. I am 90 per cent satisfied with the resolution of these matters.

These matters touch on two important principles. I think we do have a need vigorously to protect people's individual requirements. I know, Mr Speaker, that you and the Clerks of this House take a great interest in the ability of ordinary members of parliament adequately to represent their constituents. I commend you and them for it. But we must fight at all stages to ensure that members are unrestricted in their ability to represent vigorously the concerns that their constituents may have. This is a fundamental principle of our Westminster system and we must always ensure that neither the Executive nor the departments are ever able to encroach on that ability. One of the fine things about our Australian form of democracy is the physical presence of members in electorates via their electorate offices, through the staff they have working for them, and thus the ability of ordinary people to approach their member of parliament about any concern that they have.

That is not always the case. Although this Parliament may have, and should have, a great concern to protect individuals from any encroachments on privacy, in this case I was legitimately pursuing a concern that was inhibiting my staff and me from adequately pursuing those inquiries. I do not want to dwell overly on it, but people are presented with a difficulty in, for example, migration. Do we really need to get a written authority from the person seeking to sponsor a family member or do we need that in conjunction with a written authority from the person being sponsored? In some countries that may present little difficulty. But in many other countries just using the mail system can be a real problem. Therefore, I found that inhibition to be most abhorrent.

Whilst my colleagues on both sides of the House have all the natural foibles that can be seen outside in the people whom we represent, I think it is fair to say that it is exceptionally rare for members to fail to diligently and legitimately pursue the interests of their constituents. If any member fails in that regard and in some way abuses his authority for some other motive-the press is always willing to pick it up and rightly bring it to public attention-that member should receive all the condemnation that the public would heap upon him. But it is not my experience that that happens; my experience is that quite the reverse happens, that members of Parliament take the responsibility placed upon them by the public very seriously, as do the members of their staffs. They earnestly and diligently try to get the best result they can for their constituents, and they should not be inhibited by any Act of this Parliament in the pursuit of it.

It appeared that the Privacy Act was indeed inhibiting. I am pleased to say that that turned out not to be the case. However, I place on record that it is a great temptation for me at some later stage to present an amendment to the Bill which would make the rights of members of Parliament, pursuing the legitimate interests of their constituents, quite clear.

I finish by saying that I do have great confidence in the Privacy Commissioner. This legislation imposes some heavy penalties for any breaches of the Act. I suggest to anyone who is contemplating breaching the Act to desist. I have confidence that the Privacy Commissioner will vigorously exercise his duties if called upon to do so. Of course, it is up to individuals in the first instance to try to resolve their differences before the Privacy Commissioner is brought into play.

I note that, in pursuing consumer protection in its most recent form, this Government and Parliament-not so much the Parliament as certainly the Minister-established an independent banking ombudsman on the basis that cost recovery should apply. Whilst I support that great initiative, I had an alternative proposal. I ask the Minister: is there going to be any cost recovery from the credit reference area in the activity that the Privacy Commissioner may be involved in? If it is not currently provided for in the legislation, will the Minister, in the light of experience and practice, make an assessment and review the situation at a later date? I think that this Bill will be of great benefit to my constituents in Chifley. It is well and strongly supported on the Government side. It is just a pity that it has been so poorly misrepresented on the Opposition side.
Amendment negatived.
Original question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Leave granted for third reading to be moved forthwith.
Bill (on motion by Mr Duffy) read a third time.

DEBATE.TITLE: OCCUPATIONAL HEALTH AND SAFETY (COMMONWEALTH EMPLOYMENT) BILL 1990

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 18 October, on motion by Mr Willis:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Costello Mr P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Occupational Health and Safety (Commonwealth Employment) Bill 1990 is part of a package dealing with occupational health and safety which has been introduced by the Hawke Government. The first Bill created Worksafe Australia to promote the development and implementation of national occupational health and safety standards in 1985. The second Bill revised the Commonwealth employees compensation and rehabilitation scheme and created Comcare to administer the new scheme in 1988. This third Bill provides for the creation and implementation of occupational health and safety standards for Commonwealth employees. It integrates preventive measures with existing rehabilitation and compensation measures.

SPEECH.PARA: Schematically, Worksafe devises national standards and programs to ensure a safe working environment. This Bill will oblige Comcare to oversee their implementation in relation to Commonwealth employees and Comcare will take care of Commonwealth employees who, in spite of the precautions of the two previous measures, are injured. Let me make it clear at the outset that injury to employees is a matter of grave concern. First, of course, it involves suffering to the employees concerned, who often suffer substantial or long term injuries. That is to be regretted and, if at all possible, avoided. Injury to employees not only causes suffering to the employee himself or herself, however, but also causes suffering to families, who lose an income earner as a result.

Loss or injury to employees also dislocates the work force. If one of their number suffers an injury, this dislocates the work force and interrupts production. Of course, loss or injury to employees also has an enormous cost to employers. The Australian Bureau of Statistics has estimated that the cost of workers compensation claims in 1989-90 was around $4.8 billion-about 1.3 per cent of non-farm gross domestic product. That is an enormous cost not only to industry but also to the country as a whole in terms of its effect on output and the gross domestic product.

The Opposition is vitally interested in the prevention of loss and injury to employees. Prevention ought to be the focus of our deliberations when it comes to injuries in the workplace. Prevention is much better than cure. It is much better to prevent an accident before it occurs than to address the question of compensation afterwards. Employers have an interest in preventing accidents. After all, it is their employees that suffer loss. Regardless of what might be said, the reality is that employers and employees in many parts of this country have a very close connection and are interdependent and rely upon each other, and employers have a basic humane approach to avoiding accidents in the workplace.

Employees also have an interest in avoiding accidents in the workplace, not only for themselves but also for their families and their fellow employees. All too frequently, where work systems are in place, it is a problem to protect employees against injury when employees themselves ignore or avoid warnings. We need to reinforce not only to employers but also to employees that safety standards are there to be followed, to be observed and to protect them, and it is in their vital interests to ensure that they take notice of safety standards as much as employers.

This Bill directs itself at Commonwealth employees. Commonwealth employees, no less than other employees, have an interest in a safe working system; and the Commonwealth, its instrumentalities and agencies, no less than private employers, have an interest in providing such a system. This Bill applies to Commonwealth employers and is directed towards the laudable aim of ensuring safety for those employed by the Commonwealth, its agencies and business enterprises. The Opposition does not oppose the Bill for that reason. The Opposition believes that the Commonwealth, like any employer, has a responsibility to ensure that its employees work in a safe and secure environment.

The Bill has several parts. The first part is preliminary and the second part relates to occupational health and safety. It sets out the duties of various persons in relation to providing safety in the workplace. Clause 16 provides a duty of employers in relation to their employees. One must bear in mind, when discussing this Bill, that `employer' is defined to mean the Commonwealth or a Commonwealth authority. When clause 16 provides that an employer must take all reasonably practicable steps to protect the health and safety at work of the employer's employees, it is, of course, directed at the Commonwealth and Commonwealth authorities.

Clause 16 essentially provides the current state of the law and what is provided by the common law of tort. Employers have a duty to maintain an environment that is safe and that provides facilities for welfare at work. It also provides:
(b) in relation to any workplace under the employer's control, to:
(i) ensure the workplace is safe for the employer's employees and without risk to their health; and
(c) to ensure the safety at work or, and the absence or risks at work to the health of, employees in connection with the use, handling, storage or transport of plant or substances.
Essentially what that does is set out in statutory form what in fact is the law as developed through the common law courts over a long period.

As we move down clause 16, however, we see a few frills come into this statute. Clause 16(2)(d) provides that there is a responsibility on employers to develop, in consultation with any involved unions in relation to the employees of the employer, policies relating to occupational health and safety. What that paragraph is laudably directed towards is policies to provide healthy and safe workplaces. We have no objection to that. However, it enshrines and ensures that unions are to play a vital role in that process. This indicates that the Government really cannot help itself when it comes to all manner of things affecting workplaces and employment. It cannot help using every opportunity it can find to ensure the primacy of unions and to make sure that it writes provision for union rights and privileges into legislation.

The Commonwealth itself does not have to pass that legislation. The Commonwealth, as an employer, can work with unions in developing particular plans in relation to health and safety. What it attempts to do is, by legislation, bind itself in relation to that or, shall we say, not really bind itself but bind into such a scheme any successor government that may come along after this Government. This is reinforced in subclause (3) where the policy that is developed in consultation with unions must provide for the making of an agreement between the employer and unions with further mechanisms for continuing consultation. Why that has to be spelt out in legislation is rather beyond me. Unions have a proper role in representing employees. There is no reason why that cannot be done without laying it down in legislation.

As I said before, the Government cannot help itself. Every time it sees a piece of legislation it asks the question, `Why cannot we put the word ``union'' into this in some form or fashion?'. The answer probably was, `Well, it will not make much difference in the immediate term, but, yes, you can have it, yes, you can keep the constituency happy and, yes, you can try to ensure that sort of primacy which you like to see in all sorts of legislation'.
Clause 16 (2) (e) then goes on to require that employees be provided:
. . . in appropriate languages, the information, instruction, training and supervision necessary to enable them to perform their work in a manner that is safe and without risk to their health.

Of course employees who do not speak English ought to be given information in a language that they can understand to ensure that they work in a safe and healthy environment. I must say, however, that it does not strike me to be the primary responsibility of an employer to give language training. I would have thought that there was an obligation on the person who comes to Australia, maybe not speaking English, to try to learn the language. It is symptomatic of what I consider to be a general approach of this Government that all social obligations, whatever they be, even in relation to language, can be foisted on employers. In this case it is an obligation foisted on the Government because we are taking about the Commonwealth as an employer.

Recently I visited the Nissan Motor Co. (Australia) Pty Ltd factory in Melbourne where 70 nationalities were working on the assembly line producing Nissan motor cars. One of the things that struck me about the very enlightened management-a management that does provide English courses to those working on the assembly line-was that it did make the point that English was the language of Australia. The company expected all the employees to be able to communicate with each other and with management in English. There is a general perception in the community that those who live in Australia ought to make some effort to the learn the English language and that English ought to be the official language of Australia. I hope that we do not depart from that proposition. So clause 16 goes on to set out the duties of employers in relation to health and safety.

Clause 17 sets out the duty of employers in relation to third parties. Clause 18 sets out duties of manufacturers in relation to plant and substances. Essentially, of course, it sets out basically what was the common law position: that a person has a duty of care to his neighbour-a person who is foreseeably affected by his or her actions-and a duty of care that therefore obliges him or her to behave with reasonable care. The law, of course, imposes at common law an obligation on that person if he or she does not.

The Commonwealth has taken the opportunity of this Bill to stray wider. For example, in clause 18 (2) (c) it gets into the question of product safety standards. This is a general and, I believe, worrying feature of Commonwealth legislation that every opportunity is taken by the Commonwealth when it may be legislating on one thing or another to try to extend the ambit of its powers. Nonetheless, there we have product safety standards effectively introduced in that clause-again a matter of duplication because nearly all the States make provision for product safety standards.

Clause 19 goes on to prescribe the duty of suppliers in relation to plant and substances. Clause 20 provides for the duty of person erecting or installing plant in the workplace, and clause 21 provides for the duties of employees in relation to occupational health and safety. That, of course, is very important. As I said before, not only employers have responsibilities in relation to health and safety, but so do the employees. So many accidents are caused by employees. It is in the interests of employees, as much as anybody else, to ensure that they observe high standards in relation to health and safety, not only to protect themselves, but also to protect those with whom they work.

Part 3 is where the real action in this Bill begins to take place. This part, which is directed towards workplace arrangements, sets up a complicated and heavy-handed system for providing for working groups and electing representatives. It is a highly structured approach, which is so loved by this Government. It means that health and safety is nailed down and worked through in all sorts of complicated provisions which seem to owe as much to politicking in the workplace as anything else. What it provides is that a request may be made to an employer to enter into consultations to establish designated work groups. If unions are involved, the union can make such a request. The employer must enter into consultations with the unions or the employees. Designated work groups can be varied as a result of compulsory consultations. If there is no agreement about what the designated work group should be, this can be referred to the Australian Industrial Relations Commission.

Within 14 days after completing consultation concerning establishment of work groups, the work groups have to be established. Then there is a provision as to how the designated work groups can be varied and the notice and consultation that must be given. One would have thought that establishing a work group in a place of employment was not a particularly difficult thing, but this Bill provides a full two pages setting out how groups of employees can be formed and a complicated and heavy-handed structure as to how to do it. One would have thought that establishing a work group was not a matter that would take two pages of Commonwealth legislation, but if anything can be done simply, this Government likes to do it the long way around.

Then after one has established those work groups, one finds how the health and safety representatives are to be elected. If there are unions involved, the legislation makes provision for the person being elected as a health and safety representative to be nominated by the union. Clause 25 (5) states:
An employee in the designated work group may be a candidate in the election if and only if:
(b) where an involved union in relation to the group is conducting the election-the employee is nominated by an involved union in relation to the group.

Again, this is ensuring the primacy that this Government loves to give the unions involved. What would be wrong, for example, with a non-union member who had the support of his fellow employees being elected? But no, proposed section 25(5)(b) states that where a union is involved in conducting the election, it has to be a union member-again taking the opportunity of health and safety legislation to ensure the primacy of unions, to ensure their centrality and to ensure control in the workplace.

Indeed, in relation to these elections, if no union is involved the Occupational Health and Safety Commission can authorise a person to conduct a ballot. What we see here is a dual system growing up in the workplace of groups and elections and all sorts of other complicated and heavy-handed procedures. Once one has those health and safety representatives, those persons are given very wide-ranging powers. Under proposed section 28 they are given powers in relation to inspection and under proposed subsection (1) (d) the right to obtain access to any information under the employer's control relating to risks to health and safety of an employee.

So effectively the employer has to take these health and safety representatives into his or her confidence, and I imagine that one could almost make a career out of being a health and safety representative in the workplace. Under proposed section 29 there is the right to issue provisional improvement notices, and these can specify that there is a contravention of the Act and the action to be taken to fix it up. Then we go on to other powers, probably the most significant of which falls in proposed section 37, which states that where a health and safety representative for a designated work group has reasonable cause to believe there is an immediate threat to health and safety he can inform the supervisor, but if the supervisor cannot be found immediately, he can direct the employee to cease working.

So the health and safety representative not only has rights of inspection, provisional improvement notices and all the rest but the right to stop work if that should be deemed to be necessary. I would venture to suggest to the House that that is a wide-ranging power that could be used capriciously. No doubt the Government would argue in response that there is provision in the Bill for the disqualification of health and safety representatives where the power is used unreasonably or capriciously or indeed where the power is used with the intention of causing harm to the employer.

If one were to take the disqualification procedures, the obligation would be on the employer to prove the subjective intention of the employee-a matter which is very difficult, if not impossible, to prove-or to prove that a power was exercised unreasonably, capriciously or otherwise than for the purpose for which the power was conferred.

When the Government is really serious about preventing a particular practice, as for example under proposed section 76, to ensure that employees be not dismissed in prejudicial circumstances, it reverses the onus of proof and says that it is deemed to be in contravention of the Act unless the employer proves he was not motivated by a particular intention. Of course, the Government would not for a moment consider being even-handed and saying that health and safety representatives could be disqualified unless they could prove subjectively within their own province that they were not motivated to act to cause harm to the employer. But it is indicative of the general structure of this Act, and I ask rhetorically whether the Government can point to any circumstance where a health and safety representative has ever been disqualified. I do not believe it could, but if it can I would ask the Minister for Finance (Mr Willis) to come in and give us a few case studies of that particular situation.

This would not be a problem if there were not occasions where health and safety has been used as a pretext for other industrial demands. I have seen this happen in the work force, unfortunately. It is bad for two reasons: it is bad because it compromises legitimate concerns for health and safety where it is used as a cover for something else; such as where a health and safety representative cries wolf on health and safety and it is established that really it was a bit of a cover. The next time the representative complains about health and safety there is a tendency to disbelieve the representative or not take him or her seriously.

It is a notorious practice in the building industry where on a building site nearly anything can be characterised as a health and safety issue. I well remember looking at an industrial dispute which occurred on a Melbourne building site where an industrial demand was made and backed up with the threat that if the demand was not given, `We will make this the safest site in Melbourne'. There was no complaint about the site unless the industrial demand was not met. But if the industrial demand was not met, it was clear that all sorts of health and safety breaches were going to be found on that particular site. That illustrates the way in which health and safety can provide a cover for other industrial demands.

Therefore, we have in that part of the Act which relates to workplace arrangements and the functions of health and safety representatives a rather complex and cumbersome set of procedures fraught with danger-wide powers capable of being improperly used. But one might observe that if all of those powers are there and all of those powers can be used, one would think there would never ever have to be the generation of industrial action on health and safety. I would not object to all of those wide-ranging powers if the Government would come in here and say, `We are conferring all of those wide-ranging powers-all of those powers to protect health and safety-so that there will never need to be an industrial dispute generated about health and safety other than within the ambit of this Act'.

If the Government would come in here and say, `This is a code for dealing with health and safety; we can guarantee there will never be an industrial dispute about health and safety otherwise than in accordance with this code', all of that might be justified. But what we know is that, regardless of all those provisions, regardless of all those powers, industrial disputes are and still will be generated outside. This will effectively provide one mechanism, but only one mechanism amongst many others.

A concrete example of this occurred in Victoria recently in relation to the Hoechst dispute. In Victoria there are occupational health and safety laws; there are provisions for health and safety representatives, inspectors and provisional improvement notices. What the Act in Victoria does not say is that if such a person is worried about health and safety he can bring a 60 Minutes crew into the plant, and that is exactly what happened.

Why was there any need to bring a 60 Minutes crew into the plant when he had all these powers? What is the purpose of all these powers if he has to rely on the 60 Minutes crew to get a bit of health and safety? That dispute was generated out of health and safety. Then we had a picket line and massive dislocation down in the petrochemical plant. How good was the health and safety legislation that gave all those wide-ranging powers to prevent unsafe work practices? How good was it? It did not make one iota of difference. The 60 Minutes crew came down, the men went out, the Premier hopped on the picket line, and the petrochemical plant stopped. How good was the health and safety?

This Government was given the opportunity to come into this place and say to the people in Victoria, `We do not support your strike'. The Government could have come in here and said, `That strike is unnecessary. There are occupational health and safety standards down there in Victoria; activate them'. But the Government chose not to do that. The Government was quite happy to let this dual system go ahead. It was quite happy to leave that particular matter to a province wholly outside the Occupational Health and Safety Act; a wide ranging code that should have been an exhaustive code turned into nothing.

The Government ought to make clear in this debate, and Government members ought to make clear in this debate, that if this Bill goes through the Government does not expect and would not support any industrial dispute generated outside the provisions of this legislation. If the Government does not do that, it is effectively saying, `We are introducing another system. It may or it may not work, and we really do not care whether it does'.

The Government ought to come in here and say, `We believe all of these powers are justified because they will stop industrial disputes over health and safety occurring otherwise than in accordance with this particular procedure'. If it does not, its bona fides on that issue will be exposed.

Logically, this Bill should have been introduced when the Commonwealth employees compensation and rehabilitation scheme was reviewed. As a result of the time it has taken, Commonwealth employees are the only category of employees in the Australian work force without a legislative occupational health and safety framework. Various Commonwealth authorities and agencies have had interim measures in place for years, which raises doubts about the need for the Bill at all. Previous Ministers have not felt an urgent need for it.

The Bill is broadly consistent with State legislation already in place which covers not only State Public Service employees but private sector employees as well. But there are three grounds for reservations about the Bill. The first is the Bill's highly structured and regulatory approach, which I have already covered. The second is the cost of the proposals and the third has to do with the nature of the Commonwealth's involvement in health and safety.

I have covered the highly structured and complex regulatory regime. Let me come to the question of costs. The present Bill will not give rise to costs in the private sector. Nevertheless, the initial compliance costs of the Commonwealth departments, agencies and business enterprises concerned are likely to be considerable and much larger than the direct costs cited by the Minister for Finance. The Minister has estimated that the direct costs will be between $1.1m and $1.4m for additional Comcare staff and consultants during the first three years of operation. The Minister has acknowledged that there will be initial compliance costs but said that they cannot be estimated.

In relation to the Commonwealth's general involvement with occupational health and safety, let me make the point that the States have their own occupational health and safety laws. It is no problem to apply them to the Commonwealth. This is another example of duplication, admittedly only for the Commonwealth's own servants and agents. But what is wrong with applying the State laws? Why do we need another Act with another duplicated set of inspectors to apply in this particular area? The Government keeps talking about diminishing duplication but, at every opportunity it gets, it goes into duplication.

The Opposition has pledged to remove duplication between State and Federal governments, to save costs and to abolish the National Occupational Health and Safety Commission for an estimated saving of around $18m. The functions that are provided by that Commission could well be done by coordinating standards within the Department itself.

I took the opportunity to have a look at the National Occupational Health and Safety Commission annual report. If one looks, for example, at its achievements for 1989-90, it has produced a few strategies and a national approach; it has established a secretariat; it has had a memorandum of understanding, some study awards, some research grants, a training package, a handbook and a multilingual science poster. This is the way the Government gets into spending money.

If we have a look down its budget, of course, in relation to $15m of expenditure, $7.6m was on salaries. Then there were travel expenses, postage and consultants' fees. Then there were commissions, committee and working party meetings, library materials and all the rest of it. Talk about an employment scheme! This is a beauty! It is just another Commonwealth Government employment scheme where all of the money that taxpayers are paying is going out to provide jobs for educated people whose job is to look after safety in the workplace. They do it by having conferences, commissions, packages, programs and study grants. Then there are repairs and maintenance to their motor vehicles, and freight and courier services. There are tutors and guest lecturers who get a bit of money.

The Commission also gives out some resource grants. The Australian Council of Trade Unions got only $778,000 from the Commission. The Confederation of Australian Industry got $748,000. The ACTU does not need money from the Government. The CAI does not need money from the Government. They can raise funds like anybody else.

There will be substantial savings to be made. The Opposition will remove that kind of waste, that kind of duplication, and get back to some real, achievable savings in Commonwealth government spending. The Opposition supports the general thrust of the Bill. It has criticisms about the way this thing operates. I therefore move the following amendment to the motion for the second reading of the Bill and ask the Government to recognise all of those inherent weaknesses in this particular piece of legislation:
That all words after ``That'' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:

``whilst not declining to give this Bill a second reading, the House notes that the need for uniform national occupational health and safety standards has not been demonstrated; that the States and the Commonwealth are the best placed to determine their own needs; that a future Liberal/National Government would abolish the National Occupational Health and Safety Commission and resume its functions within the Department.''

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the amendment seconded?
—I second the amendment and reserve my right to speak.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Langmore Mr J.V.

TALK.START.PARA: —The speech by the honourable member for Higgins (Mr Costello) was, as usual, very disappointing on this subject. The Opposition says that it is concerned about occupational health and safety and one would like to believe that it is. Yet it says that it will severely undermine both the institutions and the codes for achieving safer and healthier working conditions. It neglects to say how it would achieve any improvement. It only criticises; it seems to have nothing positive to say. The interest it claims to have therefore cannot be taken seriously. Like its predecessor, the Fraser Government, the Opposition would apparently neglect occupational health and safety. Under it, occupational accidents and disease would therefore start to rise again.

SPEECH.PARA: The Occupational Health and Safety (Commonwealth Employment) Bill will enhance safety conditions for Commonwealth workers. It covers employees of Commonwealth departments, statutory authorities and government business enterprises (GBEs) in Australia and overseas, although not all provisions will apply overseas. It also covers persons employed by the Commonwealth under a law of the Commonwealth and of a Territory or under a contract of service or apprenticeship.

The Bill establishes a statutory framework to ensure the health and safety of Commonwealth government workers. It will provide government employees with the protection of modern occupational health and safety legislation similar to that already enjoyed by both public and private sector employees in most States.

This is legislation which many people, including me, have been advocating for several years and I am delighted that it is now before the House. Given the Fraser Government's neglect of this area, and given Australia's previous backwardness in the area of occupational health and safety, the introduction of the legislation is particularly welcome.

The Bill is part of the Federal Government's high priority national strategy on occupational health and safety which had to be developed to reduce the shocking national human and financial costs of occupational injury and disease. I noticed that the previous speaker acknowledged that this was a serious problem, but he did not articulate any definite approach to handling it. The Hawke Government, in contrast, has acted effectively in this area.

In 1983 the tripartite-that means business, unions and government, not just unions and government-National Economic Summit Conference participants all urged that this issue be given top priority. The policy was an important plank of the Australian Labor Party-Australian Council of Trade Unions statement of accord, but it has also had the endorsement of business. One of the striking features of the way this whole strategy has worked is that at every point and in every detail there has been close consultation with both business and unions equally as well as with all levels of government.

The Hawke Government established the tripartite National Occupational Health and Safety Commission to facilitate the development of a uniform approach to occupational health and safety around the country. The development of this Commonwealth legislation for the protection of its own employees is a further element of the Government's strategy.

There is now an increasing interest in occupational health and safety, and this is very good to see. It is perhaps best exemplified by the proliferation of tertiary courses on the issue. When we came to government it was hard to find a single course on this subject anywhere in Australia at a tertiary institution; now there are quite a number. Another example of the growing interest is that there have been several well researched feature articles in national papers and journals on the topic in recent times.

This legislation recognises that responsibility for health and safety issues must be placed with both those parties that directly affect workplace conditions, that is, employers and employees. Based on Robens style legislation of management-employee cooperation, its underlying principle is self-regulation and a recognition that occupational health and safety problems can be avoided only by safer and healthier working conditions and practices.

In Australia the incidence of occupational death, injury and disease in the work force has been extraordinarily high. On average, each week over 3,000 workers experience a compensable work injury resulting in a period off work of one week or more. Recent figures from the National Occupational Health and Safety Commission revealed that every week eight Australians leave home and die on the job or in transit.

Occupational injury and disease therefore have very high costs. Those costs include not only human misery, pain and suffering, but also enormous financial costs to Australian industry for lost production and retraining and costs to the community for income support, medical attention, rehabilitation, retraining and compensation.

The Australian Bureau of Statistics figures suggest, as I was glad to note the previous speaker acknowledged, that the cost of workers compensation claims in 1989-90 was $4.8 billion-that is, $4,800m. That represents 1.3 per cent of Australia's non-farm gross domestic product. That does not even take account of indirect costs, such as lost production and retraining.

Commonwealth expenditure on workers compensation in 1989-90 was $240m. Working time lost in Australia through occupational injury and disease has been estimated at around 10 times that lost through industrial disputes. Therefore, the impact of industrial accidents on Australia's economy is very substantial.

Humans beings have a need for achievement and must be assisted to fulfil their potential in a safe and secure working environment. Managers must show genuine concern about health and safety at work. But despite its importance, Australia's safety legislation developed in a piecemeal and uncoordinated manner. Often, concerns about profits have outweighed interest in workers' health.

Aligned with this mentality have been other reinforcing factors. For instance, insurance companies have been reluctant to publish statistics on death or injury at work because as part of big business it simply was not in their interest to do so. Employers might find it difficult to attract employees to workplaces with reputations for dangerous working conditions. Often workers were not concerned about dangerous chemicals or machinery if handling them involved payment of danger money and secure employment. Hazardous working conditions were often considered preferable to no job at all. In fact, not wanting to lose their jobs or be branded as troublemakers, people often concealed injuries.

The law, too, was often on the side of suppression of this issue. There are many cases documenting judicial decisions which favoured a company sued by an employee, such as a company which had clearly been negligent by placing production continuity ahead of the option of closing a factory for long enough to clean up spilt oil on the factory floor, at the risk of the workers' health.

Also there has been a genuine lack of knowledge about dangerous chemicals or machines on the part of both employers and employees. Unlike safety hazards, the effects of chemicals have often been slow to manifest themselves, are cumulative, irreversible and complicated by non- occupational factors. The most obvious example of this is asbestos related diseases, which are now coming to light many years after the first exposure of many employees.

Many workers have had difficulty in proving a correlation between a disease or injury and its place of origin, namely, the workplace. That particular problem has occurred within the Commonwealth's own service in relation to repetition strain injury. Now that we have more information on the correlation between asbestos and lung cancer, we can take preventative measures. That is what this legislation is about: prevention through information and communication.

Underpinning the culture that developed about the issue of occupational health and safety has been the idea that work accidents were not `real accidents'. The Government has adopted an integrated approach to prevention, compensation and rehabilitation. A progressive compensation and rehabilitation system was introduced under the Commonwealth Employees' Rehabilitation and Compensation Act 1988 and is administered by Comcare. It is designed to minimise the human and financial costs of work related injury and disease, whilst simultaneously providing adequate compensation and support for long term incapacitated employees.

Prevention must play a pivotal role. All the major industrial disasters of recent times have had small beginnings, often with the common thread of ignorance or an erosion of standards in ensuring compliance with safety regulations. The law can only compensate for what has occurred as a result of an accident in the workplace and award monetary compensation, but money can never fully compensate for the enormous physical and emotional losses.

Without elaborating fully on the Bill, I would like to highlight some of its features. There is to be a large degree of flexibility. That was not acknowledged by the previous speaker. Where no National Occupational Health and Safety Commission standards or codes exist, the Commonwealth will adopt the existing State or Territory standard, pending review of its appropriateness and applicability to the Commonwealth sector. There will be consultation, as there has been in the preparation of this Bill, with State and Territory authorities in these matters.

Except where any provisions are contrary to the Act, the Occupational Health and Safety (Commonwealth Employment) Bill is not meant to override any of the interim occupational health and safety agreements between the management of individual public sector bodies and relevant unions that were formulated while this legislation was being researched and drafted.

This Bill is comprehensive. It emphasises direct involvement by employers and employees in workplace occupational health and safety. Accordingly, it requires Commonwealth employers and employees in each workplace to take greater responsibility for the management of health and safety in that workplace, consistent with the contemporary coregulatory approach already adopted in most Australian States, the Australian Capital Territory and overseas countries.

The legislation provides for regulations and codes of practice to be developed to cover specific problems while imposing a duty of care on employers and employees as well as manufacturers and suppliers of plant and substances to take all reasonably practical steps to ensure a safe and healthy work environment.

It also provides a framework for employers and employees to cooperate and consult in addressing health and safety matters in the workplace through the establishment of designated work groups and health and safety committees. The previous speaker mocked that, but how on earth does he expect effective implementation, even self-regulation, without that kind of consultation? I was astonished by the apparent ignorance of his approach. These attributes are splendid.

TALK.START.PARA: —Absolutely.

—I thank the honourable member for his comment. Occupational health and safety needs a program of planned and unplanned inspections, personal involvement in safety awards and goals. This integrated safety initiative will have involvement from all quarters of the work force. The key to job safety is developing a mentality of safety.

SPEECH.PARA: Perhaps one of the most important aspects of the legislation is the role of the health and safety representative, who has the power to issue a provisional improvement notice requiring management to take corrective action to stop or to avoid a breach of the legislation. The representative, when the supervisor cannot be located, has the power to order cessation of work when there is an immediate threat to health and safety. If the supervisor is located, she or he has the right to decide whether work should cease. While this approach has been adopted in most of the existing occupational health and safety agreements in Commonwealth agencies, it has rarely, if ever, been used.

The Bill also provides for an advisory function for Comcare. This is important in assisting employers, employees and contractors with their obligations under the legislation and in dealing with occupational health and safety problems. The first step is the investigation process. The legislation enables Comcare to refer requests for advice to experts outside the Commission.

Investigations are to be carried out with a focus on a cooperative approach, but investigators are to have wide ranging powers, including powers of entry and powers to issue prohibition and improvement notices to remove threats to health and safety or to stop or prevent breaches of the legislation.

The Bill also has an appeals mechanism for appeals against investigators' decisions and provides sanctions where a breach of the legislation occurs. For instance, financial penalties can be imposed on GBEs or their employees; that again was neglected by the previous speaker.

TALK.START.PARA: —They cannot be imposed on the Government.

—Manufacturers and suppliers will also be liable to prosecution and fines for contraventions. Commonwealth departments and authorities which are not GBEs may be the subject of a report to Parliament if found to be in contravention of the Act. That answers the honourable member's interjection. Employees of such agencies may be subject to disciplinary action under the Public Service Act or other terms and conditions applying to non-Australian public service personnel.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill is not intended to exclude the application of the criminal law in appropriate cases. Instead, it is intended that the criminal law of the States will apply to Commonwealth employees to the extent that those laws are capable of concurrent operation with this legislation. Financial penalties which this Bill imposes upon GBEs and individuals who contravene the legislation are consistent with the range of penalty levels in similar State legislation and are in line with achieving greater consistency in occupational health and safety legislation, standards and strategies around the country. Surely that is desirable. Again I am astonished by the previous speaker's amendment, which shows that he does not think there is a need for uniform national occupational health and safety standards. I would have thought uniform standards were a great benefit to employers and management.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are we going to oppose the amendment?

—Obviously, we must oppose the amendment. It is simply not sensible. In response to another of the previous speaker's comments, it is essential to emphasise that the cost of implementing the proposals included in the Bill will be offset by savings already being achieved by Comcare through the rehabilitation of long term compensation claimants and by a reduction in accidents and in disease at the workplace. The provision of safe and healthy working environments and the increased emphasis on cooperation to achieve such an environment are expected to reduce the incidence of accidents and injuries in which the Commonwealth would be liable. It should result in reduced Commonwealth expenditure, reduced compensation, and reduced associated costs through unnecessary retraining, lost time and sick leave.

SPEECH.PARA: Legislation such as this is significant in the milieu it helps create in the workplace. We must have notices about dangers; noise pollution must be taken into account; work stress and powerlessness in large organisations must be offset with genuine consultation and appropriate strategies, and not simply rationalised away as individual difficulties.

With the substantial changes in the nature of working life predicted over the next two or three decades, there will be an increased need for an emphasis on occupational health and safety procedures with a preventative and consultative approach to problem solving, especially in areas using sophisticated technology. There may be need for more consultation between health economists and managements to show employers that occupational health really pays. Design of machinery, psychological considerations, the effects of education and training, influence of age, experience and fatigue must all be taken into account.
We must all learn from the repetition strain injury (RSI) epidemic and the diseases resulting from asbestos to prevent future calamities which take such a huge toll on our society.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ford Mr F.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The aim of this Bill is to provide safety in the workplace. It is essential that it promotes prevention. Therefore, its passage cannot be opposed. The honourable member for Fraser (Mr Langmore) claimed the coalition was not in favour of safety in the workplace. I totally dispute this. The honourable member for Fraser also said that the Government had a high priority for this legislation. I ask why it has taken so many years to bring the legislation before this House. Although not opposing the Bill, I want to draw attention to some problems in application, problems in the amount of regulation involved, and at the same time stress that passing the legislation is one thing, but seeing it properly applied in practice is another. This is particularly so with handling injuries-lifting and carrying, and pushing-which are by far the most prolific. Education and training is the key. I am pleased to see this being partially addressed in the National Occupational Health and Safety Commission annual report. Every employer, including the Federal Government, must provide a safe working environment. I cannot imagine employees being subjected to deliberate unsafe conditions, and I dispute the remarks of the member for Fraser.

SPEECH.PARA: The problem then is to realise potential hazards. I repeat that the key is training, for the proprietors, for managers, for safety representatives, for employees. Training or advice can be obtained from independent outside experts. This is ignored in this legislation. The Minister for Finance, in his second reading speech, indicated that this was modern educational health and safety legislation, based on various State legislative measures. Having personally tried to comply with Victoria's legislation, I trust the Victorian administration is not used as a model.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is.

—Thank you. We are in real trouble if the Victorian one is used as a model, because it has 250 pages of legislation, thousands of pages of regulations, and I believe this is reflected in the Victorian WorkCare financial situation. The Bill before the House is for a highly structured and highly regulated system for ensuring safety in the Commonwealth workplace. As the honourable member for Higgins (Mr Costello) has pointed out, this is far from right.

SPEECH.PARA: I hear frequently in this House the word `deregulation'. I hear from the Minister opposite about deregulation. But where is it? It is certainly not in this Bill. This Bill is about more regulation. It involves the formation of safety committees in enterprises with over 50 employees; it involves the appointment of safety representatives, which is all very worth while. But so is training for these safety representatives-paid for by the employer with the employee actually contributing nothing. To what extent is this person being trained?

In Victoria, occupational health courses are run by various tertiary colleges and they are three-year courses. Federally, dare we have one person in 50 away on a course for three years? The old State workers compensation schemes had many problems, as the honourable member for Fraser pointed out. However, they did involve experts visiting each enterprise at least twice a year. The insurance companies had a vital financial interest in each enterprise. If there was an accident, they paid-not as the honourable member for Fraser claimed. I believe this is lacking in the new scheme.

Full training of a person from each enterprise is completely out of the question. Where are all the facilities? The training facilities are not available to cope with the numbers involved. For instance, there are thousands of Commonwealth enterprises throughout the country, and to train one person from each would take years. The application of this Bill could take five years.

The Minister stressed costs and possible savings. Injury claims nationally involve 1.3 per cent of non-farm gross domestic product. With oncosts, the figure is far higher. We should and must decrease this huge problem. However, the same Minister is happy to apply a 1 per cent training levy on wages. These costs all make the nation less competitive.

Earlier I mentioned safety representatives as being most worth while. These representatives have wide powers; they have the power to inspect; they have the power to investigate; they can request information; they can request safety breaches to be rectified; they can investigate the process or product, and inspect how it is operating in an establishment. Having done all this, and with all these powers, they are absolved by this Bill from civil liability if, subsequently, something goes wrong. I question this provision.

The safety representative may be absolved, but look at the penalties for others: $100,000 for a government enterprise; $20,000 for a supplier or installer; $5,000 for an employee of a government enterprise. Yet the safety representative, who may have direct involvement, is absolved. This situation, I suggest, has to be addressed. As I said earlier, the cost of injury to Commonwealth employees was $240m or 1.3 per cent of non-farm GDP in 1989-90. Will adoption of this Bill reduce this huge cost in both money and people? I doubt it. Costs have been rising when so-called modern systems have been operating for three to five years. The National Occupational Health and Safety Commission has already instituted many training programs. It has issued resource kits such as Preventing Back Pain in the Workplace, which have been widely praised and accepted, yet injuries still occur. Further training and education in the workplace is essential.

There is one huge omission from this Bill. There are similar omissions from State occupational safety Acts. That omission is the individual and his or her age and habits outside the working environment. Ageing is a problem with injuries, not only in the workplace. The older we get, the more prone or susceptible we become to injury. Far more attention should be paid to this area-and it is not even mentioned in this Bill. Also, what about the state of a person's individual health: suppose he or she smokes or drinks excessively; suppose that he or she is well overweight or indulges in hazardous activities outside employment. These factors all should receive urgent attention. They affect the employment performance and may be a safety hazard in the workplace. Australia really does require uniform legislation in many fields, of which safety in the workplace is one.

It is of grave concern that the parliamentary research service indicates that, if challenged, the Federal Government would have to resort to the external treaties power to implement this Bill. I find this very difficult to accept, but it is certainly mentioned in the background papers. This Bill will, however, assess safety in the workplace. It has application errors and it has a number of important omissions. But with all these faults, it should be supported.

The Bill provides penalties for breaches, as I said earlier-$100,000 in the case of a government business in relation to its own employees or a third party, and $20,000 in the case of a manufacturer, supplier or installer. It imposes a general duty of care on employees themselves, and it provides a penalty of $5,000 for a breach by an employee in a government enterprise. The Bill also provides for the creation of conveniently and functionally designated work groups. Just how these are going to work, I do not know. It also provides for health and safety representatives, as I said earlier, to undertake accredited training courses at the employers' expense-that is, at the taxpayers' expense. There would be no expense incurred by any other source. We even subsidise the unions and the Chamber of Automotive Industries, but the taxpayer has to pay for the training.

TALK.START.PARA: —An amount of $700,000.

—I think it was $750,000. The Bill gives health and safety representatives wide powers including powers of inspection, power to investigate complaints, and power to request that causes of breaches or likely breaches of safety be rectified, and it absolves that representative from civil liability arising therefrom. That, as I mentioned earlier, must be addressed.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill provides for an employer or an involved union to apply to Comcare for disqualification of a health and safety representative for various reasons. As the honourable member for Higgins pointed out, in the past there have been many reasons for this type of activity. The Bill provides for the creation of health and safety advisory committees comprising of representatives of employers and employees where requested at a workplace of 50 or more employees. The Bill also provides for Comcare to appoint investigators with specified powers and it provides for appeals to the Australian Industrial Relations Commission against an investigator's findings. The Bill also provides for the implementation by WorkCare of codes of practice developed by Worksafe Australia, subject to ministerial approval. That is certainly providing the Minister with open slather to actually remove anything that the regulations should cover. Logically, this Bill should have been introduced when the Commonwealth employees compensation and rehabilitation scheme was reviewed. As the honourable member for Higgins mentioned, Commonwealth employees until now had no complete legislative safety framework. Mr Speaker, this Bill is long overdue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Snow Mr J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to support the legislation and I oppose the amendment by the Opposition. The Opposition wants the Commonwealth, which in virtually all its operations transcends State legislation, to be subject to eight different occupational health and safety regulation Acts. That is bad enough. We already have the confusion caused by the different State regulations in many fields-in education, where a child finds it difficult to move from one State to another and cope with a different curriculum with children of the same age; and in road laws, because people turn left in front of someone turning right in one State, and have to wait for the person turning right in another State. Do not let us extend the problems to Commonwealth operations. Do not let us extend the confusion which already exists because of our over-government.

SPEECH.PARA: The high cost of the proposal of the States would transcend the high cost of the alleged waste that the honourable member for Higgins (Mr Costello) was talking about, which I will deal with in a moment. It would certainly be a high cost to try to operate under eight different occupational health and safety rules. Of course, the emphasis put on this by the Opposition is, as usual, that it believes it to be a costly patching up exercise rather than prevention. I feel that we ought to amplify what the honourable member for Fraser (Mr Langmore) was talking about when he referred to repetition strain injury (RSI) and just what has happened over many years. I want to look at three or four papers and just see the difference in approach that has been taken to RSI and try to draw out from that what the successful approach has been. In the Medical Journal of Australia, 4 September 1989, volume 151, David S. Bell wrote an article in which he talked about the psychological basis of repetition strain injury. He said:

The psychological basis of ``repetition strain injury'' (``RSI'') is revealed by its rapid rise and fall. The epidemic of ``RSI'' evolved from a similar entity which was recognized and compensated as ``tenosynovitis''. The number of cases of this had been increasing for a decade or more but had not been questioned seriously until ``RSI'' appeared. The rapid growth of the disorder in Australia between 1983 and 1985 earned for it the derogatory term, ``kangaroo paw''. The speed and enormity of its spread in particular groups such as the Australian Public Service seemingly submerged the responsible authorities into total acceptance of a highly improbable condition before they were able to assess it.

In some Federal Government departments, ``RSI'' manifested equally rapidly in replacement staff members leaving few persons unaffected. Payments to pharmacists fell so far behind that the Federal Government adopted an extraordinary extemporaneous arrangement which, in effect, abandoned most of the fees processing system. In contrast, other offices remained untouched.
Later in the same article the writer states:

The belief that the complaints were a result of an injury, and hence compensable, has been the single indispensable factor which has impelled this epidemic. The influence of compensation is illustrated by the relative absence of the disorder in countries where it is not compensable and by events in West Germany, where the incidence of similar complaints dropped dramatically in parallel with a reduction in the numbers of complainants who were awarded compensation.

Or was it that there was improved equipment introduced for staff? I believe that that was the case. I know in my office and probably in yours, Mr Deputy Speaker, equipment has improved for staff operations. It is not only the Public Service that was affected. I can recall a constituent coming to see me who had his own computing business. He could no longer operate that business because he had repetitive strain injury. He was successful, he was selling software, working hard, enjoying it and making a lot of money. He developed RSI. Here we have the Medical Journal of Australia claiming that it was all imagination.
There have been some more enlightening articles. Andrew Hopkins of the Research School of Social Sciences at the Australian National University talked about repetition strain injury. He pointed out:

Throughout the 1970s the number of new cases of `musculoskeletal' disease recorded each year in the NSW workers' compensation statistics showed no particular tendency to increase. But in the five years from 1979 to 1984 it jumped from 980 to 4450 new cases per year, a nearly five-fold increase. We were clearly in the midst of an epidemic, an epidemic which is already showing signs of waning.
He wrote this in 1989. Further he stated:
But an epidemic of what? In the first instance, of compensation claims.
He writes later:
To take the matter to its logical extreme, could it have been merely an epidemic of malingering?

He goes on to quote what Bammer and Martin have called the standard view of RSI as adopted in a much cited article by Browne and co-workers in the Medical Journal of Australia in 1984. Quoting Bammer and Martin, he states:

RSIs are . . . musculotendinous injuries of the upper limbs, shoulder girdles, and neck caused by overload of particular muscle groups from repeated use, or by the maintenance of constrained postures, which result in pain, fatigue and a decline in work performance.
Then he goes on to quote people who claim that RSI is a neurosis. He quotes Lucire who said:

So the powerless and dependent, and those who cannot otherwise express their righteous rage at the supervisors, employers and spouses, resort to the use of their exquisitely symbolic pain and incapacity as a mode of communication of their distress.
The same author went on to say:

As long as compensation is paid for functional (i.e. non-organic, non-physical) symptoms as if they were the result of a hypothetical `injury', symptoms are rewarded and reinforced, and the epidemic will continue to spread . . . Control of this epidemic will require a complete withdrawal of the injury theory and its mythology and terminology.
Andrew Hopkins concludes in his article:

We see then that the intervention of the social constructionists in the RSI debate has been, in political terms, on the side of insurance interests. This has occurred despite the fact that they quite specifically distinguish themselves from the psychiatric interpretation of RSI on which the insurance interests tend to rely, and despite, in Willis's case, a specific endorsement of the injury theory. This has come about, in part, because of the ease with which the relatively subtle social constructionist position can be misunderstood, and in part because social constructionist thinking . . . slides into a denial of the significance or even existence of injury. I have argued that the social construction approach can nonetheless make a substantial contribution to our understanding of the epidemic of RSI in Australia, in a way which provides no comfort whatsoever for insurance interests.

I think one can say that there may have been a psychological component but very often this psychological component was due to the fact that people were not accepting the physical base of the disease. Also in 1989 an article was written by Narelle Hooper in the Business Review Weekly on 23 June. She writes in that article:

I think there was less of that malingering than anyone imagined, says David McIvor, a director of the Melbourne-based Occupational Safety and Health Associates. McIvor, who wrote a book on the issue, rejects further claims that RSI was in the minds of its victims. It is nonsense to say it is 100% psychological, as it is to say it is 100% physical; it may be a bit of both. But the more the physical component is ignored the greater the psychological component will be . . .

Mr McIvor pointed out that another term for repetitive injury, occupational overuse syndrome, was very often due to equipment. He pointed out that in operator sections of Telecom Australia, where injuries had a strong correlation to rigid job design and use of archaic equipment, the incidence climbed as high as one in four. By 1987 occupational overuse syndrome injuries cost Telecom more than $21m in medical costs, lost time and production.

David Gosling, then one of the five ergonomists now employed by Telecom, believed that the epidemic was caused partly by the industrial climate and partly by years of neglect in reviewing the welfare of workers. He stated:
I think we have succeeded in reducing the incidence. Now we are more experienced and know how to react responsibly and how to overreact.

There is one more study I want to mention. That was in the editorial research reports of congressional quarterlies in the United States dated 16 February 1990. It points out that repetitive motion is a new job ailment, recognised in the United States in 1990 in this article. In an article in that paper Robert K. Landers records that in the 1980s there was a dramatic increase in the specific kind of job related disability, repetitive motion injuries.

Employees in a wide range of industries from meat packing to data processing reported suffering debilitating pain and comfort. Some employers find it difficult to accept that their employees' complaints are work related. Most recognise that is it in their best interests to improve work conditions and eliminate factors that contribute to cumulative trauma disorders. Robert Landers pointed out how firms have been able to apply guidelines to combat cumulative trauma disorders. He talks about a management commitment. An employee involvement, work site analysis, hazard prevention and control, medical management and training and education are the very things that the honourable member for Higgins was disparaging.

It has become obvious in the United States as well as Australia that management needs to redesign jobs in many cases. I believe this legislation is long overdue-I must agree with the honourable member for Dunkley (Mr Ford) on that matter-but at least it is coming now.

It is interesting to look back again to 1989 to see how News Ltd brought the RSI epidemic under control by taking note of what was happening in Japan, where a gym had been installed in an office and staff members were required to be involved in the gymnasium program, treating not only RSI but also heart disease, stress and obesity. It has become recognised by organisations that we need to have better equipment and better management to cope with RSI.

This legislation is necessary because of the huge gap in occupational health and safety coverage for Commonwealth employees. It provides mechanisms to reduce occupational injury and disease that give rise to unacceptable human and economic costs. I say to the honourable member for Higgins that we cannot afford to allow the States to administer the law in this area. If we allowed the States to administer it, it would mean that the Commonwealth, which operates most activities transcending State boundaries, would have to adapt to the laws of eight States and Territories, and the States would be interfering in the employment of Commonwealth officers to, I believe, an intolerable extent.

Of course, if we had uniform regulations, then that sort of application could be considered, but we do not have completely uniform regulations. The honourable member's suggestions would mean more inefficiency and additional costs for the Commonwealth administration. He referred to leaflets, to teaching migrants English and to training schemes as waste. I am glad to see the honourable member for Dunkley disagreed about training and said the legislation should have more training involved in it. The things the honourable member for Higgins referred to as waste are the things which will prevent the sorts of problems I was talking about and reduce RSI. I support the legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McArthur Mr F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I respond to the comments of the honourable member for Eden-Monaro (Mr Snow) that the Federal Government should cover all these areas in terms of legislation--
—Only for Commonwealth employees.

— The honourable member made the suggestion that the Commonwealth should cover all the State legislation and should cover those areas of responsibilities, because the Commonwealth could always do it better. That is a typical remark by members of the Government-that the Commonwealth knows best in education--
—It knows best for its own workers.

—The honourable member suggested it would cover all the other workers as well. I am suggesting that the current situation is that the States handle this area of safety and health. From time to time, they do not do a bad job. I do not agree that the Commonwealth should take over this role.

SPEECH.PARA: The Occupational Health and Safety Bill that is before us arises from the discussions between the unions, the Australian Labor Party and the Government about occupational health and safety back in 1983 under the guidelines of the accord mark 1. Of course, we are up to the accord mark 6 now, and we are not sure where that will end up. In particular, this Bill seeks to extend the existing arrangements in the private and public sector with a State Government jurisdiction to all Commonwealth government employees. The coalition accepts that occupational health and safety is an issue of increasing national concern. It acknowledges that work related injuries are a cause of death and long term disability in the Australian work force which impacts significantly on the costs borne by the community.

However, from the outset the Opposition has rejected the view that a national statutory authority is the appropriate body for the protection of health and safety of workers. One only needs to look at the conclusions and recommendations contained in the McKay report in 1988, which criticised the operation of the Occupational Health and Safety Commission, to conclude that the Government's management in this area has been of very limited success. The Opposition, as the honourable member for Higgins (Mr Costello) has indicated, supports the Bill with reservations and we have moved an amendment to indicate our position. We have a commitment to abolishing the Health and Safety Commission when we are in government, because of the potential saving of some $19m.

I would like to refer to the report which was tabled recently in Parliament which gives an indication of the sorts of activities that the Commission undertakes. The key element is the $19m expenditure which I have referred to on a number of occasions in this House. The report refers to some background research and some reports into the manual handling operation. Again I refer to the guidelines and stipulations that the Commission put forward to members of the rural industry and members in manufacturing as to how they should handle heavy weights. It got itself into a great amount of trouble because of specific guidelines in relation to how workers should lift weights of a particular type.

There is also an interesting report on back pain which I commend, reports into noise and skin disorders, and one report into farm safety. These are all highly commendable, but let us look at the cost that the Commonwealth has been involved in in producing these reports and keeping the Commission in business. The State instrumentalities could easily undertake these investigations and, of course, the private sector could obviously quite easily do a very good job in this area.

The Bill itself proposes a very highly structured and regulatory approach to the fundamentals of occupational health and safety in the workplace. It imposes a general duty of care on Commonwealth employers to protect the health and safety of Commonwealth employees, manufacturers and suppliers of plant and substances to the Commonwealth employers and installers of plant. It also provides penalties of $100,000 for breaches of the duty of care owed by Government business enterprises to their employees and gives health and safety representatives wide powers of inspection.

I note that the honourable member for Higgins made some comments in relation to these very wide powers as detailed in the Bill. It should be compared, however, to the $5,000 penalty to employees who have failed to take reasonable care in the performance of their work related tasks. So there is some discrepancy between the employer's responsibilities and the workers on the job and the way in which they might protect their own safety and the safety of their fellow workers. Satisfactory health and safety arrangements surely depend on the mutual cooperation and respect for the duty of care owed by both employers and employees.

Of great concern to the Opposition and to me is the highly structured process the Bill imposes on all Commonwealth departments, agencies and enterprises subject to the Bill and the compliance costs associated with it. The Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook) has acknowledged that the direct costs amount to between $1.1m and $1.4m. At a time when Australia moves into a recession, we are adding further costs through the Federal bureaucracy.

No figures have been forthcoming as to the indirect costs of the compliance procedures. The Minister has rationalised the expense by claiming significant savings from the reductions in accidents, lost work time, and reduced compensation and rehabilitation requirements. I only hope that an Act of parliament will bring about a better state of affairs in terms of health and safety with Commonwealth employees rather than a change of attitude.

The coalition acknowledges that this Bill complements the prior agreements in health and safety and the Commonwealth Employees' Rehabilitation and Compensation Act 1988 and a further level of protection is afforded them by the code of general principles on occupational safety and health in Australian government employment implemented in September 1974 under a variety of industrial awards. The House would be aware that there has been a code of practice in existence that has assisted Government employers to look after their employees in a reasonable and sensible manner.

This code covers such things as the provision of a safe workplace, a safe working environment, arrangements for consultation between employers and employees on safety matters, provision of personal protective equipment and training in its use, and health and first aid services.

It is the coalition's belief that, far from ensuring higher occupational health standards, the Bill will achieve little by way of significant improvements. All Australians would agree that the health and well-being of everyone in the work force is of fundamental importance. The real issue remains how best to achieve this goal.

As I indicated in 1985, in my view only action on the shop floor and an understanding between the management and the workers will bring about a change in attitude towards safety and a situation in which long term improvements can be achieved in the workplace. I am sure that, whilst it may sound well-intentioned to some, what we need in Australia is legislation to encourage by positive incentives the development of a properly planned accident control-occupational program. Negative enforcement such as this Bill proposes will never work in a society such as ours.
