I would like to draw the House's attention to some proceedings that were held at the Australian National University in 1981 and a paper produced by Mr Saunders in his discussions about the United States of America Occupational Health and Safety Act which he considered to be a failure in that country. He said that to introduce a similar Act in this country would be `an absolute disaster'. He said:

I am sure that whilst it may sound very attractive to some, the reality of our situation demands the framing of legislation to encourage by positive incentives the development of properly planned accident control/occupational health programmes. Negative enforcement has never really worked in a society such as ours, and probably never will. Yet legislators tend to persist with this type of Act. A most notable example among many is the total failure of negative motivation to reduce murder and violence in the community over a consistently long period.

In my view, whilst the occupational health and safety issue is one which should not be ignored, we should be aiming to provide guidelines and encouragement for organisations to develop their own occupational health and safety programs specific to their particular needs. This has been achieved with particular success in America, where the Bechtel corporation, the largest construction company in the world, got together with the unions and, with the approval of government, organised its own approach to accident control.

There is no reason why, with the cooperation of unions, participation of employees and the resources of management, such programs could not be equally successful in Australia. I am strongly of the view that many accidents in the workplace result not from the purposeful negligence of employers but from behavioural problems often associated with outdated work practices.

I draw to the attention of the House the interesting example of the Snowy Mountains hydro-electric scheme back in 1947. I understand the manager of the project was very safety conscious. He insisted that drivers of any vehicles strap their seat belts on at all times. I understand that the accident rate from persons driving vehicles in that project was very low at that time, when safety belts were not normally in use in Australia. I also understand that, because of the attitude of senior management, the accident rate was kept to a minimum on that project, where people were working in very difficult conditions, in very dangerous areas, including tunnelling through the mountains-an occupation which tends to have a fairly high accident rate just by the nature of the work. That is again an example of a change in attitude by management in encouraging its work force to adopt safe practices.

I would like to draw attention to the more recent problem of the politicisation of health and safety issues by overzealous union officials on building and construction sites throughout Australia, which has led to increased scepticism of the validity of many of the safety and health issues complained about by employees. Again, the honourable member for Higgins drew the attention of the House to matters that had come to his attention in dealing with industrial matters. Health and safety issues on construction sites in particular are fast becoming the basis for wage increases rather than any genuine concern for the health and safety of workers.

Unions in the building industry are well known for their extremist attitudes towards health and safety issues when negotiating work conditions. It is estimated that 50 per cent of disputes with unions are now negotiated on extremely spurious health and safety issues. The Australian Bureau of Statistics in August 1990 revealed that disputes involving physical working conditions, safety issues, first aid services, protective equipment, conditions of amenities and arduous physical tasks are the second most often used reasons by unions for strike activity and the third highest in terms of working days lost.

In Victoria it is apparent that health and safety issues are a major catalyst in creating legitimacy for industrial disputes. Of particular concern is the general attitude of many in the work force to the concept of work related compensation. We have already seen in Victoria over recent years the massive blow-out of the WorkCare scheme, with $5 billion in accumulated liabilities to the end of 1989, as rorts in the system had enabled those with questionable injuries to receive compensation handouts. Even in that State the Labor administration has made adjustments to the WorkCare scheme to ensure that the payouts came back to reasonable proportions to look after those genuinely injured workers.

Based on the Australian national account figures, the Australian Bureau of Statistics has estimated the cost of Commonwealth workers compensation claims in 1989-90 to be $4.8 billion, up from $3.6 billion in 1985-86. The annual cost of workplace deaths and injuries, including compensation, lost production, retraining and welfare, is much higher and has been estimated to be in the region of $9.6 billion.

I put forward the suggestion that it is important to provide incentives for better safety in the workplace. The important aspect is a change in attitude by management and, along with this, a change in attitude by workers. The important thing is that there is an attitude of providing for safety in the workplace by both the management and the workers, that it is a high priority for everyone involved and that it is a day to day activity where everyone is concerned, especially in some of the repetitive tasks and in some industries which have an element of danger, where management and the work force are fully aware during the eight hours of work that the possibility of injury is always present and that every effort should be taken to make sure it does not happen.

I notice in some of the more progressive manufacturing industries boards indicating how long the plant has operated without any injury. Workers are encouraged to use protective eye covering, they are encouraged to utilise their protective clothing and to take evasive action in the case of any particular industry, particularly in the chemical industry and in the mining and agricultural areas.

I note in closing that in the annual report the compensated occupational incidence of injuries received gives an interesting comparison of industries which are more difficult and more dangerous to work in. The incident rate is shown per 1,000 workers, in order of those that are more dangerous. The first is mining-and I think all members of the House would be aware that the mining industry, because of its very nature, is a fairly dangerous and difficult industry to work in. That is followed by the construction industry; and equal third and fourth are manufacturing, agriculture, forestry and fishing. My background is in the area of agriculture and I can attest to the difficulties in that area. Likewise, in the forestry industry, which is represented in my electorate of Corangamite, the possibility of quite substantial injury is always present. The fifth most dangerous area is transport, followed by electricity, gas and water.

I suggest that attitude is the major factor in terms of health and safety improvements and that the important feature in relation to industrial relations is making sure that health and safety issues are looked at in their own right rather than for their merit in providing the basis for an industrial dispute. I make the point that under the current arrangements the States have the main responsibilities for organising health and safety issues, and they should maintain these responsibilities.

In conclusion, I support the amendment that has been moved by the honourable member for Higgins. We will disband the Commission; we will encourage the States and the private sector to develop practices in the health and safety area; we will discourage unions and workers from using these provisions for industrial uses; and we will encourage management and workers to provide better workplaces so that the incidence of injuries in the Australian workplace can be reduced over the next 20 years.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ferguson Mr L.D.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —Previous speakers in the debate have detailed that the Occupational Health and Safety (Commonwealth Employment) Bill, which we are debating this evening, is not a five-minute wonder but resulted from a series of negotiations and discussions from 1983 onwards. Whilst the previous speaker, the honourable member for Corangamite (Mr McArthur), assiduously referred to the involvement of the unions, the Australian Labor Party and the Government, that was rather selective because, as he well knows, other participants in these discussions have been the employers of this country.

SPEECH.PARA: As other speakers have detailed, it is very much a tripartite development in Australian industrial relations. There are employer groups that are keen to do something about the health and safety of workers in this country. The legislation being discussed tonight provides for a general duty of care and specific obligations relating to the health and safety of Commonwealth employees. The legislation comes about after discussions and a series of related pieces of legislation. The National Occupational Health and Safety Commission Act 1985 provided a focus for the development of set uniform standards and strategies for reducing accidents. Of course, two years ago, there was the Commonwealth Employees' Rehabilitation and Compensation Act. Quite clearly, those measures are interrelated and go in a direction which some speakers opposite have said they nominally favour.

Equally, we have had the activity of Worksafe Australia in coordinating standards, assisting in training and giving grants to a variety of organisations that are doing significant work to categorise accidents and analyse chemicals that are harmful in Australian society, and put out papers. Grants were given to Lidcombe Workers Health Centre, which is in my own electorate, and also to Newcastle, Wollongong, et cetera. Also, various trades and labour councils and Australian Council of Trade Union officers have been employed in related programs around Australia.

One matter that is discussed very much in Australian politics at the moment is the decline of the Victorian Government and the very large number of seats that the Australian Labor Party lost in Victoria at the last Federal election. There is a silver lining in all of these things. It is quite fortunate that the honourable member for Higgins (Mr Costello), the honourable member for Dunkley (Mr Ford) and the honourable member for La Trobe (Mr Charles) have been elected to this House, because clearly they have been able to delineate the real policies of the Opposition. We have the up-front stuff about how everyone has to work together and everyone's mutual interest, increasing productivity and everybody will be very happy with wage increases resulting therefrom. But those particular gentlemen, two of whom have participated in this debate, have come out with the fundamental realities of the Opposition's industrial relations policy.

We all recall the contribution in earlier debates of the honourable member for Dunkley-he has spoken very recently in this debate-when he said that he had fought within the Metal Trades Industry Association Inc. (MTIA) against its soft line, that he was one of the courageous members of the Association who would not go along with all these deals that it was always working out with the trade union movement. I think that has been put in some perspective by the activities of the MTIA in recent weeks. It has not exactly been the soft pushover for the Australian trade union movement. That is the kind of position we have from him.

Whilst other speakers have said that there is too much legislation, too much regulation and that it is too structured, the honourable member for Dunkley went on to demolish the contention of the honourable member for Higgins that the Hoechst dispute in Victoria should have been totally covered by this exhaustive legislation. The honourable member for Dunkley said that, after all the pages and pages of legislation, the Victorian legislation just was not adequate enough and that after all the paperwork it just did not cover the whole field. Yet the honourable member for Higgins said that Hoechst should have been sorted out in those disputes and that the recourse to industrial negotiations was totally improper.

In addition, whilst there were nice throwaway lines from the honourable member for Dunkley about more training, he also went on to decry leaflets. He said that really throwing leaflets all around the place had no impact and that people still had back injuries. I think the bottom line was that doing that was a waste of time. He had grave doubts, rather amazingly, that this legislation would have any impact whatsoever on the $240m that he said was paid out as a result of injuries in the Commonwealth sector.

The honourable member for Higgins had a number of lines of attack on this legislation. He certainly undermined the honourable member for Dundas (Mr Ruddock), who is sitting at the table. The honourable member for Dundas is doing so much for the Liberal Party out there in the migrant community, telling them how badly done by they are and that we should liberalise them and allow them greater access to Australia. The honourable member for Higgins said that Nissan was a very liberal and commendable employer in supplying foreign languages in its factory, but then he thought he would have a little sideswipe and appeal to a certain section of Australian society by saying that everyone out there should learn English and that everyone should put in the effort to go to night school and learn English. As I say, his contribution slightly undermined the efforts in the ethnic electorate for the Liberal Party.

It might be the way that industrial relations are considered in an arbitration commission, but when one is actually out there at places like James Hardie, which relies for its labour on the latest ethnic group coming into the country in which virtually no-one speaks English-and Australia does not require them to in the first place-it is a little unrealistic to say that these guys, who are working in the asbestos industry and fields like that, in pretty arduous and quite often unsafe conditions, should all know English. That was the first focus of the honourable member for Higgins. He somehow lamented the fact that the legislation provided for people to have signs around the factory in other languages.

The honourable member for Higgins made a few snide references to designated work groups, notices and that groups had to be established, complaining that the situation was too structured. Quite frankly, out in the real world, I think that factories have to be very structured. The fact of life is that people do get injured in factories-they have been getting injured for decades-and it is a continuing problem. The problem has not been sorted out by the laissez-faire attitude of the Opposition, or by the ideas of company management in plants. The fact of life is that the Government has to try to do something about it.

In relation to clause 28, the honourable member for Higgins deplored the fact that the health and safety representative in a factory would get access to any information. He failed to cite subclause 6 which makes a number of exemptions to that right of access to information. As I say, the honourable member for Higgins, in a very selective and misleading way, attempted to say that there was just an open slather and that there were no restrictions on the right of access to information.

The honourable member for Higgins then made reference to the building industry, which was also referred to by the honourable member for Corangamite (Mr McArthur). The honourable member for Higgins said that it was particularly notorious in the building industry that health and safety issues were utilised for other industrial purposes. That is all very nice. One would think that all these people who are injured in the building industry are actually committing suicide or falling off buildings, just to give it the image of being an unsafe industry. The honourable member for Corangamite, towards the end of his speech, also made reference to this point.

A major national work related fatalities survey, carried out between 1982 to 1984, found that just under 200 people died within two years from working in this industry. That 200 people died in an area that, supposedly, notoriously misuses health and safety regulations is quite significant, to my way of thinking. Of course, we occasionally have the front page lamentations of the State Ministers in New South Wales who get a bit upset that a number of people were killed at Darling Harbour, but then next week they walk away from it or pretend that the unions in this field are not really serious about the dangers in the industry. The Government put out a new safety package, a kit, in June 1990 to explain the dangers to workers in the industry. The honourable member for Higgins might be very worried about the fact that it was actually put out in foreign languages as well. Those who have some knowledge of the industry are aware of the heavy number of ethnic workers in it.

Despite the support of the honourable member for Higgins for this legislation, he managed to find a fair number of spurious reasons to denigrate it by saying, `You can trust us to support you on industrial health and safety because we are realists. We know that it is in the self interests of employers to do something about this because it saves money.'

The honourable member for Higgins said that he did not like foreign language notices. He thought the legislation was too structured and that it was attempting to cover the field too widely. The honourable member implied that it provided supposedly open slather for health and safety workers, that they would get all the information that was available and then run off and give it to some company down the road. He raised the question of the misuse of this field for industrial stoppages for other purposes. All those reasons show us where the Opposition really stands. The issue concerns not just this amendment about State rights; the reality is that deep down the Opposition would like to do nothing about this matter. It would like it to give a completely free ride to employers in industry.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about WorkCare in Victoria?

—I do not profess to be an expert on WorkCare legislation in Victoria. There was also the complaint by the honourable member for Higgins about the onus of proof in dismissing work safety representatives. In fact, it might amaze the honourable member, but the union movement might not like that provision either because it would have some concern with the fact that people elected by union members in a factory are not ultimately responsible to those members. That implies that they cannot be trusted to comply with the Act and throw out a person who misused his power and used these rights to destroy the factory, and so on.

SPEECH.PARA: In contrast to the attitude of the Opposition, the Government's practice has been to get consensus in this very important field. Again, in the last week or so, we saw another example of the sorts of fears that the Opposition must have when the latest statistics on the reduction in work time lost by industrial disputes are produced. I will not bother citing those figures because they might be said to be selective and out of context. I would rather refer to the figures between July 1989 and May this year. Despite a big increase in industrial disputes in that time, the Government could still make a fairly encouraging comparison between its performance and that of the Fraser Government. After the worst increase per month for nearly a year, the Government could still boast a position where the average number of working days lost per month had fallen by 54 per cent from 250,000-odd under the previous Government to 114,600.

When we look at work days lost per thousand employees, we see a similar measure of the success of the Government in actually going out there and discussing these matters and attempting to get some kind of agreement on the fundamental requirements of this country. Rather than indulging in all that fantasy island stuff-talking about how everyone should be good mates, slap each other on the back and produce more, as the honourable member for La Trobe constantly contends-this legislation reflects an attempt to get cooperation in the real world.

The submission of the Opposition and the main amendment it has put forward talks about the State situation and how the legislation should effectively cover the field. With a number of honourable members opposite, I had the benefit last weekend of inspecting the future direction of the Australian Taxation Office and its efforts in the area of computerisation. It really drove home-or it should have done so; even to those honourable members opposite-the reality that Federal departments are going down functional lines. What happens in those departments is more relevant to what happens in offices of the same department in Sydney and Parramatta than to what happens to some worker down the street in South Granville.

Since objections were raised by the State governments, the Government has taken a number of measures to reduce the complaints. Amongst those, of course, was a tighter description of `workplace' so that, for instance, the egress and entry for Commonwealth department workers in a private sector building block would not be covered by these Federal measures. The Government has allowed the involvement of State inspectorates. It has said that, in areas where there are no national standards applicable, then State measures will have the right to apply.

In reality there has been an attempt by the Government to reduce the objections of various States. Quite frankly, from the unions' point of view, some of the more hardline groups might say that we should have these State prescriptions such as in South Australia and Victoria, which have been alluded to on the other side of the chamber, where there is a greater right for delegates to close down plants. There have been some complaints, of course, about the rights of delegates, in the absence of supervisors, to close down unsafe practices under this legislation. Some of the people advocating the applicability of State provisions might consider the more hardline provisions that currently apply in a number of States.

In conclusion, this legislation represents the culmination of a series of consultations. It has involved a previous series of codes and a previous variety of prescriptions. It does seek to bring to government employees in the Federal arena provisions that apply to employees in the private sector. I commend the legislation to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tuckey Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The introduction of Occupational Health and Safety (Commonwealth Employment) Bill 1990 in this place raises a number of questions. It raises the questions of the rights of workers, the rights of trade union bureaucrats, such as the honourable member for Reid (Mr Ferguson) and his brother and the Minister at the table, the Minister for Science and Technology (Mr Crean). The Bill raises the question of the appropriate authority to administer any regulation and the position that it might hold.

SPEECH.PARA: Paramount in all of this is the rights of the worker. Of course, we have not heard too much said about the rights of the worker tonight; this is legislation in support of the rights of the bureaucrat, primarily the trade union bureaucrat such as the Minister for Science and Technology was until recently. He called himself a trade unionist. I have worked with trade unionists and I know what they are like-they quite frequently wear blue singlets and black shorts. They know how to drive a truck, like I do, how to work in a shearing team and how to pick up a shovel. They are trade unionists.

Then there are trade union bureaucrats. They are often overweight with frizzy hair. They are all sorts of things but they do not know about work and work practices. But trade union bureaucrats have worked very hard in Australia to build themselves a constituency, to support a political party to the point where they are able to occupy government benches in rotation with the conservative parties. During their period of occupancy, they ensure that they entrench the rights and the privileges of the trade union bureaucrats at every opportunity.

Very closely associated with them is the Government bureaucracy. One cannot have this sort of legislation and these penalties without inspectors. It is a funny thing about inspectors-there are some quite capable inspectors employed by the private sector.

Tomorrow morning all of us will fly off in aeroplanes. We will do that with some confidence in the Australian aeronautical system. Every one of the planes will be certified by a worker, not by a bureaucrat-that is a myth we create. All the licensed aircraft maintenance engineers who operate in the major airlines do not work for the Government, they work for the company. Of course they value their licence, their qualifications and their credentials and they see that they get us where we are going.

To be quite honest, when it comes to my personal safety, I would rather put my faith in those licensed aircraft maintenance engineers than in a trade union bureaucrat. But then comes the question of who is most appropriate. If one believes in this sort of legislation then one believes the answer is more laws. The second reading speech is very deficient in telling us where the financial savings are. It is also deficient in telling us how many lives we are going to save.

We know the Government is going to fine certain people $100,000, but the evidence of this rash of occupational safety legislation does not support the fact that it saves lives or reduces injury. This type of legislation is not new. Over the years I have been involved in the building, road transport and hotel industries and many other industries. There has always been an inspector; someone to tell me the sorts of things I should do to guarantee the safety of my work force. So there is nothing new about it. It is just expanding the role of the bureaucrat and opening up an opportunity for the trade union bureaucrat.

Who is going to pay for that? We live with this myth that somehow or other employers will pay for it. In regard to this legislation we will live with the myth that the Government is going to pay for it. The Government has never paid for anything in its life. It is the very workers whom the Government proposes to protect who will pay for it. I hope the Government does protect them. I hope they get value for money but if they do not this legislation is a waste of time. We are here to protect the workers but the Government does not give me any evidence in the second reading speech of how that is going to happen. The Government gives me no evidence of why the taxes of those workers must rise so they are safer because somehow or other the uniformity of Commonwealth legislation is going to make them safer than the lack of uniformity of State or local government legislation.

I do not know why it is impractical for a Commonwealth employee to be subject to the safety requirements of the Victorian State Government. If there is some difference in those particular laws from those of the Government of Western Australia, I do not know why anybody will be that much worse off. We are just putting another layer of bureaucracy, another layer of government, on top of that which already exists, and which has existed for decades. Nobody comes up with the statistics to show how this has progressively improved anything.

One would think that the previous speaker, the honourable member for Reid, with his long association with the trade union movement, would not have bothered to try to pick-with, if I might say so, a lack of skill. I do not know how much he was paid when he was in the trade union movement but I would have thought I would have been losing on my membership. But let us put it straight: why did the honourable member for Reid not spend his time laying out the evidence? He told us that 200 get killed. Why did he not tell us how many it saved, because that is important to me. The honourable member for Reid should not shake his head. He should have given the House that information. He should have told me, but he has yet to convince me that this is a worthwhile exercise. He might have told me how many lives the legislation was going to save and not how many died.

Let me tell the honourable member about a big killer in Australia: it is called the motor car. Each year 3,000 people are killed in motor car accidents in Australia and 30,000 are injured. By comparison where should we spend our money? Whether we like it or not, we just do not have enough to keep everybody alive or everybody safe from injury. It might be a question of where the Government would better spend the money, but that is not what this legislation is about. It is about increasing the power base of trade union bureaucrats.

The honourable member for Corangamite (Mr McArthur) said there are big problems-there are so many safety related issues in the building industry. I read about them in the newspaper, but do honourable members know what amazes me? All those problems are settled with money. It appears that things can be made safer by paying more dough. The honourable member for Reid knows it happens-he probably negotiated one of those deals. If he did not, the Minister for Science and Technology certainly has. The honourable member believes that as long as one gets a bit more money, we are suddenly safe. What a load of rubbish! Either a site is safe or it is unsafe.

Recently a fellow in my electorate rang me about a big government project. No doubt this legislation will apply shortly. He said, `They are driving me mad. The other day the Builders Labourers Federation (BLF) rang me up and said they were coming onto my site'. He said, `We do not really want you'. And there are not really many honourable members in this Parliament who want them either. The BLF said, `If you do not get all your people to join, we are going to pull a safety issue on you'. This bloke was ringing him from Perth, 300 miles away, saying, `We are going to pull a safety issue on you', and the honourable member for Reid tells me the system is not abused. This bloke from Perth would not know whether a site was safe or not, nor little would he care because he had not been up from Perth to look at the site. He had not worried about the workers but he wanted to make sure he collected a membership from every one of them when he got there, and that is what he did. How many times has Mr Trade Union Bureaucrat-the honourable member for Reid-done that? It happens every day.

I do not think the Minister has not done it; I see he is studiously ignoring the debate. But that is what it is about; it is not about saving the lives of workers. Health and safety legislation is in place and it is almost to the point of being draconian in most States. The situation has got silly, and that is the best word to describe it. Who pays for it? The very bloke who walks around the site in his free boots thinking he is in front of the boss. Whether the boss is the government, as this legislation covers, or whether it is a private employer, what does he do with the cost? He loads it right back on the taxpayer or the consumer.

If the Government thinks it can beat that system, it should tell me how. It is worse than that because every time the Government rushes out there and gets workers a pay increase, this Parliament takes half but the cost of living goes up 1.25 per cent. The Government has been telling them what a good job they do and they have to pay, they have to have compulsory unionism so they can pay for the services of the Government.

It is worth noting this duplication. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) needed a bit of attention-he wanted to get people's minds off the economy. So he got the Premiers, mostly his mates, up to Brisbane and they all talked about doing something about the lack of duplication. I do not know who is best equipped to run occupational health and safety but I should have thought the bloke who was closest to the job, in government terms, would have been best equipped.

I am not sure that a centralist government should have the role of running around checking on whether someone has the right planks in the scaffolding. I am not really sure that that is our responsibility. But we are going to double up on it; all the States have it, and we are going to have a bit more of it because we employ a lot of people. What is the purpose of that? How many inspectors does the Government want?

I know the Government has an unemployment problem. We will have an inspector-led recovery, but the truth is, the Government does not need them. The inspectors have been there for decades, and when the Government can prove to me that its recent trade union innovations at State level have clearly reduced the number of accidents and deaths, then I will say the Government is getting somewhere.

However, the other side of it, and the Government has been on about it here for two days, is that the Western Australia Liberal Party is paranoid about Federal Government involvement. I have a letter here: the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins) has written to the Premier of Western Australia suggesting that he can use Section 51 (15) of the Constitution-the weights and measures proposal-to impose daylight saving on Western Australia. And the Government wonders why it is not trusted. What a dopey thing to do. The Government wants to take weights and measures-a proper responsibility of central Government-and convert that responsibility to daylight saving.

I think it would be interesting to look at the paranoia that occurs. There is always an issue. We are always generating new bureaucratic processes. We have domestic violence bureaucrats now who are selling us the idea that there is domestic violence in one in three families. Of course, women said that those being bashed were all women. Of course, the statistics do not even support that.

I have some interesting statistics from the United States. In relative statistical terms, the message would be just as clear here. They relate to some of the remarks that have been made here tonight, particularly with regard to asbestos. Clean air is a problem on a work site, is it not? Clean air is a problem anyway. In America they have got to the point of being so paranoid about clean air that this year they are going to spend a huge amount of money on it. It is estimated-the figure is questionable; it is the high point-that by that clean air legislation they will save an additional 2,700 American lives at $16m a life. We can say that a life is immeasurable in cost, but this year alcoholism and drug abuse will kill 380,000 Americans, yet they spend practically nothing on preventing those deaths.

What are we doing here? How best do we look after workers? Do we employ a few more trade union bureaucrats or do we look at the areas where people are dying? It is interesting that the United States Environmental Protection Agency wants emission risks to be reduced to one per million. The equivalent risk for Americans is to drive a car 40 miles, fly 2,500 miles in a commercial jet or canoe for six minutes.

In America diet is responsible for 178,000 cancer deaths per annum. The United States Government spends $280 per death on nutrition research. Nutritional problems are the biggest killer of people. Honourable members might be interested to know that cancer deaths in laboratory rats fed a potent carcinogen can be reduced from 90 per cent to 3 per cent just by reducing their calorific intake by 20 per cent. It is not the carcinogen that kills them; they are being fed to death. The same is happening with human beings. We are debating duplicate legislation when maybe we should be looking a little more at the worker's diet.

Asbestos is another matter. The other day an oil rig, I think on the North West Shelf, was closed down because somebody had the temerity to produce an asbestos gasket. If one knows anything, one knows what a gasket does. It is squeezed between two pieces of steel or brass. There is a tiny edge sticking out. About 500 blokes went on strike. If they had sniffed it for a week they still would not have got mesothelioma.

The interesting thing is that, again in America, a program costing Americans a fortune will result in asbestos being removed from 733,000 buildings for the sorts of reasons that this Government would promote under its occupational health and safety program. This will cost hundreds of billions of dollars, and it has now been discovered that there is more risk in removing asbestos than in leaving it there. This is a very well established principle which is not contested. The program is based on a forecast that 67,000 Americans will die from airborne asbestos, but so far only 1,500 cases per annum of mesothelioma have been reported. Male asbestos mine workers over 65 comprise 80 per cent of the cases, many of whom were also heavy smokers.

The yanks have a radon bureaucracy now. People put radon measuring instruments into houses. It is said that 20,000 Americans will be killed this year by radon, but the claim is extrapolated from studies of occupational exposures of 375 uranium mine workers who were exposed to radon levels 12,000 times the level found in a typical US home. Iowa has the highest level of radon exposure and one of the lowest levels of cancer.

I will support the Government's legislation when it can show me that it is benefiting the worker-not the inspector; the worker-and that the money then spent is going to save more lives than might be saved by reducing cancer deaths through better nutritional research and better attitudinal development.

I was a member of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Road Safety, which looked at the licensing of drivers. I had a lot of preconceived ideas which are reflected in other people's thoughts today. When I had finished my work on that Committee, I had learnt that only changing people's attitudes would save lives. Everything else has been tried around the world-longer licence training and all sorts of things. In America a very big study was carried out. One group was taught by their families; one was taught by a driving school; one was taught at school; and one was given extra training. They followed the history of group members for about five years. The group that had the worst crash rate was the one that had had the advanced driver training. All of the other groups were about the same.

The only thing that will reduce our death toll on the roads and in our workplace is attitude-people taking care. This will not be done by having inspectors and fines. It will not be done by having two occupational safety levels at two levels of government. As State governments happen to be a little closer to the workplace, I think that they can do the job quite well.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Somlyay Mr A.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —There has been much talk in recent years of the need for tourist resorts and facilities to be more environmentally friendly. This has culminated in the recent publication by the Australian Tourist Industry Association of environmental guidelines for developers.

SPEECH.PARA: In my electorate of Fairfax, a major family resort was opened on 30 November-that is, last Friday-which is an object lesson for ecologically sustainable development. It sets standards for resort developments throughout Australia, and I urge the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Mrs Kelly) and the shadow Minister for the environment, the honourable member for Pearce (Mr Chaney), to make an early visit. The development is also a culmination of nine years of local controversy over environmental factors which has been resolved to the benefit of all parties.

The development I speak of is the Twin Waters Resort. It is located on the Sunshine Coast where the Maroochy River meets the Pacific Ocean and offers 1.5 kilometres of both surf beach and river frontages. In addition to the attractions of the beach and the river, the resort has also constructed a six-hectare salt water lagoon, thus providing for other forms of water sport.

The resort buildings occupy 20 hectares of the site of a total area of 267 hectares, all of which, with the exclusion of the resort and an 18-hole championship golf course, is untouched bushland. On day one of the development, all key trees on the site were marked and retained. Indeed, the natural flora includes many examples of threatened species for which a specific program of care and propagation has been implemented. All mangroves on the site which are now known to be ecologically very important have been retained.

Substantial restoration work has been undertaken on the dunes fronting the beach and the river; they have been regenerated and provided with natural growth supplemented with 1,100 plantings of appropriate species supplied by the State Government's Beach Protection Authority. No building is more than two storeys in height and all buildings are therefore below the line of the surrounding trees. The resort is visually unobtrusive. Twin Waters resort is an object lesson in creating harmony with the environment and epitomises the benefits that can result from seeking and achieving compatibility with the surroundings.

Kangaroos, wallabies and other fauna come right up to the hotel, and guests can see and enjoy the environment in its natural state, augmented only by plantings of selected flora from Brisbane's Expo site, including also the thousand-year-old forked blackboy, which is a feature of the resort. Because of its sensitivity to the environment, I am confident the Twin Waters resort will have lasting appeal not only to Australians but also to overseas visitors to this country.

It is a development of which locals are proud. Twin Waters is a resort which maximises the natural attractions and beauties of the existing local flora and fauna. It does not seek to change the character of the local area. The opening of the resort was a local community event, allowing locals to attend, participate, and share in the occasion. The opening was conducted not by a State or Federal Minister, as is usually the case, or any other political figure, but by a local achiever from my electorate, Lisa Currie. Future local participation is not only encouraged but is integral to the future success of the project.

Finally, this development has occurred in Fairfax at a time when recession-induced unemployment in the region has increased by 33 per cent in the past 12 months. As many as 260 permanent jobs have been created for local young Australians through Twin Waters. Over 1,000 people were interviewed for these jobs. Tourism is our largest export earner. Developments such as Twin Waters offer a real hope in times when we need to earn export income.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell Mr G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to talk about the wool industry, which is without a doubt the greatest decentralised industry in Australia. In my view, it is absolutely essential that this industry is maintained. I have been looking at some average prices of greasy wool since the beginning of the century. These prices are expressed in 1989 dollars, constant 1989 dollars.

SPEECH.PARA: In the depths of the Depression, from 1929 to 1933, the average price of wool was 452.63c per kilogram. In the years from 1983 to 1987 it was 452.47c per kilogram, which is very comparable. In 1960 to 1970-these were the years after the effects of the war-it was at 688.69c per kilogram. In 1970 to 1980 it was 543.16c per kilogram.

Over longer periods, from 1908 to 1939, from virtually the beginning of documentation until the Second World War, the average price was 574c per kilogram. The war years and the war influence would have been from 1939 to 1960. In that time the average price was 998c per kilogram. From 1960 to 1989 it was 583c per kilogram.

When one extrapolates these figures, one sees that in recent times wool has been relatively cheap. The prices that have been recorded do not give any reason or indication for the dropping off in the use of wool. It is the percentage of the fibre market held by wool that is of most concern to me. In 1939, wool held 15 per cent; in 1960, it was 10 per cent; in 1988, it was 4.9 per cent; and it looks as though in January 1991 it will be 2.3 per cent. This is the very worrying situation indeed, as in the long run it is the percentage of the fibre market which is going to determine whether we have a viable industry in Australia.

I am concerned that what we have in the wool industry today is a religion, where wool producers are told not to deal in facts but to have faith-blind faith-and to trust the Wool Commission, the Australian Wool Corporation, and not to rock the boat. In my view, it is an indictment of the industry and of the wool producers that they have not questioned the Corporation more strongly. In my view, the Corporation must be held responsible for this dramatic decline in the percentage of the fibre market held by wool, particularly when one recognises it has been spending an enormous sum of money on the promotion of wool. I am certain that if this contract had been given to the private sector, it would have done better. If it had not, it would have been sacked. According to the Wool Corporation, the solution seems to be to employ more people.

When it comes to information needs, I think one can be very critical of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation. Its rural department has for many, many years been an extension of the National Party. As such, it has kept many farmers in ignorance. It is interesting to note that the Wool Corporation is getting its message across very strongly and frequently on the ABC in the rural programs. The ABC is not giving anything like the same coverage to the people who are putting the alternative view.

I am told that recently the ABC has told people in its employment involved in the rural industry in Western Australia not to rock the boat; in other words, not to criticise or call into question decisions of the Wool Corporation. In the long run, the taxpayer is the one who will suffer if we lose too much market share. If the Australian wool industry contracts, the Australian taxpayer will pay very, very sorely. It is of interest to the Australian taxpayer, in my view, to get the best he can. In that regard it is important that the taxpayer buy the wool stockpile today at the discounted price, for this is the only way we can get stability into wool marketing. If that stockpile is locked up by the Government-it has to be the Government, because no-one will trust the Wool Corporation--

TALK.START.PARA: —I appreciate the opportunity to speak again tonight. Last night I discussed some essays that had been submitted, in response to a competition that I had asked for, from the local primary and secondary schools. The topic was `The Environment-The Challenge of the Future'. Last night I read an essay from Beth Mitchell, who won the senior award. Tonight it is my very great pleasure to read the essay of Adam Jackson, who is in year 6 at the Smeaton Primary School. Adam's essay is as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: In the world today, there is new technology which is achieving more each day, countries are getting bigger and stronger and the poor countries are being provided with a number of trades and also medical aid and food, but out of all these expanding topics, the environment is one of the most least beneficial areas.

The growing population of the world is using up most of the world's minerals, fauna and vegetation. Now what we have is a polluted, dying world and there are also cracks forming in the ozone layer which is something that should not be ignored.

We are losing the beauty of the world and turning it into skyscrapers and concrete slabs. The world has already lost many of it's beautiful species of animals, but we still have many which are in danger of extinction. The minerals of the world are declining and if we keep on going the way we are, they will run out.

Out in the world there are many people eager to do something for our environment that would make a significant difference. If we all combine and communicate and take it a step at a time perhaps we may be able to save our planet.

Recycling is a big help in today's world. Far too many materials are being wasted which could be easily recycled back into useable products. If we would all take a bit more care and be aware of our own throw away habits, maybe our forests would have a chance to regenerate. One small way we could be helping is by using a string bag or equivalent to carry our shopping in instead of using plastic bags or paper wrappings.
Salinity is an increasing problem and many innocent farmers are suffering because others haven't taken notice. Salinity destroys the land and makes it useless.

Logging is destroying our beautiful rain forests. Not only are we harming ourselves, but the native animals and birdlife are continually being threatened. Protests are being held everywhere to make people more aware of the forests plight.
I think that the Government and the loggers should be making very careful decisions about our timber industry to ensure that we still have forests for future generations.

The cracking of the ozone layer will have far reaching effects on the world's weather which will dramatically change our lifestyle. Pollution is the cause of it, all the household sprays, car fumes and gases. Scientists have already developed new sprays and materials which are friendly to the environment. With new technology being discovered every day maybe it is not too late to save our planet.

I think that the money spent on arms and discovering new planets should be used to fix our environment. There is a lot wrong with our world, but there is still a chance of getting it back into a healthy state, so we must keep fighting together until we have achieved this.
That is an essay from a young man who is in year six. I hope that the contribution he makes is shared by many other children in this country.

A number of other people also contributed to the essay competition: Benjamin Richardson, Regina Righetti, Cassandra Peters, Elizabeth Righetti, E. Dutton, Chuong Nguyen, Jennifer Griffith, Tim Rivett, Nikki Quinney, Lisa Zachary, Raelene Sharp, Kim Hazeldine, Jade Harris, Sophie Elsworth, Jade Holster, Travis Vallance, Andrew Knowles, Josh Roe, Tanya Britten, Melanie Twomey, Kathryn Underwood, Anthea Greville, Cameron Hook, Nerrdyn Ford, Fiona Cullen, Kellie Manton, Andrew McNaughton, David Atkins, David Dowell, Penny Kerr and Sally-Anne Day. I thank them all most sincerely for their contribution to this extremely important topic. I know that, with the contribution of our young people, we can address the very serious problems of the environment that we face today.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hollis Mr C.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a well known fact that when one wants to prove a point on which one is a little bit shaky-be it one's political popularity or something that one wants to market-one gets some usually sympathetic survey group to carry out a survey and then, when it comes up with the result one wants, the point is proven. I was glancing through the Canberra Times today and my attention was drawn to the fact that, according to the headline here, 65 per cent of the people of New South Wales and Victoria approve of the Very Fast Train idea and, it was reported, more know of its benefits.

SPEECH.PARA: Well, I do not know what its benefits are. Apparently there was a survey of 1,109 people and, from this small group, the survey deduced that 65 per cent of the people know of the proposal's benefits. I hope that the questioning was a little more thorough than this report would indicate, because apparently one of the salient features of the Very Fast Train which was put to these people was that it would take trucks off the roads. Anyone who knows anything about the Very Fast Train proposal knows that this is exactly what it is not going do. I would be the first to agree with the Very Fast Train proposal if it would take some of those trucks trundling down the Hume Highway, through my electorate, through the electorate of the honourable member for Gilmore (Mr Sharp) and others, off the road.

What the Very Fast Train will not do-and it will never become a reality-is take any of those trucks off the road. That is what we have to do. We have to get those trucks off the road and get that heavy freight on to rail. But the Very Fast Train will not do that, and the consortium admits that. I have had many, many discussions with members of the consortium. I have taken a great interest in this proposal because, if it ever comes to fruition, the Very Fast Train will go through my electorate. I believe-and I have said it in this chamber many times-that both the State and Federal governments of both political persuasions over many years have neglected our State and Federal rail systems.

I have no argument with the point that the Federal Government should be putting more money into rail. We have increased the amount under the new proposals this year and, of course, coming up we have the freight proposal that came out of the Special Premiers Conference. But I believe that governments of all political persuasions, whether they are State or Federal, have neglected rail and the trucks have been encouraged onto our roads where they are doing a massive amount of damage. If we have money to spare, we should be doing something about the rail link between Sydney and Melbourne; we should be straightening out some of those bends.

I noticed the other day it was announced that we would put in the new siding at Parkes and more crossing loops between Parkes and Broken Hill. In that way, by marshalling the trains at Parkes, we can send very fast freight trains across to Broken Hill and then across to the west. That is very important. I have also argued many times that if we had an adequate marshalling yard at Parkes, we could have an eastern seaboard port-hopefully, Port Kembla-where we could bring the containers in; put them on the rail; take them out to Parkes; remarshall at Parkes; and then, from Parkes, we could send them south to Melbourne, north to Brisbane and west to Perth. That would be a very important step and I would support that very strongly.

But as to the Very Fast Train proposal, I keep seeing different figures. I think the estimate for the proposal is up to $18 billion at the moment. Money would have to be borrowed overseas-great for the foreign debt-and it is no wonder that some of the consortium members have recently withdrawn from this proposal. If I were looking to put my meagre investments anywhere, I most certainly would not invest in this proposal. I have not seen all the details of the survey-I will try to get a copy of it-but, judging by the report in the Canberra Times today, it was very biased. Regardless of the 65 per cent of people who allegedly approve of the Very Fast Train, I am one resident of New South Wales who opposes it. I oppose it, as do most of my constituents, especially those in the southern highlands area of New South Wales who would be greatly affected by this outrageous proposal.

TALK.START.PARA: —Recently, the Australian Political Exchange Committee presented to the Parliament the printed report of the Committee for the period 1 July 1989 to 30 June 1990. The Australian Political Exchange Program administered by the Committee was established on 21 December 1981 when the then Prime Minister, Malcolm Fraser, with the support of the leaders of all parliamentary political parties, announced the establishment of an interim committee to arrange exchange visits between young political leaders of Australia and other countries. The leaders of the four parliamentary parties became the principals of this interim committee.

SPEECH.PARA: In August 1983, the interim committee, with the agreement of the principals, became the Australian Political Exchange Committee (APEC). The current Committee consists of the Chairman, the honourable Sir Robert Cotton KCMG; Mr Alan Cadman MP; Mr Robert Hogg, representing the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke); Ms Sam Hudson, representing the Leader of the Australian Democrats (Senator Powell); Mr Tony Eggleton, representing the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson); the honourable Kerry Sibraa, President of the Senate, who is also a prime ministerial representative; and me. I am privileged to serve on the Committee as the representative of the Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Tim Fischer).

The basic aims of the political exchange program are to foster international understanding and goodwill through the exchange of young political leaders, and to provide opportunities for young people involved in politics to study the political systems of other countries. The first exchange arrangement was with the United States of America. Similar arrangements have since been entered into with Canada, the People's Republic of China, the Soviet Union and the Federal Republic of Germany. The Committee continues to consider the expansion of its operations to other countries.

It is not possible to quantify the benefits that have accrued to Australia through the operation of the program. However, it is clear that it has provided a framework within which initial contacts may be made and views and ideas exchanged between potential future leaders of Australia and other countries. Delegates are carefully chosen and have worked well together in the interests of Australia, as well as adding to their own knowledge and skill.

In the period covered by the report, the delegation has travelled from Australia to the USSR, while delegations have visited Australia from Canada, the United States and West Germany. I am sure the Committee would wish me to pay a tribute to those companies who help to finance the program and who are too numerous to mention in the time I have allocated. The Federal Government is also to be thanked, as is the Prime Minister for his support.

Finally, I would like to pay a tribute on behalf of the Committee to a distinguished Australian, Sir Robert Cotton, who is the Chairman of the Committee, and also to the Secretariat, Mr John Leonart and Mrs Caroline Hughes, who are the executive officers, for their enthusiastic work for the Committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grace Mr E.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight, I wish to say a few words about the important role that migrants have played in the growth and development of the south western Sydney area. I raise this subject because, once again, it seems that we are hearing unwarranted criticism of newcomers to this great country of ours. As a member for the electorate with one of the largest ethnic populations in Australia, I feel compelled to answer some of those criticisms and relate to the House the tremendous contribution that ethnic communities and their leaders have made to Fowler.

SPEECH.PARA: I should preface my remarks by suggesting that some unkind people may feel that I speak with a bias when I come to the defence of migrants because I am a migrant myself. Of course I am and it is a fact of which, incidentally, I am extremely proud. That, however, is of no consequence as far as my feelings on this subject are concerned and of very little importance in Fowler where roughly 80 per cent of my constituents are the first or second generation of overseas-born Australians.

The fact is that the electorate of Fowler contains citizens from more than 100 different ethnic backgrounds. It contains very large communities of Italians, Croatians, Vietnamese, Chinese, people of Serbian extraction, and substantial communities of a host of other nationalities. Each and every community has brought its own distinctive style, culture and skills to the area; and each has played a part in contributing to the wider good of the region.

As the economy has slowed in recent times we have all heard the old party favourites trotted out regarding the cost to the wider community of the process of bringing new Australians to this country. We have heard that the dole queues are full of ethnic people who do not want to work. We hear that new arrivals are given handouts that far exceed anything available to ordinary Australians and we are told that multiculturalism has been a cause of all our economic and social problems and the destruction of our distinctive Australian way of life. This is all poppycock.

In the seven years I have been the member for Fowler it has been my experience that not only are those types of criticisms sad but they are fundamentally wrong. I have had the pleasure over the years in the electorate of Fowler to work very closely with a large number of ethnic communities and to study their attitude to this country and their perception of their role in the scheme of things. I must say that in each and every case I have found a community which wants to contribute and be recognised as an element of Australian society.

I have found that our ethnic communities, through their leadership, have a social philosophy which is based on three fundamental elements-a desire to teach their own culture to their children, a belief in the need to contribute to the wider society, and an aversion to actions which create ethnic tensions, which is probably the most important one.

As an example I would point to the large Croatian community in Fowler which is very capably led by a gentleman by the name of Mr Ned Maruncic. Mr Maruncic is the type of leader that is the norm from community to community-a man who considers himself above all else an Australian, but who sees advantages for his children and other members of the Croatian community in the maintenance of aspects of the culture of his homeland. Mr Maruncic is also typical of the mainstream of ethnic leaders in that he has encouraged his community to become involved in issues of much greater importance than recreational activities-issues such as the care of the sick and the elderly, and the finding of employment for the young.

In Fowler we have seen the Croatian community raise a substantial amount of money to build their Cardinal Stepinac retirement village, just as the Vietnamese, Serbian and Italian communities have done before them.

In south-western Sydney we have our share of problems. Our youth unemployment levels are abysmally high, our public infrastructure is of a very ordinary standard, and our facilities are insufficient for our needs. Nevertheless we have a region that is growing faster than the State average, and a general community that is vibrant and forward looking. A great part of our success can be directly attributed to the influence of our migrant communities, particularly their capacity for hard work, their resolve to succeed, and their willingness to re-invest the proceeds of their efforts back into the region.

Anyone who questions the value of migrants to Australia need only come to south-western Sydney. Should they take the time they will see places such as Cabramatta, which are booming under the influence of migrant communities, and they will find a general level of activity that is the envy of regions that have not been so enriched.

—You would know all about dirty tricks.
—I warn the honourable member for Fowler.

—In relation to the contents of the so-called blue files seized from under Robert Smith's bed by Federal police officers on 6 December 1988, how much did the then Attorney-General, Lionel Bowen, know of the events described in the sordid diary entries contained with the file? Was the then Attorney-General briefed on the contents of the blue file? If so, what conclusions did he draw from the entries that identified Brian Burke as an active participant in the dirty tricks campaign?

SPEECH.PARA: Watergate without the Washington Post was how the honourable member for Pearce (Mr Chaney) so eloquently described the WA Inc. scandals. I am sure that the Smith tape revelations will occupy a similar relationship with the history of Western Australia as the Nixon tapes with the history of the United States.

On Sunday 2 December the Perth Sunday Times reporter, Martin Saxon, unequivocally identified Brian Burke as the BB mentioned in the diary entries which I was able to read into Hansard some two to three weeks ago. In particular, the following is recorded in Smith's diary on 6= April 1987:
9pm to Vince's. Delivered transcript to Vince of (name deleted)-Burke tape with tape. Copy to BB. Copy to TB.

Martin Saxon's article then describes how on the following day the Premier, Brian Burke, threw a one liner across the chamber of the Legislative Assembly which suggested he, Brian Burke, was aware of the contents of the City of Stirling bribe tape, secretly recorded in the office of the Premier's brother, Terry Burke. It is clear from the diary that the current Ambassador to Ireland received regular reports from Smith of his nefarious activities which included a campaign to denigrate Gary Aslan, witness for the prosecution in the trial of Brian Burke's close friend Len Brush, Liberal State MP, Ross Lightfoot and others, including senior WA Liberal MP Ian Laurance.

In view of these revelations it is now pertinent to ask what Attorney-General Lionel Bowen knew of the blue file, the tape and the diary. It is now clear from the entries revealed in Saxon's article and the trial of Robert Smith that Brian Burke was not only the BB mentioned in the diary entries but also an active player in the dirty tricks campaign.

If Lionel Bowen was briefed on the same information that has become available to the public, thanks to that trial and to Martin Saxon's efforts, why did he not come to the same conclusion as has been arrived at by the angry and betrayed voters of Western Australia?

Now is the time for the Federal Government to recall and stand-down the Ambassador to Ireland and the Holy See. While these question marks remain over the activities of the former Premier during the dirty tricks campaign it is not appropriate for him to represent this country as emissary.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the right honourable member's question is as follows:

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hollis Mr C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Land Transport, upon notice, on 10 May 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: What is the state of discussions on linking Melbourne and Adelaide by a direct standard gauge railway.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: Australian National Railways (AN) advises that between 1983 and 1988, studies and discussions were undertaken with V/Line concerning upgrading and conversion of the Melbourne-Adelaide line, but major investigating work has been suspended pending developments on the National Freight Initiative.

Recently, I approved, under the Australian Centennial Roads Development Program, funding of $21.029m over a three year period to upgrade a one hundred km stretch of the main south line from Coonalpyn to the Victorian border. The upgrading will include replacement of poor condition wooden sleepers with concrete, gauge-convertible sleepers. Upgrading will allow AN and V/Line to provide a more competitive and efficient service and to improve rail's share of the interstate freight transport market. Furthermore, the use of gauge-convertible sleepers will yield significant potential savings if the line is standardised.

The National Freight Initiative report identifies standardisation of the Melbourne-Adelaide rail link as one of a number of investment options that could be undertaken to improve the efficiency of interstate rail operations. Standardisation is not, however, critical to the viability of the National Rail Freight Corporation (NRFC); it is one investment issue that will need to be addressed by the NRFC once it becomes fully operational.

The Melbourne-Adelaide link will be examined in a major study being carried out by the Bureau of Transport and Communications Economics into the future demands and infrastructure needs of the major interstate transport corridors.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Ruddock Mr P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs, upon notice, on 31 May 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the Minister's attention been drawn to a Chinese Government document which divides overseas Chinese students into five categories to receive various levels of punishment if they return to the People's Republic of China (PRC).

(2) If this document exists, do such discriminatory actions on the part of the Chinese Government give sufficient grounds for some or all PRC nationals in Australia to be granted residency on humanitarian or refugee grounds.
(3) How many PRC nationals have applied for residence on (a) humanitarian and (b) refugee grounds since 4 June 1989.
(4) What percentage of PRC nationals currently in Australia has applied for residence or refugee status.

(5) How many applications for residence or refugee status from PRC nationals in Australia have been determined since 4 June 1989; if none have been determined, when will his Department commence so determining.
(6) How many of the applicants referred to in part (5) are PRC (a) diplomats and (b) students in Australia.
(7) Is he able to say whether students who are PRC nationals are suffering increased financial and social difficulties in Australia.

(8) Are PRC nationals in Australia granted temporary entry permits class 829; if so, does this (a) allow them to remain until 31 January 1991 but (b) deny them (i) a grant of residence on economic grounds, (ii) the right to re-entry visa, (iii) the right to graduate after 31 January 1991, (iv) the right to hold their scholarships, (v) the opportunity to finish their courses, (vi) the right of their children to public schooling and (vii) the right to Medicare benefits.
(9) Does his Department expect to complete determining the applications referred to in part (5), on a case-by-case basis, before the 31 January 1991 deadline.

(10) Are PRC nationals in Australia who have been granted temporary entry permits class 829 unable to take up full-time employment based on their qualifications obtained in Australia because the new Migration Act specifically prohibits grant of residence on economic, occupation and special skills grounds to such applicants.

(11) Will he use his discretion to waive the prohibition referred to in part (10) so that PRC nationals can endeavour to support themselves and their families while at the same time contributing their skills to the Australian economy.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hand The Hon G.L.

TALK.START.PARA: — The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Chinese student groups have forwarded to me papers, purporting to be official Chinese Government documents, which place PRC students in the United States and Canada into five categories according to their apparent political commitment and activities.

(2) The document to which Mr Ruddock refers deals specifically with PRC nationals in the United States and Canada. But it was one element in the mosaic of information available to the Government on this issue. Individual applications on humanitarian or refugee grounds are considered on a case-by-case basis.
(3) (a) Humanitarian:

Up to 19 December 1989 approximately 6,650 applications had been received from PRC nationals for Grant of Residence Status on humanitarian and compassionate grounds. From 19 December 1989 to mid 1990 a further 3,140 applications had been received for a Permanent Entry Permit after Entry (PEPAE)-2400 humanitarian and 740 PRC. People may have made multiple applications, but there are no precise figures on this.
(b) Refugee:
1420 applications for refugee status from PRC nationals were lodged in the period from 4 June 1989 to 30 June 1990.
(4) In mid 1990 there were an estimated 44,000 PRC nationals temporarily in Australia.

By mid year there were some 13,820 (7,950 Grant of Residence Status (GORS), 4,450 PEPAE and 1,420 Refugee) applications from PRC nationals for residence or refugee status. This figure includes applications for residence on spouse and occupational grounds.
A precise percentage cannot be given of PRC nationals who have applied for residence or refugee status due to the probability of multiple applications.

(5) Approximately 1300 applications for GORS/PEPAE have been determined in the period July 1989-August 1990, the vast majority involved decisions on family and economic grounds. A small number of decisions have also been taken on compassionate and humanitarian grounds. Some applications have been withdrawn.

A small number of applications for refugee status have been determined. It is not the practice of the Government to publish specific statistics where small numbers of cases are involved, as this may lead to the identification of individuals. This could result in harm to such individuals or their relatives in their source country and thus be in breach of Australia's obligations under the 1951 Convention relating to the Status of Refugees.
(6) As noted in 5 above, information in relation to applications for refugee status, or on humanitarian grounds, could run the risk of identifying individuals.

(7) The Government's response to this issue has taken account of the financial and social difficulties of individual PRC nationals in Australia. Grants were provided to welfare and counselling agencies last year and on 10 July 1990 the Minister for Finance, Mr Ralph Willis, and I announced a range of Government services to which PRC nationals who were in Australia on 20 June 1989 and who are granted a four year temporary permit will have access.

(8) The questions about temporary entry permits class 829 have now been overtaken by the announcement on 27 June of the new temporary entry permit for PRC nationals who were in Australia on 20 June 1989.

The special permits provide for temporary residence until 30 June 1994. In deciding to provide the special permit the Government at the same time considered the question of applications by sponsored students from the PRC for grant of residence on occupational grounds. It was decided to amend the legislation to allow sponsored PRC students in Australia on 20 June 1989 to apply for residence on occupational grounds.
Holders of the special permit may apply for a single travel re-entry visa unless travel is to the PRC.

Where PRC nationals have maintained their student status they maintain their rights to scholarships. Students may apply for the balance of the permit to 30 June 1994, at the completion of their studies. Dependant children of the holders of this permit will be given access to primary and secondary education and to the English-as-second-language program. They also have access to Medicare.

(9) PRC nationals who were in Australia on 20 June 1989 who have already applied for resident status have the choice of proceeding with those applications or of applying immediately for the PRC (temporary) entry permit valid until 30 June 1994.

Those applications that are not withdrawn will be processed on a case-by-case basis. Given current processing backlogs for refugee status and grant of resident status this is not likely to occur before 31 January 1991. However this is no longer a significant date.

PRC nationals in Australia on 20 June 1989 whose applications for permanent residence are unsuccessful will be permitted to apply for the balance of the special permit's validity to 30 June 1994. Applicants for DORS are able to apply at any time for the PRC (temporary) entry permit valid until 30 June 1994.

(10) PRC nationals granted temporary entry permits class 829 were permitted to take up full-time employment. I understand there were some problems in obtaining long term employment relevant to qualifications and skills as these permits were only valid to 31 January 1991. The provision of the special permit,valid to 30 June 1994, should help resolve this problem. As indicated in response to part (8), the government has decided to amend legislation to lift the exclusion for grant of residence on occupational grounds with respect to sponsored students from the PRC who were in Australia on 20 June 1989.
(11) As noted in questions 8 and 10, this is to be dealt with by legislative change.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Ruddock Mr P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs, upon notice, on 18 September 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Does his Department require strict application of the settlement test contained in the Procedures Advice Manual.

(2) Is the settlement test applied (a) in processing all applications for permanent entry to Australia at all overseas posts and (b) where consideration is given to a grant of permanent residence status within Australia.
(3) How many applicants, otherwise eligible for entry to Australia, have been excluded by application of the settlement test at each post and under each substantial category for migrant entry.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hand The Hon G.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Procedures Advice Manual (PAM) provides guidance and assistance to officers for the purposes of implementing the Regulations. The settlement test is prescribed in the Regulations as follows and is binding on decisionmakers accordingly as force of law:

Regulation 2 of the Migration Regulations defines ``public interest criteria'' in relation to settlement as ``in the case of a person seeking to enter Australia for a period of not less than 12 months (other than a person seeking to do so under a spouse visa or as the dependent child of an Australian citizen or of an Australian permanent resident)-is likely to become established in Australia without undue personal difficulty and without imposing undue difficulties or cost on the Australian community''.
The Minister has residual powers under Sections 115 and 137 of the Migration Act to set aside these requirements.
(2) Applications for migration to Australia, temporary stay over 12 months and for a Permanent Entry Permit After Entry are all subject to the settlement requirement:

- with the exception of applicants for a spouse visa or as a dependent child of an Australian citizen or permanent resident as their immediate family links provide a high degree of settlement support.

The PAM explains how the settlement assessment is administered on the basis of the application and supporting documentation. Indicators available to the decisionmaker from the documentary information provided by the applicant are listed in the PAM. These enquiries are supplemented by a detailed assessment at personal interview where there is reason for concern. The PAM emphasises: ``If an officer considers that the applicant or a member of the family unit would be unable to settle satisfactorily in Australia the application is to be refused''.
