QUESTION.SPEAKER: Ruddock Mr P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs, upon notice, on 19 September 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: With respect to each of the Departments and agencies for which the Minister has portfolio responsibility, (a) when (i) was the first round Access and Equity Plan published and (ii) will the second round Access and Equity Plan be published, (b) what mechanisms have been set up, including at the regional level, to ensure ongoing consultation on access and equity with community organisations, (c) which community organisations or representatives are involved in such mechanisms, (d) which officer has major responsibilities for access and equity in the Department or agency and what is the officer's position and (e) what are the names and contact telephone numbers of the access and equity officers in each region.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hand The Hon G.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (a) (i) The first round Access and Equity Plan was published in 1988.
(ii) The Department is in the process of preparing a second round plan. This will be published by June 1991.
(b) and (c) The Department has consultative arrangements with ethnic community groups covering, among other issues, the access and equity strategy. Details of these consultative mechanisms are below.

A Women's Issues and Access and Equity Section was established recently in the Ethnic Affairs Branch of the Department's Central Office. Amongst other matters, the Section has responsibility for the development of the Department's access and equity policy including community consultative arrangements.
Central Office

Regular consultations at ministerial level are held with the Federation of Ethnic Communities' Councils of Australia (FECCA) on settlement and migration issues. The Settlement Branch of the Department is currently working with FECCA to involve it in settlement planning issues on a more systematic basis. Consultative arrangements are also proposed with other groups interested in migration and settlement.
Commonwealth and State consultative arrangements are currently being put in place in all States to ensure State and community input into immigration/settlement planning processes.

Under the Local Government Development Program (LGDP) funds are provided to councils to carry out specific projects of a research and developmental nature. An amount of $0.15m per annum for three years has been provided for a Multicultural Access and Equity category under the LGDP. Steering Committees for these projects may be formed comprising representatives of the local government body in receipt of the grant, other relevant bodies and community representatives. Under this category of the LGDP, initiatives by local councils to develop consultative mechanisms have been established.
The Regional level

The Department's State/Territory and regional offices maintain regular contact with Grant-in-Aid agencies, Migrant Resource Centres (MRCs) and representatives of the Office of Multicultural Affairs (OMA). State Ethnic Affairs or Community Liaison Officers are involved in ongoing consultations with community groups which include ethnic federations such as the Ethnic Communities Councils (ECCs), bilingual and ethnic workers, religious bodies, community welfare organisations, citizens advice bureaux, and cultural and educational institutions.
In addition, State/Territory and regional offices are involved in other consultative arrangements which are outlined below.

The Ethnic Affairs Section within the Victorian State Office participates in the Commonwealth Access and Equity Contact Officers Group convened by the OMA and in regular meetings concerning access and equity held by the City of Springvale. Departmental officers are members of the Springvale Migrant Settlement Committee and participate in the North-East Region Ethnic Issues Network.

The Department's State Office in New South Wales has established a network of Access and Equity Officers in each of the five regional offices, and in consultation with OMA has undertaken to establish a community consultation mechanism specifically for access and equity.

Both the ACT Territory Director and Settlement Manager have ongoing meetings with the ECC and the ACT Government which involve negotiations about service delivery to Non-English Speaking Background people. These meetings strengthen links with the community, enabling wider consultation. The Community Refugee Settlement Scheme (CRSS) coordinator receives feedback from the network of support groups and recent arrivals, and the senior social worker obtains feedback from the social service providers. Staff also develop feedback mechanisms by participating in immigration-related committees, eg. the ACT Housing Trust and the Torture and Rehabilitation and Network Service ACT (TRANSACT)
Departmental officers in Western Australia maintain contact with emergent umbrella groups such as the Multicultural Social Services Council to advise them on access and equity concerns.
The Tasmanian office produces a newsletter on issues relating to service provision as a result of its participation in the Access and Equity Forums organised by the ECC and OMA.

In Queensland a settlement committee consisting of Commonwealth, State, and local government representatives and voluntary agencies meets every three to four months to discuss migration and settlement issues. This committee includes OMA and the ECC.

The Northern Territory office participates in two monthly network meetings, convened by OMA, which also include local government representatives and other government officials. The meetings enable participants to share ideas and initiatives about cross-cultural training and other staff development issues, and to share data bases such as an ethnic communities mailing list. MRC and ECC representatives participated in the last meeting.
(d) The responsibility for access and equity is with the Women's Issues and Access and Equity Section which is part of the Ethnic Affairs Branch.
The Assistant Secretary of the Ethnic Affairs Branch, Mr Norman Hoffmann, is the contact officer.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Gayler Mr J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, upon notice, on 20 September 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What funding was granted under the compensation package for World Heritage Listing of the Wet Tropics of Queensland to (a) Barramundi Waters at Innisfail and (b) the Mareeba Shire Council for the Bicentennial Lakes Project.
(2) How many employees were engaged by (a) Barramundi Waters and (b) the Mareeba Shire Council in their respective projects.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kelly The Hon R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) (a) The decision to fund Barramundi Waters from the Wet Tropics of Queensland Structural Adjustment Package was taken by the former Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, Senator Graham Richardson, on 9 August 1989. Funding was dependent upon that business being able to employ an appropriate number of eligible retrenched timber workers. The project was to be administered by the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (DILGEA). A joint Ministerial press release was issued on 18 September 1989 stating that up to $400,000 would be provided for the project.

A contract for the Barramundi Waters project was prepared by the Office of Local Government (OLG) of DILGEA which was cleared by the Attorney-General's Department and executed by OLG. On 27 November 1989 $250,000 was paid by DASETT to OLG for expenditure for 1989/90. DILGEA has advised that to date $100,659 of this amount has been paid to the proprietors of Barramundi Waters for the project. A further $12,952 has been expended on monitoring the project and $6000 on an audit by a consultant into the operations of the business.
(2) (a) The Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs has advised that 3 displaced timber workers were engaged at Barramundi Waters under the Agreement.

(1) (b) In a letter of 28 November 1988 Senator Richardson offered funding under the Wet Tropics of Queensland Structural Adjustment Package of $622,200 to the Mareeba Shire Council Bicentennial Lakes Project. Funding was dependent upon the project being able to employ an appropriate number of eligible retrenched timber workers. Senator Richardson's offer was accepted and a contract signed by Mareeba Shire on 21 December 1988. The project involves the second stage of the development of an inland Tropical Botanical Garden at Mareeba called Bicentennial Lakes Park. The first stage was completed under Bicentennial Year funding.
To date, the total amount provided under the Structural Adjustment Package to the Mareeba Shire Council for this project is $292,384.
(2) (b) I am advised that 5 employees are engaged under the Wet Tropics of Queensland Structural Adjustment Package by the Mareeba Shire Council on the Bicentennial Lakes Project.
With respect to the employment figures above, it should be noted that staffing levels fluctuate according to the availability of displaced timber workers eligible for assistance under the Package.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Lloyd Mr B.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 15 November 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has an office of the Australian Country Information Service been established at Korumburra, Victoria; if so, what is the operating cost of the office.
(2) How many offices of the Australian Country Information Service are located throughout Australia and what is their purpose.
(3) What is the total projected cost of the service.
(4) Does funding of the service derive from Countrylink; if not, what is the source of funding.

(5) Does the South Gippsland Citizens' Advice Bureau at Leongatha, 13 kilometres from Korumburra provide similar service, at no cost to the taxpayer, as that provided by the office referred to in part (1); if so, why was the office established.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes, an Australian Country Information Service Trial site has been established by Australia Post at the Korumburra Post Office since 2 July 1990 and will operate until 30 December 1991. Australia Post has advised that the operating cost of this site is on average $1 200 per month with the initial establishment costs being $3 417. These amounts exclude an apportionment of Australia Post Head Office and Regional Office costs and evaluation costs of the Trial.

(2) There are 20 offices of the Australian Country Information Service Trial located throughout Australia. These sites include regional offices of the Commonwealth Employment Service (CES) and the Department of Social Security, Australia Post, a CES Agent, Local Government and a community group.

The purpose of the Trial is to determine the most cost-effective and efficient means of increasing through face-to-face contact, remote and smaller rural communities' access to programs and services of 5 Commonwealth Departments. The Trial period is one and a half years.

(3) Total funding for the Trial is $1.85 million, $.51 million for 1989/90, $.92 million for 1990/91 and $.42m for 1991/92. These funds have been allocated to each of the 5 agencies referred to in part (2), as well as the Department of Primary Industries and Energy who have responsibility for the evaluation of the Trial.
(4) The Government provided additional funding within the budget for this Trial.

(5) The South Gippsland Citizens' Advice Bureau does not receive direct Commonwealth funding. It does, however, receive indirect assistance from Countrylink by the provision of a stand and information. I understand that the Bureau also receives some financial assistance from the Victorian Government.

The service provided at the Trial site at Korumburra differs in some important respects to the service provided by the Citizens' Advice Bureau. For instance, staff have received training to enable them to provide more than an information service-a major part of the duties involves acting as an agent for the lodgement and acceptance of application forms such as the acceptance of unemployment benefits forms for the Department of Social Security.

All agencies determined selection of their own sites in consultation with other agencies. In Australia Post's case it selected a site in each state and attempted where possible to select sites where none of the 5 participating Commonwealth Departments whose services are available at the site had a presence.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hollis Mr C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Land Transport, upon notice, on 15 November 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: Since the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure tabled on 27 November 1989 its report on the efficiency of Australian National's East-West operations, what progress has been made on Australian National (a) marshalling longer trains at Parkes, NSW, and (b) acquiring the railway between Parkes and Broken Hill.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The operation of the railway east of Broken Hill is the responsibility of the State Rail Authority (SRA) of NSW. It is not proposed that Australian National take over the railway between Parkes and Broken Hill.

However, the Prime Minister, Premiers and Territory Chief Ministers signed Heads of Agreement at the Special Premiers' Conference in Brisbane on 31 October 1990 to establish a National Rail Freight Corporation (NRFC), to take responsibility for the inter-state rail freight operations of all rail systems in Australia from 1 July 1991. The Corporation will have responsibility for interstate operations over this route, but the details have yet to be determined.
Answers to the specific questions are:

(a) Construction of a 1.8km siding loop at Goobang Junction near Parkes is underway and expected to be completed by September 1991. With similar facilities at three other locations between Parkes and Broken Hill, it will be possible to operate longer trains over this route.
(b) It is not proposed that Australian National acquire the railway between Parkes and Broken Hill. The question of assets to be transferred to the NRFC is yet to be decided.
